Subsection.Text: Where an event referred to in subsection (1) has occurred, the certificate of registration of the aircraft is cancelled.
If a basic ultra-light aeroplane that is registered is no longer a basic ultra-light aeroplane, its certificate of registration is cancelled.
If an advanced ultra-light aeroplane that is registered is no longer an advanced ultra-light aeroplane, its certificate of registration is cancelled.

Section.Text: Where there is misrepresentation or fraudulent documentation in the application for registration of a Canadian aircraft, the certificate of registration is cancelled.

Where the certificate of registration of a Canadian aircraft expires or is cancelled, the Minister may request the owner or last registered owner to remove the Canadian marks from the aircraft and, where the Minister so requests, the owner or last registered owner, as applicable, shall remove the Canadian marks within seven days after the day on which the request is received.
No person shall fraudulently notify the Minister that the Canadian marks on an aircraft have been removed.

Heading.TitleText: Removal of Name and Address from the Canadian Civil Aircraft Register

Section.Text: Where a continuing or temporary certificate of registration issued in respect of an aircraft expires or is cancelled, the Minister shall remove from the Canadian Civil Aircraft Register the name and address of the person under whose name the aircraft was registered.

Heading.TitleText: Removal of Aircraft Particulars from the Canadian Civil Aircraft Register

Section.Text: If the certificate of registration of an aircraft is cancelled, the Minister may remove all the particulars in respect of the aircraft from the Canadian Civil Aircraft Register if any part of the legal custody and control of the aircraft is transferred to a person who is not qualified to be the registered owner of a Canadian aircraft under section 202.15 or if subsection 202.58(1) or section 202.59 applies.

Heading.TitleText: Division IX — Canadian Civil Aircraft Register

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall establish, maintain and publish a register of aircraft, to be known as the Canadian Civil Aircraft Register, in which there shall be entered, in respect of each Canadian aircraft for which a continuing or temporary certificate of registration has been issued,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of each registered owner;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the registration mark issued pursuant to section 202.02; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: such other particulars concerning the aircraft as the Minister considers necessary for registration, inspection and certification purposes.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may publish information that has been entered in the Canadian Civil Aircraft Register in respect of a Canadian aircraft.

Heading.TitleText: Two or More Persons As Owners

Section.Text: For the purposes of this Subpart, where two or more persons are the registered owners of a Canadian aircraft, a request, notice or document is duly given to each registered owner of the aircraft if the request, notice or document is given to the person who, pursuant to the Aircraft Marking and Registration Standards, has been identified as the nominee for that purpose, at the last address for that person recorded in the Canadian Civil Aircraft Register.

Heading.TitleText: Subpart 3 — Operation of a Leased Aircraft by a Non-Registered Owner

Section.Text: In this Subpart,

Definition.Text: Canadian air operator includes the holder of a flight training unit operator certificate and the holder of a private operator registration document; (exploitant aérien canadien)
lease means an agreement in respect of the operation of an aircraft that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: specifies a commencement and a termination date,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: gives the lessee legal custody and control, and the right to exclusive possession and use, of the aircraft during its term, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may include provisions respecting the operation of the aircraft for hire or reward; (location)

Definition.Text: leasing operation means the operation of an aircraft pursuant to this Subpart; (utilisation d’aéronefs loués)
operator certificate includes an air operator certificate, a flight training unit operator certificate and a private operator registration document. (certificat d’exploitation)

Subsection.Text: This Subpart applies to the following persons in respect of the operation of a leased aircraft by the lessee if the aircraft is registered in the name of the lessor:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian air operator that leases a Canadian aircraft from another Canadian air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign air operator that leases a Canadian aircraft from a Canadian air operator that is operating under Part IV, VI or VII;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian air operator that is operating under Part IV, VI or VII and that leases an aircraft registered in a foreign state; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign air operator that leases a Canadian aircraft from a Canadian aircraft manufacturer.

Subsection.Text: This Subpart does not apply in respect of the operation of a private aircraft.
No person who is not the registered owner of an aircraft shall operate the aircraft as part of a leasing operation without an authorization issued pursuant to subsection (2) unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the lessor and the lessee each hold a Canadian operator certificate issued in respect of the aircraft type to be operated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the lessee is qualified to be the registered owner of a Canadian aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance control system referred to in section 406.35 or 706.02 and the maintenance schedule approved by the Minister under subsection 605.86(2) are, during the term of the lease, equivalent for the lessor and the lessee;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the crew members of the aircraft are employed by the lessee; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the registered owner informs the Minister in writing, no later than seven days after the term of the lease commences, of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the registration mark, manufacturer model designation and serial number of the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the names, addresses and telephone numbers, and facsimile numbers, if any, of the registered owner and the lessee,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canadian operator certificate number and the approved maintenance organization certificate numbers of the lessor and the lessee,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the commencement and termination dates of the lease,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the person who is responsible for the maintenance of the aircraft during the term of the lease, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the address of the main maintenance base for the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 203.08, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application from a Canadian air operator that conforms with the Standards Respecting the Operation of a Leased Aircraft by a Non-Registered Owner and that includes evidence that establishes that the Canadian air operator meets those standards, issue a written authorization to the Canadian air operator permitting the operation of a Canadian or foreign aircraft by the Canadian air operator, or the operation of a Canadian aircraft by a foreign operator, as part of a leasing operation, and shall specify in the authorization those conditions governing the operation that are necessary to ensure aviation safety.
An authorization issued pursuant to subsection (2) expires on the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the lease is terminated,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date specified by the Minister in the authorization,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the certificate of registration of the aircraft is cancelled,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the operator certificate is suspended or cancelled, and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which there is a change in any of the information that was submitted in support of the application referred to in subsection (2) and on which the issuance of the authorization was based.

Subsection.Text: Where an authorization is required under subsection (1) and has been issued under subsection (2), no person shall operate a leased aircraft unless the authorization is carried on board.
If a leasing advisory is provided to the Minister under subsection (1), no person shall operate a leased aircraft unless a copy of the advisory is carried on board.

No person shall operate a leased aircraft if one of the lessor and the lessee of the aircraft is not a Canadian, unless the Minister and the civil aviation authority of the state of the lessor or the lessee have consented to such operation.

No person shall operate an aircraft under the circumstances referred to in subsection (1) in a third state, other than Canada and the state of the lessor or the lessee, except in accordance with the laws of the third state.

Section.Text: The certificate of registration of a leased Canadian aircraft operated pursuant to section 203.03 remains valid notwithstanding any change in the legal custody and control of the aircraft that takes place

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the commencement or termination of the lease; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the Minister has issued an authorization pursuant to subsection 203.03(2), at any other time during the term of the lease that is specified in the authorization.

Subsection.Text: Where an authorization has been issued pursuant to subsection 203.03(2) in respect of a Canadian aircraft, the registered owner of the aircraft shall, immediately on receipt of the authorization, forward to the lessee all airworthiness directives that apply to the aircraft.

Where an authorization has been issued pursuant to subsection 203.03(2) in respect of an aircraft registered in a foreign state, the Canadian lessee shall ensure that the aircraft conforms with all applicable airworthiness directives.

No Canadian air operator shall, pursuant to section 203.03, operate a number of leased aircraft registered in a foreign state that exceeds 25 per cent of the total number of aircraft registered to that Canadian air operator, rounded to the next highest whole number.

No Canadian air operator shall, pursuant to section 203.03, lease to foreign air operators a number of aircraft that exceeds 25 per cent of the total number of Canadian aircraft registered to that Canadian air operator, rounded to the next highest whole number.

Heading.TitleText: Limits on Period of Operation under Authorization

Section.Text: No authorization shall be issued to a Canadian air operator pursuant to subsection 203.03(2) with respect to the operation of an aircraft registered in a foreign state that would result in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Canadian air operator being issued with one or more such authorizations in respect of aircraft registered in a foreign state for 24 months or more during any period of 30 consecutive months; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft being the subject of one or more such authorizations issued to a Canadian air operator for 24 months or more during any period of 30 consecutive months.

Section.Text: A Canadian air operator that has been issued with an authorization by the Minister pursuant to subsection 203.03(2) shall, within seven days after the day on which the authorization was issued, submit to the Minister a signed copy of the lease.

Heading.TitleText: Part III — Aerodromes, Airports and Heliports

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Code: se="300.01",df="{aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications}{publications sur les normes et pratiques recommandées pour les aérodromes}"
Definition.Text: aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications means the following documents, namely,

Paragraph.Code: se="300.01",df="{aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications}{publications sur les normes et pratiques recommandées pour les aérodromes}",p1="a"
Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Procedures for the Certification of Aerodromes as Airports,

Paragraph.Code: se="300.01",df="{aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications}{publications sur les normes et pratiques recommandées pour les aérodromes}",p1="b"
Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Aerodrome Standards and Recommended Practices, and

Paragraph.Code: se="300.01",df="{aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications}{publications sur les normes et pratiques recommandées pour les aérodromes}",p1="c"
Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Heliport and Helideck Standards and Recommended Practices; (publications sur les normes et pratiques recommandées pour les aérodromes)

Definition.Text: aeronautical information publications means the following documents, namely,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Canada Air Pilot,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Canada Flight Supplement,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Water Aerodrome Supplement, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: A.I.P. Canada; (publications d’information aéronautique)

Definition.Text: aircraft emergency means a situation that could result in damage to an aircraft at an airport or aerodrome or injury to the persons on board the aircraft; (aéronef en état d’urgence)
airport certificate means a certificate issued pursuant to section 302.03; (certificat d’aéroport)

airport operations manual means the manual referred to in section 302.08 and includes any amendments to the manual that are approved pursuant to subsection 302.03(2); (manuel d’exploitation d’aéroport)
closed marking means a cross-shaped marking that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has the form and, subject to subsection 301.04(4), the dimensions set out in Schedule I to Subpart 1, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 301.04(8), is in a single contrasting colour, white on runways and yellow on taxiways, that is visible from an aircraft flying at an altitude of 300 m (1,000 feet) above the marking; (marque de zone fermée)

Definition.Text: fixed, in respect of a light, means having a constant luminous intensity when the light is observed from a fixed point; (fixe)
marker means an object displayed above ground level for the purpose of indicating an obstacle or obstruction or delineating a boundary; (balise)
marking means a symbol or group of symbols displayed on the surface of a movement area for the purpose of conveying aeronautical information; (marque)
movement, in respect of an aircraft, means a take-off or landing at an airport or aerodrome; (mouvement)
operator means the person in charge of an aerodrome, and includes an employee, agent or other authorized representative of that person; (exploitant)
public way means any road, path or sidewalk maintained for the use of members of the public; (voie publique)
Water Aerodrome Supplement means a publication concerning water aerodromes that is intended to be used to supplement enroute charts and the Canada Air Pilot. (Supplément hydroaérodromes)

Section.Text: This Subpart applies in respect of all aerodromes except airports, heliports and military aerodromes.

The operator of an aerodrome shall, without charge, at the request of a Department of Transport inspector, allow the inspector access to aerodrome facilities and provide the equipment necessary to conduct an inspection of the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), where the operator of an aerodrome provides the Minister with information respecting the location, markings, lighting, use and operation of the aerodrome, the Minister shall register the aerodrome and publish the information in the Canada Flight Supplement or the Water Aerodrome Supplement, as applicable.

The Minister may refuse to register an aerodrome where the operator of the aerodrome does not meet the requirements of sections 301.05 to 301.09 or where using the aerodrome is likely to be hazardous to aviation safety and, in such a case, shall not publish information with respect to that aerodrome.

The operator of an aerodrome registered pursuant to subsection (1) shall notify the Minister immediately after any change is made to the location, marking, lighting, use or operation of the aerodrome that affects the information published by the Minister pursuant to subsection (1).
An aerodrome that is listed in the Canada Flight Supplement or the Water Aerodrome Supplement on the coming into force of this Subpart is deemed to be registered pursuant to subsection (1).
When an aerodrome is closed permanently, the operator of the aerodrome shall remove all of the markers and markings installed at the aerodrome.
The operator of an aerodrome, other than a water aerodrome, shall install red flags or red cones along the boundary of an unserviceable movement area.
Subsections (4) to (8) do not apply in respect of any manoeuvring area or part thereof that is closed for 24 hours or less.
Where a runway or part of a runway is closed, the operator of the aerodrome shall place closed markings, as set out in Schedule I to this Subpart, on the runway as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the runway is greater than 1 220 m (4,000 feet) in length, a closed marking shall be located at each end of the closed runway or part thereof and additional closed markings shall be located on the closed runway or part thereof at intervals not exceeding 300 m (1,000 feet);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the runway is greater than 450 m (1,500 feet) but not greater than 1 220 m (4,000 feet) in length, a closed marking of not less than one-half the dimensions set out in that Schedule shall be located at each end of the closed runway or part thereof and an additional closed marking of the same dimensions shall be located on the closed runway or part thereof at a point equidistant from the two markings; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the runway is 450 m (1,500 feet) or less in length, a closed marking of not less than one-half the dimensions set out in that Schedule shall be located at each end of the closed runway or part thereof.

Subsection.Text: Where a taxiway or part of a taxiway is closed, the operator of the aerodrome shall place on each end of the closed taxiway, or part thereof, a closed marking with the dimensions set out in Schedule I to this Subpart.
Where a helicopter take-off and landing area at an aerodrome is closed, the operator of the aerodrome shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: place a closed marking over the letter “H”, where the letter “H” identifies the helicopter take-off and landing area, or, where no letter identifies the helicopter take-off and landing area, over the centre of the area; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: comply with subsection (4), where the helicopter take-off and landing area is a runway.

Subsection.Text: Where a manoeuvring area or part thereof is closed permanently, the operator of the aerodrome shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: obliterate all of the markings that indicate that the manoeuvring area or part thereof is open; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (8), paint on the manoeuvring area or part thereof the markings required pursuant to subsections (4) to (6).

Subsection.Text: Where the surface of a manoeuvring area or part thereof is snow-covered or otherwise unsuitable for painting or where the closure is not permanent, closed markings may be applied by means of a conspicuously coloured dye or may be constructed from a suitable conspicuously coloured material or product.

Section.Text: Where low-flying or taxiing aircraft at or in the vicinity of an aerodrome are likely to be hazardous to pedestrian or vehicular traffic, the operator of the aerodrome shall immediately

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post notices warning of the hazard on any public way that is adjacent to the manoeuvring area; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where such a public way is not owned or controlled by the operator, inform the authorities responsible for placing markings on the public way that there is a hazard.

Subsection.Text: Except where the direction of the wind at an aerodrome can be determined by radio or other means such as smoke movement in the air or wind lines on water, the operator of the aerodrome shall install and maintain at the aerodrome a wind direction indicator that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: of a conspicuous colour or colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the shape of a truncated cone;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: visible from an aircraft flying at an altitude of 300 m (1,000 feet) above the wind direction indicator; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: illuminated when the aerodrome is used at night.

Subsection.Text: When an aerodrome is closed permanently, the operator of the aerodrome shall immediately remove all of the wind direction indicators installed at the aerodrome.

Subject to subsection (2), where a runway is used at night, the operator of the aerodrome shall indicate each side of the runway along its length with a line of fixed white lights that is visible in all directions from an aircraft in flight at a distance of not less than two nautical miles.

Where it is not practical to provide at an aerodrome the fixed white lights referred to in subsection (1) for reasons such as the lack of an available electrical power source or insufficient air traffic, the operator of the aerodrome may, if a fixed white light is displayed at each end of the runway to indicate runway alignment, use white retro-reflective markers that are capable of reflecting aircraft lights and that are visible at a distance of not less than two nautical miles from an aircraft in flight that is aligned with the centre line of the runway.
The lines of lights or retro-reflective markers required by subsection (1) or (2) shall be arranged so that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the lines of lights or markers are parallel and of equal length and the transverse distance between the lines is equal to the runway width in use during the day;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the distance between adjacent lights or markers in each line is the same and is not more than 60 m (200 feet);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: each line of lights or markers is not less than 420 m (1,377 feet) in length and contains no fewer than eight lights or markers; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: each light or marker in a line of lights or markers is situated opposite to a light or marker in the line of lights or markers on the other side of the runway, so that a line connecting them forms a right angle to the centre line of the runway.

Subsection.Text: Fixed white lights displayed at each end of a runway pursuant to subsection (2) shall be placed so that they are not likely to cause a hazard that could endanger persons or property.

Where a taxiway is used at night, the operator of the aerodrome shall indicate each side of the taxiway with a line of fixed blue lights or blue retro-reflective markers placed so that the two lines of lights or markers are parallel and the distance between adjacent lights or markers in each line is not more than 60 m (200 feet).

Where a manoeuvring area or part thereof or a heliport is closed, the operator of the aerodrome shall not operate the lights or keep the retro-reflective markers thereon, except as required for maintenance of the lights and markers.
Where an aerodrome is used at night, the operator of the aerodrome shall indicate an unserviceable portion of the movement area with fixed red lights, red retro-reflective markers or floodlighting.

Where an aircraft parking area at an aerodrome is used at night, the operator of the aerodrome shall indicate the boundary of the area with fixed blue lights or blue retro-reflective markers, placed at intervals not exceeding 60 m (200 feet), or with floodlighting.

Subject to subsection (10), where a heliport is used at night for the take-off or landing of helicopters, the operator of the heliport shall illuminate the entire take-off and landing area with floodlights or

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the take-off and landing area is rectangular, shall indicate the boundary with no fewer than eight fixed yellow lights, including one light at each corner, placed so that adjacent lights are not more than 13 m (42.5 feet) apart; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the take-off and landing area is circular, shall indicate the boundary with no fewer than five fixed yellow lights placed so that adjacent lights are not more than 13 m (42.5 feet) apart.

Subsection.Text: Where it is not practical to provide at a heliport the fixed yellow lights referred to in subsection (9) for reasons such as lack of an available electrical power source or insufficient air traffic, the operator of the heliport may use yellow retro-reflective markers that are capable of reflecting aircraft lights and that are visible at a distance of not less than two nautical miles from an aircraft in flight that is aligned with the approach path, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a light source is provided to show the location of the heliport; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where there is only one path for approach and departure, two lights are used to show the approach orientation.

Subsection.Text: Where the lighting required by subsections (1), (2), (5) and (7) to (10) is operated by a radio-controlled system capable of activation from an aircraft, the system shall meet the requirements set out in Schedule II to this Subpart.
The operator of an aerodrome may display flare pots to provide temporary lighting for the landing or take-off of aircraft.

Section.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: walk, stand, drive a vehicle, park a vehicle or aircraft or cause an obstruction on the movement area of an aerodrome, except in accordance with permission given

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by the operator of the aerodrome, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where applicable, by the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: tow an aircraft on an active movement area at night unless the aircraft displays operating wingtip, tail and anti-collision lights or is illuminated by lights mounted on the towing vehicle and directed at the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: park or otherwise leave an aircraft on an active manoeuvring area at night unless the aircraft displays operating wingtip, tail and anti-collision lights or is illuminated by lanterns suspended from the wingtips, tail and nose of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: operate any vessel, or cause any obstruction, on the surface of any part of a water area of an aerodrome that is to be kept clear of obstructions in the interest of aviation safety, when ordered, by signal or otherwise, to leave or not to approach that area by the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station or by the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly remove, deface, extinguish or interfere with a marker, marking, light or signal that is used at an aerodrome for the purpose of air navigation, except in accordance with permission given

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by the operator of the aerodrome, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where applicable, by the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: at a place other than an aerodrome, knowingly display a marker, marking, light or signal that is likely to cause a person to believe that the place is an aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly display at or in the vicinity of an aerodrome a marker, marking, sign, light or signal that is likely to be hazardous to aviation safety by causing glare or by causing confusion with or preventing clear visual perception of a marker, marking, sign, light or signal that is required under this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: allow a bird or other animal that is owned by the person or that is in the person’s custody or control to be unrestrained within the boundaries of an aerodrome except for the purpose of controlling other birds or animals at the aerodrome as permitted by the operator; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: discharge a firearm within or into an aerodrome without the permission of the operator of the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection 301.07(12) and subsections (2) and (3), no person shall, while at an aerodrome, smoke or display an open flame

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on an apron;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on an aircraft loading bridge or on a gallery or balcony that is contiguous to or that overhangs an apron; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in an area where smoking or the presence of an open flame is likely to create a fire hazard that could endanger persons or property.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome may, in writing, authorize maintenance or servicing operations on an apron that involve the use, production or potential development of an open flame or that involve the production or potential development of a spark where the operations are conducted in a manner that is not likely to create a fire hazard that could endanger persons or property.

The operator of an aerodrome may permit smoking in an enclosed building or shelter located on an apron where such smoking is not likely to create a fire hazard that could endanger persons or property.

- Capacitor Discharge Lights

Provision.Text: - Medium Intensity
- Low Intensity

Provision.Label: Note 1:
Provision.Text: Medium intensity approach lighting shall not be controlled by a system employing only one intensity selection except for Omni Directional Approach Lighting Systems (ODALS).

Provision.Label: Note 2:
Provision.Text: These systems shall not be controlled by a system employing only one intensity selection.

Provision.Label: Note 3:
Provision.Text: These fixtures may be set at 10%, 100% or OFF.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), this Subpart applies in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an aerodrome that is located within the built-up area of a city or town;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a land aerodrome that is used by an air operator for the purpose of a scheduled service for the transport of passengers; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other aerodrome, other than an aerodrome referred to in subsection (2), in respect of which the Minister is of the opinion that meeting the requirements necessary for the issuance of an airport certificate would be in the public interest and would further the safe operation of the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: This Subpart does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a military aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a land aerodrome referred to in paragraph (1)(b) where the Minister has issued a written authorization for each air operator using the aerodrome to land at and take-off from the aerodrome; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: heliports.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall issue an authorization referred to in paragraph (2)(b) where it is possible to specify conditions in the authorization that will ensure a level of safety in respect of the use of the aerodrome that is equivalent to the level of safety established by this Subpart, and, in any such authorization, the Minister shall specify those conditions.
An applicant for an airport certificate shall submit to the Minister for approval

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an application for an airport certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the proposed airport operations manual in respect of the airport.

Subsection.Text: The applicant shall include in the application proof that the applicant has consulted with the interested parties in accordance with the requirements of Subpart 7.
The application shall be signed in ink by the applicant and shall be in the form set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications.

Subject to subsection 6.71(1) of the Act, the Minister shall issue an airport certificate to an applicant authorizing the applicant to operate an aerodrome as an airport if the proposed airport operations manual, submitted pursuant to paragraph 302.02(1)(b), is approved by the Minister pursuant to subsection (2) and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the standards set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications are met; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the basis of an aeronautical study, the Minister determines that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the level of safety at the aerodrome is equivalent to that provided for by the standards set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the issuance of the airport certificate is in the public interest and not detrimental to aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall approve a proposed airport operations manual if it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: accurately describes the physical specifications of the aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conforms to the requirements set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications that apply in respect of an airport operations manual.

Subsection.Text: Where an aerodrome does not meet a standard set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications, the Minister may specify in the airport certificate such conditions relating to the subject-matter of the standard as are necessary to ensure a level of safety equivalent to that established by the standard and as are necessary in the public interest and to ensure aviation safety.
When an airport certificate is transferred, it shall be transferred in accordance with this section.
The Minister shall transfer an airport certificate to a transferee where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the current holder of the airport certificate, at least 14 days before ceasing to operate the airport, notifies the Minister in writing that the current holder will cease to operate the airport as of the date specified in the notice;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the current holder of the airport certificate notifies the Minister in writing of the name of the transferee;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the transferee applies in writing to the Minister, within 14 days before the current holder ceases to operate the airport, for the airport certificate to be transferred to the transferee; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements set out in section 302.03 are met.

Subsection.Text: An application referred to in paragraph (2)(c) shall include a copy of the notice referred to in paragraph (2)(a).

The Minister may, by mail, telex or facsimile machine, issue to an applicant referred to in section 302.03 or a transferee referred to in section 302.04 an interim airport certificate authorizing the applicant or transferee to operate an aerodrome as an airport if the Minister is satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an airport certificate in respect of the aerodrome will be issued to the applicant or transferred to the transferee as soon as the application procedure in respect of the issuance or transfer is completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the issuance of the interim airport certificate is in the public interest and not detrimental to aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: An interim airport certificate issued pursuant to subsection (1) expires on the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the airport certificate is issued or transferred, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date specified in the interim airport certificate on which it will expire.

Subsection.Text: Except for paragraph 302.02(1)(b), subsections 302.03(1) and (2) and section 302.08, this Subpart applies in respect of an interim airport certificate in the same manner as it applies in respect of an airport certificate.

Heading.TitleText: Amendment and Cancellation of Airport Certificate

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, if the requirements of section 302.03 and paragraph 302.08(1)(c) are met, amend an airport certificate where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is a change in the use or operation of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is a change in the boundaries of the airport; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of the airport certificate requests the amendment.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall cancel an airport certificate where this Subpart no longer applies in respect of the aerodrome referred to in the airport certificate, as determined in accordance with section 302.01.
The operator of an airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: comply

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: subject to subparagraph (ii), with the standards set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications, as they read on the date on which the airport certificate was issued,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of any part or facility of the airport that has been replaced or improved, with the standards set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications, as they read on the date on which the part or facility was returned to service, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: with any conditions specified in the airport certificate by the Minister pursuant to subsection 302.03(3);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: without charge, at the request of a Department of Transport inspector, allow access to airport facilities and provide the equipment necessary to conduct an inspection of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: review each issue of each aeronautical information publication on receipt thereof and, immediately after such review, notify the Minister of any inaccurate information contained therein that pertains to the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: notify the Minister in writing at least 14 days before any change to the airport, the airport facilities or the level of service at the airport that has been planned in advance and that is likely to affect the accuracy of the information contained in an aeronautical information publication;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: as the circumstances require for the purpose of ensuring aviation safety, inspect the airport

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: as soon as practicable after any aviation occurrence, as that term is defined in section 2 of the Canadian Transportation Accident Investigation and Safety Board Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: during any period of construction or repair of the airport or of airport facilities that are designated in the airport certificate, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: at any other time when there are conditions at the airport that could be hazardous to aviation safety;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: subject to paragraph (d), notify the Minister in writing of any change in airport operations within 14 days after the date of the change; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: assign duties on the movement area and any other area set aside for the safe operation of aircraft, including obstacle limitation surfaces, at the airport, which are described in the airport operations manual, only to employees who have successfully completed a safety-related initial training course on human and organizational factors.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), the operator of an airport shall give to the Minister, and cause to be received at the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station, immediate notice of any of the following circumstances of which the operator has knowledge:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any projection by an object through an obstacle limitation surface relating to the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the existence of any obstruction or hazardous condition affecting aviation safety at or in the vicinity of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any reduction in the level of services at the airport that are set out in an aeronautical information publication;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the closure of any part of the manoeuvring area of the airport; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other conditions that could be hazardous to aviation safety at the airport and against which precautions are warranted.

Subsection.Text: Where it is not feasible for an operator to cause notice of a circumstance referred to in subsection (2) to be received at the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station, the operator shall give immediate notice directly to the pilots who may be affected by that circumstance.
The operator of an airport may remove from the surface of the airport any vehicle or other obstruction that is likely to be hazardous to aviation safety at or in the vicinity of the airport.
The operator of an airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the issuance of an airport certificate, provide the Minister with a copy of the airport operations manual, as approved by the Minister pursuant to subsection 302.03(2), and distribute copies of the applicable portions to the persons and institutions referred to in the airport operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: maintain the airport operations manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister for approval any proposed amendment to the airport operations manual.

Subsection.Text: The provisions of this Subpart that apply in respect of the making of an airport operations manual also apply in respect of any amendment to an airport operations manual.
An airport operations manual shall set out the standards to be met and the services to be provided by an airport operator.
An airport operations manual shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any information relating to the administration of the airport, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a record of any amendments to the airport operations manual,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a list of holders of copies of the airport operations manual or of portions thereof,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the procedure for amendment of the airport operations manual,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the organizational structure and operational procedures of the airport management,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: an enumeration of the obligations of the operator referred to in section 302.07,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: an undertaking, signed by the operator, in respect of the operator’s obligations under paragraphs 302.07(1)(c) and (d),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement, signed by the operator, certifying that the airport operations manual is complete and accurate, and that the operator agrees to comply with all of the conditions and specifications referred to therein,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement, signed by the Minister, that the Minister has approved the airport operations manual and any amendments thereto, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: a copy of any agreement or memorandum of understanding that affects the operation of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all of the information necessary to verify that the airport meets the applicable standards set out in the aerodrome standards and recommended practices publications, as they read on the date on which the airport certificate was issued, and satisfies any conditions specified by the Minister pursuant to subsection 302.03(3) in respect of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: physical characteristics,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: obstacle limitation surfaces,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: declared distances,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: lighting,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: markers,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: markings,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: signs,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: emergency response measures,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: airport safety measures,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: access to the movement area and control procedures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: apron management plans and apron safety plans;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an enumeration of the facilities and services provided and the measures in effect at the airport, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: movement area maintenance services,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: measures for the removal of disabled aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: air traffic services and aeronautical information and communication services,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: navigation aids, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: aviation weather services;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of movement area services and facilities provided at the discretion of the operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: with respect to the safety management system required under section 107.02,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the system’s components specified in section 302.502, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a list of the titles, dates and locations of any documents that are not in the airport operations manual and that describe how the operator is meeting its obligations with respect to the safety management system.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall operate the airport in accordance with the airport operations manual.

Section.Text: Where low-flying or taxiing aircraft at or in the vicinity of an airport are likely to be hazardous to pedestrian or vehicular traffic, the operator of the airport shall immediately

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post notices warning of the hazard on any public way that is adjacent to the manoeuvring area; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where such a public way is not owned or controlled by the operator, inform the authorities responsible for posting notices on the public way that there is a hazard.

Section.Text: No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: operate an aerodrome referred to in subsection 302.01(1) unless an airport certificate is issued in respect of that aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly use an airport in a manner contrary to a condition set out in the airport certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: walk, stand, drive a vehicle, park a vehicle or aircraft or cause an obstruction on the movement area of an airport, except in accordance with permission given

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by the operator of the airport, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where applicable, by the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: operate any vessel, or cause any obstruction, on the surface of any part of a water area of an airport that is to be kept clear of obstructions in the interest of aviation safety, when ordered, by signal or otherwise, to leave or not to approach that area by the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station or by the operator of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: tow an aircraft on an active movement area at night unless the aircraft displays operating wingtip, tail and anti-collision lights or is illuminated by lights mounted on the towing vehicle and directed at the aircraft being towed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: park or otherwise leave an aircraft on an active manoeuvring area at night unless the aircraft displays operating wingtip, tail and anti-collision lights or is illuminated by lanterns suspended from the wingtips, tail and nose of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: at an airport, knowingly remove, deface, extinguish or interfere with a marker, marking, light or signal that is used for the purpose of air navigation, except in accordance with permission given

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by the operator of the airport, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where applicable, by the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: at or in the vicinity of an airport, knowingly display a marker, marking, sign, light or signal that is likely to be hazardous to aviation safety by causing glare or by causing confusion with or preventing clear visual perception of a marker, marking, sign, light or signal that is required under this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: allow a bird or other animal that is owned by the person or that is in the person’s custody or control to be unrestrained within the boundaries of an airport, except for the purpose of controlling other birds or animals at the airport as permitted by the operator; or

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: discharge a firearm within or into an airport without the permission of the operator of the airport.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) to (4), no person shall, at an airport, smoke or display an open flame

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on an apron;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on an aircraft loading bridge or on a gallery or balcony that is contiguous to or that overhangs an apron; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in an area where smoking or an open flame is likely to create a fire hazard that could endanger persons or property.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport may display flare pots to provide temporary lighting for the take-off or landing of aircraft.

The operator of an airport may, in writing, authorize maintenance or servicing operations on an apron that involve the use, production or potential development of an open flame or that involve the production or potential development of a spark where the operations are conducted in a manner that is not likely to create a fire hazard that could endanger persons or property.
The operator of an airport may permit smoking in an enclosed building or shelter located on an apron where such smoking is not likely to create a fire hazard that could endanger persons or property.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Division.

Definition.Text: community organization means an organization, corporation, department or public service. (organisme communautaire)

Definition.Code: se="302.201",df="{emergency coordination centre}{centre de coordination des urgences}"
Definition.Text: emergency coordination centre means a designated area to be used in supporting and coordinating emergency operations and whose location is specified under paragraph 302.203(1)(r). (centre de coordination des urgences)

full emergency standby means attendance at an emergency scene and preparedness to respond at the necessary level when an aircraft has, or may have, an operational problem that affects flight operations to the extent that there is a possibility of an accident. (état d’alerte complet)
on-scene controller means the person identified in an airport emergency plan as being responsible for the overall coordination of the response at an emergency scene. (coordonnateur sur place)

table top exercise means an exercise requiring the participation of the community organizations and other resources identified in an airport emergency plan to review and coordinate their respective roles, responsibilities and response actions without actually activating the plan. (exercice en salle)

Subsection.Text: After consultation with a representative sample of the air operators that use the airport and with community organizations that may be of assistance during emergency operations at the airport or in its vicinity, the operator of an airport shall develop and maintain an emergency plan for the purpose of identifying

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the emergencies that can reasonably be expected to occur at the airport or in its vicinity and that could be a threat to the safety of persons or to the operation of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the measures to activate the emergency plan for each type of emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the community organizations capable of providing assistance in an emergency; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any additional resources available at the airport and in the surrounding area.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall establish a degree of supervision and control sufficient to manage the size and complexity of an emergency.
The operator of an airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain at the airport, in the format of a manual, a copy of an updated version of the emergency plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide a copy to the Minister on request.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: update the emergency plan as necessary to ensure its effectiveness in emergency operations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: review the plan and make any required updates at least once a year after consultation with a representative sample of the air operators that use the airport and the community organizations identified in the plan.

Subsection.Text: In an emergency plan, the operator of an airport shall, at a minimum,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identify the potential emergencies, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an aircraft accident or incident

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: within the airport boundaries, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: within a critical rescue and fire-fighting access area that extends 1000 m beyond the ends of a runway and 150 m at 90° outwards from the centreline of the runway, including any part of that area outside the airport boundaries,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an aircraft emergency declared by either air traffic services or a pilot,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a fuel spill that spreads at least 1.5 m in any direction or exceeds 12 mm in depth,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a medical emergency,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a fire in which airport operations or passenger safety is threatened,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: an emergency that is related to a special aviation event and that might have an impact on airport operations,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a natural disaster, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other emergency that is a threat or is likely to be a threat to the safety of persons or to the operation of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify the organizations at the airport and the community organizations that are capable of providing assistance during an emergency at an airport or in its vicinity, provide the telephone numbers and other contact information for each organization and describe the type of assistance each can provide;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identify the other resources available at the airport and in the surrounding communities for use during emergency response or recovery operations and provide their telephone numbers and other contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: describe for emergency situations the lines of authority and the relationships between the organizations identified in the emergency plan and describe how actions will be coordinated among all and within each of the organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: identify for emergency situations the supervisors and describe the responsibilities of each;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: specify the positions occupied by the airport personnel who will respond to an emergency and describe the specific emergency response duties of each;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: identify the on-scene controller and describe the controller’s emergency response duties;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: provide authorization for a person to act as an on-scene controller or a supervisor if they are not airport personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: set out the criteria to be used for positioning the on-scene controller within visual range of an emergency scene;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: set out the measures to be taken to make the on-scene controller easily identifiable at all times by all persons responding to an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: if initial on-scene control has been assumed by a person from a responding organization, describe the procedure for transferring control to the on-scene controller;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: describe any training and qualifications required for the on-scene controller and the airport personnel identified in the emergency plan;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: describe the method for recording any training provided to the on-scene controller and airport personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: describe the communication procedures and specify the radio frequencies to be used to link the operator of the airport with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the on-scene controller, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the providers of ground traffic control services and air traffic control services at the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: describe the communication procedures allowing the on-scene controller to communicate with the organizations identified in the emergency plan;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: identify the alerting procedures that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: activate the emergency plan,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: establish the necessary level of response,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: allow immediate communication with the organizations identified in the emergency plan in accordance with the required level of response,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if applicable, confirm the dispatch of each responding organization,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: establish the use of standard terminology in communications, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: establish the use of the appropriate radio frequencies as set out in the emergency plan;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: specify

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the airport communication equipment testing procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a schedule for the testing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the method of keeping records of the tests;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: for airports designated under Subpart 3, specify the location of the emergency coordination centre used to provide support to the on-scene controller;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: describe the measures for dealing with adverse climatic conditions and darkness for each potential emergency set out in paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: describe the procedures to assist persons who have been evacuated if their safety is threatened or airside operations are affected;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: describe the procedures respecting the review and confirmation of the following to permit the return of the airport to operational status after an emergency situation:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: emergency status reports,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: coordination with the coroner and the investigator designated by the Transportation Safety Board of Canada regarding the accident site conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: disabled aircraft removal,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: airside inspection results,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: accident or incident site conditions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: air traffic services and NOTAM coordination;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: describe the procedures for controlling vehicular flow during an emergency to ensure the safety of vehicles, aircraft and persons;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: specify the procedures for issuing a NOTAM in the event of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an emergency affecting the critical category for fire fighting required under section 303.07, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: changes or restrictions in facilities or services at the airport during and after an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: describe the procedures for preserving evidence as it relates to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft or aircraft part removal, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the site of the accident or incident in accordance with the Canadian Transportation Accident Investigation and Safety Board Act;

Paragraph.Label: (y)
Paragraph.Text: describe the procedures to be followed, after any exercise set out in section 302.208 or the activation of the plan for an emergency that requires a full emergency standby, in the following cases:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a post-emergency debriefing session with all participating organizations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the recording of the minutes of the debriefing session,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an evaluation of the effectiveness of the emergency plan to identify deficiencies,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: changes, if any, to be made in the emergency plan, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: partial testing subsequent to the modification of an emergency plan;

Paragraph.Label: (z)
Paragraph.Text: describe

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the process for an annual review and update of the emergency plan, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the administrative procedure for the distribution of copies of an updated version of the emergency plan to the airport personnel who require them and to the community organizations identified in the plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (z.1)
Paragraph.Text: describe the procedures to assist in locating an aircraft when the airport receives notification that an ELT has been activated.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall include a copy of the following documents in the emergency plan:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the signed agreements, if any, between the airport operator and the community organizations that provide emergency response services to the airport; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an airport grid map.

Section.Text: The on-scene controller shall be at the emergency site and shall not have other duties during an emergency, unless the life of a person is in danger nearby and the on-scene controller is alone and has the ability to assist the person.
The operator of an airport shall establish procedures that make the on-scene controller easily identifiable by all persons responding to an emergency.

Heading.TitleText: Aircraft Crash Charts and Airport Grid Maps

Subsection.Text: For aircraft operating in a passenger or cargo configuration, the operator of an airport shall make available to the emergency coordination centre aircraft crash charts specific to the aircraft used by the air operators that use the airport, and shall provide copies of the charts to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the organizations responsible for fire-fighting services that are identified in the emergency plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the on-scene controller.

Subsection.Text: In the case of aircraft that have or may have a seating configuration of not more than nine passenger seats, the operator of an airport may use, instead of the aircraft crash charts referred to in subsection (1), other documents containing equivalent information.
The operator of an airport shall develop and review and update annually, if necessary, an airport grid map that includes a minimum of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an area covering at least one kilometre around each runway;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the airport access roads and gates; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the location of rendezvous points to which persons and vehicles that are responding to an emergency situation proceed in order to receive instructions.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall provide copies of the airport grid map to the airport personnel who must have one and the organizations identified in the emergency plan.

The operator of an airport shall assign specific emergency response duties, other than those of an on-scene controller or a supervisor, only to those airport personnel who are identified in the emergency plan and who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are knowledgeable of their duties as described in the plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have the skills to carry out their duties.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall assign to act as an on-scene controller or a supervisor only those airport personnel, or other persons authorized by the operator in the emergency plan, who are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: knowledgeable about the contents of the emergency plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: familiar with the procedures for the overall coordination of emergency operations at an emergency site; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: trained for the particular role that they perform.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: keep records of the training that was received by persons to meet the requirements of subsections (1) and (2);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: preserve the records of training for three years after the day on which the training was received; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: submit a copy of the training records to the Minister on request.

Subsection.Text: In this section, international service has the same meaning as in subsection 55(1) of the Canada Transportation Act.
The operator of an airport shall test the emergency plan by conducting a full-scale exercise

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the airports designated by the Minister in the Canada Flight Supplement to be used by international service, at intervals not exceeding two years; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for other airports, at intervals not exceeding four years.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall conduct full-scale exercises based on scenarios that relate to a major aircraft accident and, at a minimum, the exercises shall include the assembly and deployment of fire-fighting, policing and medical services organizations.
The operator of an airport shall conduct a table top exercise each year in which no full-scale exercise is conducted.
The operator of an airport, when conducting a table top exercise, shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an up-to-date list of the participants and their telephone numbers and the radio frequencies used to communicate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fully operational communication equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the airport grid map.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall base the table top exercises on scenarios that include an aircraft accident or incident.

The operator of an airport shall provide the Minister with a notice in writing of the date and time when a table top or full-scale exercise is to be carried out at least 60 days before the day of the exercise.
The Minister may observe the testing of an emergency plan.

After each exercise, the operator of an airport shall conduct a debriefing with all the organizations identified in the plan and a representative of the airport personnel who participated to evaluate the effectiveness of the emergency plan and identify deficiencies.
The operator of an airport shall implement an action plan to correct any deficiencies in the emergency plan that were identified during a debriefing session.
The operator of an airport shall conduct partial exercises to assess proposed changes in the plan in order to correct deficiencies.
The operator of an airport shall record

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date of an exercise;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the type of exercise;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the minutes of the debriefing session after the exercise; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any action plans to correct deficiencies that were identified during a debriefing session.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall keep an exercise record for 10 years after the day on which the record is made.
The operator of an airport shall submit debriefing minutes and corrective action plans relating to an exercise to the Minister on request.

Section.Text: The Minister may, on application by the operator of an airport, provide to the operator written authorization not to conduct the full-scale exercise during an interval set out in paragraph 302.208(2)(a) or (b) if the operator demonstrates that the testing requirements for a full-scale exercise have been met through an activation of the emergency plan in response to an emergency during that interval.

Heading.TitleText: Division III — Airport Wildlife Planning and Management

Section.Text: In this Division,

Definition.Code: se="302.301",df="{waste disposal facility}{installation d’élimination des déchets}"
Definition.Text: waste disposal facility means a landfill site, garbage dump, waste transfer and sorting facility, recycling and composting facility or commercial fish processing plant; (installation d’élimination des déchets)
wildlife strike means a collision between an aircraft and wildlife. (impact faunique)

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), this Division applies to airports

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that, within the preceding calendar year, had 2 800 movements of commercial passenger-carrying aircraft operating under Subpart 4 or 5 of Part VII;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that are located within a built-up area;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that have a waste disposal facility within 15 km of the geometric centre of the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that had an incident where a turbine-powered aircraft collided with wildlife other than a bird and suffered damage, collided with more than one bird or ingested a bird through an engine; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where the presence of wildlife hazards, including those referred to in section 322.302 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management, has been observed in an airport flight pattern or movement area.

Subsection.Text: Section 302.303 applies to all airports.
The operator of an airport shall keep records of all wildlife strikes at the airport, including those reported by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: pilots;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ground personnel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft maintenance personnel when they identify damage to an aircraft as having been caused by a wildlife strike.

Subsection.Text: Wildlife remains that are found within 200 feet of a runway or an airside pavement area are presumed to be the result of a wildlife strike unless another cause of death is identified.
The operator of the airport shall submit a written and dated report to the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for each wildlife strike, within 30 days of its occurrence; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for all wildlife strikes that occur in a calendar year, before March 1 of the following calendar year.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall collect information in respect of the requirements set out in section 322.304 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management.

The operator of the airport shall, after consultation with a representative sample of the operators in respect of an aircraft, air operators and private operators that use the airport, conduct a risk analysis that evaluates the collected information.
The risk analysis shall be in writing and include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an analysis of the risks associated with the wildlife hazards, including those referred to in section 322.302 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the measures that are necessary to manage or remove the hazards or to manage or mitigate the risks.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the airport shall, at the request of the Minister, make the risk analysis available for inspection.
The operator of an airport shall develop an airport wildlife management plan in accordance with section 322.305 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management.

The operator of the airport shall submit the plan to the Minister, on request by the Minister, in accordance with the requirements set out in subsection 322.305(2) of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management.
The operator of the airport shall keep a copy of the plan at the airport and it shall, on request by the Minister, be made available to the Minister.
The operator of the airport shall implement the plan.
The operator of the airport shall review the plan every two years.
The operator of the airport shall amend the plan and submit the amended plan to the Minister within 30 days of the amendment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amendment is necessary as a result of the review conducted under subsection (5);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an incident has occurred in which a turbine-powered aircraft collided with wildlife other than a bird and suffered damage, collided with more than one bird or ingested a bird through an engine;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a variation in the presence of wildlife hazards, including those referred to in section 322.302 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management, has been observed in an airport flight pattern or movement area; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: there has been a change

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the wildlife management procedures or in the methods used to manage or mitigate wildlife hazards,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the types of aircraft at the airport, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the types of aircraft operations at the airport.

Section.Text: An airport wildlife management plan shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identify and describe the risks associated with all wildlife hazards, including those referred to in section 322.302 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management, at or near the airport that might affect the safe operation of aircraft, including the proximity of any waste disposal facility or migration route affecting wildlife populations near the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: specify the particular measures that are used by the operator of the airport to manage or mitigate the risks;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identify and describe the actions that are used by the operator of the airport to satisfy the requirements set out in section 322.306 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management in respect of firearm certificates and permits, wildlife control permits, wildlife strikes, wildlife management logs, and evaluations of habitats, land uses and food sources at or near the airport;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: set out a policy for the management of airport habitats that might attract wildlife;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: set out a policy that prohibits the feeding of wildlife and the exposure of food wastes;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: set out a procedure to ensure that all endangered or protected wildlife at the airport are inventoried;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: identify the role of the personnel and agencies involved in wildlife management issues and provide the contact numbers for each; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: provide details of any wildlife hazard awareness program.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide any person who has duties in respect of the airport wildlife management plan with training at least once every five years regarding their assigned duties and the matters set out in section 322.307 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that any person who has duties in respect of the airport wildlife management plan holds any required firearm permit.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the airport shall maintain a record of each person’s training for a period of five years and provide the Minister with a copy of any record, if requested.

Section.Text: The operator of an airport shall establish a communication and alerting procedure for wildlife management personnel in accordance with section 322.308 of the Airport Standards-Airport Wildlife Planning and Management to alert pilots as soon as possible of the wildlife hazards at the airport and the risks associated with those hazards.

Subsection.Text: This Division applies to an applicant for, or a holder of, an airport certificate issued under section 302.03 in respect of the following airports:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Calgary International;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Edmonton International;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Gander International;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Halifax Robert L. Stanfield International;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Montréal — Pierre Elliott Trudeau International;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Ottawa Macdonald-Cartier International;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: St. John’s International;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Toronto / Lester B. Pearson International;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: Vancouver International; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: Winnipeg James Armstrong Richardson International.

Subsection.Text: On and after January 1, 2009, this Division applies to an applicant for, or a holder of, an airport certificate issued under section 302.03.

Section.Text: The safety management system required under section 107.02 in respect of an applicant for, or a holder of, an airport certificate shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
