Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of Subpart 7 of Part I and section 302.502; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be under the control of the accountable executive appointed under paragraph 106.02(1)(a).

Heading.TitleText: Components of the Safety Management System

Section.Text: The safety management system shall include, among others, the following components:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a safety management plan that includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a safety policy that the accountable executive has approved and communicated to all employees,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the roles and responsibilities of personnel assigned duties under the safety management system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: performance goals and a means of measuring attainment of those goals,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a policy for the internal reporting of hazards, incidents and accidents, including the conditions under which immunity from disciplinary action will be granted, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a process for reviewing the safety management system to determine its effectiveness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for reporting hazards, incidents and accidents to the appropriate manager;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the collection of data relating to hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the exchange of information in respect of hazards, incidents and accidents among the operators of aircraft and the provider of air traffic services at the airport and the airport operator;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for analysing data obtained under paragraph (c) and during an audit conducted under a quality assurance program required under paragraph 107.03(g) and for taking corrective actions;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: training requirements for the person managing the safety management system and for personnel assigned duties under the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for making progress reports to the accountable executive at intervals determined by the accountable executive and other reports as needed in urgent cases; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for involving employees in the implementation and ongoing development of the safety management system.

Subsection.Text: The quality assurance program required under paragraph 107.03(g) in respect of an applicant for, or a holder of, an airport certificate shall include a process for quality assurance that includes periodic reviews or audits of the activities authorized under a certificate and reviews or audits, for cause, of those activities.

The holder of an airport certificate shall ensure that records relating to the findings resulting from the quality assurance program are distributed to the appropriate manager for corrective action and follow-up in accordance with the policies and procedures specified in the airport operations manual.
The holder of an airport certificate shall establish an audit system in respect of the quality assurance program that consists of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an initial audit conducted within 12 months after

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an airport specified in subsection 302.500(1), the later of January 1, 2008 and the day on which the airport certificate is issued, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of any other airport, the later of January 1, 2009 and the day on which the airport certificate is issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an audit of the entire quality assurance program carried out every three years, calculated from the initial audit, in one of the following ways:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a complete audit, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a series of audits conducted at intervals set out in the airport operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: checklists of all activities controlled by the airport operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a record of each occurrence of compliance or non-compliance with the airport operations manual found during an audit referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for ensuring that each finding of an audit is communicated to the accountable executive;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: follow-up procedures for ensuring that corrective actions are effective; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a system for recording the findings of an audit referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), corrective actions and follow-ups.

Subsection.Text: The records resulting from a system required under paragraph (3)(g) shall be retained for the greater of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two audit cycles, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two years.

Subsection.Text: The duties related to the quality assurance program that involve specific tasks or activities among the activities of an airport shall be fulfilled by persons who are not responsible for carrying out those tasks or activities unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the size, nature and complexity of the operations and activities authorized under the airport certificate justify the fulfilling of those duties by the person responsible for carrying out those tasks or activities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of the airport certificate demonstrates to the Minister, by means of a risk analysis, that the fulfilling of those duties by the person responsible for carrying out those tasks or activities will not result in an unacceptable risk to aviation safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of the airport certificate provides the Minister, in writing, with the information required under paragraphs (a) and (b).

Section.Text: The holder of an airport certificate shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that corrective actions are taken in respect of any findings resulting from the safety management system referred to in section 302.501;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a person to manage the safety management system; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person managing the safety management system performs the duties required under section 302.505.

Heading.TitleText: Person Managing the Safety Management System

Subsection.Text: The person managing the safety management system shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a reporting system to ensure the timely collection of information related to hazards, incidents and accidents that may adversely affect safety;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify hazards and carry out risk management analyses of those hazards;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: investigate, analyze and identify the cause or probable cause of all hazards, incidents and accidents identified under the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a safety data system, by either electronic or other means, to monitor and analyze trends in hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: monitor and evaluate the results of corrective actions with respect to hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the concerns of the civil aviation industry in respect of safety and their perceived effect on the holder of the airport certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: determine the adequacy of the training required by paragraph 302.502(f).

Subsection.Text: The person managing the safety management system shall, if a finding resulting from the safety management system referred to in section 302.501 is reported to them,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine what, if any, corrective actions are required and carry out those actions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a record of any determination made under paragraph (a) and the reason for it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if management functions have been assigned to another person under subsection (3), communicate any determination regarding a corrective action to that person; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: notify the certificate holder of any systemic deficiency and of the corrective action taken.

Subsection.Text: The person managing the safety management system may assign the management functions for the safety management system referred to in section 302.501 to another person if the assignment and its scope are described in the airport operations manual.

The person to whom management functions have been assigned under subsection (3) shall notify the person managing the safety management system of any systemic deficiency and of the corrective action taken.

The responsibility of the accountable executive is not affected by the appointment of a person to manage the safety management system under paragraph 302.504(b) or the assignment of management functions to another person under subsection (3).

Heading.TitleText: Subpart 3 — Aircraft Rescue and Fire Fighting at Airports and Aerodromes

Section.Text: In this Subpart,

Definition.Code: se="303.01",df="{aircraft category for fire fighting}{catégorie d’aéronefs — SLIA}"
Definition.Text: aircraft category for fire fighting means an aircraft category, determined in accordance with section 303.05 for the purpose of fighting fires involving aircraft; (catégorie d’aéronefs — SLIA)

Definition.Code: se="303.01",df="{aircraft fire-fighting standards}{normes de lutte contre les incendies d’aéronefs}"
Definition.Text: aircraft fire-fighting standards means the Aerodrome and Airport Standards respecting Aircraft Fire Fighting at Airports and Aerodromes published under the authority of the Minister; (normes de lutte contre les incendies d’aéronefs)

Definition.Code: se="303.01",df="{critical category for fire fighting}{catégorie critique — SLIA}"
Definition.Text: critical category for fire fighting means the aircraft category that

Paragraph.Code: se="303.01",df="{critical category for fire fighting}{catégorie critique — SLIA}",p1="a"
Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a designated airport, is determined in accordance with section 303.07 for the purpose of establishing the required level of service for fighting fires involving aircraft at the airport, and

Paragraph.Code: se="303.01",df="{critical category for fire fighting}{catégorie critique — SLIA}",p1="b"
Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a participating airport or aerodrome, is specified for the airport or aerodrome in the Canada Flight Supplement and corresponds to the level of service for fighting fires involving aircraft at that airport or aerodrome; (catégorie critique — SLIA)

Definition.Text: in response posture means, in respect of personnel, in a location at or near the airport or aerodrome that will permit an operator to obtain a satisfactory result in a response test referred to in subsection 303.18(4); (en position d’intervention)

Definition.Code: se="303.01",df="{participating airport or aerodrome}{aéroport ou aérodrome participant}"
Definition.Text: participating airport or aerodrome means an airport, other than a designated airport, or an aerodrome, for which a critical category for fire fighting is specified in the Canada Flight Supplement. (aéroport ou aérodrome participant)

rescue means the act of evacuating persons from an aircraft involved in an aircraft accident or incident at an airport by means of fire suppression and then, if circumstances permit, aircraft entry. (sauvetage)

Subsection.Text: This Subpart, except subsections 303.03(2) and 303.04(4), applies in respect of a designated airport, which is an airport at which, according to the statistics referred to in subsection 303.06(1), the total of the number of passengers that are emplaned and the number of passengers that are deplaned is more than 180,000 per year.

This Subpart, except subsections 303.03(1) and 303.04(1) to (3), sections 303.06 and 303.07, subsection 303.10(2) and sections 303.11 and 303.12, applies in respect of a participating airport or aerodrome.
The operator of a designated airport shall provide the aircraft fire-fighting vehicles and the personnel required under this Subpart to respond to an aircraft emergency at the airport

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an airport listed in the schedule to this Subpart, on the coming into force of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, twelve months after the statistics compiled in accordance with subsection 303.06(1) show that the airport meets the criteria for a designated airport set out in subsection 303.02(1).

Subsection.Text: The operator of a participating airport or aerodrome shall provide the aircraft fire-fighting vehicles and the personnel required pursuant to this Subpart that correspond to the critical category for fire-fighting published in the Canada Flight Supplement to respond to an aircraft emergency at the airport or aerodrome.

Heading.TitleText: Hours of Operation of an Aircraft Fire-fighting Service

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the operator of a designated airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the beginning of each month and after consultation with the air operators that use the airport, establish the hours of operation of an aircraft fire-fighting service for the month and ensure that those hours coincide with at least 90 per cent of the movements during that month by commercial passenger-carrying aircraft at the airport of which the operator receives notice at least 30 days in advance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the critical category for fire fighting and the hours of operation of an aircraft fire fighting service are published in the Canada Flight Supplement and in a NOTAM, if the NOTAM is published earlier.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (5), the operator of a designated airport shall provide an aircraft fire-fighting service for the operation at the airport of aeroplanes in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of 20 or more passengers if the aeroplanes are operated under

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Part VI, Subpart 4; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Part VII, Subpart 1 or 5.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport shall provide an aircraft fire-fighting service until an aircraft referred to in subsection (2) has taken off or landed or the flight has been cancelled.

The operator of a participating airport or aerodrome shall establish the hours during which an aircraft fire-fighting service is to be operated and shall ensure that the hours are published in the Canada Flight Supplement and in a NOTAM, if the NOTAM is published earlier.
Subsection (2) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a cargo flight without passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a ferry flight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a positioning flight;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a training flight if no fare-paying passengers are on board;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the arrival of an aeroplane when the airport is being used for a diversion or as an alternate aerodrome; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the subsequent departure of an aeroplane referred to in paragraph (e), if it is conducted in accordance with paragraph 602.96(7)(f).

Subsection.Text: An aircraft category for fire fighting set out in column I of an item of the table to this subsection shall be established for an aircraft based on the aircraft overall length set out in column II of the item and the aircraft maximum fuselage width set out in column III of that item.

row.entry: at least 9 m but less than 12 m
at least 12 m but less than 18 m
at least 18 m but less than 24 m
at least 24 m but less than 28 m
at least 28 m but less than 39 m
at least 39 m but less than 49 m
at least 49 m but less than 61 m
at least 61 m but less than 76 m

Subsection.Text: Where the fuselage width of an aircraft that has an overall length within the range set out in column II of an item of the table to subsection (1) is greater than the aircraft maximum fuselage width set out in column III of the item, the aircraft category for fire fighting for the aircraft shall be one category higher than the category set out in column I of that item.

Heading.TitleText: Statistics on the Number of Passengers and Aircraft Movements

Subsection.Text: The operator of an airport or aerodrome shall review, at least once every six months, the statistics in respect of the number of emplaned and deplaned passengers resulting from the Electronic Collection of Air Transportation Statistics project carried out jointly by the Department of Transport and Statistics Canada for the twelve months preceding the date of the review and determine whether the airport or aerodrome qualifies as a designated airport under subsection 303.02(1).
The operator of a designated airport shall compile monthly statistics setting out the number of movements by commercial passenger-carrying aircraft in each aircraft category for fire fighting.

The operator of a designated airport shall, at least once every six months, review the monthly statistics for the twelve months preceding the date of the review and determine the three consecutive months with the highest total number of movements by commercial passenger-carrying aircraft in all aircraft categories for fire fighting.

Where the review shows more than one period of three consecutive months having the same total number of movements by commercial passenger-carrying aircraft, the period to be used for the purposes of section 303.07 is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the period involving the highest aircraft category for fire fighting; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where those periods involve the same highest aircraft category for fire fighting, the period involving the greatest number of movements in that category.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, in writing, on application by the operator of a designated airport, authorize the operator to cease providing an aircraft fire-fighting service if the operator demonstrates by means of a risk analysis based on Standard CAN/CSA-Q850-97 entitled Risk Management: Guideline for Decision-makers as amended from time to time that the cessation of the aircraft fire-fighting service will not result in an unacceptable risk to aviation safety.

If the Minister issues an authorization under subsection (5), the operator of a designated airport shall submit the content of the authorization for publication in the Canada Flight Supplement and in a NOTAM, if the NOTAM is published earlier.
The operator of a designated airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: retain the monthly statistics referred to in subsection (2) for five years after the date of the review; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide them to the Minister at the Minister’s request.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport shall determine a critical category for fire fighting for the airport based on the number of movements at the airport during the three-month period determined in accordance with subsection 303.06(3) or (4) by commercial passenger-carrying aircraft in the highest and the next highest aircraft categories for fire fighting.

Where, during the period referred to in subsection (1), the number of movements at the designated airport by aircraft in the highest aircraft category for fire fighting is 700 or more, the critical category for fire fighting is equivalent to that highest aircraft category for fire fighting.

If, during the period referred to in subsection (1), the number of movements at the designated airport by aircraft in the highest aircraft category for fire fighting is less than 700, the critical category for fire fighting shall be determined by decreasing the highest aircraft category for fire fighting by one category.

If the operator of a designated airport anticipates a period of one or more hours of movements of aircraft of a lower aircraft category for fire fighting only, the operator may reduce the critical category for fire fighting to the highest aircraft category for fire fighting anticipated for that period if the operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: documents the anticipated situation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notifies the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station of the reduced critical category for fire fighting for publication in a NOTAM.

Heading.TitleText: Division II — Extinguishing Agents and Aircraft Fire-Fighting Vehicles

Section.Text: The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall provide its aircraft fire-fighting service with both the principal and the complementary extinguishing agents and the equipment delivering the agents that meet the requirements set out in the aircraft fire-fighting standards.

Heading.TitleText: Extinguishing Agent and Aircraft Fire-fighting Vehicle Requirements

Section.Text: Subject to sections 303.10 and 303.11, the operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome the critical category for fire fighting of which is set out in column I of an item of the table to this section shall provide to the aircraft fire-fighting service at the airport or aerodrome the quantities of water and complementary extinguishing agents set out in columns II and III of the item, and the minimum number of aircraft fire-fighting vehicles set out in column IV of that item necessary to provide the total discharge capacity set out in column V of that item.

row.entry: Quantity of Complementary Extinguishing Agents (in kilograms)
Minimum Number of Aircraft Fire-fighting Vehicles
Total Discharge Capacity (in litres per minute)

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome does not have to meet the requirements referred to in section 303.09 where those requirements cannot be met because of a personnel shortage or unserviceable equipment at the airport or aerodrome caused by circumstances beyond the control of its operator and a notification of the reduced level of aircraft fire-fighting service at the airport or aerodrome has been given to the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station for publication in a NOTAM.
When the condition described in subsection (1) continues for seven days or more, the operator of a designated airport shall, no later than seven days after the onset of the condition,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish a plan specifying the corrective measures that are necessary to meet the requirements of section 303.09 and the dates by which those measures shall be taken, which dates shall be as early as practicable given the circumstances; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit the plan to the Minister.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport shall implement the submitted plan by the date specified in the plan.

The Minister may, in writing, on application by the operator of a designated airport, authorize the operator to meet the requirements set out in the table to section 303.09 for a lower critical category for fire fighting than that established for the airport pursuant to section 303.07 where that operator demonstrates that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the critical category for fire fighting was the result of movements by unusually large commercial passenger-carrying aircraft or an unusually high number of movements by commercial passenger-carrying aircraft at the airport and either of these situations is unlikely to be repeated within the next year; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of movements by, or the size of, commercial passenger-carrying aircraft at the airport is expected to be altered in a manner that would result in a lower critical category for fire fighting.

Subsection.Text: Where a written authorization has been issued pursuant to subsection (1), the operator of the designated airport shall meet the requirements set out in the table to section 303.09 for the lower critical category for fire fighting specified in the authorization and shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notification of the reduced level of aircraft fire-fighting service and the period during which the level is reduced is given to the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station for publication in the Canada Flight Supplement and in a NOTAM, where the NOTAM is published earlier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: procedures are established to restore the level of aircraft fire-fighting service to the previous higher level if the reduction in the number of movements by, or in the size of, commercial passenger-carrying aircraft at the airport is temporary; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures for a reduction in the level of aircraft fire-fighting service and the procedures referred to in paragraph (b) are set out in the airport operations manual.

Section.Text: Where an increase in the number of movements by, or in the size of, commercial passenger-carrying aircraft at a designated airport results in the establishment for the airport of a higher critical category for fire fighting than the previous category, the operator of the airport shall meet the requirements for that higher category as set out in the table to section 303.09 within one year after the date of establishing the higher critical category for fire fighting.

During the hours of operation of the aircraft fire-fighting service, the operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall ensure that trained aircraft fire-fighting personnel are in response posture and in sufficient number to operate the aircraft fire-fighting vehicles and apply the extinguishing agents required by section 303.09.

The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall ensure that all personnel assigned to aircraft fire-fighting duties are trained in accordance with the aircraft fire-fighting standards.

The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall provide all personnel assigned to aircraft fire-fighting duties with the equipment and protective clothing necessary to perform their duties.

Subsection.Text: No operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as an aircraft firefighter at the airport or aerodrome unless the person has, within the previous 12 months, successfully completed the training specified in the aircraft fire-fighting standards.
The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain, for each aircraft firefighter, a training record containing the information specified in the aircraft fire-fighting standards;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: preserve the training record for three years after the aircraft firefighter leaves the service of the airport or aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at the request of the Minister, provide the Minister with a copy of the training record.

Section.Text: The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall ensure that, during the hours of operation of its aircraft fire-fighting service, of the fire-fighting personnel required to be available pursuant to section 303.13, the number of personnel capable of immediate response is sufficient to meet the requirements of the response test referred to in section 303.18.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall carry out a response test to evaluate the response time and effectiveness of the aircraft fire-fighting service required to be maintained during the hours of operation specified in section 303.04

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: every 12 months; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at any time at the request of the Minister, where the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe that the aircraft fire-fighting service at the airport or aerodrome does not meet the requirements of this Subpart.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall give the Minister at least four weeks written notice of the date on which a response test is to be carried out.
The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall provide the Minister with a copy of the results of a response test within 14 days after the date of the test.
A response test at a designated airport or at a participating airport or aerodrome has a satisfactory result if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within three minutes after an alarm is sounded, aircraft fire-fighting vehicles in a number sufficient for applying the principal extinguishing agent at 50 per cent of the total discharge capacity required by section 303.09 are dispatched from their assigned position and, under optimum surface and visibility conditions at the airport or aerodrome, reach the midpoint of the farthest runway serving commercial passenger-carrying aircraft, or another predetermined point of comparable distance and terrain; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within four minutes after the alarm is sounded, any other aircraft fire-fighting vehicle required by section 303.09 reaches the location referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall record the results of a response test and shall preserve the records for two years after the date of the test.
If a response test does not have a satisfactory result, the operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within six hours after the test, identify the deficiencies that caused the result and notify the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service of the critical category for fire fighting that corresponds to the level of service that can be provided, for publication in a NOTAM; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within seven days after the test, if any deficiency is not corrected, submit a plan to the Minister specifying the measures necessary to obtain a satisfactory result and the dates by which they must be taken, which shall be as early as practicable given the circumstances.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall implement the submitted plan by the dates specified in the plan.

Heading.TitleText: Division V — Communication and Alerting System

Section.Text: The operator of a designated airport or of a participating airport or aerodrome shall provide a communication and alerting system that meets the aircraft fire-fighting standards.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a designated airport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: until November 30, 1998, except in respect of aircraft referred to in subsection 303.04(2), maintain the aircraft fire-fighting service that was provided on November 30, 1997; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: effective December 1, 1998, meet the requirements for an aircraft fire-fighting service prescribed in subsections 303.03(1) and 303.04(1) and sections 303.07 to 303.19.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a participating airport or aerodrome shall, effective December 1, 1998, meet the requirements for an aircraft fire-fighting service prescribed in subsections 303.03(2) and 303.04(4), sections 303.08 and 303.09, subsection 303.10(1) and sections 303.13 to 303.19.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Subpart.

Definition.Code: se="305.01",df="{applicable heliport standard}{norme sur les héliports applicable}"
Definition.Text: applicable heliport standard means the standard that is applicable to a heliport or to a part of it, or to its administration and operation, as determined under subsection 305.17(1). (norme sur les héliports applicable)

FATO means a final approach and take-off area, which consists of a defined area over which the final phase of a helicopter approach manoeuvre to hover or land is completed and from which the take-off manoeuvre is commenced. (FATO)
heliport certificate means a certificate issued under section 305.08, 305.11 or 305.12. (certificat d’héliport)

Definition.Code: se="305.01",df="{heliport closed marking}{marque de zone fermée d’héliport}"
Definition.Text: heliport closed marking means a marking that meets the requirements of subsection 305.41(1). (marque de zone fermée d’héliport)

Definition.Code: se="305.01",df="{heliport operations manualHOM}{manuel d’exploitation d’héliport ou MEH}"
Definition.Text: heliport operations manual or HOM means the manual referred to in sections 305.53 to 305.57 and includes any amendments to the manual that are approved pursuant to subsection 305.08(4). (manuel d’exploitation d’héliport ou MEH)
TLOF means a touchdown and lift off area, which consists of a load-bearing area on which a helicopter may touch down or lift off. (TLOF)

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), this Subpart applies in respect of the operation of a heliport

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that is located within a built-up area of a city or town;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is used by an air operator providing a scheduled air service for the purpose of transporting persons;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for which an instrument approach procedure to precision limits is established in accordance with the applicable heliport standard; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that is any other heliport in respect of which the issuance of a heliport certificate would be in the public interest and would further the safe operation of the heliport.

Subsection.Text: This Subpart does not apply in respect of a military heliport.

Heading.TitleText: Requirement to Hold a Heliport Certificate

Section.Text: No person shall operate a heliport referred to in subsection 305.02(1) unless a heliport certificate is issued in respect of the heliport and the person complies with the requirements of the heliport certificate and operates the heliport in accordance with the heliport operations manual.

Heading.TitleText: Eligibility to Hold a Heliport Certificate

Section.Text: A person is eligible to hold a heliport certificate if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a citizen of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a permanent resident of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a corporation incorporated under the territorial, provincial or federal laws of Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a municipal, provincial or federal entity.

Section.Text: No heliport operator shall manage another heliport operator’s heliport unless they are authorized to do so in the heliport operations manual of the other operator’s heliport.

Heading.TitleText: Application and Issuance of a Heliport Certificate

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a heliport certificate shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the heliport meets the certification requirements and criteria set out in these Regulations and the applicable heliport standard;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister for approval their copy of a proposed heliport operations manual that describes the manner in which the heliport meets the requirements and criteria referred to in paragraph (b) and the physical specifications of the heliport; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister proof that the applicant has consulted with the local government authority relating to the proposed heliport and adjacent land in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection 6.71(1) of the Act, the Minister shall, after receipt of an application for a heliport certificate, issue the certificate if the applicant demonstrates to the Minister the ability

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to maintain an organizational structure in accordance with the requirements of their heliport operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to maintain an operation of aviation activities at the heliport that ensures the operational requirements set out in their heliport operations manual are met; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to conduct operations at the heliport in a safe manner.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2), an applicant shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an organization capable of exercising heliport operational management; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: operational support services and equipment that are in accordance with their heliport operations manual.

Subsection.Text: If a heliport does not meet a requirement set out in the applicable heliport standard, the Minister may specify replacement conditions to be included in the heliport operations manual that relate to the same subject matter as the unmet requirement and that are necessary to achieve a level of safety that is equivalent to the one established by the requirement to protect the public interest and to ensure aviation safety.

Section.Text: A heliport certificate shall contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the certificate number;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the heliport;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the heliport operator;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the signature of the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue.

Heading.TitleText: General Conditions of a Heliport Certificate

Subsection.Text: The holder of a heliport certificate shall ensure that the heliport meets the applicable certification criteria set out in these Regulations and in the applicable heliport standard.
The holder of a heliport certificate shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain the organizational structure referred to in paragraph 305.08(2)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify the Minister within 10 working days after any change in its legal name, trade name or managerial personnel under paragraph 305.08(3)(a).

Subsection.Text: The holder of a heliport certificate shall conduct operations at the heliport in a safe manner.

Section.Text: The Minister shall approve the transfer of a heliport certificate to a transferee and issue an amended heliport certificate only if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the current holder of the heliport certificate notifies the Minister in writing at least 14 days before ceasing to operate the heliport that they will cease to operate the heliport as of the date specified in the notice and of the name of the transferee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the transferee applies in writing to the Minister for the issuance of a new heliport certificate and includes a copy of the transfer notice referred to in paragraph (a) within 14 days before the current holder ceases to operate the heliport; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements set out in section 305.10 are met on the day of transfer and there are no indications that they will not continue to be met.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may issue an interim heliport certificate in writing to the following persons authorizing them to operate a heliport:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an applicant referred to in section 305.08, until the day of issuance of the heliport certificate that will be issued to the applicant as soon as the application procedure in respect of the issuance is completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a transferee referred to in section 305.11, until the day of issuance of an amended heliport certificate in respect of the heliport that will be issued to the transferee as soon as the application procedure in respect of the transfer is completed.

Subsection.Text: An interim heliport certificate expires on the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the heliport certificate or the amended heliport certificate is issued, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day specified in the interim heliport certificate as the day on which it will expire.

Subsection.Text: Except for sections 305.08 and 305.09, this Subpart applies in respect of an interim heliport certificate in the same manner as it applies in respect of a heliport certificate.

Heading.TitleText: Division III — Operator of a Heliport

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall comply with the requirements

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with respect to the heliport as a whole, the following heliport standards as identified in their heliport operations manual:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: unless the operator has voluntarily adopted the standard referred to in subparagraph (ii), for heliports in respect of which a heliport certificate was issued before the coming into force of these Regulations, the Heliport and Helideck Standards and Recommended Practices, TP 2586E, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for any other heliport, standard 325 — Heliport Standards, as they read on the day on which the heliport certificate was issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with respect to any procedure pertaining to the administration, heliport traffic management, safety and security, emergency response and heliport maintenance, standard 325 — Heliport Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: with respect to any replacement or improvement to the heliport since the day on which the heliport certificate was issued, the following heliport standards:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for parts or facilities of the heliport that returned to service before the coming into force of these Regulations, the most recent applicable heliport standard for the heliport as identified in their heliport operations manual, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for parts or facilities of the heliport returned to service on or after the day of coming into force of these Regulations, standard 325 — Heliport Standards, as they read on the day on which the part or facility was returned to service.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: review each aeronautical information publication as soon as possible after its issuance and immediately after the review notify the Minister and the provider of aeronautical information services of any inaccurate information contained in the publication that pertains to the heliport that they operate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify the provider of an aeronautical information publication before any planned change to the heliport, the heliport facilities or the level of service at the heliport that would affect the accuracy of information contained in the publication;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the notification is in accordance with the processes and procedures established by the provider of the aeronautical information services to meet the standards referred to in Part VIII;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: notify the provider of aeronautical information services of all changes to operational information published in the aeronautical information publications; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: notify the Minister in writing of any change in heliport operations within 14 days after the day of the change and take the following measures, as applicable:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if a hazardous condition has been identified, have a NOTAM issued identifying the hazard, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if a change in heliport operations constitutes a change to the provisions identified in the heliport certificate, ensure that the change has been approved by the Minister.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), the operator of a heliport shall give to the Minister, and cause to be received at the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station, immediate notice of any of the following circumstances of which the operator has knowledge:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any projection by an object through an obstacle limitation surface relating to the heliport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the existence of any obstruction or hazardous condition affecting aviation safety at or in the vicinity of the heliport;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any reduction in the level of services at the heliport that are set out in an aeronautical information publication as being provided at the heliport;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the closure of any part of the manoeuvring area of the heliport; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other conditions that could be hazardous to aviation safety at the heliport and against which precautions are warranted.

Subsection.Text: Where it is not feasible for the operator of a heliport to cause notice of a circumstance referred to in subsection (3) to be received at the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station, the operator of the heliport shall give immediate notice directly to the pilots who may be affected by that circumstance.

Prior to the use of a heliport for helicopter operations, the operator of the heliport shall remove from the surface of the heliport, or from the surrounding ground over which the operator has control, any vehicle or other obstruction that is likely to be hazardous to aviation safety.
The operator of a heliport shall, as soon as possible after the issuance of the heliport certificate,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide the Minister with their copy of the heliport operations manual as approved under paragraph 305.08(1)(c) and any amendments to the manual approved under paragraph (2)(b); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: distribute copies of the applicable portions and amendments to the applicable persons and institutions referred to in the manual.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the heliport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: keep their heliport operations manual up to date; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister for approval any proposed amendment to their heliport operations manual.

Section.Text: The operator of a heliport shall determine the heliport classification in accordance with standard 325 — Heliport Standards in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the classification of non-instrument heliports; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: performance requirements of helicopters that are expected to use the heliport.

Section.Text: The operator of a heliport shall determine, and record in their heliport operations manual, the heliport operational limitations in accordance with the applicable heliport standard with respect to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: load bearing strength of the TLOF when required by the applicable heliport standard;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum helicopter overall length for which each operational area at a heliport is certified; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the heliport classification as specified in paragraph 305.19(a) and category as determined in accordance with the applicable heliport standard.

Section.Text: Unless otherwise specified in the applicable heliport standard, units of measurement used in this Division and in the heliport operations manual shall use the following rounding rules and specified measurement units:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: elevations to the nearest foot;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: linear dimensions to the nearest metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: geographic coordinates in latitude and longitude to the nearest second;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: geographic coordinates measured in accordance with North American Datum 1983;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: bearings to the nearest degree;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: water depths, measured in the specified unit expressed, to the nearest foot or metre; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: range of tides or water levels, measured in the specified unit expressed, to the nearest foot or metre.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the heliport has at least one FATO; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no FATO is used to accommodate the manoeuvres of more than one helicopter at a time.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (3) to (6), the operator of a heliport shall ensure that the heliport meets the requirements set out in the applicable heliport standard in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: FATOs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: safety areas;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: rejected take-off areas, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: helicopter clearways, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: TLOFs, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: taxiways as follows, if applicable:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: air taxiways,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: helicopter ground taxiways,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: helicopter ground taxiway shoulders, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: helicopter ground taxiway strips;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: aprons, if applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: helicopter parking positions, if applicable.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a surface-level heliport shall ensure that the heliport meets the special requirements for a surface-level heliport set out in the applicable heliport standard in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: TLOFs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: taxiways; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aprons.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an elevated or rooftop heliport shall ensure that the heliport meets the special requirements for an elevated or rooftop heliport set out in the applicable heliport standard in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: TLOFs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: safety nets; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: helicopter parking positions.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport located on an aerodrome primarily designed to serve aeroplanes shall ensure that the heliport meets the special requirements for a heliport located on an aerodrome set out in the applicable heliport standard in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: application of additional standards regarding aerodromes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: FATOs;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ground taxiway separation distances;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: taxi-holding positions;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: aprons; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: helicopter parking positions.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an H1 heliport shall ensure that the heliport meets the special requirements for an H1 heliport set out in the applicable heliport standard in respect of FATOs and TLOFs.

Subject to subsections (2) to (4), the operator of a heliport shall establish the following obstacle limitation surfaces in accordance with the applicable heliport standard for a non-instrument, non-precision or precision FATO and meet the special requirements for the surfaces and any obstacles that may affect them, set out in the applicable heliport standard:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: approach surfaces;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take-off surfaces; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: transitional surfaces.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an H1 heliport shall ensure that the heliport meets the special requirements for obstacle limitation surfaces for non-instrument FATOs set out in the applicable heliport standard for an H1 heliport in respect of approach or take-off surfaces.

The operator of an H1 heliport shall conduct a survey of the approach and take-off surface to determine obstacle information and submit a copy to the Minister at the time of the initial heliport certification and after that at least once every five years, unless no new obstacle has been established in the approach and take-off surface during the five-year period and a report to that effect is made to the Minister.

The operator of an H2 heliport shall ensure that the heliport meets the special requirements for obstacle limitation surfaces for non-instrument FATOs set out in the applicable heliport standard for an H2 heliport in respect of approach or take-off surfaces.

The operator of a heliport equipped with an instrument FATO shall ensure that the heliport meets the special requirements for obstacle limitation surfaces for instrument FATOs set out in the applicable heliport standard.

Heading.TitleText: Division VII — Visual Aids for Air Navigation

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall equip the heliport with at least one wind direction indicator and meet the requirements for wind direction indicators set out in the applicable heliport standard.
The operator of a heliport shall meet the requirements for heliport markings set out in the applicable heliport standard in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: heliport identification marking;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a hospital heliport, hospital heliport identification marking;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an aiming point marking for each FATO;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: FATO edge marking;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a FATO designation marking for each FATO;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a FATO centre line marking for each FATO;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: approach and take-off direction indicator marking;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a TLOF edge marking for each TLOF;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum allowable helicopter weight marking for each TLOF;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the following taxiway markings:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: taxiway centre line marking,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: taxiway holding position marking, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: taxiway edge marking;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: where the apron edge is not easily identifiable, an apron edge marking;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: where a helicopter parking position is provided, a helicopter parking position marking;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: where a helicopter parking position is provided and helicopters are required to have a specific alignment on the parking position, an alignment marking;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: where a helicopter parking position is not large enough for the largest helicopter for which the heliport is designed or where the size of the parking position is limited by the minimum separation requirement to an obstacle or an adjacent parking position, a helicopter parking position information marking; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: where passengers are required to walk on a specific path on an apron between a helicopter parking position and the passenger terminal, an apron passenger path marking.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall extinguish, screen or otherwise modify a ground light, other than an aeronautical ground light, that may cause confusion to heliport users within the heliport boundary or other spaces within the boundaries of the control of the heliport operator.
The operator of a heliport shall meet the requirements set out in the applicable heliport standard in respect of the installation of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: elevated approach lights;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: elevated lights for operational areas;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: inset lights;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: light intensity and control; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a heliport beacon.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport equipped with a non-instrument FATO that is certified to be available for use at night shall provide an approach and take-off direction light that meets the requirements set out in the applicable heliport standard where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least one approach and departure path is required to be indicated to pilots; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: obstacle clearance, noise abatement or air traffic control procedures require that a specific direction be flown.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall provide a visual approach slope indicator system that meets the requirements set out in the applicable heliport standard where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there are inadequate visual references;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: obstacle clearance, noise abatement or air traffic control procedures require that a particular slope be flown; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the surrounding terrain may produce misleading information.

Subsection.Text: Where a heliport approach path indicator or an abbreviated heliport approach path indicator is provided at a heliport, the visual approach slope indicator system shall meet the general design requirements and specific requirements set out in the applicable heliport standard.
The operator of a heliport shall monitor the visual approach slope indicator system provided at a heliport in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

Where a visual approach slope indicator system is provided, the operator of a heliport shall provide, when required, an obstacle protection surface (OPS) in accordance with the applicable heliport standard.
The operator of a heliport shall provide FATO lights that meet the requirements of the applicable heliport standard for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a surface-level heliport unless the FATO and the TLOF are coincidental or the extent of the FATO is conspicuous;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an instrument FATO; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where an illuminated TLOF is not provided, a FATO that is certified to be available for use at night unless the FATO edge marking is clearly visible to heliport users by means of external floodlighting.

Subsection.Text: Where a TLOF is not located within a FATO that is certified to be available for use at night, the operator of a heliport shall ensure the aiming point is illuminated in accordance with the applicable heliport standard.

The operator of a heliport shall provide TLOF lights consisting of perimeter lights, floodlights or luminescent panels for a TLOF that is certified to be available for use at night and, if the perimeter of the TLOF is not coincidental with that of the FATO, in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

Where a rejected take-off area is established for a surface-level heliport that is certified to be available for use at night, the operator of a heliport shall provide in that area rejected take-off area lights in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

The operator of a heliport shall provide taxiway centre line lights in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard for a taxiway that is used in runway visual range conditions of less than 1200 feet or in conditions of ground visibility of less than one-quarter statute mile.

The operator of a heliport shall provide taxiway edge lights in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard for a taxiway that is available at a heliport that is certified to be available for use at night and that is not provided with taxiway centre line lights.

Where an apron is available at a heliport that is certified to be available for use at night, the operator of the heliport shall provide apron edge lights, retro-reflective edge markers or apron floodlighting in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

The operator of a heliport shall ensure that the markers installed at the heliport are either flush mounted or lightweight and frangibly mounted and in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.
The operator of a heliport shall provide FATO markers where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a FATO edge marking is not provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the extent of the FATO and the adjacent ground is not conspicuous.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall provide ground taxiway edge markers in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard if the helicopters must travel along a ground taxiway to or from a FATO to an apron, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the edges of the taxiway are conspicuous;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: taxiway centre line lights are provided;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: taxiway edge lights are provided; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: taxiway centre line markers are provided.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall provide air taxiway markers if the helicopters must travel by air to or from a FATO to an apron via a specific corridor in accordance with the applicable heliport standard.

Heading.TitleText: Division X — Visual Aids for Denoting Obstacles
Requirements for Marking or Lighting Obstacles

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), the operator of a heliport shall ensure that obstacles, other than aircraft, on the movement, manoeuvring and safety areas of the heliport are marked and lighted as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vehicles and other mobile obstacles on the movement area shall be marked so as to be visible to pilots during aircraft operations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the heliport is used at night or in conditions of low visibility, vehicles and other mobile obstacles on the manoeuvring area shall be lighted;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: elevated aeronautical ground lights on the movement area shall be marked so as to be conspicuous by day; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the applicable heliport standard, a fixed obstacles located on the safety area shall be

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: marked, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the heliport is certified to be available for use at night, lighted.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall mark and, if the heliport is certified to be available for use at night, light fixed obstacles located within the area identified in the applicable heliport standard, except where the obstacle is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shielded by another fixed obstacle that is marked in accordance with Standard 621;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conspicuous by reason of its shape, dimensions or colour;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identified in an aeronautical evaluation as being sufficiently lit by ambient light at night; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: not more than 150 m above the adjacent ground and lighted in accordance with Standard 621.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport where a fixed obstacle that is more than 150 m above the surrounding ground is located within the area identified in the applicable heliport standard shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: light the obstacle by high-intensity obstacle lights by day in accordance with Standard 621; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: mark the obstacle in accordance with the applicable heliport standard.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall mark an elevated obstacle on the helicopter ground taxiway strips and, where the heliport is certified to be available for use at night, light the obstacle.
The operator of a heliport shall mark and, if applicable, light an obstacle referred to in subsection (2) unless an aeronautical evaluation determines that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the obstacle is conspicuous by reason of its shape, dimensions or colour; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: retro-reflective tape or markers are sufficiently conspicuous to be used instead of lights.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall ensure that a fixed obstacle or a mobile obstacle on the heliport is marked in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.
Obstacles required to be marked shall, in accordance with Standard 621, be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: coloured;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: marked by markers; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: marked by flags.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall light a fixed obstacle in accordance with Standard 621.
The operator of a heliport shall ensure that maintenance and service vehicles in use display lights in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.
The operator of a heliport shall ensure that emergency vehicles in use that are required to be lighted display the lights specified in the applicable heliport standard.

Heading.TitleText: Division XI — Visual Aids for Denoting Restricted Use Areas

Subsection.Text: When a FATO, helicopter parking position, taxiway, or any part of those areas is permanently closed, the operator of a heliport shall display a closed marking on the area that meets the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.
When an area of a heliport is temporarily closed or an area is snow-covered, the heliport operator shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notice of the closure is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: included in the Canada Flight Supplement, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: reported in a NOTAM; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a closed marking referred to in subsection (1) is displayed on the affected area.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall ensure that non-load-bearing surfaces adjacent to a FATO, helicopter parking position or taxiway that cannot be visually distinguished from load-bearing surfaces are marked as set out in the applicable heliport standard.

The operator of a heliport shall ensure that unserviceability markers consisting of flags, cones or marker boards that meet the requirements of the applicable heliport standard and are positioned in conformity with that standard are displayed on any part of a taxiway or apron that is unfit for the movement of aircraft.

The operator of a heliport shall ensure that unserviceability lights that meet the requirements of the applicable heliport standard are displayed in conformity with that standard wherever any portion of a taxiway or apron at a heliport that is certified to be available for use at night is unfit for the movement of aircraft.
The operator of a heliport shall ensure that the lights of a visual approach slope indicator system, when required and installed as specified in subsection 305.33(4), are aligned by means of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a daily inspection of alignment and, if necessary, a correction of any misalignment of more than 3 minutes of arc; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an automatic shut-off switch installed in the system.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall ensure that a fence or other barrier is installed on the heliport and that the fence or other barrier meets the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

The operator of a heliport or a person under the operator’s authority shall direct any vehicle that is operated on an apron or manoeuvring area of the heliport or, in the case of a vehicle in a manoeuvring area, shall ensure that the vehicle’s operation is under the direction of the air traffic services unit or the heliport operator or a person working under their authority, in accordance with the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

The operator of the heliport shall ensure that the drivers of vehicles on an apron or manoeuvring area are trained for the tasks to be performed and that they know they must comply with instructions issued by the air traffic services unit or the heliport operator or a person working under their authority.

The operator of a heliport shall ensure that equipment required for air navigation purposes that is located on a safety area, a taxiway strip or within the separation distances specified in the applicable heliport standard is located, constructed and installed in accordance with that standard.
The operator of a heliport shall ensure that visual aids, precision approach FATO lights and centre line lights on a taxiway are maintained in accordance with the applicable heliport standard.

Heading.TitleText: Division XIII — Emergency and Other Services

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall develop and have available a heliport emergency response plan at the heliport.
The operator of a heliport shall identify in the emergency response plan those organizations that are capable of providing assistance in responding to an emergency at the heliport or in its vicinity.
The operator of a heliport shall specify in the emergency response plan the procedures to be followed for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft crash or other accident within the heliport perimeter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft crash outside the heliport perimeter; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any medical emergency.

Subsection.Text: Where an approach and departure path at a heliport is located over water, the operator of the heliport shall specify in the emergency response plan

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the organization that is responsible for co-ordinating rescue in the event of an aircraft ditching; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: how to contact that organization.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall include in the emergency response plan the information required in accordance with standard 325 — Heliport Standards.
The operator of a heliport shall consult with all organizations identified in the emergency response plan concerning their role in it.
The operator of a heliport shall annually review the emergency response plan and update the information.
The operator of a heliport that provides a scheduled service for the transport of passengers shall carry out a test of the emergency response plan at intervals not exceeding three years.

The operator of a surface-level heliport or of a heliport over a parking garage or on an elevated structure that is not an occupied building shall ensure that fire protection services are provided at the heliport and that those services and the fire resistance of the structure meets the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

The operator of a rooftop heliport shall ensure that fire protection services are provided at the heliport and that those services and the fire resistance of the structure meets the requirements of the applicable heliport standard.

Section.Text: The operator of a heliport shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine the requirements for extinguishing agents and equipment used for fire protection at the heliport based on the longest dimension helicopter for which the heliport has been certified;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the agents and equipment are in accordance with the applicable heliport standard; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide a fire extinguisher or fire fighting system that is protected from freezing.

Section.Text: The operator of a rooftop heliport shall ensure that a minimum of one trained safety person is in attendance during helicopter operations.
The operator of a heliport shall provide initial and refresher training to safety personnel provided at the heliport in accordance with the applicable heliport standard.

Subsection.Text: The provisions of this Subpart that specify the procedures for making a heliport operations manual also apply in respect of any amendment to the manual.
The operator of a heliport shall set out in the heliport operations manual

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the heliport certification standards that were met for issuance of the heliport certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the level and types of services to be provided by the operator of the heliport.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall operate the heliport in accordance with the heliport operations manual.
The operator of a heliport shall determine and record in the heliport operations manual, the following data in respect of the heliport in accordance with the applicable heliport standard:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: geographic coordinates for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the heliport reference point if

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the heliport is not located on an aerodrome that already has a reference point, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the heliport operator intends to have a zoning regulation made under the Aeronautics Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the heliport geometric centre,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the FATO coordinates,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the heliport elevation,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the heliport magnetic variation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: where installed, the electronic navigation aids; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information in respect of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the heliport type,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the dimensions, slope and surface type of all TLOFs,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the length, width, slope, category, surface type and designation number of all FATOs,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the length, width and surface type of all safety areas,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the designation, width and surface type of helicopter ground and air taxiways,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the apron surface type and description of helicopter parking positions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the declared distances for

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: take-off distance available,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: rejected take-off distance available, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: landing distance available.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall ensure that a heliport geometric centre is redetermined and recorded in the manual if the physical characteristics of the heliport change because

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an existing FATO is closed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the boundaries of an existing FATO are altered; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a new FATO is constructed.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a heliport shall report the heliport data specified in paragraph (1)(a) to the Aeronautical Information Services of NAV Canada within 14 days after the Minister’s approval of certification.

Section.Text: The operator of a heliport shall ensure that the heliport operations manual contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a table of contents; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information relating to the administration of the heliport including but not limited to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a copy of any amendments to the manual and the page numbers affected,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a list of holders of copies of the manual or of portions of it,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of a procedure for amending the manual,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the organizational structure of the heliport management,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the operational procedures of the heliport,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: a declaration, signed and dated by the operator, in which they agree to fulfill the obligations of the operator referred to in section 305.17,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement, signed and dated by the operator, certifying that their heliport operations manual is complete and accurate, and that the operator agrees to comply with all of the conditions and specifications set out in it,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement, signed by the Minister, that the heliport operations manual and any amendments to it have been approved,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: a copy of any agreement or memorandum of understanding that affects the operation of the heliport, including the provision of emergency services at the heliport, and

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: the information necessary to verify that the heliport meets the applicable heliport standard.

Section.Text: The operator of a heliport shall ensure that their heliport operations manual sets out the information specified in subsection 305.25(1).
The operator of a heliport shall ensure that the following are provided in accordance with the applicable heliport standard and recorded in their heliport operations manual:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicable physical characteristics set out in section 305.25;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the obstacle limitation surfaces set out in section 305.29;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the visual aids for navigation set out in section 305.31;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the lighting or marking of obstacles set out in section 305.37;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the visual aids utilized for denoting restricted use areas set out in section 305.41;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment and installations set out in section 305.43; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency response plan set out in section 305.45.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Subpart.

Definition.Text: aerodrome work means work, other than work necessary to comply with a new requirement imposed by or under the Act, carried out for any of the following purposes:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: building a new aerodrome; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at an existing aerodrome,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: building a new runway for aeroplanes, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: increasing the length of an existing runway for aeroplanes by 100 m or by 10%, whichever is greater. (travaux d’aérodrome)

Definition.Text: proponent means a person who proposes to carry out aerodrome work. (promoteur)
protected area means a natural area or habitat that is protected by or under federal legislation. (aire protégée)

Section.Text: This Subpart applies to existing and proposed aerodromes that are not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: military aerodromes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: water aerodromes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aerodromes that are used primarily for agricultural operations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
