Paragraph.Text: in cases other than those described in paragraphs (a) and (b), the performance of the maintenance by the person or organization has been approved by the Minister as being in conformity with these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall ensure that a maintenance arrangement made with a person or organization pursuant to subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: specifies the maintenance required and clearly defines the tasks to be performed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is made in accordance with the procedures governing maintenance arrangements included in the maintenance control manual or is approved by the Minister as being in conformity with these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Where a flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter makes a maintenance arrangement referred to in paragraph (1)(b), the Minister shall, in the following cases, authorize the arrangement by issuing a maintenance specification to indicate that the maintenance control procedures set out in the arrangement conform to the personnel licensing standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the issuance of a maintenance specification is either required by the agreement or requested by the foreign state; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance is performed in a state that is not party to an agreement with Canada that provides for recognition of the work performed.

Section.Text: A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall establish and comply with policies and procedures to ensure that an aircraft is not operated unless it is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: airworthy;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: appropriately equipped, configured and maintained for its intended use; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: maintained in accordance with the flight training unit’s maintenance control manual.

Heading.TitleText: Defect Recording, Rectification and Control Procedures

Section.Text: A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall establish and comply with policies and procedures that meet the personnel licensing standards for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: recording aircraft defects, including defects that are detected during aircraft operation or during the performance of elementary work or servicing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identifying defects that recur and reporting those defects as recurring defects to maintenance personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring that defects are rectified in accordance with the requirements of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to sections 605.09 and 605.10, scheduling the rectification of defects whose repair has been deferred.

Section.Text: The holder of a flight training unit operator certificate who operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall report to the Minister, in accordance with Division IX of Subpart 21 of Part V, any reportable service difficulty related to any aircraft that it operates.
No flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall authorize a person to perform, without supervision, a task that is elementary work set out in section 605.85 unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has satisfactorily completed training for the task under a training program required by section 406.45; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has previously performed that task under the direct supervision of the holder of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME) licence or a training organization approved pursuant to Subpart 3.

Section.Text: A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall ensure that each person who performs or requests the performance of servicing has satisfactorily completed training, under a training program required by section 406.45, for the servicing to be performed.

A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall implement a training program to ensure that persons who are authorized to perform a function under this Division are trained in respect of the regulations, standards and flight training unit procedures applicable to that function, as specified in the personnel licensing standards.

Subsection.Text: A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall establish, maintain and retain for at least two years after an entry is made a record of maintenance personnel that meets the personnel licensing standards.
Where an authorization is given or training is completed, the flight training unit shall provide a copy of each record required by subsection (1) to the person to whom the record refers.

The holder of an operator certificate issued in respect of a flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall, in order to ensure that its maintenance control system and all of the included maintenance schedules continue to be effective and to comply with these Regulations, establish and maintain a quality assurance program that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is under the sole control of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the person responsible for the maintenance control system appointed under paragraph 406.19(1)(a), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the person to whom the management functions for the program have been assigned under subsection 406.36(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of section 426.47 of the personnel licensing standards.

Subsection.Text: The person responsible for the maintenance control system shall ensure that records relating to the findings resulting from the quality assurance program are distributed to the appropriate manager for corrective action and follow-up in accordance with the policies and procedures specified in the maintenance control manual (MCM).
The person responsible for the maintenance control system shall establish an audit system in respect of a quality assurance program that consists of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an initial audit within 12 months after the date on which the flight training unit operator certificate is issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsequent audits conducted at intervals set out in the MCM;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a record of each occurrence of compliance or non-compliance with the MCM found during an audit referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for ensuring that each finding of an audit is communicated to them and, if management functions have been assigned to another person under subsection 406.36(2) or (3), to that person;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: follow-up procedures for ensuring that corrective actions are effective; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a system for recording the findings of initial and periodic audits, corrective actions and follow-ups.

Subsection.Text: The records required under paragraph (3)(f) shall be retained for the greater of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two audit cycles; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two years.

Subsection.Text: If a flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter is also the holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate issued under section 573.02, the person responsible for the quality assurance program of the flight training unit under paragraph (1)(a) shall be the person responsible for the quality assurance program of the AMO.

The duties related to the quality assurance program that involve specific tasks or activities within a flight training unit's activities shall be fulfilled by persons who are not responsible for carrying out those tasks or activities.

Section.Text: No flight training unit that conducts flight training in accordance with a flight training operations manual that has been approved by the Minister shall operate an aircraft unless the flight training unit has an operational control system that meets the personnel licensing standards and is under the control of its chief flight instructor.

Subsection.Text: A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane to conduct training for a private pilot licence, a commercial pilot licence or a flight instructor rating shall have access to at least one aeroplane that is certified under Part V for the spin manoeuvre.

A flight training unit that operates a helicopter to conduct training for a pilot permit — recreational, a private pilot licence, a commercial pilot licence or a flight instructor rating shall have access to at least one helicopter that is configured for and capable of full-on autorotational landings.

Section.Text: A flight training unit shall have facilities at a base of operations that meet the personnel licensing standards.

No flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall permit a person to conduct a take-off in an aircraft that is subject to the operational control of the flight training unit unless the aircraft has been maintained in accordance with a maintenance control system.

No flight training unit shall permit a person to operate a land aircraft over water, except when conducting a take-off or landing, beyond a point where the land aircraft could reach shore in the event of an engine failure.

No flight training unit that operates an aeroplane or a helicopter shall permit a person to conduct the solo cross-country flight required by Subpart 1 for the private pilot licence — aeroplane or the private pilot licence — helicopter unless the flight training unit notifies the Minister in writing of the planned route of the flight originating from the main base or any satellite base.

A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane, a helicopter or a glider shall, for the purpose of maintaining operational control, establish, maintain and retain for at least two years after an entry is made a daily flight record that meets the personnel licensing standards.
A flight training unit that operates an aeroplane, a helicopter or a glider shall designate a person to make journey log entries in accordance with section 605.94.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Training at a Satellite Base

Subsection.Text: A flight training unit that conducts flight training at a satellite base shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assign a flight instructor, other than a Class 4 flight instructor, to be responsible for flight training operations at the satellite base; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that a qualified flight instructor is on duty at that satellite base while a solo training flight is in progress.

Subsection.Text: A Class 4 flight instructor shall not conduct flight training at a satellite base unless a qualified Class 1 or Class 2 flight instructor is on duty.

Heading.TitleText: Division VI — Manuals and Course Certificates

Subsection.Text: Every flight training unit that conducts an integrated course or operates a sub-base shall establish and maintain a flight training operations manual that includes the instructions and information necessary to enable the personnel concerned to perform their duties safely and that meets the personnel licensing standards.
The flight training operations manual may be issued in separate parts corresponding to specific aspects of operations.
Whenever the flight training operations manual no longer meets the personnel licensing standards, the flight training unit shall amend it to bring it into compliance with the standards.

A flight training unit shall submit to the Minister its flight training operations manual and, if they relate to the information required by the personnel licensing standards, any separately issued parts and any subsequent amendments to them or to the manual.

If the personnel licensing standards are met, the Minister shall approve the parts of a flight training operations manual that relate to the information required by the personnel licensing standards and any subsequent amendments to the parts.

A flight training unit shall distribute its flight training operations manual, any separately issued parts and any subsequent amendments to the manual or parts in accordance with the personnel licensing standards.
The chief flight instructor shall maintain a master list of the holders of the flight training operations manual and ensure that the manual is distributed in accordance with the list.
The following operational personnel shall hold copies of the flight training operations manual and shall be responsible for its amendment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the chief flight instructor;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the assistant chief flight instructor;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the check instructor; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person responsible for the maintenance control system or the approved maintenance organization.

Subsection.Text: The chief flight instructor shall make manuals available to all other operational personnel who are involved in operational control, including flight instructors, students and, if applicable, flight dispatchers.

Every person who has been provided with a copy of the appropriate parts of a flight training operations manual pursuant to subsections (7) and (8) shall keep it up to date by inserting in it the amendments provided and shall ensure that the appropriate parts are accessible when the person is performing assigned duties.
Every flight training unit that conducts an integrated course shall establish and maintain a training manual that meets the personnel licensing standards.
The training manual may be issued in separate parts corresponding to specific aspects of the integrated course.
Whenever the training manual no longer meets the personnel licensing standards, the flight training unit shall amend it to bring it into compliance with the standards.

A flight training unit shall submit to the Minister its training manual and, if they relate to the information required by the personnel licensing standards, any separately issued parts and any subsequent amendments to them or to the manual.

If the personnel licensing standards are met, the Minister shall approve the parts of a training manual that relate to the information required by the personnel licensing standards and any subsequent amendments to the parts.
A flight training unit that conducts an integrated course shall provide to each trainee, at the start of the course, a certificate of enrolment that meets the personnel licensing standards.
A flight training unit that conducts an integrated course shall maintain a current list of the trainees enrolled in each integrated course conducted by the flight training unit.

Section.Text: A flight training unit that conducts an integrated course shall provide to each trainee, on successful completion of the course, a course completion certificate that meets the personnel licensing standards.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, competency check means a certification by the chief flight instructor or an instructor delegated by the chief flight instructor that a flight instructor conducting training under an integrated course has demonstrated in flight an ability to perform both normal and emergency manoeuvres appropriate to the most complex single-engined aeroplane to be used for the flight instruction.

A flight training unit that conducts flight training in accordance with a flight training operations manual that has been approved by the Minister shall establish and maintain a ground and flight training program for operational personnel as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: indoctrination training is required upon employment for all persons assigned to an operational control function, including chief flight instructors, assistant chief flight instructors, flight instructors and persons responsible for flight following;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the training referred to in paragraph (a) shall ensure that persons involved in the control of flight operations are aware of their responsibilities, know reporting relationships and are competent to fulfil their assigned duties related to flight training operations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the training referred to in paragraph (a) shall include a review of the flight training operations manual and the training manual, as applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: each flight instructor who conducts training in accordance with an integrated course shall, before receiving authorization to conduct the training, successfully complete, under the supervision of the chief flight instructor, assistant chief flight instructor or check instructor,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the indoctrination training referred in paragraph (a),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a review of, and a briefing on, the contents of the flight training operations manual and the training manual, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an initial competency check in each type of aircraft in which the flight instructor conducts training in accordance with the integrated course; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: each flight instructor who conducts training in accordance with an integrated course shall, every 12 months after the month in which the initial competency check was completed, successfully complete

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a recurrent competency check in one of the aircraft in which the flight instructor conducts training in accordance with the integrated course,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an in-flight monitoring of a training flight conducted by the flight instructor,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a flight test toward the issuance of a flight instructor rating, multi-engine class rating or instrument rating, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a competency check in accordance with Part VI or a pilot proficiency check in accordance with Part VII, as applicable.

Section.Text: An integrated course shall be conducted under the supervision of the chief flight instructor of a flight training unit that holds a flight training unit operator certificate and shall be arranged by that flight training unit in accordance with the personnel licensing standards.

The flight training unit shall ensure that an applicant, before being admitted to an integrated course, has a secondary school diploma or equivalent in accordance with the personnel licensing standards.

Any trainee wishing to transfer to another flight training unit during an integrated course shall apply to the other flight training unit for a formal assessment of the further hours of training required at that flight training unit. The assessment shall be recorded in the applicant’s training record.

Subsection.Text: Any reference in this Subpart to the flight testing standards is a reference to Standard 428 — Personnel Licensing and Training Standards respecting the Conduct of Flight Tests.
The following definitions apply in this Subpart.

Definition.Code: se="408.01",ss="2",df="{air flight test item}{exercice en vol}"
Definition.Text: air flight test item means a flight test item performed using an aeroplane, helicopter or synthetic flight training equipment, including the pre-flight inspection, start-up, run-up, taxiing and emergency procedures. (exercice en vol)
examiner means a person designated by the Minister to conduct flight tests for the issuance or renewal of flight crew permits, licences or ratings for an aeroplane or helicopter. (examinateur)

Definition.Code: se="408.01",ss="2",df="{ground flight test item}{exercice au sol}"
Definition.Text: ground flight test item means a flight test item performed prior to the pre-flight inspection of the aeroplane or helicopter. (exercice au sol)

Section.Text: This Subpart applies in respect of the conduct, using an aeroplane, helicopter or synthetic flight training equipment, of flight tests required for the issuance or renewal of a flight crew permit, licence or rating.
The Minister shall maintain a record of each flight test in accordance with this Subpart and the flight testing standards. The record shall contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an assessment of the results of each flight test item;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the overall results; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the candidate passed or failed the flight test.

Section.Text: Before conducting a flight test or partial re-test, the examiner shall ensure that they have received the documentation specified in section 1 of Schedules 1 to 18 to the flight testing standards, dated, if applicable, as specified in that section.

Heading.TitleText: Aircraft and Equipment Required for a Flight Test

Section.Text: The examiner shall ensure that the candidate who takes a flight test provides the aircraft and equipment described in section 2 of Schedules 1 to 18 to the flight testing standards.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a flight test conducted in accordance with Schedules 1 to 8 to the flight testing standards, a candidate successfully completes the flight test if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate completes all of the items set out in section 5 of those schedules; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate receives at least the passing grade for the permit, licence or rating specified in the following table and does not fail any flight test item for any of the reasons set out in subsection 408.18(1).

Subsection.Text: In the case of a flight test conducted in accordance with Schedules 9 to 18 to the flight testing standards, a candidate successfully completes the flight test if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate completes all of the items set out in section 5 of those schedules; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate successfully completes each item of the flight test and does not fail the test for any of the reasons set out in section 408.19.

Subsection.Text: The examiner shall conduct a flight test in accordance with section 3 of Schedules 1 to 18 to the flight testing standards.

The examiner shall evaluate the performance of a candidate in accordance with section 4 of Schedules 1 to 18 to the flight testing standards by verifying, during the flight test, the candidate’s knowledge and skills when performing the items set out in section 4 of those schedules, taking into account the general tolerances specified in that section. The examiner shall record the results on the form entitled Flight Test Report in the manner specified by the Minister.

In the case of a flight test conducted in accordance with Schedules 1 to 8 to the flight testing standards, the examiner shall not take part in the pilotage of the aeroplane or helicopter during the flight test except in the cases set out in paragraph 3(b) of those schedules.

Section.Text: In the case of a flight test conducted in accordance with Schedules 1 to 8 to the flight testing standards, the examiner may have the candidate repeat an item if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the item is discontinued for safety reasons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the examiner intervened on the flight controls to avoid a collision with another aircraft that the candidate could not see;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate understood the specific nature of the item but did not understand the examiner’s request to perform it; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the examiner was distracted to the point of not being able to adequately observe the candidate’s performance of the item.

Section.Text: If the candidate has successfully completed some of the items during a flight test but the flight test cannot be completed for reasons beyond the candidate’s control, the subsequent flight test shall meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: only the items that the candidate could not perform during the initial flight test shall be performed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate shall take the subsequent flight test within

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 60 days after the date of the incomplete flight test, in the case of a flight test described in Schedule 1 to the flight testing standards, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 30 days after the date of the incomplete flight test, in the case of a flight test described in Schedules 2 to 18 to the flight testing standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight test conducted in accordance with Schedule 8 to the flight testing standards, the subsequent flight test shall be conducted using an aircraft in the same instrument rating group as the aircraft used in the initial flight test.

Heading.TitleText: Failure and Re-test — Schedules 1 to 8 to Flight Testing Standards

Subsection.Text: In the case of a flight test conducted in accordance with Schedules 1 to 8 to the flight testing standards, a candidate fails the flight test if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate’s performance of an item includes deviations that are repeated or that the candidate either does not recognize or does not correct in a timely manner;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate’s handling of the aircraft is rough or includes uncorrected or excessive deviations from specified tolerances;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate, as a result of a pilot error or faulty handling of the aircraft, exceeds by more than double the deviation tolerances specified in the table to section 4 of Schedules 1 to 8 of those standards, even if a correction is made;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate does not demonstrate the level of technical proficiency or knowledge necessary to carry out the functions of a holder of a licence, permit or rating;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate has lapses in situational awareness that are not identified or corrected;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate’s flight management skills are ineffective; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the safety of the flight is compromised.

Subsection.Text: A candidate who fails not more than two air flight test items described in Schedules 1 to 7 to the flight testing standards may take a re-test of each failed item within:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 60 days after the date of the failed test, in the case of a flight test described in Schedule 1 to those standards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 30 days after the date of the failed test, in the case of a flight test described in Schedules 2 to 7 to those standards.

Subsection.Text: A candidate who fails not more than one air flight test item described in Schedule 8 to the flight testing standards may take a re-test of the failed item within 30 days after the date of the failed test.
A candidate must take a complete re-test for a licence, permit or rating referred to in Schedules 1 to 8 to the flight testing standards if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: during a flight test, the candidate displays unsafe airmanship or dangerous flying resulting in the flight test being assessed as a failure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate repeatedly fails to use appropriate and effective visual scanning techniques to ensure that the area is cleared before or while performing an item that involves visual manoeuvres;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: during a complete flight test, the candidate fails any ground flight test item;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: during a complete flight test, the candidate fails more than two air flight test items in the case of a flight test described in Schedules 1 to 7 to the flight testing standards or more than one air flight test item in the case of a flight test described in Schedule 8 to those standards;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate fails an item during a partial re-test; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate does not complete a partial re-test within a period specified in subsection (2).

Heading.TitleText: Failure of a Flight Test — Schedules 9 to 18 to Flight Testing Standards

Section.Text: In the case of a flight test conducted in accordance with Schedules 9 to 18 to the flight testing standards, a candidate fails the flight test if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate performs an air flight test item using unsafe airmanship or completes the item with major deviations from the level of competency required for the issuance of a commercial pilot licence — aeroplane or a commercial pilot licence — helicopter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate fails to use appropriate and effective visual scanning techniques to ensure that the area is cleared before or while performing an item that involves visual manoeuvres;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate acts or fails to act in such a manner that the examiner is required to take corrective action to maintain safe flight;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate instructs, on the ground or in the air, in a manner that the examiner determines would result in a lack of understanding or in a misunderstanding that could lead to a dangerous flight situation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate fails to accomplish the aim of one or more of the items of the flight test;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate does not demonstrate the level of technical proficiency or knowledge necessary to carry out the functions of a holder of a flight instructor rating; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the candidate displays an ineffective instructional technique.

Section.Text: In this Part, rotorcraft means a gyroplane or a helicopter.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the owner of a Canadian aircraft, other than an ultra-light aeroplane, shall submit to the Minister an Annual Airworthiness Information Report in respect of the aircraft, in the form and manner specified in Chapter 501 of the Airworthiness Manual, either as

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an individual report; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where approved in conformity with Chapter 501 of the Airworthiness Manual, a consolidated fleet report.

Subsection.Text: The submission of the Annual Airworthiness Information Report is not required where the aircraft is out of service and its owner

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: reports, in the form and manner specified in Chapter 501 of the Airworthiness Manual, that the aircraft is out of service and is expected to remain out of service for one or more of the reporting periods for which an Annual Airworthiness Information Report would otherwise be required; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notifies the Minister forthwith when that aircraft is brought back into service.

Section.Text: The owner of a Canadian aircraft shall provide in the Annual Airworthiness Information Report the information on the characteristics of the aircraft and on the maintenance of its airworthiness that is specified in Chapter 501 of the Airworthiness Manual.

The owner of a Canadian aircraft shall submit the Annual Airworthiness Information Report to the Minister by not later than the anniversary of the day on which the aircraft’s flight authority was issued or another date agreed on, beforehand, by the owner and the Minister.

Heading.TitleText: Subpart 7 — Flight Authority and Certificate of Noise Compliance

Section.Text: This Subpart applies in respect of aircraft, other than ultra-light aeroplanes and hang gliders, that are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Canadian aircraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: operated in Canadian airspace.

Section.Text: Where an application for a flight authority is made pursuant to section 507.06, the Minister shall issue a certificate of airworthiness in respect of an aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for which an aircraft type design has been certified by the Minister and the certification is not in respect of a restricted category aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that conforms to its certified type design; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that is safe for flight.

Section.Text: Where an application for a flight authority is made pursuant to section 507.06, the Minister shall issue a special certificate of airworthiness in respect of an aircraft that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the criteria for one of the classifications of a special certificate of airworthiness specified in Chapter 507 of the Airworthiness Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conforms to the applicable type design or, in the case of an amateur-built aircraft, is designed and constructed in a way that ensures its airworthiness, in conformity with the requirements of Chapter 549 of the Airworthiness Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is safe for flight.

Section.Text: Where an application for a flight authority is made pursuant to section 507.06, the Minister shall issue a flight permit in respect of an aircraft that meets the criteria for one of the classifications of a flight permit specified in Chapter 507 of the Airworthiness Manual and that is safe for flight.

Where an aircraft is operating under a foreign flight authority that is issued in respect of the aircraft or the fleet of which it is a part and that does not conform to Article 31 of the Convention, and the Minister determines that the aircraft is safe for flight, the Minister shall validate the foreign flight authority, thereby authorizing the operation of the aircraft in Canadian airspace.

Subsection.Text: An application for a flight authority shall be signed by the owner of the aircraft in respect of which it is submitted, or by a representative of the owner as defined in Chapter 507 of the Airworthiness Manual.
A person who applies for a flight authority shall do so in the form and manner specified in Chapter 507 of the Airworthiness Manual.
An applicant for a flight authority shall include with the application a declaration, made by a person authorized to do so pursuant to section 507.10, attesting that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application for a certificate of airworthiness, the aircraft meets the requirements of section 507.02;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application for a special certificate of airworthiness, the aircraft meets the requirements of section 507.03; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an application for a flight permit, the aircraft meets the requirements of section 507.04.

Subsection.Text: In the case of an application to validate a foreign flight authority, the applicant shall submit a copy of the foreign flight authority, including any operational limitation imposed in respect of that flight authority.

The Minister may inspect, or may cause to be inspected, any aircraft for which an application for flight authority has been made, for the purposes of determining conformity with its type design and compliance with the applicable requirements of these Regulations.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Authority for an Imported Aircraft

Section.Text: Where an application for a flight authority is made in respect of an aircraft being imported, the applicant must comply with the importation requirements specified in Chapter 507 of the Airworthiness Manual.

Subsection.Text: Where the owner of an aircraft requests an additional flight authority in accordance with section 507.06 and demonstrates compliance with the applicable standards contained in Standard 507 — Flight Authority and Certificate of Noise Compliance and if the aircraft is safe for flight, the Minister shall issue

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft that has been damaged or has inoperative systems such that it no longer conforms to the conditions of the existing flight authority, an additional flight authority to allow the aircraft to be flown to a location where the required maintenance can be performed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft that has been modified to allow multiple configurations one of which results in the aircraft no longer meeting the conditions of issue of the existing flight authority, an additional flight authority in respect of the new configuration.

Subsection.Text: Where an additional flight authority is issued in respect of an aircraft pursuant to this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the additional flight authority takes effect when an entry indicating that it is in effect, is made in the aircraft journey log; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: except where provided for by technical dispatch procedures required by subsection 706.06(1), the flight authority specified in the most recent journey log entry made pursuant to paragraph 571.06(3)(a) remains in effect until a new flight authority is specified.

Section.Text: Where an aircraft does not meet the requirements for the issue of a flight authority that conforms to Article 31 of the Convention, the Minister shall make the flight authority subject to operating conditions where the conditions are required to ensure the safety of the aircraft, other aircraft, persons, animals or property.

Heading.TitleText: Persons Who May Attest to Condition and Conformity

Section.Text: No person shall make a declaration of an aircraft’s condition or conformity to its certified type design for the purpose of obtaining a flight authority other than the holder of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME) licence issued pursuant to Part IV or

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a new aircraft, an authorized representative of the manufacturer; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft that is operated under a special certificate of airworthiness in the owner-maintenance or amateur-built classification, the owner of the aircraft.

Section.Text: Unless surrendered, suspended or cancelled, a flight authority issued pursuant to this Subpart remains in force during the period or for the number of flights specified in it or, where no limit is specified, indefinitely, if the aircraft continues to meet the conditions subject to which the flight authority was issued.
No person other than the Minister shall amend a flight authority issued pursuant to this Subpart.

Heading.TitleText: Replacing a Lost or Destroyed Flight Authority

Section.Text: The Minister shall replace a lost or destroyed flight authority of a Canadian aircraft on receipt of a written application from the registered owner, or from a representative of the owner as specified in Standard 507 — Flight Authority and Certificate of Noise Compliance, if the aircraft continues to meet the requirements for the issue of the flight authority.

If an application for a certificate of noise compliance is made in respect of an aircraft under section 507.21 and the aircraft meets the applicable noise emission levels specified in Chapter 516 of the Airworthiness Manual, the Minister shall issue the certificate.

Heading.TitleText: Application for a Certificate of Noise Compliance

Subsection.Text: An application for a certificate of noise compliance shall be signed by the owner or operator of the aircraft in respect of which it is submitted or by a representative of the owner within the meaning of Chapter 507 of the Airworthiness Manual.
A person who applies for a certificate of noise compliance shall do so in the form and manner specified in Chapter 507 of the Airworthiness Manual.
An applicant for a certificate of noise compliance shall include with the application evidence that the aircraft meets the noise emission levels referred to in section 507.20.

Heading.TitleText: Suspension of a Certificate of Noise Compliance

Section.Text: A certificate of noise compliance is suspended and shall be surrendered to the Minister on request if the aircraft in respect of which it was issued no longer meets the noise emission levels referred to in section 507.20.

Heading.TitleText: Validation of a Foreign Certificate of Noise Compliance

Section.Text: In the process of validating a foreign flight authority in respect of an aircraft under section 507.05, if a foreign certificate of noise compliance is in effect in respect of the aircraft, the Minister shall validate the foreign certificate of noise compliance in the form and manner specified for the validation of the flight authority.

This Subpart applies in respect of the following aircraft if they meet the export requirements specified in Chapter 509 of the Airworthiness Manual, except for aircraft that are operated under a special certificate of airworthiness in the owner-maintenance or amateur-built classification, ultra-light aeroplanes and hang gliders:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: new aircraft manufactured in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Canadian aircraft in respect of which a Certificate of Airworthiness has been issued pursuant to Subpart 7; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft that were last registered in Canada but are no longer registered in any state.

Heading.TitleText: Application for an Export Airworthiness Certificate

Subsection.Text: A person who applies for an Export Airworthiness Certificate shall do so in the form and manner specified in Chapter 509 of the Airworthiness Manual.

An applicant for an Export Airworthiness Certificate shall include with the application a declaration made by a person authorized to do so pursuant to section 509.04, attesting that the aircraft conforms to the certified type design specified in the application.
Subject to subsection (2), the Minister shall issue an Export Airworthiness Certificate where the aircraft in respect of which the application is made conforms to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the type design specified in a type certificate; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: another type design specified in the application, where the aircraft is being exported to a state with which Canada has entered into an agreement that provides for the acceptance of Export Airworthiness Certificates and the aircraft conforms to any special requirements specified by that state.

Subsection.Text: Where an aircraft does not meet the requirements of subsection (1), the Minister may issue an Export Airworthiness Certificate that specifies the non-conformity to the applicable type design or any special requirement and the acceptance of that non-conformity by the state to which the aircraft is being exported.

Heading.TitleText: Persons Who May Attest to Condition and Conformity

Section.Text: No person shall make a declaration of an aircraft’s condition or conformity to its certified type design for the purpose of obtaining an Export Airworthiness Certificate in respect of the aircraft, other than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME) licence issued pursuant to Part IV that is applicable to that aircraft type; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a new aircraft manufactured in Canada, an authorized representative of the manufacturer.

Section.Text: Where an Export Airworthiness Certificate has been issued in respect of an aircraft, the owner of the aircraft shall, on transfer of its title,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: forward to the new owner all of the documents and information required by Chapter 509 of the Airworthiness Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the exported aircraft is disassembled, forward to the new owner the manufacturer’s assembly instructions and the other documents relating to the aircraft specified in Chapter 509 of the Airworthiness Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the temporary equipment, if any, incorporated into the aircraft for the purpose of the export delivery flight is removed and the aircraft is restored to the configuration approved in the type certificate.

Heading.TitleText: Subpart 21 — Approval of the Type Design or a Change to the Type Design of an Aeronautical Product

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Subpart.

Definition.Text: aeronautical product means an aircraft, aircraft engine, aircraft propeller or aircraft appliance or part, or a component part of any of those things. (produit aéronautique)

applicant means an individual or organization responsible for the design of an aeronautical product, or a representative of such an individual or organization, that makes an application for the issuance of or a change to a design approval document in respect of an aeronautical product. (demandeur)

Definition.Code: se="521.01",df="{design approval document}{document d’approbation de la conception}"
Definition.Text: design approval document means a type certificate, a supplemental type certificate, a repair design approval, a part design approval or a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval. (document d’approbation de la conception)
foreign aeronautical product means an aeronautical product for which the state of design is a state other than Canada. (produit aéronautique étranger)

Definition.Code: se="521.01",df="{VLAvery light aeroplane}{VLA ouavion très léger}"
Definition.Text: VLA or very light aeroplane means an aeroplane that has a single engine with a spark or compression ignition, has no more than two seats and is designed and manufactured to have

Paragraph.Code: se="521.01",df="{VLAvery light aeroplane}{VLA ouavion très léger}",p1="a"
Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a maximum certificated take-off weight not exceeding 750 kg; and

Paragraph.Code: se="521.01",df="{VLAvery light aeroplane}{VLA ouavion très léger}",p1="b"
Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a stall speed in the landing configuration (Vso) of 45 knots (52 mph) calibrated air speed (CAS), or less. (VLA ouavion très léger)

Section.Text: This Subpart applies to applicants for and holders of the following documents and applicants for a change to one of those documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a type certificate issued under section 521.57 in respect of an aeronautical product;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval issued under section 521.109 in respect of an appliance or a part;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a supplemental type certificate issued under section 521.206 in respect of an aeronautical product;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a repair design approval issued under section 521.256 in respect of an aeronautical product; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a part design approval issued under section 521.306 in respect of a replacement part for an aeronautical product.

Section.Text: An appliance or a part, other than a standard part, may be approved by the issuance of any one of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a type certificate, in the case of an appliance or part that is part of an aeronautical product on which it is installed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a supplemental type certificate, in the case of an appliance or part that is part of a change to the type design of an aeronautical product; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a part design approval, in the case of a part that is a replacement part.

Section.Text: This Division applies

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of the issuance of a type certificate for an aeronautical product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to applicants for and holders of a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product.

Section.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product shall have, or have access to, the technical capability to conduct the design analyses and tests required to demonstrate the conformity of the aeronautical product with its certification basis.

Subsection.Text: An applicant may, in the case of an aircraft, request a type certificate in respect of the following aircraft categories or any combination of them:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: normal category;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: utility category;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aerobatic category;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: commuter category;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: transport category; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: restricted category.

Subsection.Text: An applicant may, in the case of an aircraft for which no standards of airworthiness are listed in subsection 521.31(1), request a type certificate in respect of an aircraft category that is not listed in subsection (1).

Section.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product shall submit to the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an application that contains the information specified on the form published by the Minister entitled Type Certificate Application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the aeronautical product that contains, in addition to its principal design features and its specifications,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft, a three-view drawing, the preliminary data respecting the design and performance, and the proposed operating characteristics and limitations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft engine or propeller, a general arrangement drawing, and the proposed operating characteristics and limitations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a proposed certification basis; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a certification plan that identifies

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the means to be used to demonstrate that the aeronautical product conforms to the applicable certification basis,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the documentation that demonstrates the conformity of the aeronautical product with the applicable certification basis,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the resources necessary for carrying out the demonstration of conformity referred to in subparagraph (i), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the schedule for carrying out the demonstration of conformity referred to in subparagraph (i).

Subsection.Text: Unless an applicant demonstrates, at the time of submitting an application for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product, that a longer period is required for the design, development and testing of the product, and for that reason the Minister approves a longer period, the application is effective during one of the following periods, beginning on the date of the application:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: five years, in the case of a transport category aeroplane or a transport category rotorcraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: three years, in the case of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an aircraft other than an aircraft referred to in paragraph (a),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an aircraft engine, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an aircraft propeller.

Subsection.Text: If a type certificate is not issued within the applicable effective period referred to in subsection (1), the applicant may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submit a new application for a type certificate; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: apply for an extension of the effective period of the original application.

Subsection.Text: If the effective period of an application for a type certificate is extended under paragraph (2)(b), the standards of airworthiness applicable to the aeronautical product are those in force on the date that precedes, by one of the periods referred to in subsection (1), the date of the issuance of the type certificate.
The Minister shall establish, in respect of an aeronautical product, a certification basis consisting of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections (2) to (5), the applicable standards of airworthiness referred to in section 521.31 that are in force on the date of application for the type certificate, unless the applicant

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: elects to include in the certification basis later amendments to those standards of airworthiness, in accordance with subsection (5), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is required to comply with later amendments to the standards of airworthiness in accordance with subsection 521.29(3);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicable aircraft emissions standards referred to in section 521.32;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any special conditions that are necessary to ensure that the type design of an aeronautical product having a novel or unusual design feature provides a level of safety equivalent to that provided by the standards of airworthiness in force on the date of application for the type certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any finding of equivalent safety based on any factors or design features that provide for an alternate means of compliance with the standards of airworthiness in force on the date of application for the type certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any exemptions.

Subsection.Text: In the case of an aeronautical product to which no complete standards of airworthiness referred to in section 521.31 apply, the applicable standards of airworthiness are the portions of the standards of airworthiness referred to in section 521.31 that are in force on the date of application for the type certificate.

In the case of an aircraft, including its engine and propeller, that is designed in accordance with the requirements of, and accepted for use by, the Department of National Defence, other than an aircraft referred to in paragraph (4)(b), the applicable standards of airworthiness are those referred to in section 521.31

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that are appropriate to the type of aircraft, the number and type of its engines and propellers, and its MCTOW; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that provide a level of safety equivalent to that provided by the standards of airworthiness in force on the date that the aircraft was accepted for use by that Department.

Subsection.Text: In the case of an aircraft for which a type certificate in the restricted category is requested, the applicable standards of airworthiness are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the standards of airworthiness referred to in section 521.31 that are in force on the date of application for the type certificate, except for those that are inappropriate for the use specified on the application for the type certificate; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the design and performance requirements established by the Department of National Defence in respect of the aircraft on the date that the aircraft was accepted for use by that Department.

Subsection.Text: An applicant may elect to include in the certification basis later amendments to the applicable standards of airworthiness referred to in subsections (1) to (4), if the applicant complies with any other amendment that is directly related to those standards.

For the issuance of a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product, the standards of airworthiness, including the aircraft categories set out in subsection 521.27(1), are those specified in the following chapters of the Airworthiness Manual, as applicable:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 522 — Gliders and Powered Gliders;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 523 — Normal, Utility, Aerobatic and Commuter Category Aeroplanes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 523 – VLA — Very Light Aeroplanes;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 525 — Transport Category Aeroplanes;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 527 — Normal Category Rotorcraft;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 529 — Transport Category Rotorcraft;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 531 — Manned Free Balloons;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 533 — Aircraft Engines;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 535 — Propellers; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: Chapter 541 — Airships.

Subsection.Text: The standards of airworthiness for the design and installation of an item of aircraft equipment required by Part VI or VII are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: those specified in Chapter 551 — Aircraft Equipment and Installation of the Airworthiness Manual; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if no standards of airworthiness for the design and installation of the item of aircraft equipment are specified in Chapter 551 — Aircraft Equipment and Installation of the Airworthiness Manual, those specified in the certification basis of the aircraft on which the equipment is installed.

Section.Text: The aircraft emissions standards applicable to the issuance of a type certificate are the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft other than an aircraft for which certification is requested in the restricted category for use in agricultural operations or fire prevention and suppression, the noise standards specified in Subchapter A of Chapter 516 — Aircraft Emissions of the Airworthiness Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a turbine-powered aircraft, the standards respecting the prevention of intentional fuel venting specified in Subchapter B of Chapter 516 — Aircraft Emissions of the Airworthiness Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft engine, the smoke and gaseous aircraft emissions standards specified in Subchapter B of Chapter 516 — Aircraft Emissions of the Airworthiness Manual.

Section.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: demonstrate to the Minister that the aeronautical product conforms to the certification basis established by the Minister under section 521.30;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister a declaration attesting to the demonstration of conformity of the aeronautical product with its certification basis;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make available to the Minister the means by which conformity is established;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft, record the noise levels in its flight manual or in a supplement to that manual using the Guidelines for the Administration of Noise Certification Documentation set out in Attachment G of Annex 16, Volume I to the Convention; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister for approval any manuals, instructions and limitations that are required by the certification basis established in respect of the aeronautical product.

Section.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure, before conducting a test, that the item to be tested conforms to the drawings, specifications and manufacturing processes proposed for the type design of the aeronautical product and that the measuring device and test equipment to be used are appropriate and calibrated for the test;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the equipment and procedures used for conducting a test flight meet the requirements set out in sections 521.45 and 521.46;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conduct all the inspections, analyses and tests necessary to demonstrate to the Minister that the type design of the aeronautical product conforms to its certification basis;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the certification plan, submit to the Minister for review the data and reports resulting from the inspections, analyses and tests conducted under paragraph (c); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: provide the Minister with access to the aeronautical product for the purpose of making any inspection, making any engineering assessment, or conducting or witnessing any test,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: required to verify the applicant’s declaration attesting to the demonstration of conformity of the aeronautical product with its certification basis, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: required to make a determination of the conformity of the aeronautical product with its certification basis.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product who conducts a test flight shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make provisions for emergency situations and provide the emergency equipment required for the safety of the test flight personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct the inspections, analyses, structural tests, wind tunnel tests and functional tests of the critical systems and components of the aircraft used for the test flight — including an evaluation of the effect of their failure — to ensure that the aircraft will operate safely within the operating limitations and restrictions specified by the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide a pilot who holds a licence endorsed with a rating appropriate for conducting the test flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: conduct the test flight in accordance with the conditions specified by the Minister in a flight authority issued in respect of that flight.

Subsection.Text: The applicant shall, before conducting the first test flight of an aircraft type, submit

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a written airworthiness declaration attesting that the aircraft being used for the test flight satisfies the conditions referred to in paragraph (1)(b); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a written declaration attesting to the condition of the aircraft and its conformity with the configuration specified for the purposes of the test flight, made by a person authorized to do so by the manufacturer of the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product who intends to conduct a test flight and who has the resources, personnel and facilities for conducting a test flight shall establish and maintain a test flight operations manual that is appropriate to the size, nature and complexity of the test flight operations and that contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement signed by the person responsible for the test flight operations certifying that the test flight operations are being carried out in accordance with the policies and procedures set out in the manual and in any document incorporated into that manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the system used by the applicant to supervise the test flight operations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the system used by the applicant to manage matters relating to safety and risk during the conduct of a test flight;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of record-keeping practices and procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of how the configuration of an aircraft used in a test flight is defined and how a change to that configuration is documented;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the qualification, training and currency requirements of the test flight crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the test flight planning procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: duty time limitations for test flight crew members.

Subsection.Text: The person responsible for test flight operations shall submit the test flight operations manual and any amendment to the manual to the Minister for approval.
The Minister shall approve the test flight operations manual and any amendment to the manual if they meet the requirements set out in this section.

Subject to subsection (3), an applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aircraft shall conduct one or more function and reliability test flights in order to demonstrate to the Minister that the aircraft, its components and its equipment are reliable and function properly.
A function and reliability test flight shall consist of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft that uses a turbine engine of a type not previously used in an aircraft for which a type certificate has been issued, at least 300 hours of operation of the aircraft with a full complement of engines that conform to a type certificate or to an equivalent certificate issued by the airworthiness authority of a foreign state with which Canada has an airworthiness agreement or similar arrangement; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of every other aircraft, at least 150 hours of operation of the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the following aircraft:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aeroplanes having a MCTOW of 2 720 kg (6,000 pounds) or less,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: gliders,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: airships having a seating configuration, excluding pilot seats, of nine or less,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: manned free balloons, or

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: restricted category aircraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a change to a type design, unless otherwise determined by the Minister taking into consideration the certification plan submitted under paragraph 521.28(d).

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall issue a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product if the applicant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submits the declaration required under paragraph 521.33(b);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submits a signed undertaking to carry out the responsibilities specified in Division VIII; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements set out in subsection (2) or (3) in respect of the category of the aeronautical product.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product other than a restricted category aircraft shall demonstrate to the Minister that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the type design of the aeronautical product conforms to its certification basis;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft, no feature or characteristic makes the aircraft unsafe, taking into account the category in which certification is requested;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to paragraph (d), any test flights required under paragraph 521.44(c) and section 521.47 have been conducted; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the function and reliability test flights required under section 521.47 have not been completed, a program exists to ensure their completion before the later of the delivery of the first aircraft and the issuance of the certificate of airworthiness.

Subsection.Text: An applicant for a type certificate in respect of a restricted category aircraft shall demonstrate to the Minister that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: no feature or characteristic makes the aircraft unsafe when that aircraft is operated within the limitations specified for its intended use; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has a type design that conforms to its certification basis, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is of a type manufactured in accordance with the requirements of, and accepted for use by, the Department of National Defence and has been modified for its intended use.

Heading.TitleText: Change to the Type Design Approved in a Type Certificate

Section.Text: The holder of a type certificate in respect of an aeronautical product who proposes to make a change to the type design approved in the type certificate shall meet the requirements set out in section 521.152.

Heading.TitleText: Division III — Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) Design Approvals

Section.Text: This Division applies

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of the issuance of a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval for an appliance or a part; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to applicants for and holders of a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part.

Section.Text: An applicant for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part shall have, or have access to, the technical capability to conduct the design analyses and tests required to demonstrate the conformity of the appliance or part with its certification basis.

Heading.TitleText: Application for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) Design Approval

Section.Text: An applicant for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part shall submit to the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an application that contains the information specified on the form published by the Minister entitled Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) Design Approval Application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the appliance or part that contains its principal design features and its specifications;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a proposed certification basis;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a certification plan that identifies

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the means to be used to demonstrate that the appliance or part conforms to the applicable certification basis,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the documentation that demonstrates the conformity of the appliance or part with the applicable certification basis,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the resources necessary for carrying out the demonstration of conformity referred to in subparagraph (i), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the schedule for carrying out the demonstration of conformity referred to in subparagraph (i);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a draft of the declaration of design and performance referred to in paragraph 521.107(b); and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the means to be used to identify the model number of an appliance or a part and the part number of each component of the appliance or part and how changes to the appliance or part will be identified.

Subsection.Text: Unless an applicant demonstrates, at the time of submitting an application for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part, that a longer period is required for the design, development and testing of the appliance or part, and for that reason the Minister approves a longer period, the application is effective during one of the following periods, beginning on the date of the application:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two years, in the case of an appliance or a part other than a turbine-powered APU; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: three years, in the case of a turbine-powered APU.

Subsection.Text: If a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval is not issued within the applicable effective period referred to in subsection (1), the applicant may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submit a new application for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: apply for an extension of the effective period of the original application.

Subsection.Text: If the effective period of an application for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval is extended under paragraph (2)(b), the standards of airworthiness applicable to the appliance or part are those in force on the date that precedes, by one of the periods referred to in subsection (1), the date of the issuance of the Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval.

Section.Text: The Minister shall establish, in respect of an appliance or a part, a certification basis consisting of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicable standards of airworthiness referred to in section 521.106 that are in force on the date of application for the Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any finding of equivalent safety based on any factors or design features that provide for an alternate means of compliance with the standards of airworthiness in force on the date of application for the Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO).

Section.Text: The standards of airworthiness for the issuance of or a change to a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: those specified in Chapter 537 — Appliances and Parts of the Airworthiness Manual; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if no standards of airworthiness for the issuance of or a change to a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of the appliance or part are specified in Chapter 537 — Appliances and Parts of the Airworthiness Manual, the minimum performance standards specified by the Minister.

Section.Text: An applicant for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: demonstrate to the Minister that the appliance or part conforms to the certification basis established by the Minister under section 521.105;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister a declaration of design and performance that contains

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the content of the certification basis,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a declaration attesting to the demonstration of conformity of the appliance or part with its certification basis,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: information identifying the components of the type design of the appliance or part,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the rated performance of the appliance or part,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a reference to the record documenting the means of demonstrating conformity with the certification basis, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: a reference to the maintenance, overhaul and repair manuals;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make available to the Minister the means by which conformity is established; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister for approval any manuals, instructions and limitations that are required by the certification basis established in respect of the appliance or part.

Section.Text: An applicant for a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure, before conducting a test, that the item to be tested conforms to the drawings, specifications and manufacturing processes proposed for the type design of the appliance or part and that the measuring device and test equipment to be used are appropriate and calibrated for the test;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct all the inspections, analyses and tests necessary to demonstrate to the Minister that the type design of the appliance or part conforms to its certification basis;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the certification plan, submit to the Minister for review the data and reports resulting from the inspections, analyses and tests conducted under paragraph (b); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide the Minister with access to the appliance or part for the purpose of making any inspection, making any engineering assessment, or conducting or witnessing any test,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: required to verify the applicant’s declaration attesting to the demonstration of conformity of the appliance or part with its certification basis, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: required to make a determination of the conformity of the appliance or part with its certification basis.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) Design Approval

Section.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall issue a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part if the applicant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements set out in section 521.107; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submits a signed undertaking to carry out the responsibilities specified in Division VIII.

Heading.TitleText: Change to a Type Design Approved in a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) Design Approval

Subsection.Text: The holder of a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part who proposes to make a change to the appliance or part shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a change to the type design, apply for a new Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval under section 521.103; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, establish procedures to ensure that the changed appliance or part continues to conform to its certification basis and make the change after the Minister accepts the procedures.

Subsection.Text: An individual or organization, other than the holder of a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval in respect of an appliance or a part, who proposes to make a change or repair to the appliance or part shall make an application in respect of that appliance or part for the issuance of a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval, a supplemental type certificate, or a repair design approval.

Heading.TitleText: Division IV — Changes to a Type Design

Section.Text: This Division applies

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of the approval of a change to the type design of an aeronautical product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to applicants for an approval of a change to the type design of an aeronautical product.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 521.153, no person shall undertake a change to the type design of an aeronautical product that has other than a negligible effect on the weight and centre-of-gravity limits, structural strength, performance, power plant operation, flight characteristics or other qualities affecting its airworthiness or environmental characteristics except in accordance with sections 521.155 to 521.160.
In any other case, no person shall undertake a change to the type design of an aeronautical product except in accordance with section 521.154.

Heading.TitleText: Change to a Type Design Requiring a New Type Certificate
