Paragraph.Text: in the case of maintenance performed on an aircraft that is operated under a special certificate of airworthiness in the owner-maintenance classification, the person is a licensed pilot and an owner of the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: Except as provided in subsection (7), no person shall sign a maintenance release in respect of maintenance performed on an aircraft operated under Part IV or VII, or on parts intended to be installed on the aircraft, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person is authorized to sign in accordance with a maintenance policy manual (MPM) established by the holder of an AMO certificate issued under section 573.02 with a rating of a category appropriate to the work performed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the maintenance is performed outside Canada, the person is authorized to sign in accordance with a foreign document equivalent to an MPM, established by a maintenance organization approved under the laws of a state that is party to an agreement or technical arrangement with Canada and the agreement or technical arrangement provides for such certification.

Subsection.Text: Except as provided in subsection (5), no person shall sign a maintenance release in respect of maintenance performed on a transport category aeroplane or a turbine-powered helicopter, unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed a course of maintenance training that has been approved by the Minister and that is applicable to the type of aircraft, engine or system on which the maintenance is performed, in accordance with Appendix M of Chapter 571 of the Airworthiness Manual; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: held a type rating applicable to the type of aircraft, engine or system on which the maintenance is performed, issued by the Minister before August 1, 1999.

Subsection.Text: The holder of an applicable AME licence may sign a maintenance release in respect of maintenance performed on a transport category aeroplane or a turbine-powered helicopter that consists of any of the types of work set out in Schedule III without having successfully completed the course required by paragraph (4)(a) and without having held the type rating required by paragraph (4)(b).

If a maintenance release is signed by a person in respect of work performed by another person, the person signing the maintenance release must personally observe the work to the extent necessary to ensure that it is performed in accordance with the requirements of any applicable standards of airworthiness and, specifically, the requirements of sections 571.02 and 571.10.

A person who is not the holder of an AME licence specifying a rating appropriate to the aeronautical product being maintained may sign a maintenance release if the person holds a restricted certification authority issued in accordance with subsection (8), in respect of a particular case specified on the restricted certification authority.
The Minister shall issue a restricted certification authority and specify therein its validity period and the scope of the work that may be performed, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an application is made in accordance with section 571.11 of the Airworthiness Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant demonstrates to the Minister that there is no holder of an AME licence specifying a rating appropriate to the aeronautical product being maintained available within a geographical area accessible within one hour by surface transportation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person to whom the restricted certification authority is to be issued has received the training and has the knowledge equivalent to that of a holder of an AME licence specifying a rating appropriate to the aeronautical product being maintained; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the level of aviation safety is not affected by the issuance of the restricted certification authority.

Heading.TitleText: Reporting Major Repairs and Major Modifications

Section.Text: A person who performs a major repair or major modification on an aeronautical product or installs on an aircraft a part that has undergone a major repair or major modification shall report the action to the Minister in accordance with the procedures specified in section 571.12 of the Airworthiness Manual.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 571.07 to 571.09, no person shall install a part on an aeronautical product unless the part is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inspected and its accompanying documentation verified in accordance with a procedure that ensures that the part conforms to its type design, as is indicated by the maintenance release; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: installed in accordance with the requirements of section 571.13 of the Airworthiness Manual.

Subsection.Text: If a part is obtained from an aeronautical product that was damaged or permanently withdrawn from service, the part shall not be installed unless it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can be traced to the manufacturer certificate holder; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is inspected in conformity with the instructions for continued airworthiness or, if the part has been repaired or modified, it can be ascertained that the work was performed in accordance with approved data within the meaning of section 571.06 of the Airworthiness Manual.

row.entry: NDT using liquid penetrant, magnetic particle, eddy current or ultrasonic methods, not performed pursuant to Appendix K of Chapter 571 of the Airworthiness Manual
CAN/CGSB 48.9712-95, Level 2 or Level 3; MIL-Std-410; or Specification ATA 105
Level 2 or Level 3 of the following standards: CAN/CGSB 48.9712-95 or MIL-Std-410; or Level 2 or Level 3 of the following specification: ATA 105

Provision.Text: The following tasks constitute the specialized maintenance referred to in section 571.04 of these Regulations.
The modification, repair or replacement by riveting, bonding or laminating, or the making of any of the following airframe parts is structural specialized maintenance:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: a box beam;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: a wing stringer or chord member;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: a spar;

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: a spar flange;

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: a member of a truss-type beam;

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: the web of a beam;

Provision.Label: (g)
Provision.Text: a keel or chine member of a flying boat hull or a float;

Provision.Label: (h)
Provision.Text: a corrugated sheet compression member in a wing or tail surface;

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: a wing main rib;

Provision.Label: (j)
Provision.Text: a wing or tail surface brace strut;

Provision.Label: (k)
Provision.Text: an engine mount;

Provision.Label: (l)
Provision.Text: a fuselage longeron or frame;

Provision.Label: (m)
Provision.Text: a member of a side truss, horizontal truss or bulkhead;

Provision.Label: (n)
Provision.Text: a seat support brace or bracket, excluding the replacement of seat rails;

Provision.Label: (o)
Provision.Text: a seat rail replacement for transport category aircraft;

Provision.Label: (p)
Provision.Text: a landing gear strut or brace strut;

Provision.Label: (q)
Provision.Text: an axle;

Provision.Label: (r)
Provision.Text: a wheel; and

Provision.Label: (s)
Provision.Text: a ski or ski pedestal, excluding the replacement of a low-friction coating.
The modification or repair of any of the following parts of an airframe is structural specialized maintenance:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: aircraft skin, or the skin of an aircraft float, if the work requires the use of a support, jig or fixture;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: aircraft skin that is subject to pressurization loads, if the damage to the skin measures more than 15 cm (6 inches) in any direction;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: a load-bearing part of a control system, including a control column, pedal, shaft, quadrant, bellcrank, torque tube, control horn and forged or cast bracket, but excluding

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: the swaging of a repair splice or cable fitting, and

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: the replacement of a push-pull tube end fitting that is attached by riveting; and

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: any other structure that a manufacturer has identified as a primary structure in its maintenance manual, structural repair manual or any instructions for continuing airworthiness.
Any of the following types of tasks is engine specialized maintenance:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: the reassembly of a multi-part engine crankshaft or a crankshaft equipped with a dynamic counterweight system;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: the reassembly of the crankcase of a reciprocating engine that is equipped with an integral supercharger or a propeller reduction gear;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: the overhaul of a reciprocating engine that is equipped with an integral or turbo supercharger; and

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: the overhaul of a turbine engine or turbine engine module.

Any of the following types of propeller repair, if the work is beyond the limits recommended in the manufacturer’s maintenance manual or service instructions for service in the field is propeller specialized maintenance:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: the re-contouring, twisting, shortening or straightening of a propeller blade or the blending of damage thereto;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: the repair or machining of a propeller hub, excluding the removal of surface corrosion or application of a protective coating;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: the reinstallation of a metal leading edge sheath or tip of a wooden blade;

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: the replacement of the outer protective coating on a wooden blade, excluding the restoration of varnish;

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: the repair of an elongated propeller attachment or propeller blade attachment bolt hole;

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: the inlaying of a repair patch on a wooden blade;

Provision.Label: (g)
Provision.Text: the repair of a composite blade; and

Provision.Label: (h)
Provision.Text: an overhaul or repair involving the reassembly of a controllable-pitch propeller, excluding the reassembly of a propeller that has been disassembled for shipping purposes, or the replacement of seals.
The repair of avionics components and systems is avionics specialized maintenance, except for:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: repairs of wiring and connectors;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: replacement of connectors and electrical components with identical or equivalent items;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: replacement of antennas with identical or equivalent items;

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: replacement of integral fuses and lighting components when the line replaceable unit (LRU) is designed for flight-line replacement of these components;

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: replacement of an avionics LRU provided that any testing required can be done using standard test equipment, built-in test equipment (BITE) or equipment specified in the aircraft manufacturer’s instructions for continuing airworthiness;

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: on-site maintenance of passenger entertainment systems performed in accordance with the applicable instructions in the maintenance manual of the aircraft or systems manufacturer or the manufacturer’s instructions for continuing airworthiness; and

Provision.Label: (g)
Provision.Text: routine maintenance that is described in the aircraft manufacturer’s maintenance manual or instructions for continuing airworthiness or performed in accordance with currently recognized industry practices for service in the field.
Any avionics system installation or modification is avionics specialized maintenance except for:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: installation of ELT systems conforming to CAN-TSO-C91/C91a;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: installation of single VHF communication or single integrated navigation/communication systems that are not interfaced with any other system, other than an intercom system;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: installation of VFR long-range navigation systems which are not interfaced with any other systems;

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: modifications to existing avionics installations, where no additional test requirements are imposed on the affected system other than those which would be required following routine maintenance of that system;

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: installation of instruments which are not interfaced with any other systems; and

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: replacement of an avionics LRU where equivalency is maintained, and where no additional test requirements are imposed on the affected system other than those which would be required following routine maintenance of that system.

Maintenance of instruments, other than display devices whose operation is integrated with an appliance to which another category of specialized maintenance applies, if the work is beyond the limits recommended in the manufacturer’s maintenance manual or service instructions for service in the field, is instrument specialized maintenance.

Any of the following types of maintenance of an appliance or component, where the work is beyond the limits recommended in the manufacturer’s maintenance manual or service instructions for service in the field, is component specialized maintenance:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: the reassembling of valves that are activated electrically or through the use of controlled fluid pressure;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: the calibrating or flow checking of any fuel metering or air metering component, other than a float-type carburettor;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: the overhaul of any pressure-type fuel, oil, pneumatic or hydraulic pump;

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: a repair involving the disassembly of speed-regulating devices, including an engine or propeller governor or a constant-speed drive;

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: the overhaul of a rotor head, transmission or any mechanism used to transmit power to the rotors of a tilt-wing aircraft or helicopter;

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: the repair of a helicopter rotor blade;

Provision.Label: (g)
Provision.Text: the rewinding of the field coil or armature of an electrical accessory;

Provision.Label: (h)
Provision.Text: the overhaul of an aircraft magneto; and

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: the patch repair of a bladder-type fuel tank.
The welding of the following parts is welding specialized maintenance:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: any part of the primary structure, including a wheel, an axle and a passenger restraint or cargo restraint system;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: any part of an aircraft system, including a fuel tank, an oil tank and a pneumatic or hydraulic container; and

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: any structural or dynamic engine part.

Any required inspection of an aeronautical product that uses liquid penetrant, magnetic particle, radiographic, ultrasonic or eddy current methods, unless the inspection is performed under Appendix K to Standard 571 — Maintenance, is Non-Destructive Testing (NDT) Specialized Maintenance.

Item.Text: Application of fabric patches to aircraft skin, not involving the removal of control surfaces
Replacement of tires, wheels, brakes, skis, landing skids and skid shoes
Replacement of seats, safety belts and seat harnesses
Repair of upholstery and cabin trim, repositioning of non-structural cabin compartment dividers and passenger service units
Removal and replacement of cabin doors in non-pressurized aircraft
Cleaning, testing and replacement of spark-plugs and igniters
Draining and replenishment of oil systems
Cleaning and replacement of fuel, oil and air filters
Checking and replacement of magnetic chip detectors
Adjustment of generator and alternator drive belt tension
Replacement, charging, testing and deep cycling of batteries
Replacement of fuses, light-bulbs and reflectors
Replacement of voice communication line replaceable units designed for rapid replacement
Replacement of instruments and indicators that do not require calibration or adjustment after installation
Opening and securing of circuit breakers in accordance with an approved minimum equipment list
Calibration and adjustment of direct reading magnetic direction indicators
Disabling and locking of thrust reverser systems in accordance with an approved minimum equipment list
Stowage of airstairs and doors by other than normal means, in accordance with an approved minimum equipment list
Installation of slides, rafts and emergency equipment
Aircraft structural repairs that do not affect aircraft systems

Subsection.Text: An applicant for an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate or for an amendment of an AMO certificate that is in effect shall make an application in the form and manner specified in Standard 573—Approved Maintenance Organizations.
An applicant referred to in subsection (1) shall submit to the Minister with the application a copy of its maintenance policy manual (MPM) required pursuant to subsection 573.10(1).

Heading.TitleText: Entitlement to and Scope of Certificate

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall issue to a maintenance organization that demonstrates that it meets the requirements of this Subpart an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate authorizing the maintenance of specified aeronautical products or the provision of specified maintenance services.

The AMO certificate shall specify, in accordance with the criteria specified in section 573.02 of Standard 573 — Approved Maintenance Organizations, any category in which ratings have been issued and shall list the aeronautical products that the AMO is authorized to maintain or the maintenance services that the AMO is authorized to perform.
The scope of the work that may be performed under each rating specified on the AMO certificate is determined by limitations that are set out in the certificate.
Unless an expiry date is specified in an AMO certificate issued pursuant to subsection (1), the certificate remains in effect until it is surrendered, suspended or cancelled.
The holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a person responsible for maintenance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person responsible for maintenance meets the requirement set out in subsection 573.04(1);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (4), ensure that the person responsible for maintenance

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has achieved a grade of 70% or more in an open-book examination that demonstrates knowledge of the provisions of the Canadian Aviation Regulations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: meets the experience requirement set out in subsection 573.04(1) of Standard 573 — Approved Maintenance Organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person responsible for maintenance demonstrates to the Minister knowledge of the topics set out in subsection 573.04(2) of Standard 573 — Approved Maintenance Organizations within 30 days after their appointment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person responsible for maintenance performs the duties referred to in subsections 573.04(2) and (3) and 573.09(2) and (3);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: provide the person responsible for maintenance with the financial and human resources necessary to ensure that the holder of the AMO certificate meets the requirements of these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that corrective actions are taken in respect of any findings resulting from a quality assurance program established under subsection 573.09(1) or a safety management system referred to in section 573.30; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: conduct reviews of the safety management system to determine its effectiveness.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall conduct an interview with the person appointed under paragraph (1)(a) to assess their knowledge of the topics referred to in paragraph (1)(d).

The Minister shall notify the person appointed under paragraph (1)(a) of the results of the assessment and identify any deficiencies in their knowledge of the topics within ten days after the interview.
The knowledge requirement set out in subparagraph (1)(c)(i) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person responsible for maintenance who held that position on January 1, 1997; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME) licence.

Subsection.Text: The experience requirement set out in subsection 573.04(1) of Standard 573 — Approved Maintenance Organizations does not apply in the case of an AMO certificate in respect of which no rating in the aircraft, avionics, instrument, engine or propeller category has been issued if the accountable executive can demonstrate to the Minister by means of a risk assessment that the lesser experience is appropriate to the scope of work performed by the AMO and will not affect aviation safety or the safety of the public.

The holder of an AMO certificate shall ensure that no person is appointed to be responsible for maintenance or remains responsible for maintenance if, at the time of their appointment or during their tenure, they have a record of conviction for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under section 7.3 of the Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two or more offences under any of sections 571.10 and 571.11 not arising from a single occurrence.

Subsection.Text: The holder of a certificate referred to in subsection (1) shall ensure that the person managing the safety management system who is referred to in section 573.32 performs the duties set out in that section.

The person responsible for maintenance shall, within 30 days after their appointment under paragraph 573.03(1)(a), submit to the Minister a signed statement that they accept the responsibilities of their position.

The person responsible for maintenance shall manage the activities of the approved maintenance organization (AMO) in accordance with the policies set out in the maintenance policy manual (MPM) established under section 573.10.

The person responsible for maintenance shall, where a finding resulting from a quality assurance program established under subsection 573.09(1) or a safety management system referred to in section 573.30 is reported to them,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine what, if any, corrective actions are required and carry out those actions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a record of any determination made under paragraph (a) and the reason for it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if management functions have been assigned to another person under subsection (4) or (5), communicate any determination regarding a corrective action to that person; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: notify the accountable executive of any systemic deficiency and of the corrective action taken.

Subsection.Text: The person responsible for maintenance may assign the management functions for the entire quality assurance program established under subsection 573.09(1) or for the safety management system referred to in 573.30 to another person if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that person meets the requirements set out in paragraphs 573.03(1)(c) and (d) and subsection 573.03(6); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the assignment and its scope are described in the AMO's MPM.

Subsection.Text: The person responsible for maintenance may assign the management functions for specific maintenance activities to another person if the assignment and its scope are described in the AMO's MPM.
The responsibility of the person responsible for maintenance is not affected by the assignment to another person of management functions under subsection (4) or (5).

Heading.TitleText: Authorization to Sign a Maintenance Release

Subsection.Text: No approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder shall authorize a person to sign a maintenance release unless the person meets the applicable requirements of section 571.11 and has successfully completed the training required by section 573.06.

No AMO certificate holder shall authorize a person to sign a maintenance release under paragraph 571.11(2)(c) unless the person has, in respect of the work being certified, demonstrated to the certificate holder levels of knowledge and experience that are appropriate and that meet the applicable criteria set out in section 573.05 of Standard 573 — Approved Maintenance Organizations.

An approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder shall implement a training program to ensure that persons authorized to perform or supervise the performance of any function under this Subpart are trained in respect of the regulations, the standards and the AMO procedures applicable to that function.

The program required by subsection (1) shall include initial training, updating and any other training necessary, within the meaning assigned to those terms in section 573.06 of Standard 573 — Approved Maintenance Organizations, to ensure continued qualification that is appropriate to the function to be performed or supervised.
An approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder shall establish, maintain and retain for at least two years after an entry is made, for each affected person, a record of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all personal qualifications in respect of appointments made pursuant to section 573.03 and in respect of assignments of functions made pursuant to section 573.04;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all of the authorizations to sign a maintenance release pursuant to section 573.05; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all of the training conducted pursuant to section 573.06.

Subsection.Text: An AMO certificate holder shall provide a copy of a record required by this section to the person to whom the record refers on the completion of each training activity or the granting of an authorization referred to in paragraph (1)(b).

An approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder shall provide the facilities and equipment specified in Standard 573—Approved Maintenance Organizations that are necessary for the work to be performed.

Except in cases provided for in a maintenance policy manual (MPM), work performed by an AMO certificate holder shall be performed in the facilities required by subsection (1), unless unforeseen circumstances do not permit the work to be performed in those facilities and the safety of the aircraft is not affected by the fact that the work is performed elsewhere.

Where an AMO uses standards equivalent to those of the manufacturer of an aeronautical product for the performance of work pursuant to paragraph 571.02(1)(b), those standards shall be identified in accordance with section 573.10.

Where a task undertaken by an AMO is divided into sub-tasks, the person appointed pursuant to section 573.03 shall establish a system of task control to ensure that all of the sub-tasks are completed prior to the signing of a maintenance release in respect of the completion of that task.

The holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate shall establish and maintain a quality assurance program consisting of provisions for sampling maintenance processes to evaluate the AMO's ability to perform its maintenance in a safe manner.

The person responsible for maintenance shall ensure that records relating to the findings resulting from the quality assurance program are distributed to the appropriate manager for corrective action and follow-up in accordance with the policies and procedures specified in the maintenance policy manual (MPM).
The person responsible for maintenance shall establish an audit system in respect of the quality assurance program that consists of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an initial audit within 12 months after the date on which the AMO certificate is issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsequent audits conducted at intervals set out in the MPM;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: checklists of all activities controlled by the MPM;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a record of each occurrence of compliance or non-compliance with the MPM found during an audit referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for ensuring that each finding of an audit is communicated to them and, if management functions have been assigned to another person under subsection 573.04(4) or (5), to that person;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: follow-up procedures for ensuring that corrective actions are effective; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a system for recording the findings of initial and periodic audits, corrective actions and follow-ups.

Subsection.Text: The records required under paragraph (3)(g) shall be retained for the greater of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two audit cycles; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two years.

Subsection.Text: The duties related to the quality assurance program that involve specific tasks or activities within an AMO's activities shall be fulfilled by persons who are not responsible for carrying out those tasks or activities.

An approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder shall establish, maintain and authorize the use of a maintenance policy manual (MPM) that contains information to ensure the efficiency of the AMO’s maintenance policies, dealing with the subjects set out in Standard 573—Approved Maintenance Organizations.

The Minister may authorize the incorporation by reference in an MPM of detailed procedures manuals and lists prepared by the AMO certificate holder, dealing with the subjects set out in Standard 573—Approved Maintenance Organizations, where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the policy affecting those detailed procedures and the composition of the lists is set out in the MPM;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each incorporation is clearly indicated in the MPM; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the AMO certificate holder ensures that the incorporated procedures manuals and lists meet the requirements of this section.

Subsection.Text: Where detailed procedures manuals or lists are being incorporated by reference in an MPM, the person appointed pursuant to section 573.03 or another person to whom that management function is assigned pursuant to section 573.04 shall certify in writing that the incorporated documents and every amendment thereto meet the requirements of the policy established in the MPM with respect to those documents.

An AMO certificate holder need not conform to the policy and procedures contained in its MPM, where the Minister has authorized the non-conformity in writing, after it has been demonstrated that such non-conformity would not affect the safety of the aeronautical product to be maintained or the maintenance service to be offered.

An AMO certificate holder shall submit each page of its MPM to the Minister for approval, either individually or in accordance with a procedure that ensures compliance with the requirements of Standard 573—Approved Maintenance Organizations.
An AMO certificate holder shall amend its MPM when instructed to do so by the Minister, where the MPM does not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of this Subpart; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contain policies or procedures that are sufficiently detailed to demonstrate that the AMO’s quality assurance program meets the requirements of these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: An AMO certificate holder shall take steps to ensure that a current copy of its MPM, or the portions thereof that are relevant to the task to be performed, is made available to each person who performs or certifies that task.
An AMO certificate holder shall amend each copy of its MPM within 30 days after receiving an approval issued pursuant to subsection (5).
The Minister shall, if the standards set out in Standard 573—Approved Maintenance Organizations are met, approve an MPM and any amendments to that manual.
Except as provided in subsection (2), no approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder shall permit an external agent to perform maintenance on its behalf unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the external agent holds an AMO certificate with a rating of a category specified pursuant to section 573.02 that is appropriate to the type of work to be performed or the aeronautical product to be maintained;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the work is to be performed outside Canada, the external agent has been authorized to do the type of work to be performed or to perform maintenance on the type of aeronautical product to be maintained under the laws of a state that is party to an agreement with Canada and the agreement provides for the recognition of maintenance functions; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in all other cases, the performance of the maintenance by the person or organization has been approved by the Minister as being in conformity with these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), an AMO certificate holder may permit work to be performed by an external agent other than an agent described in subsection (1) where the work is performed in accordance with an arrangement that provides for it, under the direct supervision of the person appointed pursuant to section 573.03 or 573.04 and certified by persons authorized to do so in accordance with the approved procedures set out in the AMO’s maintenance policy manual (MPM).

Arrangements respecting work to be performed by external agents pursuant to subsection (2) shall be made in accordance with procedures governing maintenance arrangements set out in the MPM or, if no such procedures are set out in the MPM, shall be approved by the Minister as ensuring conformity with the requirements of this Subpart.
An AMO certificate holder that requests an external agent to perform work shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the work is to be performed pursuant to subsection (1) or (2), be responsible for specifying the tasks to be performed by the agent and ensuring completion of the work; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the work is to be performed pursuant to subsection (2), be responsible for ensuring the conformity of that work with the requirements of Subpart 71.

Subsection.Text: A maintenance arrangement that is made by a foreign air operator to have its maintenance done in Canada by a person or organization that holds an AMO certificate issued pursuant to section 573.02 shall be authorized by a maintenance specification issued to the AMO in accordance with the requirements of Standard 573—Approved Maintenance Organizations, where the air operator is from a state that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is party to an agreement with Canada that provides for recognition of the work performed and the issuance of a maintenance specification is specified in the agreement; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not party to an agreement with Canada that provides for recognition of the work performed and the issuance of a maintenance specification is requested by that state.

Section.Text: The holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate shall report to the Minister, in accordance with Division IX of Subpart 21 of Part V, any reportable service difficulty related to an aeronautical product being maintained.

An application submitted by a maintenance organization for the issuance or amendment of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate authorizing the performance of work in facilities located outside Canada is granted if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant has demonstrated that the issuance of the approval in respect of those facilities is in the public interest as provided for in subsection 6.71(1) of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant has recognized by advance agreement the Minister’s right to enter and inspect those facilities and seize anything found in those facilities, under the same conditions as would govern the exercise of the Minister’s powers pursuant to subsection 8.7(1) of the Act if the facilities were located in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the AMO has agreed to reimburse the Minister for any expenses incurred by Department of Transport personnel in carrying out the activities provided for in paragraph (b) in respect of those facilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an AMO whose facilities are located outside Canada, the Minister specifies on the AMO certificate the date on which the certificate expires.

Subsection.Text: No person, other than the holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate issued in accordance with this Subpart, shall identify oneself as an AMO certificate holder.

A person who holds an AMO certificate issued in accordance with this Subpart shall not include, in a list of approved maintenance services offered for aeronautical products, a service that is outside the scope of the person’s AMO certificate.

Section.Text: An approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder shall maintain records in accordance with section 573.15 of Standard 573 — Approved Maintenance Organizations for work performed on all aeronautical products maintained and keep those records for at least two years beginning on the date that the maintenance release was signed.

The safety management system required under section 107.02 in respect of an applicant for, or a holder of, an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate authorizing the holder to perform maintenance on an aircraft operated under Subpart 5 of Part VII shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of Subpart 7 of Part I and section 573.31; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be under the control of the person responsible for maintenance appointed under paragraph 573.03(1)(a).

Heading.TitleText: Components of the Safety Management System

Subsection.Text: The safety management system shall include, among others, the following components:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a safety management plan that includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a safety policy that the accountable executive has approved and communicated to all employees,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the roles and responsibilities of personnel assigned duties under the quality assurance program established under subsection 573.09(1) or the safety management system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: performance goals and a means of measuring attainment of those goals,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a policy for the internal reporting of a hazard, an incident or an accident, including the conditions under which immunity from disciplinary action will be granted, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a review of the safety management system to determine its effectiveness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for reporting a hazard, an incident or an accident to the appropriate manager;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the collection of data relating to hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for analysing data obtained under paragraph (c) and during an audit conducted under subsection 573.09(3) and for taking corrective actions;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an audit system referred to in subsection 573.09(3);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: training requirements for the person responsible for maintenance and for personnel assigned duties under the safety management system; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for making progress reports to the accountable executive at intervals determined by the accountable executive and other reports as needed in urgent cases.

Subsection.Text: The components specified in subsection (1) shall be set out in the approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate holder's maintenance policy manual (MPM).

Heading.TitleText: Person Managing the Safety Management System

Section.Text: The person managing the safety management system in respect of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a reporting system to ensure the timely collection of information related to hazards, incidents and accidents that may adversely affect safety;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify hazards and carry out risk management analyses of those hazards;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: investigate, analyze and identify the cause or probable cause of all hazards, incidents and accidents identified under the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a safety data system, by either electronic or other means, to monitor and analyze trends in hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: monitor and evaluate the results of corrective actions with respect to hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the concerns of the civil aviation industry in respect of safety and their perceived effect on the AMO;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: determine the adequacy of the training required by paragraph 573.31(1)(f); and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: where the person responsible for maintenance has assigned the management functions for the safety management system under subsection 573.04(4) to another person, report to the person responsible for maintenance the hazards, incidents and accidents identified under the safety management system required under section 573.30 or as a result of an audit required under paragraph 573.31(1)(e).

Heading.TitleText: Part VI — General Operating and Flight Rules

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Code: se="600.01",df="{ADIZAir Defence Identification Zone}{ADIZzone d’identification de défense aérienne}"
Definition.Text: ADIZ or Air Defence Identification Zone means the airspace that extends upward from the surface in those areas of Canada and off the coasts of Canada, the boundaries of which are specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook; (ADIZouzone d’identification de défense aérienne)
aerial application means the seeding from an aircraft or the spraying or dusting of chemicals from an aircraft, or any other operation of a similar nature; (traitement aérien)

aerial inspection means the inspection from an aircraft of crops, forests, livestock or wildlife, the patrolling of pipelines or power lines, a flight inspection or any other operation of a similar nature; (inspection aérienne)

large aircraft means an aeroplane having a maximum permissible take-off weight in excess of 5 700 kg (12,566 pounds) or a rotorcraft having a maximum permissible take-off weight in excess of 2 730 kg (6,018 pounds); (gros aéronef)

police authority means the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, Ontario Provincial Police, Sûreté du Québec or Canadian Coast Guard, or any municipal or regional police force established pursuant to provincial legislation. (corps policier)

Heading.TitleText: Division I — Airspace Structure, Classification and Use

Subsection.Text: Controlled airspace consists of the following types of airspace:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Arctic Control Area, Northern Control Area and Southern Control Area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: high level airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: high level airways;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: low level airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: low level airways;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: fixed RNAV routes;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: terminal control areas;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: military terminal control areas;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: control area extensions;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: transition areas;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: control zones;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: restricted airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: advisory airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: military operations areas; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: danger areas.

Subsection.Text: Uncontrolled airspace consists of the following types of airspace:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: high level airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: low level airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: high level air routes;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: low level air routes;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: fixed RNAV routes;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: restricted airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: advisory airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: military operations areas; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: danger areas.

Subsection.Text: The horizontal and vertical limits of any type of airspace referred to in subsection (1) or (2) are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a high level air route, a low level air route and an uncontrolled fixed RNAV route, those specified on an aeronautical chart; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, those specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook.

Subsection.Text: The geographical location and the horizontal and vertical limits of the following items are those specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Canadian Domestic Airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Canadian minimum navigation performance specifications (CMNPS) airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the CMNPS transition area;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: reduced vertical separation minimum (RVSM) airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: required navigation performance capability (RNPC) airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: transponder airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the air defence identification zone (ADIZ);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: flight information regions (FIR);

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: standard pressure regions;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: altimeter setting regions;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: mountainous regions; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: any other areas, zones, regions and points.

Subsection.Text: The class of any controlled airspace of a type referred to in subsection 601.01(1) is one of the following, as specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class A;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class B;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Class C;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Class D;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Class E;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Class F Special Use Restricted; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Class F Special Use Advisory.

Subsection.Text: The class of any uncontrolled airspace of a type referred to in subsection 601.01(2) is one of the following, as specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class G;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class F Special Use Restricted; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Class F Special Use Advisory.

Section.Text: Transponder airspace consists of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all Class A, B and C airspace as specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any Class D or E airspace specified as transponder airspace in the Designated Airspace Handbook.

Heading.TitleText: IFR or VFR Flight in Class F Special Use Restricted Airspace or Class F Special Use Advisory Airspace

Subsection.Text: The procedures for the operation of aircraft in Class F Special Use Restricted airspace and Class F Special Use Advisory airspace are those specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook.
No person shall operate an aircraft in Class F Special Use Restricted airspace unless authorized to do so by the person specified for that purpose in the Designated Airspace Handbook.

For the purposes of subsection (2), a person specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook may authorize the operation of an aircraft where activities on the ground or in the airspace are not hazardous to aircraft operating in that airspace and access by aircraft to that airspace does not jeopardize national security interests.

Heading.TitleText: IFR Flight in Class A, B, C, D or E Airspace or Class F Special Use Restricted or Class F Special Use Advisory Controlled Airspace

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an IFR aircraft in Class A, B, C, D or E airspace or in Class F Special Use Restricted or Class F Special Use Advisory controlled airspace unless the aircraft is operated in accordance with an air traffic control clearance or an authorization issued by the Minister.
The Minister may issue an authorization referred to in subsection (1) where the operation of the aircraft is in the public interest and is not likely to affect aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: VFR Flight in Class A Airspace

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a VFR aircraft in Class A airspace unless the aircraft is operated in accordance with an authorization issued by the Minister.
The Minister may issue an authorization referred to in subsection (1) where the operation of the aircraft is in the public interest and is not likely to affect aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: VFR Flight in Class B Airspace

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a VFR aircraft in Class B airspace unless the aircraft is operated in accordance with an air traffic control clearance or an authorization issued by the Minister.
The Minister may issue an authorization referred to in subsection (1) where the operation of the aircraft is in the public interest and is not likely to affect aviation safety.

The pilot-in-command of a VFR aircraft operating in Class B airspace in accordance with an air traffic control clearance shall, when it becomes evident that it will not be possible to operate the aircraft in VMC at the altitude or along the route specified in the air traffic control clearance,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the airspace is a control zone, request authorization to operate the aircraft in special VFR flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: request an amended air traffic control clearance that will enable the aircraft to be operated in VMC to the destination specified in the flight plan or to an alternate aerodrome, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: request an air traffic control clearance to operate the aircraft in IFR flight.

Heading.TitleText: VFR Flight in Class C Airspace

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person operating a VFR aircraft shall enter Class C airspace unless the person receives a clearance to enter from the appropriate air traffic control unit before entering the airspace.

The pilot-in-command of a VFR aircraft that is not equipped with radiocommunication equipment capable of two-way communication with the appropriate air traffic control unit may, during daylight in VMC, enter Class C airspace if the pilot-in-command receives authorization to enter from the appropriate air traffic control unit before entering the airspace.
Class C airspace becomes Class E airspace when the appropriate air traffic control unit is not in operation.

Heading.TitleText: VFR Flight in Class D Airspace

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person operating a VFR aircraft shall enter Class D airspace unless the person establishes two-way radio contact with the appropriate air traffic control unit before entering the airspace.

The pilot-in-command of a VFR aircraft that is not equipped with radiocommunication equipment capable of two-way communication with the appropriate air traffic control unit may, during daylight in VMC, enter Class D airspace if the pilot-in-command receives authorization to enter from the appropriate air traffic control unit before entering the airspace.
Class D airspace becomes Class E airspace when the appropriate air traffic control unit is not in operation.

Heading.TitleText: Division II — Aircraft Operating Restrictions and Hazards to Aviation Safety

Section.Text: In this Division,

Definition.Code: se="601.14",df="{directed bright light source}{source lumineuse dirigée de forte intensité}"
Definition.Text: directed bright light source means any directed light source (coherent or non-coherent), including lasers, that may create a hazard to aviation safety or cause damage to an aircraft or injury to persons on board the aircraft; (source lumineuse dirigée de forte intensité)

Definition.Code: se="601.14",df="{fire control authority}{responsable de la lutte contre l’incendie}"
Definition.Text: fire control authority means an official of a government forestry service or other fire control agency that is responsible for the protection of persons and property against fire; (responsable de la lutte contre l’incendie)
forest fire area means an area on the surface of the earth on which standing timber, grass or any other vegetation or buildings are burning. (région sinistrée)

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: over a forest fire area, or over any area that is located within five nautical miles of a forest fire area, at an altitude of less than 3,000 feet AGL; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any airspace that is described in a NOTAM issued pursuant to section 601.16.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of NOTAM for Forest Fire Aircraft Operating Restrictions

Section.Text: The Minister may issue a NOTAM that relates to restrictions on the operation of aircraft in the case of a forest fire and that describes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location and dimensions of the forest fire area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the airspace in which forest fire control operations are being conducted.

Section.Text: Section 601.15 does not apply to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: persons who are operating an aircraft at the request of an appropriate fire control authority; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Department of Transport personnel who are operating an aircraft in the performance of duties related to surveillance and the enforcement of aviation legislation.

Heading.TitleText: Orders Prohibiting or Restricting Aircraft Operation

Section.Text: The Minister may make orders prohibiting or restricting the operation of aircraft over such areas as are specified by the Minister, either absolutely or subject to such exceptions or conditions as may be specified by the Minister.
[Reserved, SOR/2011-285, s. 5]

Heading.TitleText: Projection of Directed Bright Light Source at an Aircraft

Section.Text: Subject to section 601.21, no person shall project or cause to be projected a directed bright light source into navigable airspace in such a manner as to create a hazard to aviation safety or cause damage to an aircraft or injury to persons on board the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: Any person planning to project or cause to be projected a directed bright light source into navigable airspace shall, before the projection,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submit a written request to the Minister for an authorization to project the directed bright light source into navigable airspace; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: obtain a written authorization from the Minister to do so.

Subsection.Text: On receipt of the request for authorization, the Minister shall issue a written authorization if the projection is not likely to create a hazard to aviation safety or to cause damage to an aircraft or injury to persons on board the aircraft.

The Minister may specify in the authorization any conditions necessary to ensure that the projection is not likely to create a hazard to aviation safety or to cause damage to an aircraft or injury to persons on board the aircraft.

No pilot-in-command shall intentionally operate an aircraft into a beam from a directed bright light source or into an area where a directed bright light source is projected, unless the aircraft is operated in accordance with an authorization issued by the Minister.
The Minister may issue the authorization if the operation of the aircraft is not likely to create a hazard to aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: Division III — Marking and Lighting of Obstacles to Air Navigation

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Division, any building, structure or object, including any addition to it, constitutes an obstacle to air navigation if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it penetrates an airport obstacle limitation surface as calculated in Chapter 4 of the Standard entitled Aerodrome Standards and Recommended Practices, TP 312E, published by the Department of Transport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is higher than 90 m AGL and is located within 6 km of the geographical centre of an aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is higher than 90 m AGL and is located within 3.7 km of the centreline of a recognized VFR route, including, but not limited to, a valley, a railway track, a transmission line, a pipeline, a river and a highway;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: it is higher than 150 m AGL; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of any catenary wires crossing over a river, any portion of the wires or supporting structures is higher than 90 m AGL.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), an addition to a building, structure or object includes any vertical mast, pole, tower or other object erected on top of the building, structure or object and adding to its height.

Heading.TitleText: Marking and Lighting of Obstacles to Air Navigation

Subsection.Text: Any person who plans to construct or modify a building, structure or object, or launch a tethered object shall notify the Minister of the proposed construction, modification or launch in accordance with the requirements of Standard 621 if the building, structure or object, or tethered object, will constitute an obstacle to air navigation.
A person who has responsibility for or control over a building, structure or object that constitutes an obstacle to air navigation shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: mark and light the building, structure or object in accordance with the requirements of Standard 621; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: use the equivalent marking and lighting approved by the Minister under subsection 601.27(2).

Subsection.Text: If the Minister determines that a building, structure or object, other than a building, structure or object described in section 601.23, is hazardous to air navigation because of its height or location, the Minister shall require the person who has responsibility for or control over the building, structure or object to mark and light it in accordance with the requirements of Standard 621.
A person who is required by the Minister to mark and light a building, structure or object under subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: do so within six months; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cause to be received at the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station a notice identifying the nature, location and height of the building, structure or object.

Section.Text: A person who has responsibility for or control over an obstacle to air navigation shall upgrade the markings and lights of the whole obstacle to the most recent requirements set out in Standard 621 if any change occurs in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the obstacle with respect to any other marked or lighted obstacle; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the surrounding conditions of the obstacle that can affect aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: A person who proposes to use equivalent marking and lighting on an obstacle to air navigation for which the person has responsibility or over which the person has control shall apply to the Minister for approval.
The Minister shall approve the equivalent marking and lighting if the applicant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submits a risk assessment that identifies the risks to air navigation associated with the obstacle and the methods for eliminating or reducing those risks; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: demonstrates that the equivalent marking and lighting provides a level of safety at least equivalent to the level provided by the requirements of Standard 621.

Subsection.Text: In determining whether the equivalent marking and lighting provides the level of safety required by paragraph (2)(b), the Minister shall consider the following factors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the obstacle;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the surrounding terrain, buildings, structures and objects;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the VFR air traffic volume; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the proximity of the obstacle to an aerodrome.

Heading.TitleText: Notification of Deterioration, Failure or Malfunction

Section.Text: A person who has responsibility for or control over an obstacle to air navigation shall report immediately any deterioration of a marking or any failure or malfunction of a light required under this Division to the nearest flight service station.
No person shall deface, alter or otherwise damage a marking or a light required, under this Division, to be displayed on an obstacle to air navigation.

Heading.TitleText: Reckless or Negligent Operation of Aircraft

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft in such a reckless or negligent manner as to endanger or be likely to endanger the life or property of any person.

No operator of an aircraft shall require any person to act as a flight crew member and no person shall act as a flight crew member, if either the person or the operator has any reason to believe, having regard to the circumstances of the particular flight to be undertaken, that the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is suffering or is likely to suffer from fatigue; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is otherwise unfit to perform properly the person’s duties as a flight crew member.

Section.Text: No person shall act as a crew member of an aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within eight hours after consuming an alcoholic beverage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while under the influence of alcohol; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: while using any drug that impairs the person’s faculties to the extent that the safety of the aircraft or of persons on board the aircraft is endangered in any way.

Subsection.Text: In this section, intoxicating liquor means a beverage that contains more than 2.5 per cent proof spirits.
No person shall consume on board an aircraft an intoxicating liquor unless the intoxicating liquor

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has been served to that person by the operator of the aircraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where no flight attendant is on board, has been provided by the operator of the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: No operator of an aircraft shall provide or serve any intoxicating liquor to a person on board the aircraft, where there are reasonable grounds to believe that the person’s faculties are impaired by alcohol or a drug to an extent that may present a hazard to the aircraft or to persons on board the aircraft.

Subject to subsection (5), no operator of an aircraft shall allow a person to board the aircraft, where there are reasonable grounds to believe that the person’s faculties are impaired by alcohol or a drug to an extent that may present a hazard to the aircraft or to persons on board the aircraft.

The operator of an aircraft may allow a person whose faculties are impaired by a drug to board an aircraft, where the drug was administered in accordance with a medical authorization and the person is under the supervision of an attendant.
Every passenger on board an aircraft shall comply with instructions given by any crew member respecting the safety of the aircraft or of persons on board the aircraft.

Every crew member on board an aircraft shall, during flight time, comply with the instructions of the pilot-in-command or of any person whom the pilot-in-command has authorized to act on behalf of the pilot-in-command.
No person shall smoke on board an aircraft during take-off or landing or when directed not to smoke by the pilot-in-command.
No person shall smoke in an aircraft lavatory.
No person shall tamper with or disable a smoke detector installed in an aircraft lavatory without permission from a crew member or the operator of the aircraft.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft unless it is operated in accordance with the operating limitations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out in the aircraft flight manual, where an aircraft flight manual is required by the applicable standards of airworthiness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out in a document other than the aircraft flight manual, where use of that document is authorized pursuant to Part VII;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: indicated by markings or placards required pursuant to section 605.05; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prescribed by the competent authority of the state of registry of the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: No operator of an aircraft shall permit the use of a portable electronic device on board an aircraft, where the device may impair the functioning of the aircraft’s systems or equipment.
No person shall use a portable electronic device on board an aircraft except with the permission of the operator of the aircraft.

Section.Text: No person operating an aircraft shall permit the fuelling of the aircraft while an engine used for the propulsion of the aircraft is running and passengers are on board the aircraft or are embarking or disembarking, unless subsection 604.84(1), 704.33(4) or 705.40(3), as applicable, is complied with.

Heading.TitleText: Starting and Ground Running of Aircraft Engines

Subsection.Text: No person shall start an engine of an aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a pilot’s seat is occupied by a person who is competent to control the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: precautions have been taken to prevent the aircraft from moving; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a seaplane, the aircraft is in a location from which any movement of the aircraft will not endanger persons or property.

Subsection.Text: No person shall leave an engine of an aircraft running unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a pilot’s seat is occupied by a person who is competent to control the aircraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where no persons are on board the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: precautions have been taken to prevent the aircraft from moving, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft is not left unattended.

Subsection.Text: In this section, critical surfaces means the wings, control surfaces, rotors, propellers, horizontal stabilizers, vertical stabilizers or any other stabilizing surface of an aircraft and, in the case of an aircraft that has rear-mounted engines, includes the upper surface of its fuselage.
No person shall conduct or attempt to conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has frost, ice or snow adhering to any of its critical surfaces.

Notwithstanding subsection (2), a person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has frost adhering to the underside of its wings that is caused by cold-soaked fuel, if the take-off is conducted in accordance with the aircraft manufacturer’s instructions for take-off under those conditions.
Where conditions are such that frost, ice or snow may reasonably be expected to adhere to the aircraft, no person shall conduct or attempt to conduct a take-off in an aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for aircraft that are not operated under Subpart 5 of Part VII,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft has been inspected immediately prior to take-off to determine whether any frost, ice or snow is adhering to any of its critical surfaces, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the operator has established an aircraft inspection program in accordance with the Operating and Flight Rules Standards, and the dispatch and take-off of the aircraft are in accordance with that program; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for aircraft that are operated under Subpart 5 of Part VII, the operator has established an aircraft inspection program in accordance with the Operating and Flight Rules Standards, and the dispatch and take-off of the aircraft are in accordance with that program.

Subsection.Text: The inspection referred to in subparagraph (4)(a)(i) shall be performed by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a flight crew member of the aircraft who is designated by the pilot-in-command; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person, other than a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), who

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is designated by the operator of the aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has successfully completed training relating to ground and airborne icing operations under Subpart 4 or relating to aircraft surface contamination under Part VII.

Subsection.Text: Where, before commencing take-off, a crew member of an aircraft observes that there is frost, ice or snow adhering to the wings of the aircraft, the crew member shall immediately report that observation to the pilot-in-command, and the pilot-in-command or a flight crew member designated by the pilot-in-command shall inspect the wings of the aircraft before take-off.
Before an aircraft is de-iced or anti-iced, the pilot-in-command of the aircraft shall ensure that the crew members and passengers are informed of the decision to do so.

Heading.TitleText: Overflight of Built-up Areas or Open-air Assemblies of Persons during Take-offs, Approaches and Landings

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section and sections 602.14 and 602.15, an aircraft shall be deemed to be operated over a built-up area or over an open-air assembly of persons if the built-up area or open-air assembly of persons is within a horizontal distance of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 500 feet from a helicopter or balloon; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 2,000 feet from an aircraft other than a helicopter or balloon.

Subsection.Text: Except at an airport, heliport or military aerodrome, no person shall conduct a take-off, approach or landing in an aircraft over a built-up area or over an open-air assembly of persons, in a manner that is likely to create a hazard to persons or property.

Except at an airport, heliport or military aerodrome, no person shall conduct a take-off, approach or landing in an aircraft over a built-up area or over an open-air assembly of persons unless that aircraft will be operated at an altitude from which, in the event of an engine failure or any other emergency necessitating an immediate landing, the aircraft can land without creating a hazard to persons or property.

Heading.TitleText: Take-offs, Approaches and Landings within Built-up Areas of Cities and Towns

Subsection.Text: Except if otherwise permitted under this section, section 603.66 or Part VII, no person shall conduct a take-off, approach or landing in an aircraft within a built-up area of a city or town, unless that take-off, approach or landing is conducted at an airport, heliport or a military aerodrome.
A person may conduct a take-off or landing in an aircraft within a built-up area of a city or town at a place that is not located at an airport, heliport or a military aerodrome where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the place is not set apart for the operation of aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is conducted without creating a hazard to persons or property on the surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for the purpose of a police operation that is conducted in the service of a police authority, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for the purpose of saving human life.

Subsection.Text: A person may conduct a take-off in a balloon within a built-up area of a city or town from a place that is not located at an airport, heliport or a military aerodrome, where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: permission to use the place as a launch site has been obtained from the land owner;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a special aviation event is not being held at that place at the time of take-off;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: no written objection in respect of the use of the place as a launch site has been received by the Minister from a competent land use authority;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the diameter of the launch site is no less than the greater of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 100 feet, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the greatest dimension of the balloon, be it the length, width or height, plus 25 per cent; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the take-off point within the launch site is upwind of the highest obstacle in the take-off path by a horizontal distance equal to the height of that obstacle, and the take-off is conducted

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: using a positive rate of climb to a minimum altitude of 500 feet above the highest obstacle located within a horizontal distance of 500 feet from the balloon, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the flight path of the balloon is directly over residential or commercial buildings or over an open-air assembly of persons, using the maximum rate of climb possible, considering operational and passenger safety.

Subsection.Text: A person may conduct a landing in a balloon within a built-up area of a city or town at a place that is not located at an airport, heliport or military aerodrome, where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the landing is necessary to avoid endangering the safety of the persons on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command contacts the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station, either prior to landing or as soon as possible after landing, and provides

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the balloon’s nationality mark and registration mark,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the estimated or actual, as applicable, time and location of the landing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reasons why it is believed that the safety of the persons on board is or was endangered.

Subsection.Text: Except where conducting a take-off, approach or landing or where permitted under section 602.15, no person shall operate an aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: over a built-up area or over an open-air assembly of persons unless the aircraft is operated at an altitude from which, in the event of an emergency necessitating an immediate landing, it would be possible to land the aircraft without creating a hazard to persons or property on the surface, and, in any case, at an altitude that is not lower than

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for aeroplanes, 1,000 feet above the highest obstacle located within a horizontal distance of 2,000 feet from the aeroplane,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for balloons, 500 feet above the highest obstacle located within a horizontal distance of 500 feet from the balloon, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: for an aircraft other than an aeroplane or a balloon, 1,000 feet above the highest obstacle located within a horizontal distance of 500 feet from the aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in circumstances other than those referred to in paragraph (a), at a distance less than 500 feet from any person, vessel, vehicle or structure.

Subsection.Text: A person may operate an aircraft at altitudes and distances less than those specified in subsection 602.14(2) where the aircraft is operated at altitudes and distances that are no less than necessary for the purposes of the operation in which the aircraft is engaged, the aircraft is operated without creating a hazard to persons or property on the surface and the aircraft is operated

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of a police operation that is conducted in the service of a police authority;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of saving human life;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for fire-fighting or air ambulance operations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of the administration of the Fisheries Act or the Coastal Fisheries Protection Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of the administration of the national or provincial parks; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of flight inspection.

Subsection.Text: A person may operate an aircraft, to the extent necessary for the purpose of the operation in which the aircraft is engaged, at altitudes and distances less than those set out in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 602.14(2)(a), where operation of the aircraft is authorized under Subpart 3 or section 702.22; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 602.14(2)(b), where the aircraft is operated without creating a hazard to persons or property on the surface and the aircraft is operated for the purpose of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aerial application or aerial inspection,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: aerial photography conducted by the holder of an air operator certificate,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: helicopter external load operations, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: flight training conducted by or under the supervision of a qualified flight instructor.

Heading.TitleText: Flights over Open-Air Assemblies of Persons or Built-up Areas — Helicopters with External Loads

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a helicopter that is carrying a Class B, C or D external load over an open-air assembly of persons.
Except where authorized under section 603.66 or 702.22, no person shall operate a helicopter that is carrying a Class B, C or D external load over a built-up area.

Heading.TitleText: Carriage of Persons during Low Altitude Flight
