Section.Text: No person operating an aircraft shall conduct helicopter Class B, C or D external load operations or engage in aerial application or aerial inspection at altitudes less than 500 feet AGL while carrying on board any person other than a flight crew member, unless that person’s presence on board is essential to the purposes of the flight.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a balloon over a built-up area without carrying on board sufficient fuel to permit the balloon to fly clear of the built-up area, taking into consideration the take-off weight of the balloon, the ambient temperature and actual and forecast winds, and possible variations of those factors.

No person shall operate a balloon on a flight that is planned to enter Class C airspace while over a built-up area unless the clearance to enter that airspace that is required pursuant to section 601.08 has been obtained from the appropriate air traffic control unit prior to take-off.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command of an aircraft that has the right of way shall, if there is any risk of collision, take such action as is necessary to avoid collision; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the pilot-in-command of an aircraft is aware that another aircraft is in an emergency situation, the pilot-in-command shall give way to that other aircraft.

Subsection.Text: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude, the pilot-in-command of the aircraft that has the other on its right shall give way, except as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a power-driven, heavier-than-air aircraft shall give way to airships, gliders and balloons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an airship shall give way to gliders and balloons;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a glider shall give way to balloons; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a power-driven aircraft shall give way to aircraft that are seen to be towing gliders or other objects or carrying a slung load.

Subsection.Text: When two balloons operating at different altitudes are converging, the pilot-in-command of the balloon at the higher altitude shall give way to the balloon at the lower altitude.

Where an aircraft is required to give way to another aircraft, the pilot-in-command of the first-mentioned aircraft shall not pass over or under, or cross ahead of, the other aircraft unless passing or crossing at such a distance as will not create a risk of collision.
Where two aircraft are approaching head-on or approximately so and there is a risk of collision, the pilot-in-command of each aircraft shall alter its heading to the right.

An aircraft that is being overtaken has the right of way and the pilot-in-command of the overtaking aircraft, whether climbing, descending or in level flight, shall give way to the other aircraft by altering the heading of the overtaking aircraft to the right, and no subsequent change in the relative positions of the two aircraft shall absolve the pilot-in-command of the overtaking aircraft from this obligation until that aircraft has entirely passed and is clear of the other aircraft.
Where an aircraft is in flight or manoeuvring on the surface, the pilot-in-command of the aircraft shall give way to an aircraft that is landing or about to land.

The pilot-in-command of an aircraft that is approaching an aerodrome for the purpose of landing shall give way to any aircraft at a lower altitude that is also approaching the aerodrome for the purpose of landing.

The pilot-in-command of an aircraft at a lower altitude, as described in subsection (8), shall not overtake or cut in front of an aircraft at a higher altitude that is in the final stages of an approach to land.

No person shall conduct or attempt to conduct a take-off or landing in an aircraft until there is no apparent risk of collision with any aircraft, person, vessel, vehicle or structure in the take-off or landing path.

Heading.TitleText: Right of Way — Aircraft Manoeuvring on Water

Subsection.Text: Where an aircraft on the water has another aircraft or a vessel on its right, the pilot-in-command of the first-mentioned aircraft shall give way.
Where an aircraft on the water is approaching another aircraft or a vessel head-on, or approximately so, the pilot-in-command of the first-mentioned aircraft shall alter its heading to the right.
The pilot-in-command of an aircraft that is overtaking another aircraft or a vessel on the water shall alter its heading to keep well clear of the other aircraft or the vessel.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft in such proximity to another aircraft as to create a risk of collision.
No person shall operate an aeroplane that is towing an object unless the aeroplane is equipped with a tow hook and release control mechanism.
No person shall create a hazard to persons or property on the surface by dropping an object from an aircraft in flight.
No person shall operate an aircraft in formation with other aircraft except by pre-arrangement between

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilots-in-command of the aircraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the flight is conducted within a control zone, the pilots-in-command and the appropriate air traffic control unit.

Heading.TitleText: Entering or Leaving an Aircraft in Flight

Subsection.Text: No person shall enter or leave an aircraft in flight except with the permission of the pilot-in-command of the aircraft.
No pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall permit a person to enter or leave the aircraft during flight unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person leaves for the purpose of making a parachute descent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the entering or leaving is permitted under section 702.19; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is conducted in accordance with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a special flight operations certificate-special aviation event issued under section 603.02, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a special flight operations certificate issued under section 603.67.

Section.Text: Except where permitted in accordance with section 603.37, no pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall permit, and no person shall conduct, a parachute descent from the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in or into controlled airspace or an air route; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: over or into a built-up area or an open-air assembly of persons.

Heading.TitleText: Aerobatic Manoeuvres — Prohibited Areas and Flight Conditions

Section.Text: No person operating an aircraft shall conduct aerobatic manoeuvres

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: over a built-up area or an open-air assembly of persons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in controlled airspace, except in accordance with a special flight operations certificate issued pursuant to section 603.67;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when flight visibility is less than three miles; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: below 2,000 feet AGL, except in accordance with a special flight operations certificate issued pursuant to section 603.02 or 603.67.

Section.Text: No person operating an aircraft with a passenger on board shall conduct an aerobatic manoeuvre unless the pilot-in-command of the aircraft has engaged in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least 10 hours dual flight instruction in the conducting of aerobatic manoeuvres or 20 hours conducting aerobatic manoeuvres; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one hour of conducting aerobatic manoeuvres in the preceding six months.

Heading.TitleText: Hang Glider and Ultra-light Aeroplane Operation

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a hang glider or an ultra-light aeroplane

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at night;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in IFR flight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections (2) and (3), in controlled airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: unless the aircraft is equipped with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a suitable means of restraint that is attached to the primary structure of the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a radiocommunication system adequate to permit two-way communication on the appropriate frequency when the aircraft is operated within

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: Class D airspace,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the ADIZ, or

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: an MF area, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the aircraft is an ultra-light aeroplane, a placard that is affixed to a surface in plain view of any occupant seated at the flight controls and that states, "THIS AEROPLANE IS OPERATING WITHOUT A CERTIFICATE OF AIRWORTHINESS/CET AVION EST UTILISÉ SANS CERTIFICAT DE NAVIGABILITÉ";

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections (4) and (5), while carrying another person on board; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: unless each person on board

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is secured by a means of restraint referred to in subparagraph (d)(i), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the aircraft is not an advanced ultra-light aeroplane, is wearing a protective helmet.

Subsection.Text: A person may operate a hang glider or an ultra-light aeroplane in controlled airspace

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within five nautical miles from the centre of an airport or heliport or within a control zone of an uncontrolled airport where the person has obtained permission from the airport or heliport operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within a control zone of a controlled airport where the person has obtained an air traffic control clearance by two-way radio voice communication from the air traffic control unit of the airport; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is an advanced ultra-light aeroplane, if the aeroplane is equipped in accordance with section 605.14.

Subsection.Text: A person may operate a hang glider in Class E airspace where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is at least 16 years of age,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is in possession of a Category 1, 3 or 4 medical certificate, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: has obtained a grade of not less than 60 per cent on a Department of Transport written examination pertaining to the Canadian Aviation Regulations, air traffic procedures, flight instruments, navigation, flight operations and human factors respecting hang glider operations in Class E airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hang glider is equipped with a magnetic compass and altimeter;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is a cross-country flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot informs the nearest flight service station of the time of departure and estimated duration of the flight in Class E airspace.

Subsection.Text: A person may operate

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a hang glider with one other person on board if the flight is conducted for the purpose of providing dual flight instruction; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an ultra-light aeroplane with one other person on board if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the flight is conducted for the purpose of providing dual flight instruction,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot is a holder of a pilot permit — ultra-light aeroplane endorsed with a passenger-carrying rating and the aeroplane has no restrictions against carrying another person, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the other person is a holder of a pilot licence or permit, other than a student pilot permit, that allows them to act as pilot-in-command of an ultra-light aeroplane.

Subsection.Text: A person may operate an advanced ultra-light aeroplane with another person on board where the pilot holds a permit or licence issued pursuant to Subpart 1 of Part IV that is appropriate to the functions or privileges being exercised.

Section.Text: No person shall jettison fuel from an aircraft in flight unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is necessary to do so in order to ensure aviation safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all appropriate measures are taken to minimize danger to human life and damage to the environment, insofar as the circumstances permit.

Heading.TitleText: Compliance with Air Traffic Control Instructions and Clearances

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), the pilot-in command of an aircraft shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: comply with and acknowledge, to the appropriate air traffic control unit, all of the air traffic control instructions directed to and received by the pilot-in-command; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: comply with all of the air traffic control clearances received and accepted by the pilot-in-command and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), in the case of an IFR flight, read back to the appropriate air traffic control unit the text of any air traffic control clearance received, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a VFR flight, read back to the appropriate air traffic control unit the text of any air traffic control clearance received, when so requested by the air traffic control unit.

Subsection.Text: Except if requested to do so by an air traffic control unit, the pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft is not required to read back the text of an air traffic control clearance pursuant to paragraph (1)(b)(i) where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air traffic control clearance is received on the ground by the pilot-in-command before departing from a controlled aerodrome in respect of which a standard instrument departure procedure is specified in the Canada Air Pilot; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the receipt of the air traffic control clearance is acknowledged by the pilot-in-command by electronic means.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft may deviate from an air traffic control clearance or an air traffic control instruction to the extent necessary to carry out a collision avoidance manoeuvre, if the manoeuvre is carried out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with a resolution advisory generated by an ACAS; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in response to an alert from a TAWS or a Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS).

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as possible after initiating the collision avoidance manoeuvre referred to in subsection (3), inform the appropriate air traffic control unit of the deviation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: immediately after completing the collision avoidance manoeuvre referred to in subsection (3), comply with the last air traffic control clearance received and accepted by, or the last air traffic control instruction received and acknowledged by, the pilot-in-command.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: operate an aircraft at an indicated airspeed of more than 250 knots if the aircraft is below 10,000 feet ASL; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: operate an aircraft at an indicated airspeed of more than 200 knots if the aircraft is below 3,000 feet AGL within 10 nautical miles of a controlled aerodrome unless authorized to do so in an air traffic control clearance.

Subsection.Text: A person may operate an aircraft at an indicated airspeed greater than the airspeeds referred to in subsection (1) if the aircraft is being operated in accordance with a special flight operations certificate – special aviation event issued pursuant to section 603.02.
If the minimum safe airspeed for the flight configuration of an aircraft is greater than the airspeed referred to in subsection (1), the aircraft shall be operated at the minimum safe airspeed.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft at a true Mach number of 1 or greater.

Heading.TitleText: Cruising Altitudes and Cruising Flight Levels

Subsection.Text: The appropriate cruising altitude or cruising flight level for an aircraft in level cruising flight is determined in accordance with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the magnetic track, in the Southern Domestic Airspace; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the true track, in the Northern Domestic Airspace.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), the pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall ensure that the aircraft is operated at a cruising altitude or cruising flight level appropriate to the track, as set out in the table to this section, unless the pilot-in-command is assigned another altitude or flight level by an air traffic control unit and the aircraft is operated in level cruising flight

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at more than 3,000 feet AGL, in VFR flight; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in IFR flight.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (2) does not apply where an aircraft is operated for the purpose of aerial survey or mapping and the following conditions are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command of the aircraft contacts the appropriate air traffic control unit as far in advance as possible of the proposed flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command of the aircraft provides, as far in advance as possible of the proposed take-off time of the aircraft, to any air traffic control unit that so requests, a topographical map at either a 1:500 000 or a 1:1 000 000 scale of the area to be surveyed or mapped, with proposed tracks and planned entry and exit points clearly delineated on the map;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command of the aircraft files a flight plan or flight itinerary with an air traffic control unit as far in advance as possible of the proposed take-off time of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the flight plan or flight itinerary referred to in paragraph (c) specifies the area to be surveyed or mapped

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by reference to the relevant maps of the National Topographic System,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: by reference to the geographic co-ordinates of the area, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: where required by an air traffic control unit, by reference to the air photograph block reference grid map provided by the air traffic control unit; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated in controlled airspace, it is operated in accordance with an air traffic control clearance.

table.title: CRUISING ALTITUDES AND CRUISING FLIGHT LEVELS APPROPRIATE TO AIRCRAFT TRACK

Provision.Text: TRACK
TRACK

row.entry: Cruising Altitudes or Cruising Flight Levels — 18,000 feet and below

Heading.TitleText: Altimeter-setting and Operating Procedures in the Altimeter-setting Region

Section.Text: When an aircraft is operated in the altimeter-setting region, each flight crew member who occupies a flight crew member position that is equipped with an altimeter shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately before conducting a take-off from an aerodrome, set the altimeter to the altimeter setting of the aerodrome or, if that altimeter setting is not obtainable, to the elevation of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while in flight, set the altimeter to the altimeter setting of the nearest station along the route of flight or, where the nearest stations along the route of flight are separated by more than 150 nautical miles, to the altimeter setting of a station near the route of flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: immediately before commencing a descent for the purpose of landing at an aerodrome, set the altimeter to the altimeter setting of the aerodrome, if that altimeter setting is obtainable.

Heading.TitleText: Altimeter-setting and Operating Procedures in the Standard Pressure Region

Subsection.Text: When an aircraft is operated in the standard pressure region, each flight crew member who occupies a flight crew member position that is equipped with an altimeter shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately before conducting a take-off from an aerodrome, set the altimeter to the altimeter setting of the aerodrome or, if that altimeter setting is not obtainable, to the elevation of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before reaching the flight level at which the flight is to be conducted, set the altimeter to 29.92 inches of mercury or 1,013.2 millibars; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: immediately before commencing a descent for the purpose of landing at an aerodrome, set the altimeter to the altimeter setting of the aerodrome, if that altimeter setting is obtainable.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding paragraph (1)(c), when a holding procedure is being conducted before landing at an aerodrome located in the standard pressure region, each flight crew member who occupies a flight crew member position that is equipped with an altimeter shall set the altimeter to the altimeter setting of the aerodrome immediately before descending below the lowest flight level at which the holding procedure is conducted.

Heading.TitleText: Altimeter-setting and Operating Procedures in Transition between Regions

Section.Text: Except where otherwise authorized by an air traffic control unit, each flight crew member who occupies a flight crew member position that is equipped with an altimeter shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when flying from the altimeter-setting region into the standard pressure region, set the altimeter to 29.92 inches of mercury or 1,013.2 millibars immediately after the aircraft’s entry into the standard pressure region; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when flying from the standard pressure region into the altimeter-setting region, set the altimeter to the altimeter setting of the nearest station along the route of flight or, where the nearest stations along the route of flight are separated by more than 150 nautical miles, the altimeter setting of a station near the route of flight immediately before the aircraft’s entry into the altimeter-setting region.

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command of a Canadian aircraft that is in flight over the high seas shall comply with the applicable Rules of the Air set out in Annex 2 to the Convention and the applicable Regional Supplementary Procedures set out in Document 7030/4 of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

No pilot-in-command of a single-engined aircraft, or of a multi-engined aircraft that would be unable to maintain flight in the event of the failure of any engine, shall commence a flight that will leave Canadian Domestic Airspace and enter airspace over the high seas unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command holds a pilot licence endorsed with an instrument rating;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the equipment referred to in section 605.18,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a high frequency radio capable of transmitting and receiving on a minimum of two appropriate international air-ground general purpose frequencies, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: hypothermia protection for each person on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft carries sufficient fuel to meet the requirements of section 602.88 and, in addition, carries contingency fuel equal to at least 10 per cent of the fuel required pursuant to section 602.88 to complete the flight to the aerodrome of destination.

Heading.TitleText: Landing at or Take-off from an Aerodrome at Night

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall conduct a landing or a take-off in a heavier-than-air aircraft at night at an aerodrome unless the aerodrome is lighted in accordance with the aerodrome lighting requirements specified in Part III.
A person may conduct a landing or a take-off in a heavier-than-air aircraft at night at an aerodrome that is not lighted in accordance with the requirements referred to in subsection (1) where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is conducted without creating a hazard to persons or property on the surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for the purpose of a police operation that is conducted in the service of a police authority, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for the purpose of saving human life.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an unmanned air vehicle in flight except in accordance with a special flight operations certificate or an air operator certificate.

No person shall release an unoccupied free balloon having a gas-carrying capacity of more than 115 cubic feet (3.256 m3) except in accordance with an authorization issued by the Minister pursuant to section 602.44.

No person shall launch a rocket, other than a model rocket or a rocket of a type used in a fireworks display, except in accordance with an authorization issued by the Minister pursuant to section 602.44.

The Minister may issue an authorization referred to in section 602.42 or 602.43 where the release of the balloon or the launch of the rocket is in the public interest and is not likely to affect aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: Model Aircraft, Kites and Model Rockets

Section.Text: No person shall fly a model aircraft or a kite or launch a model rocket or a rocket of a type used in a fireworks display into cloud or in a manner that is or is likely to be hazardous to aviation safety.

No air operator or private operator shall transport a person if at the time of check-in or at boarding the actions or statements of the person indicate that the person may present a risk to the safety of the aircraft, persons or property.

Heading.TitleText: Division II — Operational and Emergency Equipment Requirements

Section.Text: This Division applies to persons operating

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Canadian aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: foreign aircraft in Canada where those persons are Canadian citizens, permanent residents or corporations incorporated by or under the laws of Canada or a province.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft referred to in section 602.57 unless the operational and emergency equipment required by these Regulations is carried on board.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall operate an aircraft unless the operational and emergency equipment carried on board the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the applicable standards specified in the Airworthiness Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is functional.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(a) does not apply in respect of the following operational and emergency equipment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: survival equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a personal flotation device;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a hand-held fire extinguisher, except if carried on board an aircraft operated under Subpart 4 or Part VII, where the extinguisher meets the applicable standards published by the Canadian Standards Association;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a first aid kit, except if carried on board an aircraft operated under Subpart 4 or Part VII;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: aeronautical charts and publications;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a timepiece; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a flashlight.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a power-driven aircraft, other than an ultra-light aeroplane, unless the following operational and emergency equipment is carried on board:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a checklist or placards that enable the aircraft to be operated in accordance with limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual, aircraft operating manual, pilot operating handbook or any equivalent document provided by the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all of the necessary current aeronautical charts and publications covering the route of the proposed flight and any probable diversionary route, if the aircraft is operated in VFR OTT, night VFR flight or IFR flight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a current database, if the aircraft is operated in IFR flight, in VFR OTT flight or in night VFR flight under Subpart 4 of Part VI or Subpart 2, 3, 4 or 5 of Part VII and database-dependent navigation equipment is used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: current data covering the route of the proposed flight and any probable diversionary route, if the aircraft is operated in VFR OTT flight other than VFR OTT flight referred to in paragraph (c) and database-dependent navigation equipment is used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a hand-held fire extinguisher in the cockpit that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is of a type suitable for extinguishing fires that are likely to occur,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is designed to minimize the hazard of toxic gas concentrations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is readily available to each flight crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a timepiece that is readily available to each flight crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a flashlight that is readily available to each crew member, if the aircraft is operated at night; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a first aid kit.

Subsection.Text: A checklist or placards referred to in paragraph (1)(a) shall enable the aircraft to be operated in normal, abnormal and emergency conditions and shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a pre-start check;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a pre-take-off check;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a post-take-off check;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a pre-landing check; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: emergency procedures.

Subsection.Text: Emergency procedures referred to in paragraph (2)(e) shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: emergency operation of fuel, hydraulic, electrical and mechanical systems, where applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: emergency operation of instruments and controls, where applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: engine inoperative procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other procedure that is necessary for aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: Checks and emergency procedures referred to in subsections (2) and (3) shall be performed and followed where they are applicable.

Subject to subsection (2), no person shall operate an aircraft over land unless there is carried on board survival equipment, sufficient for the survival on the ground of each person on board, given the geographical area, the season of the year and anticipated seasonal climatic variations, that provides the means for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: starting a fire;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: providing shelter;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: providing or purifying water; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: visually signalling distress.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a balloon, a glider, a hang glider, a gyroplane or an ultra-light aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft that is operated within 25 nautical miles of the aerodrome of departure and that has the capability of radiocommunication with a surface-based radio station for the duration of the flight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a multi-engined aircraft that is operated south of 66° 30’ north latitude

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in IFR flight within controlled airspace, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: along designated air routes;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft that is operated by an air operator, where the aircraft is equipped with equipment specified in the air operator’s company operations manual, but not with the equipment required by subsection (1); or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft that is operated in a geographical area where and at a time of year when the survival of the persons on board is not jeopardized.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off or a landing on water in an aircraft or operate an aircraft over water beyond a point where the aircraft could reach shore in the event of an engine failure, unless a life preserver, individual flotation device or personal flotation device is carried for each person on board.
No person shall operate a land aeroplane, gyroplane, helicopter or airship at more than 50 nautical miles from shore unless a life preserver is carried for each person on board.
No person shall operate a balloon at more than two nautical miles from shore unless a life preserver, individual flotation device or personal flotation device is carried for each person on board.

For aircraft other than balloons, every life preserver, individual flotation device and personal flotation device referred to in this section shall be stowed in a position that is easily accessible to the person for whose use it is provided, when that person is seated.

Heading.TitleText: Life Rafts and Survival Equipment — Flights over Water

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate over water a single-engined aeroplane, or a multi-engined aeroplane that is unable to maintain flight with any engine failed, at more than 100 nautical miles, or the distance that can be covered in 30 minutes of flight at the cruising speed filed in the flight plan or flight itinerary, whichever distance is the lesser, from a suitable emergency landing site unless life rafts are carried on board and are sufficient in total rated capacity to accommodate all of the persons on board.

Subject to subsection (3), no person shall operate over water a multi-engined aeroplane that is able to maintain flight with any engine failed at more than 200 nautical miles, or the distance that can be covered in 60 minutes of flight at the cruising speed filed in the flight plan or flight itinerary, whichever distance is the lesser, from a suitable emergency landing site unless life rafts are carried on board and are sufficient in total rated capacity to accommodate all of the persons on board.

A person may operate over water a transport category aircraft that is an aeroplane, at up to 400 nautical miles, or the distance that can be covered in 120 minutes of flight at the cruising speed filed in the flight plan or flight itinerary, whichever distance is the lesser, from a suitable emergency landing site without the life rafts referred to in subsection (2) being carried on board.

No person shall operate over water a single-engined helicopter, or a multi-engined helicopter that is unable to maintain flight with any engine failed, at more than 25 nautical miles, or the distance that can be covered in 15 minutes of flight at the cruising speed filed in the flight plan or flight itinerary, whichever distance is the lesser, from a suitable emergency landing site unless life rafts are carried on board and are sufficient in total rated capacity to accommodate all of the persons on board.

No person shall operate over water a multi-engined helicopter that is able to maintain flight with any engine failed at more than 50 nautical miles, or the distance that can be covered in 30 minutes of flight at the cruising speed filed in the flight plan or flight itinerary, whichever distance is the lesser, from a suitable emergency landing site unless life rafts are carried on board and are sufficient in total rated capacity to accommodate all of the persons on board.
The life rafts referred to in this section shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: stowed so that they are easily accessible for use in the event of a ditching;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: installed in conspicuously marked locations near an exit; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with an attached survival kit, sufficient for the survival on water of each person on board the aircraft, given the geographical area, the season of the year and anticipated seasonal climatic variations, that provides a means for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: providing shelter,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: providing or purifying water, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: visually signalling distress.

Subsection.Text: Where a helicopter is required to carry life rafts pursuant to subsection (4) or (5), no person shall operate the helicopter over water having a temperature of less than 10oC unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a helicopter passenger transportation suit system that conforms to paragraph 551.407(c) of the Airworthiness Manual is provided for each passenger on board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a helicopter crew member transportation suit system is provided for each crew member on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command directs all persons on board to wear their helicopter transportation suit system.

Subsection.Text: Every person who has been directed to wear a helicopter transportation suit system pursuant to paragraph (7)(c) shall wear that suit system.

Subject to section 602.65, no person shall dispatch or conduct a take-off in a helicopter to conduct an offshore operations flight if, during the pre-flight check required under section 602.71 or the weather check required under section 602.72, the pilot-in-command or the air operator is aware that the sea state at any point along the planned route exceeds the sea state for which the helicopter is certified, as part of its type design, to conduct a ditching.

An air operator who uses a helicopter to conduct an offshore operations flight shall notify the pilot-in-command if, at take-off or during the flight, the air operator is or becomes aware that the sea state at any point along the planned route between the position of the helicopter and the destination exceeds the sea state for which the helicopter is certified, as part of its type design, to conduct a ditching.

If the pilot-in-command of a helicopter who is conducting an offshore operations flight is or becomes aware that the sea state at any point along the planned route between the position of the helicopter and the destination exceeds the sea state for which the helicopter is certified, as part of its type design, to conduct a ditching, the pilot-in-command shall, subject to section 602.65, proceed directly to a land base.

Section.Text: Subsections 602.64(1) and (3) do not apply in respect of an offshore operations flight conducted for the purpose of responding to an emergency.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a helicopter to conduct an offshore operations flight over Canadian waters unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a EUBA is provided for each person on board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each EUBA

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is readily accessible for immediate use in the event of a ditching,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: can be donned quickly,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: provides a supplemental air supply that is effective to a depth of at least 3.6 m, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: is not likely to pose a snagging risk during an evacuation of the helicopter; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: each person on board has, in the 36-month period preceding the flight, received EUBA training that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is specific to the type of EUBA provided,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: includes classroom theory training on the use of the EUBA and its limits and hazards, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: includes practical pool training that simulates the evacuation of a helicopter that has overturned or is sinking after a ditching.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a helicopter to conduct an offshore operations flight over Canadian waters that have a temperature of 10°C or more unless the EUBA that is provided for a person under subsection (1) is attached to the life preserver, individual flotation device or personal flotation device that is carried on board the helicopter for that person.

No person shall operate a helicopter to conduct an offshore operations flight over Canadian waters that have a temperature of less than 10°C unless the EUBA that is provided for a person under subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is in a pocket or pouch that is part of the person’s helicopter passenger transportation suit system or helicopter crew member transportation suit system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is in a pouch that is worn with the person’s helicopter passenger transportation suit system or helicopter crew member transportation suit system; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is attached to the person’s helicopter passenger transportation suit system or helicopter crew member transportation suit system.

Heading.TitleText: Division III — Flight Preparation, Flight Plans and Flight Itineraries

Section.Text: In this Division,

Definition.Text: overdue, in respect of an aircraft, means an aircraft for which an arrival report has not been filed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a flight plan has been filed in respect of the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if a search and rescue notification time is specified in the flight plan, immediately after the last reported such time, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in all other cases, within one hour after the last reported estimated time of arrival, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where a flight itinerary has been filed in respect of the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if a search and rescue notification time is specified in the flight itinerary, immediately after the last reported such time, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in all other cases, within 24 hours after the last reported estimated time of arrival; (en retard)

Definition.Text: responsible person means an individual who has agreed with the person who has filed a flight itinerary to ensure that the following are notified in the manner prescribed in this Division, if the aircraft is overdue, namely,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a Rescue Co-ordination Centre. (personne de confiance)

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall, before commencing a flight, be familiar with the available information that is appropriate to the intended flight.
The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall, before commencing a flight, be familiar with the available weather information that is appropriate to the intended flight.

Heading.TitleText: Requirement to File a Flight Plan or a Flight Itinerary

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no pilot-in-command shall operate an aircraft in IFR flight unless an IFR flight plan has been filed.

No pilot-in-command shall operate an aircraft in VFR flight unless a VFR flight plan or a VFR flight itinerary has been filed, except where the flight is conducted within 25 nautical miles of the departure aerodrome.
A pilot-in-command may file an IFR flight itinerary instead of an IFR flight plan where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is conducted in part or in whole outside controlled airspace; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: facilities are inadequate to permit the communication of flight plan information to an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding anything in this Division, no pilot-in-command shall, unless a flight plan has been filed, operate an aircraft between Canada and a foreign state.

Heading.TitleText: Contents of a Flight Plan or a Flight Itinerary

Section.Text: A flight plan or flight itinerary shall contain such information as is specified by the Minister in the Canada Flight Supplement.

Heading.TitleText: Filing of a Flight Plan or a Flight Itinerary

Subsection.Text: A flight plan shall be filed with an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station.
A flight itinerary shall be filed with a responsible person, an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station.
A flight plan or flight itinerary shall be filed by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sending, delivering or otherwise communicating the flight plan or flight itinerary or the information contained therein; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: receiving acknowledgement that the flight plan or flight itinerary or the information contained therein has been received.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft for which an IFR flight plan or an IFR flight itinerary has been filed shall follow the procedure set out in subsection (2) where the pilot-in-command intends to make any change in the plan or itinerary in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the cruising altitude or cruising flight level;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the route of flight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the destination aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight plan, the true airspeed at the cruising altitude or cruising flight level, where the change intended is five per cent or more of the true airspeed specified in the IFR flight plan; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the Mach number, where the change intended is .01 or more of the Mach number that has been included in the air traffic control clearance.

Subsection.Text: A pilot-in-command of an aircraft who intends to make any of the changes in the IFR flight plan or the IFR flight itinerary that are referred to in subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify as soon as practicable an air traffic control unit or the responsible person, as the case may be, of the intended change; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the flight is being conducted in controlled airspace, receive an air traffic control clearance before making the intended change.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft for which a VFR flight plan or a VFR flight itinerary has been filed shall follow the procedure set out in subsection (4) where the pilot-in-command intends to make a change in the plan or itinerary in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the route of flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the duration of the flight; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the destination aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: A pilot-in-command of an aircraft who intends to make any of the changes in the VFR flight plan or the VFR flight itinerary that are referred to in subsection (3) shall notify as soon as practicable an air traffic control unit, a flight service station, a community aerodrome radio station or the responsible person, of the intended change.

Heading.TitleText: Requirement to File an Arrival Report

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), a pilot-in-command of an aircraft who terminates a flight in respect of which a flight plan has been filed under subsection 602.75(1) shall ensure that an arrival report is filed with an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station as soon as practicable after landing but not later than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the search and rescue action initiation time specified in the flight plan; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where no search and rescue action initiation time is specified in the flight plan, one hour after the last reported estimated time of arrival.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), a pilot-in-command of an aircraft who terminates a flight in respect of which a flight itinerary has been filed under subsection 602.75(2) shall ensure that an arrival report is filed with an air traffic control unit, a flight service station, a community aerodrome radio station or, if the flight itinerary was filed with a responsible person, the responsible person, as soon as practicable after landing but not later than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the search and rescue action initiation time specified in the flight itinerary; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where no search and rescue action initiation time is specified in the flight itinerary, 24 hours after the last reported estimated time of arrival.

Subsection.Text: A pilot-in-command who terminates an IFR flight at an aerodrome where there is an operating air traffic control unit or flight service station is not required to file an arrival report unless requested to do so by the appropriate air traffic control unit.

A pilot-in-command of an aircraft who conducts a flight in respect of which a flight plan or flight itinerary has been filed with an air traffic control unit, flight service station or community aerodrome radio station may file an arrival report by closing the flight plan or flight itinerary with an air traffic control unit, flight service station or community aerodrome radio station prior to landing.

Section.Text: An arrival report shall contain such information as is specified by the Minister in the Canada Flight Supplement.

Any person who assumes responsibilities with respect to an aircraft and who has reason to believe that the aircraft is overdue, or any other person who has been directed by that person to do so, shall immediately, by the quickest means available,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify an air traffic control unit, a flight service station, a community aerodrome radio station or a Rescue Co-ordination Centre; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide, to the best of the person’s knowledge, all of the available information concerning the overdue aircraft that may be requested by the air traffic control unit, the flight service station, the community aerodrome radio station or the Rescue Co-ordination Centre.

Heading.TitleText: Division IV — Pre-Flight and Fuel Requirements

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft with carry-on baggage, equipment or cargo on board, unless the carry-on baggage, equipment and cargo are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: stowed in a bin, compartment, rack or other location that is certified in accordance with the aircraft type certificate in respect of the stowage of carry-on baggage, equipment or cargo; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: restrained so as to prevent them from shifting during movement of the aircraft on the surface and during take-off, landing and in-flight turbulence.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft with carry-on baggage, equipment or cargo on board unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safety equipment, the normal and emergency exits that are accessible to passengers and the aisles between the flight deck and a passenger compartment are not wholly or partially blocked by carry-on baggage, equipment or cargo;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all of the equipment and cargo that are stowed in a passenger compartment are packaged or covered to avoid possible injury to persons on board;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is type-certificated to carry 10 or more passengers and passengers are carried on board,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: no passenger’s view of any “seat belt” sign, “no smoking” sign or exit sign is obscured by carry-on baggage, equipment or cargo except if an auxiliary sign is visible to the passenger or another means of notification of the passenger is available,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all of the passenger service carts and trolleys are securely restrained during movement of the aircraft on the surface, take-off and landing, and during in-flight turbulence where the pilot-in-command or in-charge flight attendant has directed that the cabin be secured pursuant to subsection 605.25(3) or (4), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all of the video monitors that are suspended from the ceiling of the aircraft and extend into an aisle are stowed and securely restrained during take-off and landing; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all of the cargo that is stowed in a compartment to which crew members have access is stowed in such a manner as to allow a crew member to effectively reach all parts of the compartment with a hand-held fire extinguisher.

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall ensure that each crew member, before acting as a crew member on board the aircraft, has been instructed with respect to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the duties that the crew member is to perform; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location and use of all of the normal and emergency exits and of all of the emergency equipment that is carried on board the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of any glider, balloon or ultra-light aeroplane.

No pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall commence a flight or, during flight, change the destination aerodrome set out in the flight plan or flight itinerary, unless the aircraft carries sufficient fuel to ensure compliance with subsections (3) to (5).
An aircraft operated in VFR flight shall carry an amount of fuel that is sufficient to allow the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft other than a helicopter,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when operated during the day, to fly to the destination aerodrome and then to fly for a period of 30 minutes at normal cruising speed, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when operated at night, to fly to the destination aerodrome and then to fly for a period of 45 minutes at normal cruising speed; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a helicopter, to fly to the destination aerodrome and then to fly for a period of 20 minutes at normal cruising speed.

Subsection.Text: An aircraft operated in IFR flight shall carry an amount of fuel that is sufficient to allow the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a propeller-driven aeroplane,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where an alternate aerodrome is specified in the flight plan or flight itinerary, to fly to and execute an approach and a missed approach at the destination aerodrome, to fly to and land at the alternate aerodrome and then to fly for a period of 45 minutes, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where an alternate aerodrome is not specified in the flight plan or flight itinerary, to fly to and execute an approach and a missed approach at the destination aerodrome and then to fly for a period of 45 minutes; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane or a helicopter,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where an alternate aerodrome is specified in the flight plan or flight itinerary, to fly to and execute an approach and a missed approach at the destination aerodrome, to fly to and land at the alternate aerodrome and then to fly for a period of 30 minutes, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where an alternate aerodrome is not specified in the flight plan or flight itinerary, to fly to and execute an approach and a missed approach at the destination aerodrome and then to fly for a period of 30 minutes.

Subsection.Text: Every aircraft shall carry an amount of fuel that is sufficient to provide for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: taxiing and foreseeable delays prior to take-off;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meteorological conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: foreseeable air traffic routings and traffic delays;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: landing at a suitable aerodrome in the event of loss of cabin pressurization or, in the case of a multi-engined aircraft, failure of any engine, at the most critical point during the flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other foreseeable conditions that could delay the landing of the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall ensure that all of the passengers on board the aircraft are briefed before take-off with respect to the following, where applicable:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location and means of operation of emergency and normal exits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location and means of operation of safety belts, shoulder harnesses and restraint devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the positioning of seats and the securing of seat backs and chair tables;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the stowage of carry-on baggage;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is unpressurized and it is possible that the flight will require the use of oxygen by the passengers, the location and means of operation of oxygen equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any prohibition against smoking.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall ensure that all of the passengers on board the aircraft are briefed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an over-water flight where the carriage of life preservers, individual flotation devices or personal flotation devices is required pursuant to section 602.62, before commencement of the over-water portion of the flight, with respect to the location and use of those items; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a pressurized aircraft that is to be operated at an altitude above FL 250, before the aircraft reaches FL 250, with respect to the location and means of operation of oxygen equipment.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall, before take-off, ensure that all of the passengers on board the aircraft are provided with information respecting the location and use of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: first aid kits and survival equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is a helicopter or a small aircraft that is an aeroplane, any ELT that is required to be carried on board pursuant to section 605.38; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any life raft that is required to be carried on board pursuant to section 602.63.

Heading.TitleText: Division V — Operations at or in the Vicinity of an Aerodrome

Subsection.Text: This section applies to persons operating VFR or IFR aircraft at or in the vicinity of an uncontrolled or controlled aerodrome.
Before taking off from, landing at or otherwise operating an aircraft at an aerodrome, the pilot-in-command of the aircraft shall be satisfied that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is no likelihood of collision with another aircraft or a vehicle; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aerodrome is suitable for the intended operation.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft operating at or in the vicinity of an aerodrome shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: observe aerodrome traffic for the purpose of avoiding a collision;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conform to or avoid the pattern of traffic formed by other aircraft in operation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: make all turns to the left when operating within the aerodrome traffic circuit, except where right turns are specified by the Minister in the Canada Flight Supplement or where otherwise authorized by the appropriate air traffic control unit;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the aerodrome is an airport, comply with any airport operating restrictions specified by the Minister in the Canada Flight Supplement;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where practicable, land and take off into the wind unless otherwise authorized by the appropriate air traffic control unit;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: maintain a continuous listening watch on the appropriate frequency for aerodrome control communications or, if this is not possible and an air traffic control unit is in operation at the aerodrome, keep a watch for such instructions as may be issued by visual means by the air traffic control unit; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: where the aerodrome is a controlled aerodrome, obtain from the appropriate air traffic control unit, either by radio communication or by visual signal, clearance to taxi, take off from or land at the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise authorized by the appropriate air traffic control unit, no pilot-in-command shall operate an aircraft at an altitude of less than 2,000 feet over an aerodrome except for the purpose of landing or taking off or if the aircraft is operated pursuant to subsection (5).

Where it is necessary for the purposes of the operation in which the aircraft is engaged, a pilot-in-command may operate an aircraft at an altitude of less than 2,000 feet over an aerodrome, where it is being operated

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the service of a police authority;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of saving human life;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for fire-fighting or air ambulance operations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of the administration of the Fisheries Act or the Coastal Fisheries Protection Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of the administration of the national or provincial parks;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of flight inspection;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of aerial application or aerial inspection;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of highway or city traffic patrol;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of aerial photography conducted by the holder of an air operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of helicopter external load operations; or

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of flight training conducted by the holder of a flight training unit operator certificate.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off or landing at a designated airport without an aircraft fire-fighting service in an aeroplane in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of 20 or more passengers if the aeroplane is operated under

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Part VI, Subpart 4; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Part VII, Subpart 1 or 5.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (6) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a cargo flight without passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a ferry flight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a positioning flight;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a training flight if no fare-paying passengers are on board;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the arrival of an aeroplane when the airport is being used for a diversion or as an alternate aerodrome; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the subsequent departure of an aeroplane referred to in paragraph (e) if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the air operator or private operator has notified the operator of the designated airport of the intended time of departure,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the operator of the designated airport has advised the air operator or private operator that aircraft fire-fighting services cannot be made available within one hour after the later of the time that notification was given under subparagraph (i) and the time of landing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command and the operations manager of the air operator or private operator have agreed that the aeroplane will depart without aircraft fire-fighting services being available.

Heading.TitleText: VFR and IFR Aircraft Operations at Uncontrolled Aerodromes within an MF Area

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no pilot-in-command shall operate a VFR or IFR aircraft within an MF area unless the aircraft is equipped with radiocommunication equipment pursuant to Subpart 5.
The pilot-in-command of a VFR or IFR aircraft operating within an MF area shall maintain a listening watch on the mandatory frequency specified for use in the MF area.

The pilot-in-command of a VFR aircraft that is not equipped with the radiocommunication equipment referred to in subsection (1) may operate the aircraft to or from an uncontrolled aerodrome that lies within an MF area if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a ground station is in operation at the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prior notice of the pilot-in-command’s intention to operate the aircraft at the aerodrome has been given to the ground station;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when conducting a take-off, the pilot-in-command ascertains by visual observation that there is no likelihood of collision with another aircraft or a vehicle during take-off; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when approaching for a landing, the aircraft enters the aerodrome traffic circuit from a position that will require it to complete two sides of a rectangular circuit before turning onto the final approach path.

Subsection.Text: Every report made pursuant to this Division shall be made on the mandatory frequency that has been specified for use in the applicable MF area.
Every report referred to in subsection (1) shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: directed to the ground station associated with the MF area, if a ground station exists and is in operation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: broadcast, if a ground station does not exist or is not in operation.

Heading.TitleText: MF Reporting Procedures before Entering Manoeuvring Area

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command of a VFR or IFR aircraft that is operated at an uncontrolled aerodrome that lies within an MF area shall report the pilot-in-command’s intentions before entering the manoeuvring area of the aerodrome.
The pilot-in-command of a VFR or IFR aircraft that is departing from an uncontrolled aerodrome that lies within an MF area shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before moving onto the take-off surface, report the pilot-in-command’s departure procedure intentions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before take-off, ascertain by radiocommunication and by visual observation that there is no likelihood of collision with another aircraft or a vehicle during take-off; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: after take-off, report departing from the aerodrome traffic circuit.

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command of a VFR aircraft arriving at an uncontrolled aerodrome that lies within an MF area shall report

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before entering the MF area and, where circumstances permit, shall do so at least five minutes before entering the area, giving the aircraft’s position, altitude and estimated time of landing and the pilot-in-command’s arrival procedure intentions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when joining the aerodrome traffic circuit, giving the aircraft’s position in the circuit;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when on the downwind leg, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when on final approach; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: when clear of the surface on which the aircraft has landed.

Heading.TitleText: MF Reporting Procedures When Flying Continuous Circuits

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command of a VFR aircraft carrying out continuous circuits at an uncontrolled aerodrome that lies within an MF area shall report

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when joining the downwind leg of the circuit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when on final approach, stating the pilot-in-command’s intentions; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when clear of the surface on which the aircraft has landed.

Heading.TitleText: Reporting Procedures When Flying through an MF Area

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft flying through an MF area shall report

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before entering the MF area and, where circumstances permit, shall do so at least five minutes before entering the area, giving the aircraft’s position and altitude and the pilot-in-command’s intentions; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when clear of the MF area.

Heading.TitleText: Reporting Procedures for IFR Aircraft When Approaching or Landing at an Uncontrolled Aerodrome

Subsection.Text: This section applies to persons operating IFR aircraft when approaching or landing at an uncontrolled aerodrome, whether or not the aerodrome lies within an MF area.
The pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft who intends to conduct an approach to or a landing at an uncontrolled aerodrome shall report

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command’s intentions regarding the operation of the aircraft

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: five minutes before the estimated time of commencing the approach procedure, stating the estimated time of landing,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when commencing a circling manoeuvre, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: as soon as practicable after initiating a missed approach procedure; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft’s position

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when passing the fix outbound, where the pilot-in-command intends to conduct a procedure turn or, if no procedure turn is intended, when the aircraft first intercepts the final approach course,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when passing the final approach fix or three minutes before the estimated time of landing where no final approach fix exists, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: on final approach.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft at or in the vicinity of an aerodrome except in accordance with the applicable noise abatement procedures and noise control requirements specified by the Minister in the Canada Air Pilot or Canada Flight Supplement, including the procedures and requirements relating to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: preferential runways;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: minimum noise routes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: hours when aircraft operations are prohibited or restricted;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: arrival procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: departure procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: duration of flights;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the prohibition or restriction of training flights;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: VFR or visual approaches;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: simulated approach procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum altitude for the operation of aircraft in the vicinity of the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall operate a subsonic turbo-jet aeroplane that has a maximum certificated take-off weight of more than 34 000 kg (74,956 pounds) on take-off at a noise-restricted runway set out in column II of an item of the table to this section at an aerodrome set out in column I of that item, unless there is on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of airworthiness indicating that the aeroplane meets the applicable noise emission standards;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of noise compliance issued in respect of the aeroplane; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the aeroplane is not a Canadian aircraft, a document issued by the state of registry that specifies that the aeroplane meets the applicable noise emission requirements of that state.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the extent that it is inconsistent with any obligation assumed by Canada in respect of a foreign state in a treaty, convention or agreement;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the pilot-in-command of an aircraft has declared an emergency; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where an aircraft is operated on

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an air evacuation operation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other emergency air operation , or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a departure from an aerodrome at which it was required to land because of an emergency.

row.entry: Winnipeg / James Armstrong Richardson International Airport

Footnote.Text: Information taken from the aeronautical information publication of the Department of Transport entitled Canada Flight Supplement

Heading.TitleText: Minimum Visual Meteorological Conditions for VFR Flight in Controlled Airspace

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft in VFR flight within controlled airspace unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated with visual reference to the surface;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: flight visibility is not less than three miles;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the distance of the aircraft from cloud is not less than 500 feet vertically and one mile horizontally; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated within a control zone,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when reported, ground visibility is not less than three miles, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: except when taking off or landing, the distance of the aircraft from the surface is not less than 500 feet.

Heading.TitleText: Minimum Visual Meteorological Conditions for VFR Flight in Uncontrolled Airspace

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft in VFR flight within uncontrolled airspace unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated with visual reference to the surface;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated at or above 1,000 feet AGL

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: during the day, flight visibility is not less than one mile,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: during the night, flight visibility is not less than three miles, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in either case, the distance of the aircraft from cloud is not less than 500 feet vertically and 2,000 feet horizontally;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is not a helicopter and is operated at less than 1,000 feet AGL

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: during the day, flight visibility is not less than two miles, except if otherwise authorized in an air operator certificate,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: during the night, flight visibility is not less than three miles, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in either case, the aircraft is operated clear of cloud; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is a helicopter and is operated at less than 1,000 feet AGL

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: during the day, flight visibility is not less than one mile, except if otherwise authorized in an air operator certificate or a flight training unit operator certificate — helicopter,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: during the night, flight visibility is not less than three miles, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in either case, the aircraft is operated clear of cloud.

Section.Text: Notwithstanding paragraphs 602.114(a) and 602.115(a), an aircraft may be operated in VFR OTT flight during the cruise portion of the flight during the day if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated at a vertical distance from cloud of at least 1,000 feet;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated between two cloud layers, the vertical distance between the layers is at least 5,000 feet;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: flight visibility at the cruising altitude of the aircraft is at least five miles; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the weather at the aerodrome of destination is forecast to have a sky condition of scattered cloud or clear and a ground visibility of five miles or greater with no forecast of precipitation, fog, thunderstorms or blowing snow, and those conditions are forecast to exist

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where the forecast is an aerodrome forecast (TAF), for the period from one hour before to two hours after the estimated time of arrival; and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where an aerodrome forecast (TAF) is not available and the forecast is an area forecast (FA), for the period from one hour before to three hours after the estimated time of arrival.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding paragraph 602.114(b), an aircraft may be operated in special VFR flight within a control zone if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: weather conditions preclude compliance with paragraph 602.114(b);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: flight visibility is not less than

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: one mile, where the aircraft is not a helicopter, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: one-half mile, where the aircraft is a helicopter;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated clear of cloud and with visual reference to the surface at all times; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: authorization to do so has been requested and obtained from the appropriate air traffic control unit.

Subsection.Text: Where aerodrome traffic permits, an air traffic control unit shall authorize a pilot-in-command to operate an aircraft in special VFR flight within a control zone if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command requests authorization to operate the aircraft in special VFR flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when reported, ground visibility within the control zone is not less than

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: one mile, where the aircraft is not a helicopter, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: one-half mile, where the aircraft is a helicopter;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with radiocommunication equipment capable of maintaining communication with the appropriate air traffic control unit; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is not a helicopter and is operated during the night, and the authorization is for the purpose of allowing the aircraft to land at the destination aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: No pilot-in-command shall operate an aircraft in IMC in any class of airspace, except in accordance with IFR.

No pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall conduct an IFR flight within controlled airspace unless the aircraft is operated in accordance with an air traffic control clearance pursuant to section 602.31.
