Section.Text: Except as otherwise authorized by the Minister in an air operator certificate or in a special authorization issued under subsection 604.05(2), no pilot-in-command shall operate an aircraft in IFR flight unless the IFR flight plan or IFR flight itinerary that has been filed for the flight under section 602.73 includes an alternate aerodrome having a landing area suitable for use by that aircraft.

No pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall include an alternate aerodrome in an IFR flight plan or IFR flight itinerary unless available weather information indicates that the ceiling and visibility at the alternate aerodrome will, at the expected time of arrival, be at or above the alternate aerodrome weather minima specified in the Canada Air Pilot.

Heading.TitleText: Minimum Altitudes to Ensure Obstacle Clearance

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall, except when taking off or landing, or when being radar-vectored by an air traffic control unit, ensure that the aircraft is operated at or above

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the MOCA, when the aircraft is on an airway or air route; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum altitude established by the Minister to ensure obstacle clearance and specified on an IFR chart, when the aircraft is within airspace in respect of which such a minimum altitude has been established.

Subsection.Text: When an aircraft referred to in subsection (1) is not being operated on an airway or air route or within airspace in respect of which a minimum altitude referred to in paragraph (1)(b) has been established, the pilot-in-command shall ensure that the aircraft is operated at or above

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an altitude of 1,000 feet above the highest obstacle located within a horizontal distance of five nautical miles from the estimated position of the aircraft in flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a region designated as a mountainous region in the Designated Airspace Handbook and identified therein as area 1 or 5, an altitude of 2,000 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal distance of five nautical miles from the estimated position of the aircraft in flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a region designated as a mountainous region in the Designated Airspace Handbook and identified therein as area 2, 3 or 4, an altitude of 1,500 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal distance of five nautical miles from the estimated position of the aircraft in flight.

Subsection.Text: If aviation safety would be at risk as a result of the presence of obstacles to air navigation, the Minister may issue a NOTAM that establishes a higher minimum altitude requirement than that referred to in subsection (1) or (2).

The pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall transmit position reports over compulsory reporting points specified on an IFR chart unless advised by the appropriate air traffic control unit that the aircraft is radar-identified.
A position report transmitted pursuant to subsection (1) shall contain the information specified by the Minister in the Canada Flight Supplement.
No pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall conduct a take-off if the take-off visibility, as determined in accordance with subsection (2), is below the minimum take-off visibility specified in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator certificate where the aircraft is operated in accordance with Part VII;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a special authorization issued under subsection 604.05(2); or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Canada Air Pilot in any case other than a case described in paragraph (a) or (b).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the take-off visibility is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the RVR of the runway, if the RVR is reported to be at or above the minimum take-off visibility specified in a document or the manual referred to in subsection (1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ground visibility of the aerodrome for the runway, if the RVR

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is reported to be less than the minimum take-off visibility specified in a document or the manual referred to in subsection (1),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is reported to vary between distances less than and greater than the minimum take-off visibility specified in the Canada Air Pilot or a certificate referred to in subsection (1), or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is not reported; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the runway visibility as observed by the pilot-in-command, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the RVR is not reported, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ground visibility of the aerodrome is not reported.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise authorized by the appropriate air traffic control unit, the pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall, when conducting an approach to an aerodrome or a runway, ensure that the approach is made in accordance with the instrument approach procedure.

No pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall commence an instrument approach procedure unless the aircraft altimeter is set to an altimeter setting that is usable at the aerodrome where the approach is to be conducted.
No pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall conduct an instrument approach procedure except in accordance with the minima specified in the Canada Air Pilot or the Restricted Canada Air Pilot.
No pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall, unless the required visual reference necessary to continue the approach to land has been established,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a CAT I or CAT II precision approach, continue the final approach descent below the decision height; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a non-precision approach, descend below the minimum descent altitude.

Subsection.Text: Where the pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft conducting an instrument approach does not establish the required visual reference referred to in subsection (2), the pilot-in-command shall initiate a missed approach procedure

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a CAT I or CAT II precision approach, at decision height; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a non-precision approach, at the missed approach point.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding anything in this Division, no pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall conduct a precision approach to CAT II or CAT III minima unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight crew has received the training specified in the Manual of All Weather Operations (Categories II and III); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated in accordance with the procedures, the equipment requirements and the limitations specified in the manual referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of aircraft operated under Part VII.
For the purposes of subsection (4), the RVR with respect to an aeroplane is less than the minimum RVR if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR measured by RVR “A” for the runway of intended approach is less than 1,200 feet or the RVR measured by RVR “B” for the runway of intended approach is less than 600 feet; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by only one of RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR for the runway of intended approach is less than 1,200 feet.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (4), the RVR with respect to a helicopter is less than the minimum RVR if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR measured by RVR “A” for the surface of intended approach is less than 1,200 feet; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by only one of RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR for the surface of intended approach is less than 1,200 feet.

Subsection.Text: Where the RVR is reported to be less than the minimum RVR set out in subsection (2) or (3), as applicable, no person shall continue an instrument approach in an IFR aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the time the RVR report is received, the aircraft has passed the FAF inbound or, where there is no FAF, the point where the final approach course is intercepted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is on a training flight where a landing is not intended and the appropriate air traffic control unit is informed that a missed approach procedure will be initiated at or above the decision height or minimum descent altitude, as appropriate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the RVR is varying between distances less than and greater than the minimum RVR;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the RVR is less than the minimum RVR, and the ground visibility at the aerodrome where the runway is located is reported to be at least one quarter of a mile; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command of the aircraft is conducting a precision approach to CAT III minima.

Subsection.Text: No pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft shall commence a non-precision approach, an APV or a CAT I or CAT II precision approach to an airport where low-visibility procedures are in effect.
This section does not apply in respect of aircraft operated under Part VII.

No person shall continue a CAT III precision approach in an IFR aircraft beyond the FAF inbound or, where there is no FAF, the point where the final approach course is intercepted, unless the RVR reported is equal to or greater than the minimum RVR specified in the Canada Air Pilot in respect of the runway or surface of intended approach for the instrument approach procedure conducted.
When no reading from RVR “A” or RVR “B” for the runway of intended approach is available, runway visibility is assessed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by a pilot holding an instrument rating and in the manner set out in section 622.131 of Standard 622 — Pilot Assessment of Runway Visibility Standards of the General Operating and Flight Rules Standards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by a person qualified in accordance with section 804.26 and in the manner set out in section 804.25.

Subsection.Text: The assessment of runway visibility is valid only for a period of 20 minutes after it is established.

Section.Text: English and French are the languages of aeronautical radiocommunication in Canada.

Heading.TitleText: Locations Where Services Are Available in English and French

Subsection.Text: Any person operating an aircraft who wishes to receive the services referred to in this section in one of either English or French shall so indicate to the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station by means of an initial radiocommunication in English or French, as appropriate.
Every flight service station set out in Table 1 to this section and every air traffic control unit set out in Table 3 to this section shall provide advisory services in English and French.
Every air traffic control unit set out in Table 3 to this section shall provide air traffic services in English and French.
Every temporary air traffic control unit located in the province of Quebec shall provide air traffic services in English and French.

Every flight service station set out in Table 2 to this section shall provide, between any person operating an aircraft and any air traffic control unit set out in Table 3 to this section, a relay service of IFR air traffic control messages in English or French, as indicated by that person.

Heading.Label: TABLE 1
Heading.TitleText: FLIGHT SERVICE STATIONS WHERE ADVISORY SERVICES ARE AVAILABLE IN ENGLISH AND FRENCH

Heading.Label: TABLE 2
Heading.TitleText: FLIGHT SERVICE STATIONS WHERE RELAY SERVICES OF IFR AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL MESSAGES ARE AVAILABLE IN ENGLISH AND FRENCH

Heading.Label: TABLE 3
Heading.TitleText: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL UNITS WHERE ADVISORY SERVICES AND AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL SERVICES ARE AVAILABLE IN ENGLISH AND FRENCH
Locations Where Services Are Available in English

Section.Text: All air traffic control units and flight service stations shall provide aeronautical radiocommunication services in English.
Subject to sections 602.137 and 602.138, where an aircraft is equipped with radiocommunication equipment, the pilot-in-command shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a listening watch is maintained on the appropriate frequency; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where communications are required, communication is established with an air traffic control unit, flight service station or community aerodrome radio station, as applicable, on that appropriate frequency.

Heading.TitleText: Two-way Radiocommunication Failure in IFR Flight

Subsection.Text: Where there is a two-way radiocommunication failure between the controlling air traffic control unit and an IFR aircraft that is in or has received a clearance to enter controlled airspace, the pilot-in-command shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain a listening watch on the appropriate frequency for control messages or further clearance and acknowledge receipt of any such messages, if possible, by any means available;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set the transponder to code 7600; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: attempt to establish communications with any air traffic services facility or other aircraft, inform the facility or aircraft of the difficulty and request it to relay the information to the last air traffic control unit with which communications had been established.

Subsection.Text: Where communications cannot be established with any air traffic services facility, either directly or by relay through an intermediary, the pilot-in-command shall, except where specific instructions to cover an anticipated communications failure have been received from an air traffic control unit, comply with the procedures specified by the Minister in the Canada Air Pilot and the Canada Flight Supplement.

Heading.TitleText: Two-way Radiocommunication Failure in VFR Flight

Section.Text: Where there is a two-way radiocommunication failure between the controlling air traffic control unit and a VFR aircraft while operating in Class B, Class C or Class D airspace, the pilot-in-command shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: leave the airspace

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where the airspace is a control zone, by landing at the aerodrome for which the control zone is established, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any other case, by the shortest route;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is equipped with a transponder, set the transponder to code 7600; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: inform an air traffic control unit as soon as possible of the actions taken pursuant to paragraph (a).

Heading.TitleText: Division IX — Emergency Communications and Security

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft equipped with two-way VHF radiocommunication equipment unless the equipment is capable of providing communication on VHF frequency 121.5 MHz.

Heading.TitleText: Interception Signals, Interception of Aircraft and Instructions to Land

Subsection.Text: No person shall give an interception signal or an instruction to land except

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a peace officer, an officer of a police authority or an officer of the Canadian Forces acting within the scope of their duties; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person authorized to do so by the Minister pursuant to subsection (2).

Subsection.Text: The Minister may authorize a person to give an interception signal or an instruction to land if such authorization is in the public interest and is not likely to affect aviation safety.

The pilot-in-command of an aircraft who receives an instruction to land from a person referred to in subsection (1) shall, subject to any direction received from an air traffic control unit, comply with the instruction.
The pilot-in-command of an intercepting aircraft and the pilot-in-command of an intercepted aircraft shall comply with the rules of interception set out in the Canada Flight Supplement.
This section applies in respect of aircraft before entering into and while operating within the ADIZ, the dimensions of which are specified in the Designated Airspace Handbook.
Every flight plan or flight itinerary required to be filed pursuant to this section shall be filed with an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station.

The pilot-in-command of an aircraft whose point of departure within the ADIZ or last point of departure before entering the ADIZ has facilities for the transmission of flight plan or flight itinerary information shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before take-off, file a flight plan or flight itinerary;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a VFR aircraft where the point of departure is outside the ADIZ,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: indicate in the flight plan or flight itinerary the estimated time and point of ADIZ entry, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: as soon as possible after take-off, communicate by radio to an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station a position report of the aircraft’s location, altitude, aerodrome of departure and estimated time and point of ADIZ entry; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a VFR aircraft where the point of departure is within the ADIZ, as soon as possible after take-off, communicate by radio to an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station a position report of the aircraft’s location, altitude and aerodrome of departure.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft whose point of departure within the ADIZ or last point of departure before entering the ADIZ does not have facilities for the transmission of flight plan or flight itinerary information shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as possible after take-off, file by radiocommunication a flight plan or flight itinerary; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a VFR aircraft, indicate in the flight plan or flight itinerary the estimated time and point of ADIZ entry, if applicable.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of a VFR aircraft shall revise the estimated time and point of ADIZ entry and inform an air traffic control unit, a flight service station or a community aerodrome radio station, when the aircraft is not expected to arrive

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within plus or minus five minutes of the estimated time at

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a reporting point,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the point of ADIZ entry, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the point of destination within the ADIZ; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within 20 nautical miles of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the estimated point of ADIZ entry, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the centre line of the route of flight indicated in the flight plan or flight itinerary.

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of aircraft before entering into and while operating within Canadian domestic airspace or the ADIZ.
The pilot-in-command of an aircraft referred to in subsection (1) who is notified by an air traffic control unit of the implementation of the ESCAT Plan shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before take-off, obtain approval for the flight from the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: comply with any instruction to land or to change course or altitude that is received from the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide the appropriate air traffic control unit or flight service station with position reports

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when operating within controlled airspace, as required pursuant to section 602.125, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when operating outside controlled airspace, at least every 30 minutes.

Heading.TitleText: Division X — Noise Emission Levels for Subsonic Turbo-Jet Aeroplanes

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a subsonic turbo-jet aeroplane that has a maximum certificated take-off weight of 34 000 kg (74,956 pounds) or more to or from an aerodrome other than Gander International Airport unless the aeroplane meets the noise emission standards set out in Chapter 3 or 4 of Volume I, Aircraft Noise, of Annex 16 to the Convention.
For the purpose of subsection (1), the following expressions, used in Annex 16 to the Convention, have the following meanings:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: aeroplane has the same meaning as in subsection 101.01(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: maximum certificated take-off mass has the same meaning as maximum certificated take-off weight in subsection 101.01(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subsonic jet has the same meaning as subsonic turbo-jet aeroplane in subsection (1).

Heading.TitleText: Certification Requirements for Special Aviation Events

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a special aviation event unless the person complies with the provisions of a special flight operations certificate — special aviation event issued by the Minister pursuant to section 603.02.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Special Aviation Event

Section.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by and within the time limits specified in the Special Flight Operations Standards, issue a special flight operations certificate-special aviation event to an applicant who demonstrates to the Minister the ability to conduct a special aviation event in accordance with the Special Flight Operations Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Contents of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Special Aviation Event

Section.Text: A special flight operations certificate — special aviation event shall contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the certificate holder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the validity period of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the general conditions identified in section 603.04; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: specific conditions with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the types of aircraft authorized to operate at the special aviation event and, if applicable, their registration,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the names and, if applicable, the qualifications of the flight crew members authorized to participate in the special aviation event, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other condition pertaining to the special aviation event that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: General Conditions of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Special Aviation Event

Section.Text: A special flight operations certificate — special aviation event shall contain the following general conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the certificate holder shall maintain an adequate management organization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the certificate holder shall ensure that participants are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: qualified for the type of demonstration to be flown, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: provided with a briefing that meets the Special Flight Operations Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the certificate holder shall conduct the special aviation event in a safe manner.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a special aviation event unless the person has a management organization that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is capable of exercising supervision and operational control over

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: persons attending the special aviation event,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any flight that is to be operated at the special aviation event; and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: personnel involved in the conduct of the special aviation event whose duties and responsibilities are specified in the Special Flight Operations Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the Special Flight Operations Standards.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft or permit an aircraft to be operated in a special aviation event unless the person operating the aircraft and the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the eligibility requirements specified in section 623.06 of the Special Flight Operations Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are authorized to do so in a special flight operations certificate-special aviation event.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft in a special aviation event at a distance from, or at an altitude above, a spectator area, a built-up area or an occupied building if that distance or altitude is less than the minimum specified in section 623.07 of the Special Flight Operations Standards.
No person shall operate an aircraft in a special aviation event in weather conditions that are below the minimum conditions specified in the Special Flight Operations Standards.
No person shall operate an aircraft in a special aviation event unless the person has received a participant briefing that meets the Special Flight Operations Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Division II — Balloons with Fare-paying Passengers

Section.Text: This Division applies in respect of the operation of a balloon where fare-paying passengers are carried on board.

No person shall operate a balloon under this Division unless the person complies with the provisions of a special flight operations certificate — balloons issued by the Minister pursuant to section 603.18.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Balloons

Section.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by the Special Flight Operations Standards, issue a special flight operations certificate — balloons to an applicant who demonstrates to the Minister the ability to conduct the flight operation in accordance with the Special Flight Operations Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Contents of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Balloons

Section.Text: A special flight operations certificate — balloons shall contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the balloon operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the general conditions identified in section 603.20; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: specific conditions with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the types and AX class of balloons authorized and, where the balloon is of a special shape or is a foreign-registered balloon, its registration,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the external carriage of passengers, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other condition pertaining to the operation that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: General Conditions of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Balloons

Section.Text: A special flight operations certificate — balloons shall contain the following general conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the balloon operator shall maintain balloons that are properly equipped for the area of operation and the type of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the balloon operator shall maintain its balloons in accordance with the requirements of Subpart 5;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the balloon operator shall employ flight crew members who meet the Special Flight Operations Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the balloon operator shall conduct a safe operation.

Section.Text: No balloon operator shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as the pilot-in-command of a balloon unless the person meets the qualification and currency requirements set out in the Special Flight Operations Standards.
The pilot-in-command of a balloon shall ensure that passengers are given a safety briefing that meets the Special Flight Operations Standards.
No person shall operate a balloon in free flight at night unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the balloon is equipped in accordance with section 605.19; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: landings are conducted during the day.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a balloon in tethered flight with passengers on board unless the pilot-in-command is on board.
The pilot-in-command shall record all time spent in tethered flight as air time for the purpose of maintenance.

Section.Text: No person shall operate a balloon with passengers on board unless each passenger is carried in the basket.
This Division applies in respect of the conduct of parachute descents

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in or into controlled airspace or an air route; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: over or into a built-up area or open-air assembly of persons.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 602.26, a pilot-in-command may permit and a person may conduct a parachute descent under this Division if the person complies with the provisions of a special flight operations certificate — parachuting issued by the Minister pursuant to section 603.38.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Parachuting

Section.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by the Special Flight Operations Standards, issue a special flight operations certificate — parachuting to an applicant who demonstrates to the Minister the ability to conduct the flight operation in accordance with the Special Flight Operations Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Contents of Special Flight Operations Certificate — Parachuting

Section.Text: A special flight operations certificate — parachuting shall contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the certificate holder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the validity period of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the type of flight operation authorized; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any condition pertaining to the operation that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: Division IV — Miscellaneous Special Flight Operations

Section.Text: This Division applies in respect of the following flight operations when not conducted under Part VII:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of an aircraft, other than a balloon, for the purpose of conducting a take-off or landing within a built-up area of a city or town at a place other than an airport, heliport or military aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of an aircraft for the purpose of conducting aerial application, aerial inspection or aerial photography at altitudes and distances less than those specified in paragraph 602.14(2)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of a helicopter while conducting Class B, C or D external load operations over a built-up area or open-air assembly of persons, including flight at altitudes and distances less than those specified in paragraph 602.14(2)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of an unmanned air vehicle;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of a powered aircraft while persons enter or, except for parachute descents, leave the aircraft in flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of an aircraft while conducting aerobatic manoeuvres

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in or into controlled airspace or an air route, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: below 2,000 feet AGL.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a flight operation referred to in section 603.65 unless the person complies with the provisions of a special flight operations certificate issued by the Minister pursuant to section 603.67.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of Special Flight Operations Certificate

Section.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by the Special Flight Operations Standards, issue a special flight operations certificate to an applicant who demonstrates to the Minister the ability to conduct the flight operation in accordance with the Special Flight Operations Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Contents of Special Flight Operations Certificate

Section.Text: A special flight operations certificate shall contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the certificate holder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the validity period of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the type of flight operation authorized; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any condition pertaining to the operation that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in this Subpart.

Definition.Text: main base means a location where a private operator has personnel, aircraft and facilities for its operations and that is established as the principal place of business of the private operator. (base principale)
PBN Manual means ICAO Document 9613, entitled Performance-based Navigation (PBN) Manual. (manuel PBN)

special authorization means an authorization issued by the Minister under subsection 604.05(2) that permits the carrying out of an activity referred to in Division IV or an activity in respect of which the Minister has established requirements under subsection 604.74(1). (autorisation spéciale)

sub-base means a location where a private operator has personnel and aircraft and from which operational control is exercised in accordance with the private operator’s operational control system. (base secondaire)

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of interpreting a document incorporated by reference into this Subpart, unless the context requires otherwise,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: “should” and “must” shall be read as “shall”;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: “operator” and “aircraft operator” shall be read as “private operator”; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: “authority”, “competent aviation authority” and “operating authority” shall be read as “Minister”.

Section.Text: This Subpart applies to the following Canadian aircraft:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: large aeroplanes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: turbine-powered aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: pressurized aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: multi-engined aircraft.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall operate any of the following Canadian aircraft for the purpose of transporting passengers or goods unless the person is the holder of a private operator registration document:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a large aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a turbine-powered pressurized aeroplane certificated for more than six passenger seats.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to the operation of an aircraft referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) to (c) by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an air operator who operates the aircraft in accordance with the requirements of Part VII; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who operates the aircraft under a flight permit issued under section 507.04.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance of a Private Operator Registration Document

Subsection.Text: The applicant for a private operator registration document shall submit to the Minister an application containing the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s legal name and, if any, trade name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the operations manager, chief pilot and maintenance manager;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the proposed area of operation, using the chart depicted in the Index to Application of Supplementary Procedures in ICAO Document 7030, entitled Regional Supplementary Procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the applicant’s main base and, if any, sub-bases; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for each aircraft that will be operated, the aircraft type, the nationality mark and the registration mark.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall, on receipt of the application referred to in subsection (1), issue a private operator registration document to the applicant if the applicant is the registered owner of all the aircraft that will be operated under this Subpart or is permitted to use those aircraft under section 203.03.
A private operator who wishes to operate an aircraft under a special authorization shall submit to the Minister an application that

Paragraph.Label: a)
Paragraph.Text: identifies the activity referred to in Division IV that the applicant wishes to carry out; and

Paragraph.Label: b)
Paragraph.Text: includes a copy of the part of the private operator’s operations manual that sets out the processes, practices and procedures relating to the special authorization requested.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall, on receipt of the application referred to in subsection (1), issue a special authorization to the applicant if the applicant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holds a private operator registration document;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is able to meet the requirements of Division IV relating to the special authorization requested; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has an operations manual that sets out the processes, practices and procedures that are necessary to meet the requirements of Division IV relating to the special authorization requested.

Section.Text: A private operator shall notify the Minister if a change is made to the information contained in an application submitted under subsection 604.04(1) within ten days after the day on which the change is made.

Heading.TitleText: Amendment of Private Operator’s Operations Manual

Section.Text: A private operator who has been issued a special authorization, and who amends the part of the private operator’s operations manual that sets out the processes, practices and procedures relating to the special authorization, shall submit to the Minister a copy of that part of the operations manual within ten days after the day on which the amendment is made.
A private operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that no person is appointed operations manager or chief pilot or continues to serve as operations manager or chief pilot if, at the time of the person’s appointment or during the person’s tenure, the person has a record of conviction for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an offence under section 7.3 of the Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: two or more offences under these Regulations that did not arise from a single incident;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that no person is appointed maintenance manager or continues to serve as maintenance manager if, at the time of the person’s appointment or during the person’s tenure, the person has a record of conviction for an offence under section 7.3 of the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the operations manager performs the duties set out in section 604.204;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: perform the duties set out in section 604.208; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: provide the operations manager and the maintenance manager with the financial and human resources necessary to ensure that the private operator meets the requirements of these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: No operations manager, no chief pilot and no maintenance manager shall assign to another person a management function for which he or she is responsible and accountable unless the private operator’s operations manual

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identifies the functions that may be assigned;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identifies either by name or by position the persons to whom those functions may be assigned; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: describes the scope of the assignment.

Subsection.Text: The responsibility and accountability of an operations manager, a chief pilot and a maintenance manager are not affected by the assignment of a management function to another person under subsection (1).

A private operator shall have an operational control system that is adapted to the complexity of the private operator’s operations and to the private operator’s area of operation, and that meets the requirements of subsections (2) and (3).
The operational control system shall include procedures for ensuring that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all the operational requirements specified in this Subpart are met;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each aircraft is operated within the weight and balance limits specified in the aircraft flight manual;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the persons on board an aircraft are recorded by the private operator before each flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: search and rescue authorities are notified in a timely manner if a flight is overdue or missing.

Subsection.Text: The operational control system shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: pilot self-dispatch procedures that set out the following elements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: flight planning requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the timing within which a flight crew member must inform the private operator of an aircraft’s departure and arrival, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a method of confirming that an aircraft has arrived safely at an unattended aerodrome during a VFR flight or that an IFR flight plan has been cancelled prior to landing; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: co-authority dispatch procedures that set out the following elements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: flight planning requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: flight following requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: flight watch requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a method of confirming that an aircraft has arrived safely at an unattended aerodrome during a VFR flight or that an IFR flight plan has been cancelled prior to landing,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the method by which the operational flight plan is approved and recorded by the pilot-in-command and the flight dispatcher,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: if operational flight plans are prepared and accepted for a series of flights, the method by which any changes to those plans are approved and recorded by the pilot-in-command and the flight dispatcher,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: if flight planning and flight watch are two separate functions, the method of switching from one to the other, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: a means to ensure that, at each location where a flight originates, the pilot-in-command will

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: receive meteorological information related to the flight,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: receive a copy of the operational flight plan, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: can contact the responsible flight dispatcher prior to take-off.

Subsection.Text: Documentation related to the operational control of a flight shall be retained by the private operator for at least 180 days after the day on which the flight is completed.
A private operator shall designate, for each flight, a pilot-in-command or, if the crew includes two or more flight crew members, a pilot-in-command and a second-in-command.

The private operator shall record the name of the pilot-in-command and, if applicable, second-in-command designated for each flight under subsection (1) and shall retain the record for at least 180 days after the day on which the flight is completed.

Section.Text: A flight dispatcher and a flight follower shall, in respect of a flight conducted by a private operator,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: perform flight following and flight watch;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide any operational information requested by a flight crew member; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: notify search and rescue authorities in a timely manner if a flight is overdue or missing.

Section.Text: No person shall, in an aircraft operated by a private operator, conduct a landing following an instrument approach unless, immediately before landing, the pilot-in-command ascertains, by means of radiocommunication or visual inspection,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the condition of the runway or surface of intended landing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the wind direction and speed.

Subsection.Text: A private operator shall provide every crew member with the checklist referred to in paragraph 602.60(1)(a) or with the part of the checklist that is necessary for the performance of the crew member’s duties.
Every crew member shall follow, in the performance of his or her duties, the checklist or part of the checklist referred to in subsection (1).
A private operator may establish an aircraft operating manual for the operation of its aircraft.
An aircraft operating manual shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contain aircraft operating procedures that are consistent with those contained in the aircraft flight manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contain, if the aircraft flight manual is not carried on board the aircraft, the aircraft performance data and limitations specified in that manual, and clearly identify them as aircraft flight manual requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: contain the private operator’s standard operating procedures, if any; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: identify the aircraft to which it relates.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator unless an operational flight data sheet has been prepared and contains the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft’s nationality mark and registration mark;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the pilot-in-command;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the departure aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the destination aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the alternate aerodrome, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated flight time;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the fuel endurance;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the weight of the fuel on board the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the zero fuel weight of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the take-off weight and centre of gravity of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the number of persons on board the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the proposed time of departure; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated time of arrival.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft referred to in subsection (1) shall, on the completion of each flight, record on the operational flight data sheet the flight time, time of departure, time of arrival and aerodrome of arrival.
The private operator shall retain a copy of the operational flight data sheet for at least 180 days after the day on which the flight is completed.

Heading.TitleText: Division IV — Flight Operations — Special Authorizations
Minimum Performance Capability of Long-range Navigation Systems

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Division, a long-range navigation system shall have the following performance capability:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the standard deviation of the lateral track deviations is less than 6.3 nautical miles;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the proportion of the total flight time that is spent by the aircraft at a distance of 30 or more nautical miles from the cleared track is less than 5.3 x 10-4; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the proportion of the total flight time that is spent by the aircraft at a distance of 50 to 70 nautical miles from the cleared track is less than 1.3 x 10-4.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Division, a global navigation satellite system (GNSS) receiver is considered to be a long-range navigation system if it is installed in accordance with the requirements of Advisory Circular 20-138B, entitled Airworthiness Approval of Positioning and Navigation Systems, dated September 27, 2010 and published by the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States, as amended from time to time.

Subject to subsection (2), no person shall carry out any activity referred to in this Division or in respect of which the Minister has established requirements under subsection 604.74(1) unless that person is a private operator.
A person other than a private operator may conduct an instrument approach using a GNSS receiver to the following minima:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: lateral navigation (LNAV);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: lateral navigation/vertical navigation (LNAV/VNAV);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: localizer performance without vertical guidance (LP); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: localizer performance with vertical guidance (LPV).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 602.122, a pilot-in-command may conduct an IFR flight in an aircraft operated by a private operator when an alternate aerodrome has not been designated in the IFR flight plan or in the IFR flight itinerary if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized to do so under a special authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated flight time is not more than six hours and the departure aerodrome is located in North America, Bermuda or the Caribbean islands;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the forecast or reported weather at the destination aerodrome, from one hour before until one hour after the estimated time of arrival, does not include

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: conditions, including fog or precipitation, that restrict flight visibility to less than three miles,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a thunderstorm,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a ceiling of less than 1,000 feet above the FAF altitude and a ground visibility of less than three miles,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a ceiling of less than 1,500 feet above the minimum descent altitude and a ground visibility of less than six miles, or

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: freezing rain, freezing drizzle or sleet;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the destination aerodrome

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has at least two runways that are

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: operational,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: separate and not reciprocal directions of the same runway, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: suitable for the aircraft on the basis of the aircraft operating procedures, the aircraft performance data and limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual, and the factors that affect the performance of the aircraft, such as atmospheric and surface conditions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is equipped with an emergency electrical power supply to operate the equipment and facilities that are essential for a safe landing of the aircraft in the event of a failure of the main electrical power supply; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received training, for which the validity period has not expired, in the conduct of an IFR flight when an alternate aerodrome has not been designated in the IFR flight plan or in the IFR flight itinerary.

Subsection.Text: If the requirements of paragraphs (1)(a) to (e) are met, and regardless of the departure aerodrome, the pilot-in-command of an aircraft that is operated by a private operator, and that is on a flight to a destination aerodrome in Canada, may file a new IFR flight plan or a new IFR flight itinerary that does not include an alternate aerodrome when the aircraft is within six hours’ flight time of the destination aerodrome.

Section.Text: For the purposes of paragraph 602.126(1)(b),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a pilot-in-command may conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator when the reported RVR is at least 1,200 feet or the reported ground visibility is at least one quarter of a statute mile if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator is authorized to do so under a special authorization,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft is operated by at least two flight crew members,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the flight plan filed for the flight specifies a take-off alternate aerodrome that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in the case of a twin-engined aircraft, is within the distance that can be flown in 60 minutes at normal cruising speed, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in the case of an aircraft with three or more engines, is within the distance that can be flown in 120 minutes at normal cruising speed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command and, if the operations manual provides that the second-in-command may conduct the take-off, the second-in-command have received the following training for which the validity period has not expired:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: take-off alternate aerodrome requirements,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: pilot-in-command experience requirements,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: pilot-in-command responsibility for visibility and obstacle clearance requirements, and

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: minimum aircraft and runway equipment requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: identifies any obstructions that may be in the take-off path,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: determines — using the aircraft performance data and limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual — that the aircraft is, with the critical engine inoperative, able to

Subclause.Label: (II)
Subclause.Text: maintain at least the minimum enroute altitude to the take-off alternate aerodrome, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: verifies that the RVR is at least 1,200 feet or the ground visibility is at least one quarter of a statute mile,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the runway is equipped with high-intensity runway lights, or runway centre line lights, that are serviceable and functioning and that are visible to the pilot throughout the take-off run, or with runway centre line markings that are visible to the pilot throughout the take-off run,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command and second-in-command attitude indicators provide a clear depiction of total aircraft attitude that includes the incorporation of pitch attitude index lines in appropriate increments up to 15° above and 15° below the reference line,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: failure warning systems to immediately detect failures and malfunctions in attitude indicators, directional gyros and horizontal situation indicators are operative, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command and, if the operations manual provides that the second-in-command may conduct the take-off, the second-in-command have demonstrated to the private operator the ability to operate the aircraft in accordance with this paragraph; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a pilot-in-command may conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator when the reported RVR is at least 600 feet if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator is authorized to do so under a special authorization,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft is operated by at least two flight crew members,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the flight plan filed for the flight specifies a take-off alternate aerodrome that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in the case of a twin-engined aircraft, is within the distance that can be flown in 60 minutes at normal cruising speed, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in the case of an aircraft with three or more engines, is within the distance that can be flown in 120 minutes at normal cruising speed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command and, if the operations manual provides that the second-in-command may conduct the take-off, the second-in-command have received the following training for which the validity period has not expired:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: ground training in

Subclause.Label: (III)
Subclause.Text: pilot-in-command responsibility for visibility and obstacle clearance requirements, and

Subclause.Label: (IV)
Subclause.Text: minimum aircraft and runway equipment requirements, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: level C or D flight simulator training that includes

Subclause.Label: (I)
Subclause.Text: one completed take-off at an RVR of 600 feet, and

Subclause.Label: (II)
Subclause.Text: one rejected take-off, at an RVR of 600 feet, that includes an engine failure,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: identifies any obstructions that may be in the take-off path,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: determines — using the aircraft performance data and limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual — that the aircraft is, with the critical engine inoperative, able to

Subclause.Label: (II)
Subclause.Text: maintain at least the minimum enroute altitude to the take-off alternate aerodrome, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: verifies that the RVR is at least 600 feet,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the runway is equipped

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: with high-intensity runway lights, and runway centre line lights, that are serviceable and functioning and that are visible to the pilot throughout the take-off run, and with runway centre line markings that are visible to the pilot throughout the take-off run, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: with two RVR sensors that each show an RVR of at least 600 feet, one sensor being situated at the approach end of the runway and the other at

Subclause.Label: (I)
Subclause.Text: the mid-point of the runway, or

Subclause.Label: (II)
Subclause.Text: the departure end of the runway, if the runway is equipped with three RVR sensors and the sensor situated at the mid-point is not serviceable,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command and second-in-command attitude indicators provide a clear depiction of total aircraft attitude that includes the incorporation of pitch attitude index lines in appropriate increments up to 15° above and 15° below the reference line,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: failure warning systems to immediately detect failures and malfunctions in attitude indicators, directional gyros and horizontal situation indicators are operative, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: the pilot-in-command and, if the operations manual provides that the second-in-command may conduct the take-off, the second-in-command have demonstrated to the private operator the ability to operate the aircraft in accordance with this paragraph.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct an instrument procedure using a GNSS receiver in an aircraft operated by a private operator unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized to do so under a special authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received the following training for which the validity period has not expired:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ground training in

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the GNSS and its theory of operation,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the operation of the model of GNSS receiver that will be used, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the actions to be taken in response to GNSS receiver warnings and messages, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in-flight training

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in the operation of the model of GNSS receiver that will be used,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in the actions to be taken in response to GNSS receiver warnings and messages,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: in the use of the GNSS receiver for instrument procedures and other associated duties for each crew position that the flight crew member will occupy,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: provided

Subclause.Label: (II)
Subclause.Text: using a Level C or D flight simulator equipped with the same model of GNSS receiver as is installed in the private operator’s aircraft or with a model with a user interface comparable to the user interface of that GNSS receiver, and

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: provided by a pilot who has received training on the same model of GNSS receiver as is installed in the private operator’s aircraft or on a model with a user interface comparable to the user interface of that GNSS receiver;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has demonstrated to the private operator the ability to conduct an instrument approach using a GNSS receiver in accordance with this section;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the coverage area of the GNSS receiver database is compatible with the area of operation in which the aircraft will be operated;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator has established procedures to ensure that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the GNSS receiver database is updated so that it remains current,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: flight crew members who identify GNSS receiver database errors communicate those errors to the private operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the GNSS receiver database errors identified are communicated to the private operator’s other personnel and to the GNSS receiver database provider;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the aircraft is designed to be operated by one flight crew member, the GNSS course deviation and distance displays are located at the pilot station normally occupied by the pilot-in-command and within the primary field of vision of the flight crew member who occupies the pilot station;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the aircraft is designed to be operated by two flight crew members, the GNSS course deviation and distance displays are located at each pilot station and within the primary field of vision of the flight crew member who occupies the pilot station;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if the aircraft is designed to be operated by one flight crew member, but can be operated by two flight crew members,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the control display unit that is linked to the GNSS receiver is centrally located in relation to the two pilot stations and provides navigation information that is visible to the pilot not flying, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the GNSS course deviation and distance displays are located at each pilot station and within the primary field of vision of the flight crew members who occupy those pilot stations; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator has established GNSS approach procedures in order to prevent confusion between GNSS distance information and distance measuring equipment (DME) information.

Heading.TitleText: Precision Approaches — CAT II and CAT III

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a CAT II or a CAT III precision approach in an aircraft operated by a private operator unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized to do so under a special authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements of section 602.128 are met;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received, in respect of CAT II and CAT III precision approaches, ground training for which the validity period has not expired that includes the following elements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the characteristics, capabilities and limitations of the instrument landing system (ILS), including how its performance is affected by interference from other airborne or taxiing aircraft and from ground vehicles,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the characteristics of the visual aids and the limitations on their use in reduced visibility at the various glide path angles and cockpit cut-off angles, and the height at which visual cues are expected to appear in actual operating conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the operation, capabilities and limitations of the airborne systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures and techniques for an approach, a missed approach and a rejected landing, and a description of the factors affecting height loss during a missed approach in normal and abnormal aircraft configurations,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the use and limitations of RVR, including the applicability of RVR readings from different positions along the runway,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: obstacle limitation surfaces, obstacle-free zones, missed approach design criteria, obstacle clearance for a CAT II or CAT III precision approach, and obstacle clearance for a go-around and a rejected landing,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the effects of turbulence, precipitation and low level windshear,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures and techniques for making the transition from instrument flight to visual flight in low RVR conditions, including the geometry of eye, wheel and antenna positions in relation to ILS reference datum height,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken if the required visual reference becomes inadequate when the aircraft is below the decision height, and the technique to be used for making the transition from visual flight to instrument flight if a go-around is necessary,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a failure of the approach and landing equipment above and below the decision height or alert height,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: the recognition of a failure of the ground equipment, and the actions to be taken in the event of such a failure,

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: the factors to be taken into account in the determination of the decision height or alert height,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: the effect of aircraft malfunctions, including engine failure, on auto-throttle and auto-pilot performance,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiv)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to be followed and the precautions to be taken while taxiing in reduced visibility, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xv)
Subparagraph.Text: the standard operating procedures to be followed by crew members in normal, abnormal and emergency conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received, in respect of CAT II and CAT III precision approaches, training on a synthetic flight training device that includes the following elements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: two approaches, at least one of which is in an engine-out configuration if the aircraft is certified under Part V to perform in that configuration,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a missed approach from the lowest minima specified in the special authorization, or a rejected landing, as applicable,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an automatic landing or a manual landing from one of the approaches, as applicable, at the maximum crosswind authorized for the aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: for CAT III approaches based on the use of a fail-passive rollout control system, a manual rollout using visual references or a combination of visual and instrument references;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received, in respect of CAT II and CAT III precision approaches, training on a synthetic flight training device for which the validity period has not expired that includes the following elements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: one precision approach resulting in a landing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a missed approach from the lowest minima specified in the special authorization, or a rejected landing, as applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has demonstrated to the private operator the ability to operate the aircraft in accordance with this section.

Heading.TitleText: Instrument Procedures — Restricted Canada Air Pilot

Section.Text: No person shall, in an aircraft operated by a private operator, conduct an instrument procedure that is specified in the Restricted Canada Air Pilot for an aerodrome unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized to do so under a special authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person conducts the procedure in accordance with the requirements set out in the Restricted Canada Air Pilot in respect of the procedure; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received the training necessary to mitigate the risks or hazards associated with that procedure with respect to the safety of the aircraft, persons or property, and the validity period for that training has not expired.

Section.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated in accordance with Canadian minimum navigation performance specifications (CMNPS) or required navigation performance capability (RNPC) unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with CMNPS or RNPC;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received CMNPS or RNPC training, for which the validity period has not expired, in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: normal operating procedures, including long-range navigation system pre-flight data entry and periodic cross-checking of the system position display against the aircraft position,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the method of monitoring and cross-checking the long-range navigation system that is coupled to the auto-pilot,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a discrepancy among long-range navigation systems, and the method of determining which is the most accurate or reliable system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: contingency procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a failure of one or more long-range navigation systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedure for manually updating long-range navigation systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: airborne emergency procedures, including realignment, if applicable,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedure for regaining track after a deliberate or accidental deviation from the cleared track, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: RNAV systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with at least two independent long-range navigation systems or is operated as follows:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft equipped only with the radio navigation equipment referred to in paragraph 605.18(j), the aircraft is operated only on high level airways, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft equipped with at least two independent navigation systems, one of which is a long-range navigation system, the aircraft is operated only in RNPC airspace

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: on high level fixed RNAV routes,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: on direct routes that begin and end within the reception range of ground-based navigation aids, or

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: on high level airways.

Heading.TitleText: RNPC Requirements — High Level Fixed RNAV Routes

Section.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated on a high level fixed RNAV route in accordance with required navigation performance capability (RNPC) unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with RNPC;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received RNPC training, for which the validity period has not expired, in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: normal operating procedures, including navigation system pre-flight data entry and periodic cross-checking of the system position display against the aircraft position,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the method of monitoring and cross-checking the navigation system that is coupled to the auto-pilot,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a discrepancy among navigation systems, and the method of determining which is the most accurate or reliable system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: contingency procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a failure of one or more navigation systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedure for manually updating navigation systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: airborne emergency procedures, including realignment, if applicable,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedure for regaining track after a deliberate or accidental deviation from the cleared track, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: RNAV systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with at least two independent navigation systems, one of which is a long-range navigation system.

Subsection.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated in accordance with North Atlantic minimum navigation performance specifications (NAT-MNPS) unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with NAT-MNPS;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received NAT-MNPS training, for which the validity period has not expired, in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: normal operating procedures, including long-range navigation system pre-flight data entry and periodic cross-checking of the system position display against the aircraft position,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the method of monitoring and cross-checking the long-range navigation system that is coupled to the auto-pilot,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a discrepancy among long-range navigation systems, and the method of determining which is the most accurate or reliable system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: contingency procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a failure of one or more long-range navigation systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedure for manually updating long-range navigation systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: airborne emergency procedures, including realignment, if applicable,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedure for regaining track after a deliberate or accidental deviation from the cleared track, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: RNAV systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections (2) and (4), the aircraft is equipped with at least two independent long-range navigation systems.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate, in NAT-MNPS airspace, an aircraft operated by a private operator that is equipped with only one long-range navigation system, or that has only one functioning long-range navigation system, except on routes that are specified by the civil aviation authority of a contracting state as routes for aircraft equipped with only one long-range navigation system.
If the long-range navigation system referred to in subsection (2) is a GNSS receiver, it may be used if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian Technical Standard Order (CAN-TSO) design approval has been issued in respect of the GNSS receiver; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the GNSS receiver meets the performance requirements of Technical Standard Order TSO-C196a, Airborne Supplemental Navigation Sensors for Global Positioning System Equipment Using Aircraft-Based Augmentation, published by the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate, in NAT-MNPS airspace, an aircraft operated by a private operator that is equipped only with short-range navigation equipment (VOR, DME, ADF), except on routes G3 or G11.

Section.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated in accordance with reduced vertical separation minima (RVSM) unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with RVSM;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received RVSM training, for which the validity period has not expired, in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the floor, ceiling and horizontal boundaries of RVSM airspace,
