Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: rules on the exclusion of non-RVSM-compliant aircraft from the airspace,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to be followed by flight crew members with respect to

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: pre-flight and in-flight altimeter checks,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: use of the automatic altitude control system,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: items on the minimum equipment list,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: in-flight contingencies,

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: weather deviation procedures,

Clause.Label: (F)
Clause.Text: track offset procedures for wake turbulence,

Clause.Label: (G)
Clause.Text: inconsequential collision-avoidance systems alerts, and

Clause.Label: (H)
Clause.Text: pilot level-off call,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures relating to non-RVSM-compliant aircraft required to carry out ferry flights, humanitarian flights or delivery flights, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the use of an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS) and a Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft meets the following eligibility requirements set out in Advisory Circular 91–85, entitled Authorization of Aircraft and Operators for Flight in Reduced Vertical Separation Minimum Airspace, published by the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of aircraft performance, the requirements set out in paragraphs 8c(3), 8c(4), 8c(8), 8d and 10b(5)(d)6, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of aircraft equipment, the requirements set out in paragraphs 9a to 9d;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator meets the aircraft continued airworthiness maintenance requirements set out in paragraphs 11d, 11e and 11g of the advisory circular referred to in paragraph (c); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with a navigation system that meets the requirements set out in paragraph 1.3.3, subparagraphs 1.3.4a) and b), and paragraph 1.3.5 of NAT Doc 007, entitled Guidance Concerning Air Navigation In and Above the North Atlantic MNPS Airspace, published by ICAO.

Section.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated in accordance with required navigation performance 10 (RNP 10) requirements unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with RNP 10 requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received RNP 10 training, for which the validity period has not expired, in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: flight planning requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: navigation performance requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: enroute procedures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: contingency procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft meets one of the following eligibility requirements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft flight manual or the pilot operating handbook, or any equivalent document provided by the manufacturer of the avionics equipment or by the aircraft manufacturer, specifies that the aircraft can be operated in accordance with RNP 10 requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft can be operated in accordance with another navigation standard with performance criteria that are equivalent to RNP 10 requirements, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator has demonstrated to the Minister, using one of the data collection methods set out in section 1.3.3.1.4.2 of Chapter 1 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual, that the aircraft meets the navigational accuracy requirements for RNP 10;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with the navigation equipment referred to in sections 1.3.4 and 1.3.6.1 of Chapter 1 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment referred to in paragraph (d) meets the standards, criteria and performance requirements set out in sections 1.3.4.1, 1.3.4.2, 1.3.6.1 and 1.3.11 of Chapter 1 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator applies the processes, practices and procedures relating to the duties and practices set out in sections 1.3.7, 1.3.8 and 1.3.9.2 to 1.3.9.9 of Chapter 1 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual.

Section.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated in accordance with required navigation performance 4 (RNP 4) requirements unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with RNP 4 requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received the training referred to in paragraph 604.60(b), and the validity period for that training has not expired;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft meets one of the following eligibility requirements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft flight manual or the pilot operating handbook, or any equivalent document provided by the manufacturer of the avionics equipment or by the aircraft manufacturer, specifies that the aircraft can be operated in accordance with RNP 4 requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft can be operated in accordance with another navigation standard with performance criteria that are equivalent to RNP 4 requirements, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator has demonstrated to the Minister that the aircraft meets the navigational accuracy requirements for RNP 4;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with the navigation equipment referred to in sections 1.3.3.1 and 1.3.3.2 of Chapter 1 of Part C of Volume II of the PBN Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment referred to in paragraph (d) meets the standards, criteria and functional requirements set out in sections 1.3.3.4 to 1.3.3.7 of Chapter 1 of Part C of Volume II of the PBN Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator applies the processes, practices and procedures relating to the duties and practices set out in sections 1.3.4.2.1 to 1.3.4.4.4 and 1.3.6 of Chapter 1 of Part C of Volume II of the PBN Manual.

Section.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated in accordance with area navigation 5 (RNAV 5) requirements unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with RNAV 5 requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received the training referred to in paragraph 604.60(b) and the validity period for that training has not expired;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft meets one of the following eligibility requirements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft flight manual or the pilot operating handbook, or any equivalent document provided by the manufacturer of the avionics equipment or by the aircraft manufacturer, specifies that the aircraft can be operated in accordance with RNAV 5 requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft can be operated in accordance with another navigation standard with performance criteria that are equivalent to RNAV 5 requirements, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator has demonstrated to the Minister that the aircraft meets the navigational accuracy requirements for RNAV 5;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with at least one of the position sensors referred to in section 2.3.3 of Chapter 2 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the position sensors referred to in paragraph (d) meet the performance requirements, criteria and functional requirements set out in sections 2.3.3.1 to 2.3.3.3 of Chapter 2 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator applies the processes, practices and procedures relating to the duties and practices set out in section 2.3.4 of Chapter 2 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual.

Section.Text: No person shall file a flight plan indicating that an aircraft operated by a private operator can be operated in accordance with area navigation 1 (RNAV 1) or area navigation 2 (RNAV 2) requirements unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate the aircraft in accordance with RNAV 1 or RNAV 2 requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received RNAV 1 or RNAV 2 training, for which the validity period has not expired, in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: pre-flight procedures for initialization, loading and verification of the area navigation system,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the normal operation of the area navigation system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedure for manually updating the position of the area navigation system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the method of monitoring and cross-checking the area navigation system,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the operation of the area navigation system in a compass unreliability area,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: malfunction procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: terminal area procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: waypoint symbology, plotting procedures and record-keeping duties and practices,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: timekeeping procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: post-flight performance checks,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: flight planning,

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: navigation performance requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: enroute procedures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xiv)
Subparagraph.Text: contingency procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft meets one of the following eligibility requirements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft can be operated in accordance with precision area navigation (P-RNAV) requirements based on GNSS capability under an authorization issued by the competent authority of a contracting state,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft can be operated in accordance with area navigation (RNAV) requirements based on DME/DME or DME/DME/IRU capability under an authorization issued by the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aircraft flight manual or the pilot operating handbook, or any equivalent document provided by the manufacturer of the avionics equipment or by the aircraft manufacturer, specifies that the aircraft can be operated in accordance with RNAV 1 or RNAV 2 requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with at least one of the pieces of equipment referred to in section 3.3.3 of Chapter 3 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment referred to in paragraph (d) meets the performance requirements, criteria and functional requirements set out in sections 3.3.3.1 to 3.3.3.2.1.1 and 3.3.3.2.1.3 to 3.3.3.3 of Chapter 3 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has demonstrated to the Minister the ability to operate the aircraft in accordance with this section; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator applies the processes, practices and procedures relating to the duties and practices set out in sections 3.3.3.2.1.2, 3.3.4.2 to 3.3.4.6 and 3.3.6 of Chapter 3 of Part B of Volume II of the PBN Manual.

Heading.TitleText: Other Activities Approved by the Minister

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall establish requirements in respect of an activity that is not set out in sections 604.48 to 604.60 and in respect of which a special authorization may be issued if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the activity is subject to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: operational and technical requirements established by ICAO or by the civil aviation authority of a foreign state, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a submission to the Minister, by a private operator, an air operator or a third party, that establishes operational and technical requirements and risk mitigation measures based on an analysis of aviation-safety-related hazards;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case referred to in subparagraph (a)(i), the operational and technical requirements are necessary for the conduct of flights abroad or in Canada by private operators, and those flights can be conducted in a safe manner; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case referred to in subparagraph (a)(ii), the operational and technical requirements and risk mitigation measures ensure the safety of the flights conducted by private operators and will not have an adverse effect on aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: If the Minister establishes requirements in respect of an activity referred to in subsection (1), no person shall, in an aircraft operated by a private operator, carry out the activity unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator is authorized to carry out the activity under a special authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has received, if applicable, the training specified by the Minister under subsection (3) in respect of the activity, and the validity period for that training has not expired; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: every flight crew member has demonstrated to the Minister the ability to carry out the activity in accordance with the operational and technical requirements referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(i) or (ii), as applicable, and to take the measures that are necessary to manage or mitigate the risks associated with that activity.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall specify training in respect of an activity referred to in subsection (1) taking into account

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any training that is recommended by the civil aviation authority of a foreign state or by ICAO in respect of the activity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the risks and hazards associated with the activity with respect to the safety of the aircraft, persons or property; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the level of safety required by the activity.

Section.Text: [Reserved, SOR/2015-127, s. 11]

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft that is operated by a private operator and that has passengers on board, move the aircraft on the surface or direct that the aircraft be moved unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: safety belts are adjusted and fastened in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(a), infants are held in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(b), and persons using child restraint systems are secured in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(c);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (5), seat backs are secured in the upright position;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: chair tables are stowed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: carry-on baggage is stowed; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: no seat located at an emergency exit is occupied by a passenger — including a passenger who has not been informed as to how that exit operates — whose presence in that seat could adversely affect the safety of passengers or crew members during an evacuation.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a landing in an aircraft operated by a private operator unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: passengers have been directed to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: adjust and fasten their safety belts in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(a), hold infants in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(b), and secure persons using child restraint systems in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(c),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subject to subsection (5), secure their seat backs in the upright position,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: stow their chair tables, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: stow their carry-on baggage; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a seat located at an emergency exit is occupied by a passenger whose presence in that seat could adversely affect the safety of passengers or crew members during an evacuation, the passenger has been directed to move to another seat.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft operated by a private operator shall, in the event of an emergency and if time and circumstances permit,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: direct passengers to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: adjust and fasten their safety belts in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(a), hold infants in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(b), and secure persons using child restraint systems in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(c),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subject to subsection (5), secure their seat backs in the upright position,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: stow their chair tables,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: stow their carry-on baggage,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: review the safety features card and assume the brace position until the aircraft stops moving, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: in the event of an emergency over water, don their life preservers; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a seat located at an emergency exit is occupied by a passenger whose presence in that seat could adversely affect the safety of passengers or crew members during an evacuation, direct the passenger to move to another seat.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft operated by a private operator shall, if the “fasten safety belt” sign is turned on during the flight, direct passengers to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: adjust and fasten their safety belts in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(a), hold infants in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(b), and secure persons using child restraint systems in accordance with paragraph 605.26(1)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: stow their carry-on baggage.

Subsection.Text: The seat of a passenger who is certified by a physician as unable to sit upright may remain in the reclining position during movement on the surface, take-off and landing if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger is not seated in a location that would restrict the evacuation of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger is not seated in a row that is next to or immediately in front of an emergency exit; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the seat immediately behind the passenger’s seat is vacant.

Subsection.Text: No person operating an aircraft operated by a private operator shall permit the fuelling of the aircraft while passengers are on board or are embarking or disembarking, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in order for persons on board the aircraft to be notified promptly of a situation that could threaten their safety, two-way communication is maintained between the ground personnel supervising the fuelling and a person on board the aircraft who has received training in emergency evacuation procedures for that aircraft type;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no ground power generator or other electrical ground power supply is being connected to or disconnected from the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: no combustion heater installed on the aircraft is being used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: every combustion heater used in the vicinity of the aircraft has a marking, applied by the manufacturer, indicating that the heater is manufactured to Canadian Standards Association (CSA) or Underwriters Laboratories of Canada (ULC) standards;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: no high-energy-emitting equipment, including high-frequency radios and airborne weather radar, is being operated unless the aircraft flight manual contains procedures for its use during fuelling and those procedures are followed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: no aircraft battery is being removed or being installed;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: no external battery charger is being operated or is being connected to or disconnected from an aircraft battery;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: no auxiliary power unit having an efflux that discharges into the fuelling safety zone is started after filler caps are removed or fuelling connections are made;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: no auxiliary power unit that is stopped is restarted until the flow of fuel has ceased, unless the aircraft flight manual establishes procedures for restarting the unit during fuelling and those procedures are followed;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: no tool that is likely to produce a spark or electric arc is being used;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: no photographic equipment is being used within the fuelling safety zone;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the fuelling is suspended if there is a lightning discharge within eight kilometres of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the fuelling is carried out in accordance with the aircraft manufacturer’s instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft emergency lighting system, if any, is armed or on;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: “no smoking” signs, if any, on board the aircraft are illuminated;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: no passenger is smoking or otherwise producing a source of ignition;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: two exits, one of which is the door through which passengers embarked, are free of obstruction and are available for immediate use by passengers and crew members in the event of an evacuation;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the escape route from each of the exits referred to in paragraph (q) is free of obstruction and is available for immediate use by passengers and crew members in the event of an evacuation;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is authorized by the private operator to suspend fuelling is on board the aircraft and is ready to direct the suspension of fuelling if a requirement of this subsection ceases to be met;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: a means of evacuation is in place at the door used for the embarkation or disembarkation of passengers, is free of obstruction and is available for immediate use by passengers and crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: the person on board the aircraft who has received the training referred to in paragraph (a) is ready to initiate and oversee an evacuation and is at or near the door referred to in paragraph (v); and

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: the embarkation door is open, unless

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a crew member determines that, for climatic reasons, it is desirable to close it,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a crew member is on board the aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the door

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: opens inward or can be fully opened to the exterior without the need to reposition the loading stairs or stand,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: is latched, if that is necessary in order to keep it closed, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: is not locked.

Subsection.Text: The person who is authorized by the private operator to suspend fuelling shall direct the suspension of fuelling if a requirement of subsection (1) ceases to be met.

For the purposes of subsection (1), fuelling safety zone means an area that extends three metres (10 feet) radially from the filling and venting points on the aircraft and from the fuelling equipment.

Heading.TitleText: Fuelling with Passengers on Board and an Engine Running

Subsection.Text: Despite section 602.09, a person operating an aircraft operated by a private operator may permit the fuelling of the aircraft while an engine used for the propulsion of the aircraft is running and passengers are on board or are embarking or disembarking, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements set out in subsection 604.83(1) are met;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft flight manual indicates that the engine that is running may be used as an auxiliary power unit; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the engine that is running has a propeller brake and that brake is set.

Subsection.Text: The person who is authorized by the private operator to suspend fuelling shall direct the suspension of fuelling if a requirement of subsection (1) ceases to be met.

Despite section 602.89, no person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator unless passengers are given a safety briefing — orally by a crew member, or by audio or audiovisual means — that contains the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when and where carry-on baggage is to be stowed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when and how to fasten, adjust and release safety belts and, if any, shoulder harnesses;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when seat backs are to be secured in the upright position and chair tables are to be stowed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the location of emergency exits and, in the case of a passenger seated next to such an exit, how that exit operates;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the requirement to comply with the instructions given by crew members and with the “fasten safety belt” and “no smoking” signs, and the location of those signs;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the location and operation of the passenger oxygen system, if any, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be performed by a passenger in order to

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: obtain a mask,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: activate the flow of oxygen, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: don and secure the mask, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirement for a passenger to don and secure the passenger’s own mask before assisting another passenger with his or her mask;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the use of life preservers, including how to remove them from their packaging, how to don them and when to inflate them;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: when and where smoking is prohibited;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the emergency equipment required under sections 602.62, 602.63, 604.116 and 604.117, and how to access that equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the portable electronic devices that may be used, and when they may be used; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the location and purpose of the safety features card.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), a person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator without a safety briefing being given to the passengers if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is the second or subsequent flight in a series of flights;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no additional passengers have embarked on board the aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a crew member has verified that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: carry-on baggage is stowed,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: safety belts and, if any, shoulder harnesses are properly adjusted and securely fastened,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: seat backs are secured in the upright position, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: chair tables are stowed.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), a person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator without a safety briefing being given to the passengers if each passenger on board the aircraft has, within the 12 months preceding the date of the take-off, received the information referred to in subsection (1) and training in the performance of the following actions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fastening, adjusting and releasing safety belts and, if any, shoulder harnesses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: operating each type of floor-level exit and window emergency exit;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identifying the location of the passenger oxygen system, if any, and performing the actions necessary in order to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: obtain a mask,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: activate the flow of oxygen, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: don and secure the mask;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: identifying the location of life preservers, if any, removing them from their packaging, donning them and inflating them; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: identifying the location of the emergency equipment required by sections 602.62, 602.63, 604.116 and 604.117 and accessing that equipment.

Subsection.Text: A private operator shall record the name of every passenger who receives the training referred to in subsection (3) and the date on which the training is received. The private operator shall retain the record for two years after the day on which the most recent entry was made.

If the safety briefing referred to in subsection (1) is insufficient for a passenger because of that passenger’s physical, sensory or comprehension limitations or because the passenger is responsible for another person on board the aircraft, the passenger shall, subject to subsection (6), be given a safety briefing that consists of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: communication of the elements of the safety briefing referred to in subsection (1) that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the passenger is not able to receive either during that briefing or by referring to the safety features card, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are necessary for the safety of the persons on board the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: communication of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the most appropriate brace position for the passenger, given the passenger’s condition, injury or stature and the orientation and pitch of his or her seat, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the passenger’s service animal, if any, is to be located;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a mobility-impaired passenger who would require assistance in order to move to an exit in the event of an emergency, communication of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the most appropriate exit for the passenger,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the assistance that the passenger would require to reach that exit,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the most appropriate means of providing that assistance,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the most appropriate route to that exit, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the most appropriate time to begin to move to that exit;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a visually impaired passenger,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a tactile familiarization with

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the equipment that the passenger may be required to use in the event of an emergency, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: if requested, the exits, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: communication of

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: where the passenger’s cane, if any, is to be stored,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the number of rows of seats separating the passenger’s seat from the closest exit and from the alternate exit, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the features of those exits;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a passenger who is responsible for another person on board the aircraft, communication of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if the passenger is responsible for an infant,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the requirement to fasten the passenger’s safety belt and, if any, the passenger’s shoulder harness and not to secure the infant in that safety belt or shoulder harness,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: how to hold the infant during take-off and landing,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: how to use the child restraint system, if any,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: how to place and secure the oxygen mask on the infant’s face,

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: the most appropriate brace position for the passenger, and

Clause.Label: (F)
Clause.Text: the location of the infant’s life preserver, how to remove it from its location and its packaging, how to assist the infant with donning it and when to inflate it, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the passenger is responsible for a person, other than an infant,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: how to assist that person with donning and securing his or her oxygen mask, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: how to use that person’s personal restraint system, if any, on board the aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an unaccompanied minor, communication of the need to pay close attention to the safety briefing.

Subsection.Text: A passenger may decline the safety briefing referred to in subsection (5).

No person shall permit passengers to disembark from an aircraft operated by a private operator unless the passengers are given a safety briefing — orally by a crew member, or by audio or audiovisual means — that contains the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safest route for passengers to take in order to move away from the aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazards, if any, associated with the aircraft, including the location of Pitot tubes, propellers, rotors and engine intakes.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a private operator shall, before passengers on board an aircraft are given the safety briefing referred to in subsection 604.85(1), provide each passenger at his or her seat with a safety features card that shows the aircraft type and that contains safety information only in respect of the aircraft, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft configured for 19 or fewer passenger seats,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when and how to fasten, adjust and release safety belts and, if any, shoulder harnesses,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the passenger brace position

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: for each type of seat and passenger restraint system, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: for a passenger who is holding an infant, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location, operation and use of each emergency exit, including whether it is unusable in a ditching because of the aircraft configuration,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the location and operation of the passenger oxygen system, if any, including

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a description of the masks and their use,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the actions to be performed by a passenger in order to

Subclause.Label: (II)
Subclause.Text: activate the flow of oxygen, and

Subclause.Label: (III)
Subclause.Text: don and secure the mask, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the requirement for a passenger to don and secure the passenger’s own mask before assisting another passenger with his or her mask,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of life preservers, how they are to be removed from their packaging, how they are to be donned by adults, by children aged two years or older and by infants, and when they are to be inflated,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: when and where smoking is prohibited, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location, removal and use of flotation devices and, if any, life rafts; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft configured for more than 19 passenger seats,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the information set out in subparagraphs (a)(i) to (vii),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when and where carry-on baggage is to be stowed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the positioning of seats, securing of seat backs in the upright position and stowage of chair tables for take-off and landing,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the form, function, colour and location of the floor proximity emergency escape path markings, if any,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the safest route for passengers to take in order to move away from the aircraft in the event of an emergency, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the attitude of the aircraft while floating, as determined by the aircraft manufacturer.

Subsection.Text: If a flight attendant is not required on board an aircraft, the safety features card referred to in subsection (1) shall also contain the information on the location of the emergency equipment required under sections 604.116, 604.117 and 604.119 and how to access that equipment.

Heading.TitleText: Division VI — Flight Time and Flight Duty Time

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall assign flight time to a flight crew member, and no flight crew member shall accept such an assignment, if the flight crew member’s total flight time in all flights conducted under this Subpart, Part IV or Part VII would, as a result, exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1,200 hours in a period of 12 consecutive months;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 300 hours in a period of 90 consecutive days;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 120 hours in a period of 30 consecutive days; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: 8 hours in a period of 24 consecutive hours, if the assignment is for a single-pilot IFR flight.

Subsection.Text: If a flight crew’s flight duty time is extended under section 604.101, each flight crew member accumulates, for the purposes of subsection (1), the total flight time for the flight or the total flight time for the series of flights, as the case may be.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Duty Time Limits and Rest Periods

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 604.100 to 604.102, no private operator shall assign flight duty time to a flight crew member, and no flight crew member shall accept such an assignment, if the flight crew member’s flight duty time would, as a result, exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 14 consecutive hours in a period of 24 consecutive hours; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 15 consecutive hours in a period of 24 consecutive hours, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the flight crew member’s total flight duty time in the previous 30 consecutive days does not exceed 70 hours, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the rest period before the flight is at least 24 hours.

Subsection.Text: A private operator shall ensure that, prior to reporting for flight duty, a flight crew member is provided with the minimum rest period and with any additional rest period required by this Division.
A flight crew member shall use the following periods to be adequately rested prior to reporting for flight duty:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum rest period provided under subsection (2);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any additional rest period required by this Division; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any period with no assigned duties provided under section 604.104.

Section.Text: Flight duty time may be extended by one half of the length of the rest period, to a maximum of four hours, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before a flight crew member reports for the first flight or reports as a flight crew member on standby, as the case may be, the private operator provides the flight crew member with notice of the extension of the flight duty time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator provides the flight crew member with a rest period of at least four consecutive hours in suitable accommodation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the flight crew member’s next minimum rest period is increased by an amount of time at least equal to the length of the extension of the flight duty time.

Section.Text: If a flight crew is augmented by at least one flight crew member, if there is a balanced distribution of flight deck duty time and rest periods among the flight crew members, and if the next minimum rest period is at least equal to the length of the preceding flight duty time, the flight crew’s flight duty time may be extended

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to 17 hours with a maximum flight deck duty time of 12 hours, if a flight relief facility — seat is provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to 20 hours with a maximum flight deck duty time of 14 hours, if a flight relief facility — bunk is provided.

Subsection.Text: Flight duty time may be extended by up to three hours if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command, after consultation with the other flight crew members, considers it safe to do so;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the flight duty time is extended as a result of unforeseen operational circumstances;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the next minimum rest period is increased by an amount of time that is at least equal to the length of the extension of the flight duty time; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command notifies the private operator of the unforeseen operational circumstances and of the length of the extension of the flight duty time.

Subsection.Text: The private operator shall retain a copy of the notification for five years.

Section.Text: When a private operator delays a flight crew member’s reporting time by more than three hours, the flight crew member’s flight duty time is considered to start three hours after the original reporting time if the private operator notifies the flight crew member of the delay

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 12 hours before the original reporting time; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one hour before the flight crew member leaves a rest facility.

Section.Text: No private operator shall assign duties to a flight crew member, and no flight crew member shall accept those duties, unless the private operator provides the flight crew member with one of the following periods with no assigned duties:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least 36 consecutive hours in a period of seven consecutive days; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least three consecutive calendar days in a period of 17 consecutive days.

Heading.TitleText: Rest Period — Flight Crew Member Positioning

Section.Text: If a flight crew member is required by a private operator to travel for the purpose of positioning after the completion of flight duty time, the private operator shall provide the flight crew member with an additional rest period that is at least equal to one half of the time spent for that purpose that is in excess of the flight duty time referred to in paragraphs 604.99(1)(a) and (b).

Heading.TitleText: Controlled Rest on the Flight Deck

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall allow a flight crew member to take a controlled rest on the flight deck of an aircraft operated by the private operator unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator has a controlled-rest-on-the-flight-deck program that includes the following elements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: guidelines on the use of controlled rest, including the factors allowing or preventing its use,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the general principles relating to fatigue and fatigue countermeasures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to be followed by participating crew members before, during and after a controlled rest; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every participating crew member has received training relating to the elements of the controlled-rest-on-the-flight-deck program.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft operated by a private operator shall determine whether the flight conditions, the duration of the flight and the physiological condition of the crew members allow a controlled rest on the flight deck to be taken by a flight crew member.
The pilot-in-command of an aircraft operated by a private operator shall give participating crew members a briefing that includes the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the order in which the periods of controlled rest are to be taken by the flight crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the planned duration of each period of controlled rest;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the circumstances under which a resting flight crew member is to be woken;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures for the transfer of flight controls and duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: flight attendant duties in relation to a controlled rest.

Subsection.Text: The flight crew members on board an aircraft operated by a private operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prior to each controlled rest on the flight deck,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: participate in an operational briefing,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: carry out the transfer of duties, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: inform the flight attendants of the controlled rest; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remain on the flight deck during the controlled rest.

Subsection.Text: The flight crew member who supervises a controlled rest on the flight deck of an aircraft operated by a private operator shall, during the controlled rest,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: perform the duties of the resting flight crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the controlled rest is taken only during the cruise portion of the flight and is completed at least 30 minutes before top of descent;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the period of controlled rest is of no more than 45 minutes in duration;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the resting flight crew member is awake for at least 15 minutes before the resumption of duties, except in abnormal or emergency conditions; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: after the completion of the controlled rest, give an operational briefing to the flight crew member who has taken the controlled rest.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, participating crew member means the resting flight crew member and the flight crew member who supervises the controlled rest on the flight deck.

No person shall operate over land an aircraft operated by a private operator, other than an aircraft referred to in subsection 602.61(2), unless a survival manual is carried on board that contains information about how to survive on the ground and how to use the survival equipment that is carried on board to meet the requirements of subsection 602.61(1).

No person shall operate over water an aircraft operated by a private operator unless a survival kit is carried on board that, in addition to meeting the requirement of paragraph 602.63(6)(c), contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a radar reflector;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a life raft repair kit;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a bailing bucket and a sponge;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a whistle;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a waterproof flashlight;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a two-day supply of potable water — based on 500 millilitres per person per day and calculated using the overload capacity of the life raft — or a means of desalting or distilling salt water that can provide 500 millilitres of potable water per person per day;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a waterproof survival manual that contains information about how to survive at sea;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a first aid kit that contains antiseptic swabs, burn dressing compresses, bandages and motion sickness pills; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a pyrotechnic signalling device, or an aviation visual distress signal that has a marking, applied by the manufacturer, indicating that the signal meets the requirements of CAN‑TSO-C168, a signalling mirror and a dye marker for visually signalling distress.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph 602.60(1)(h), no person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator that is configured as follows unless the corresponding number of first aid kits is carried on board, and each kit contains the supplies and equipment set out in the Aviation Occupational Health and Safety Regulations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on board an aircraft configured for 1 to 50 passenger seats, one kit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on board an aircraft configured for 51 to 150 passenger seats, two kits;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on board an aircraft configured for 151 to 250 passenger seats, three kits; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on board an aircraft configured for 251 or more passenger seats, four kits.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the first aid kits referred to in subsection (1) are distributed throughout the cabin and are readily available to crew members and passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each first aid kit is clearly identified; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if a first aid kit is stowed in a bin or compartment, the bin or compartment is clearly marked as containing a first aid kit.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a pressurized aircraft operated by a private operator that has flight attendants on board unless one unit of protective breathing equipment with a 15-minute portable supply of breathing gas at a pressure-altitude of 8,000 feet is available

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the entry into each Class A, B, E and F cargo compartment accessible to crew members during flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the site of each hand-held fire extinguisher that is located in an isolated galley;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on the flight deck; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: at the site of each hand-held fire extinguisher that is required under section 604.119.

Subsection.Text: If the breathing gas in the protective breathing equipment referred to in subsection (1) is oxygen, each unit of that equipment reduces by 15 minutes the crew member oxygen requirements specified in subsection 605.31(2).

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft operated by a private operator unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: hand-held fire extinguishers are available as follows:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: extinguishers are distributed, in every passenger compartment configured as follows, in the numbers indicated:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in a passenger compartment configured for fewer than 20 passenger seats, one extinguisher,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in a passenger compartment configured for 20 to 60 passenger seats, two extinguishers,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: in a passenger compartment configured for 61 to 200 passenger seats, three extinguishers, and

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: in a passenger compartment configured for 201 or more passenger seats, one additional extinguisher for each additional unit of 100 passenger seats,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: one extinguisher is located at the entrance to each Class E cargo compartment that is accessible to crew members during flight, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: one extinguisher is located in each isolated galley; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a hand-held fire extinguisher is stowed in a bin or compartment, the bin or compartment is clearly marked as containing a fire extinguisher.

Section.Text: The maintenance manager is responsible and accountable for the maintenance control system.
A private operator shall have, in respect of its aircraft, a maintenance control system that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a private operator who provides the parts and materials that will be used in the performance of maintenance or elementary work, procedures to ensure that only parts and materials that meet the requirements of Subpart 71 of Part V are used, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the details of part pooling arrangements, if any, that have been entered into by the private operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures used for the inspection and storage of incoming parts and materials;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the private operator authorizes, for the performance of elementary work, the use of methods, techniques, practices, parts, materials, tools, equipment or test apparatuses referred to in paragraph 571.02(1)(b) or (c), the source of those methods, techniques, practices, parts, materials, tools, equipment or test apparatuses and a general description of the elementary work;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to ensure that the persons who perform maintenance, elementary work or servicing are authorized to do so under section 604.128;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to ensure that an aircraft is not returned to service unless it is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: airworthy, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: equipped, configured and maintained for its intended use;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the defect reporting and control procedures required by section 604.129;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft service information review procedures required by section 604.131;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to ensure that the records referred to in section 604.132 are established and retained in accordance with that section;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to ensure that the tasks required by a maintenance schedule or by an airworthiness directive are completed within the time limits set out in Subpart 5 of Part VI;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to ensure that the particulars relating to aircraft empty weight and empty centre of gravity are entered in accordance with the requirements of Item 2 of Schedule I to Subpart 5 of Part VI;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a general description of the maintenance schedule required under paragraph 605.86(1)(a) and, in the case of a turbine-powered pressurized aeroplane or a large aeroplane, the approval number of the maintenance schedule approved under subsection 605.86(2); and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: details of the methods used to record the maintenance, elementary work or servicing performed and to ensure that any defects are recorded in the technical records that are required to be kept under subsection 605.92(1).

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall authorize a person to perform maintenance or elementary work on any of its aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has received the training referred to in subsection 604.182(1), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of elementary work, has performed that work at least once under the supervision of the holder of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME) licence or the holder of an approved training organization certificate; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person is authorized to do so under a written agreement that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: describes the maintenance or elementary work to be performed, including the specific tasks and activities and the conditions under which they are to be performed, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: provides that the private operator is responsible for ensuring that the maintenance or elementary work is performed.

Subsection.Text: If a member of the private operator’s personnel performs servicing on any of the private operator’s aircraft, the private operator shall ensure that the member meets the training requirements set out in subsection 604.182(2).
A private operator shall retain a copy of the written agreement referred to in paragraph (1)(b) for two years after the day on which the agreement comes into force.

Section.Text: A private operator shall have procedures to ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft defects are recorded in accordance with subsection 605.94(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft defects are rectified in accordance with the requirements of Subpart 5 of Part VI;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft defect that occurs three times within 15 flights is identified and is reported as a recurring defect to the flight crew and maintenance personnel in order to avoid the repetition of unsuccessful attempts at rectification; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft defect, the rectification of which has been deferred, is scheduled for rectification.

Section.Text: A private operator shall report to the Minister, in accordance with Division IX of Subpart 21 of Part V, any service difficulty related to the aircraft that it operates under this Subpart.
A private operator shall have procedures to ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is aware of the aircraft service information that the holder of a design approval document produces in respect of the aeronautical products used by the private operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft service information is assessed, and the results of the assessment are signed and dated by the maintenance manager and retained for six years; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance schedule or any other procedure is, if necessary, amended in response to the assessment.

Subsection.Text: A private operator shall have for its personnel a record that includes the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any person authorized under section 571.11 to sign a maintenance release under section 571.10; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of any person who has performed elementary work in accordance with subparagraph 604.128(1)(a)(ii).

Subsection.Text: The private operator shall retain the record for two years after the day on which it was last updated.
Subject to subsections (2) and (3), for the purposes of this Division and Division IV, the validity period of any training, any competency check or any pilot proficiency check expires on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of training in the performance of the emergency procedures referred to in subsection 604.169(2) and in subparagraphs 604.179(z)(viii) and (ix), and the high altitude indoctrination training referred to in section 604.176, the first day of the thirty-seventh month after the month in which the training was completed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of all other training, the first day of the thirteenth month after the month in which the training was completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a competency check or pilot proficiency check, the first day of the twenty-fifth month after the month in which the competency check or pilot proficiency check was successfully completed.

Subsection.Text: If any training, competency check or pilot proficiency check is renewed within the last 90 days of its validity period, its validity period is extended by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 36 months, in the case of training in the performance of the emergency procedures referred to in subsection 604.169(2) and in subparagraphs 604.179(z)(viii) and (ix), and the high altitude indoctrination training referred to in section 604.176;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 12 months, in the case of all other training; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 24 months, in the case of a competency check or pilot proficiency check.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall extend the validity period of any training, competency check or pilot proficiency check for a period of not more than 60 days beginning on the day after the day on which the validity period expires, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the application for extension is made during the validity period; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant demonstrates that there has been no reasonable opportunity to renew the training, competency check or pilot proficiency check within the 90 days before the day on which the training, competency check or pilot proficiency check would otherwise expire.

Subsection.Text: A person who will act as a crew member for a private operator, and who has received crew member training under the ground and flight training program of an air operator or under the training program of another private operator, may use that training to meet an equivalent training requirement set out in this Subpart if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the training received by the person is in respect of the aircraft type that the person will operate and the private operator’s area of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the validity period, if any, of that training has not expired; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator provides the person with training in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the processes, practices and procedures set out in the private operator’s operations manual, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator’s emergency procedures for the aircraft in respect of which the person will be assigned duties.

Subsection.Text: A person who will act as a flight crew member for a private operator, and who has successfully completed a pilot proficiency check with an air operator or a competency check with another private operator, meets the requirements of paragraph 604.143(1)(e) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot proficiency check or competency check was conducted using an aircraft of the same type that the person will operate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the validity period of the pilot proficiency check or competency check has not expired; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator provides the person with training in respect of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the processes, practices and procedures set out in the private operator’s operations manual,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any differences between the equipment that is installed on the aircraft operated by the private operator and the equipment that is installed on the aircraft operated by the air operator or the other private operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any differences between the private operator’s operational procedures and those of the air operator or the other private operator.

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as the operations manager unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: holds, or has held, the licence and ratings required by Part IV to act as a pilot-in-command on an aircraft operated by the private operator, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has acquired at least three years of supervisory experience with a private operator or air operator whose operations and activities are of a size, nature and complexity that correspond to the size, nature and complexity of the operations and activities of the private operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the content of the private operator’s operations manual, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the provisions of this Subpart and of any other applicable laws, regulations or standards that ensure the safety of the private operator’s operations or affect the person’s responsibilities.

Subsection.Text: The operations manager is responsible for the operational control of the private operator’s operations and shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: coordinate the activities that affect operational control, including activities relating to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: maintenance,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: crew members’ schedules,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: load control, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft operation schedules;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: implement the private operator’s policies and procedures to ensure that the private operator’s operations meet the requirements of this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the operations manager receives aeronautical information that indicates a risk to the safety of a flight, ensure that corrective actions are taken to manage or mitigate the risk;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure the dissemination of aircraft safety information to the private operator’s personnel; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: implement the emergency response procedures referred to in paragraph 604.203(1)(e).

Heading.TitleText: Chief Pilot Qualifications, Training and Responsibilities

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as a chief pilot unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person meets the requirements of paragraphs 604.143(1)(a), (b), (d) and (e) for acting as pilot-in-command on an aircraft operated by the private operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the content of the private operator’s operations manual, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the provisions of this Subpart and of any other applicable laws, regulations or standards that ensure the safety of the private operator’s operations or affect the person’s responsibilities.

Subsection.Text: The chief pilot is responsible for the flight crew members involved in the private operator’s operations and shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: develop standard operating procedures in respect of aircraft operated by the private operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: verify whether the aerodromes and routes for aircraft used by the private operator are suitable for aircraft operated by the private operator;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the operational requirements of the aerodromes and routes used by the private operator are met; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: process any flight crew member reports and take any necessary follow-up action.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Member Qualifications and Training

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as a pilot-in-command or second-in-command unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person holds the licence, ratings and medical certificate required by Part IV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a pilot-in-command,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the person has received, in respect of the aircraft type that the person will operate, the training set out in subsections 604.169(1) and 604.170(1) and, if applicable, the training set out in subsection 604.169(3) and sections 604.177 and 604.178, or equivalent training that meets the requirements of subsection 604.140(1), as the case may be, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the validity period of the training has not expired;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a second-in-command,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the person has received, in respect of the aircraft type that the person will operate, the training set out in subsections 604.169(1) and 604.170(1) and, if applicable, the training set out in subsection 604.169(3) and section 604.177, or equivalent training that meets the requirements of subsection 604.140(1), as the case may be, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the validity period of the training has not expired;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person has received, in respect of the aircraft type that the person will operate, training in the performance of the emergency procedures referred to in subsection 604.169(2) or equivalent training that meets the requirements of subsection 604.140(1), and the validity period of the training has not expired;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the person has successfully completed, in respect of the aircraft type that the person will operate, a competency check that meets the requirements of this section or a competency check or pilot proficiency check that meets the requirements of subsection 604.140(2), and the validity period of the competency check or pilot proficiency check has not expired; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the person is required to operate an aircraft above 13,000 feet ASL, the person has received the training set out in section 604.176 or equivalent training that meets the requirements of subsection 604.140(1).

Subsection.Text: A person who undergoes a competency check referred to in paragraph (1)(e)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall have completed, within 30 days before the day on which the competency check is conducted, the training set out in subsection 604.170(1) or equivalent training that meets the requirements of subsection 604.140(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall have been recommended for the competency check by an instructor who provided the person with the training or equivalent training referred to in paragraph (a); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall meet the following requirements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the person holds the licence required by Part IV in respect of the aircraft that will be used for the competency check,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the person holds a type rating required by Part IV in respect of the aircraft that will be used for the competency check, or meets the knowledge and experience requirements set out in paragraph 421.40(3)(a) of Standard 421 — Flight Crew Permits, Licences and Ratings, and the knowledge requirement was met within 24 months before the day on which the competency check is conducted, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the person holds an instrument rating required by Part IV in respect of the aircraft that will be used for the competency check, or meets the knowledge and experience requirements set out in subsection 421.46(2) of Standard 421 — Flight Crew Permits, Licences and Ratings, and the knowledge requirement was met within 24 months before the day on which the competency check is conducted.

Subsection.Text: The competency check referred to in paragraph (1)(e)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be based on the processes, practices and procedures set out in the private operator’s operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall consist of the exercises set out in chapters 2 or 3, as the case may be, of the standard entitled Flight Test Guide — Competency Check (Private Operators), published by the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall assess the exercises referred to in paragraph (b) in accordance with the marking scale set out in section 1.3 of that standard;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall assess the competency as satisfactory or unsatisfactory in accordance with sections 1.4 and 1.5 of that standard; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: shall be subject to the retest procedures referred to in section 1.6 of that standard.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (5), the competency check referred to in paragraph (1)(e) shall be conducted by a person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holds the licence and ratings required by Part IV to act as pilot-in-command of the aircraft used for the competency check;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: holds an instrument rating required by Part IV in respect of the aircraft used for the competency check;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: meets one of the following requirements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a pilot examiner authorized by the Minister to conduct instrument rating flight tests under Part IV,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is an approved check pilot authorized by the Minister to conduct a pilot proficiency check under Part VII in respect of the aircraft type used for the competency check, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: holds an authorization issued by the competent authority of a contracting state to conduct flight tests that are equivalent to competency checks, in which case the person shall have demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of the standard referred to in paragraph (3)(b); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is not the instructor who made the recommendation referred to in paragraph 2(b) in respect of the person undergoing the competency check.

Subsection.Text: The competency check referred to in paragraph (1)(e) may be conducted by a person who is not referred to in paragraph 4(c) if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has been assigned to conduct the competency check by the private operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements set out in paragraphs (4)(a) and (b);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not have a record of conviction for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an offence under section 7.3 of the Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: two or more offences under these Regulations not arising from a single occurrence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is at least 21 years old;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: has at least 3,000 hours of flight time in an aircraft of the same category as the aircraft that will be used for the competency check, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 2,000 hours as pilot-in-command,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 500 hours in a multi-engined aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 500 hours of instrument time, including at least 100 hours as pilot-in-command; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed, within 24 months before the day on which the person conducts the competency check, training provided by a pilot examiner or by an approved check pilot that includes the following elements:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the responsibilities of a person conducting a competency check,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: evaluation principles,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the conduct of a competency check,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the content of the standard referred to in paragraph (3)(b), and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the record-keeping requirements set out in section 604.149.

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as a flight instructor or a flight simulator instructor unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight instructor, the person holds, in respect of the aircraft type used for the training, the licence and ratings required by Part IV or, in the case of a flight instructor licensed by a contracting state, a licence and ratings equivalent to those required by Part IV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight simulator instructor, the person holds, or has held, in respect of the aircraft type used for the training, the licence and ratings required by Part IV or, in the case of an flight simulator instructor licensed by a contracting state, a licence and ratings equivalent to those required by Part IV;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the private operator is authorized under a special authorization to operate an aircraft in IFR flight, the person holds a valid instrument rating in respect of the aircraft type used for the training;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person has received, in respect of the aircraft type used for the training, training that includes the elements set out in subsection 604.170(1), and the validity period of the training has not expired; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the person has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the content of the private operator’s operations manual, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the provisions of this Subpart that relate to the training of flight crew members.

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as a ground instructor unless the person has received, before the day on which the person begins to act as ground instructor, training that includes the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the teaching and learning processes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: instructional techniques; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the student-instructor relationship.

Section.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as a flight attendant unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person has received the training set out in section 604.179 or equivalent training that meets the requirements of subsection 604.140(1), and the validity period of the training has not expired; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the provisions of these Regulations and of standards that affect the responsibilities of a flight attendant,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: aeronautical terminology,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the physiological effects of flight, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the theory of flight.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Dispatcher and Flight Follower Training

Subsection.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as a flight dispatcher unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holds a flight dispatcher certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has received the training set out in subsection 604.180(1) and the validity period of the training has not expired.
