Subsection.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to act — and no person shall act — as a flight follower unless the person has received the training set out in subsection 604.180(2) and the validity period of the training has not expired.

Heading.TitleText: Ground and Airborne Icing Operations Training

Section.Text: No private operator shall permit a person to perform — and no person shall perform — duties relating to ground and airborne icing operations unless the person has received the training set out in section 604.181 and the validity period of the training has not expired.
A private operator shall ensure that the operations manager, the maintenance manager and all other personnel receive the training set out in section 604.183.

Subsection.Text: A private operator shall have for its personnel a training and qualifications record that includes the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: each person’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the dates on which the person received training and the name of the instructor who provided the training;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the operations manager, information on how the operations manager has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of the elements referred to in paragraph 604.141(1)(b) and the date of that demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the chief pilot, information on how the chief pilot has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of the elements referred to in paragraph 604.142(1)(b) and the date of that demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight instructor, information on how the flight instructor has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of the elements referred to in paragraph 604.144(1)(e) and the date of that demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight crew member,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the flight crew member licence number, the category and expiry date of the flight crew member’s medical certificate, a list of the flight crew member’s ratings and, if applicable, the expiry date of those ratings,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of the training referred to in subsection 604.170(1) and sections 604.177 and 604.178, information indicating whether the training was completed using an aircraft or a flight simulation training device, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of the competency check referred to in paragraph 604.143(1)(e),

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the name of the person who conducted the competency check and the date on which it was conducted,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the name of the instructor who made the recommendation referred to in paragraph 604.143(2)(b) and the date on which it was made,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the date of each attempt by the flight crew member to complete a competency check and the result of each attempt,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: information indicating whether the competency check was conducted using an aircraft or a flight simulation training device, and

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: in the case of a competency check conducted by the person referred to in subparagraph 604.143(4)(c)(iii), information indicating how the person has demonstrated to the private operator knowledge of the standard referred to in that subparagraph and the date of that demonstration,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of a pilot proficiency check conducted under Part VII, the name of the air operator for which the check was conducted and the date on which the check was conducted, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the dates on which the flight crew member demonstrated the ability to operate an aircraft in accordance with paragraphs 604.50(c), 604.51(f), 604.60(f) and 604.74(2)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME), the aircraft maintenance engineer licence number.

Subsection.Text: If the training referred to in Divisions IV or X includes a written examination, the private operator shall retain a master copy of each examination.
The private operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: retain the records referred to in subsections (1) and (2) for two years after the day on which the records were last updated; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: retain the written examination referred to in subsection (3) for two years after the day on which the examination was given.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a private operator shall have a training program that covers the subject matter set out in Division IV and in this Division, and the competency check referred to in paragraph 604.143(1)(e), and that takes into account

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft types operated by the private operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s area of operation.

Subsection.Text: A private operator who is also an air operator shall have a training program that covers the subject matter set out in this Division and that takes into account

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft types operated by the private operator that are not specified in the air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the differences, if any, between the areas in which operations are conducted.

Section.Text: A private operator shall design its training program so that a person who receives training required under this Subpart

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: will, if the person is receiving the training for the first time, acquire the competency necessary to perform his or her duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: will, if the person is receiving subsequent training, maintain the competency referred to in paragraph (a) and acquire any new competency necessary to perform his or her duties.

Heading.TitleText: Training Program Content and Training Facilities

Section.Text: A private operator shall ensure that any training provided to meet the requirements of this Subpart is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: based on the content of the private operator’s training program; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provided in facilities that are equipped with the appropriate furnishings, audiovisual equipment and training aids.

Subsection.Text: The ground instruction component of the training program for flight crew members shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the content of the private operator’s operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft systems operation and limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual and, if the private operator has established an aircraft operating manual and standard operating procedures, those specified in that manual and in those procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of the aircraft equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the differences, if any, between the equipment, operation and layout of aircraft of the same type;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the standard operating procedures, if any were established by the private operator;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft performance and limitations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: weight and balance control procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft servicing and ground handling;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the location and operation of emergency equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of aircraft fire on the ground or in the air;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of a security-related event;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to avoid Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT);

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: if the flight crew members will be assigned to medical evacuation flights (MEDEVAC), emergency procedures specific to medical evacuations, including the evacuation of patients from aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s operational control system.

Subsection.Text: The ground instruction component of the training program for flight crew members shall include training in the performance of the following emergency procedures:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the use of fire extinguishers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operation and use of emergency exits;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: passenger preparation for an emergency landing or ditching;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: emergency evacuation procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the flight crew members will be assigned to aircraft equipped with life preservers, the donning and inflation of life preservers;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the flight crew members will be assigned to aircraft equipped with life rafts, the removal of life rafts from the stowage compartment, and the deployment, inflation and boarding of life rafts; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for dealing with pilot incapacitation.

Subsection.Text: If a private operator operates a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane, the ground instruction component of the training program for flight crew members who will operate that aeroplane shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the low-energy landing regime for that type of aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the performance and handling characteristics of the aeroplane and engine in the low-energy regime; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: balked landing procedures for the aeroplane.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — Aircraft Operation Training

Subsection.Text: The aircraft operation component of the training program for flight crew members shall include procedures for the normal, abnormal and emergency operation of an aircraft and its systems and components, including the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft performance during take-off, climb, cruise, holding, descent, landing and diversion;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: calculations of the aircraft’s take-off and landing distances and speeds, and the aircraft’s fuel consumption, weight and centre of gravity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the flight characteristics of the aircraft, including any abnormal characteristics that are applicable to the aircraft, such as dutch roll, buffet boundary onset and aircraft upset;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the effects of airframe and engine icing and the use of de-icing and anti-icing equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: flight planning and instrument flight procedures, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: departure, enroute, holding, arrival and diversion procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: precision, non-precision and missed approaches in minimum visibility conditions, with the flight director in automatic mode and in degraded states of operation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: circling approaches, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: pre-flight checks of the interior and exterior of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the use of aircraft checklists;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft manoeuvres on the ground;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: normal, crosswind, noise abatement and maximum performance take-offs and landings;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: take-offs and landings on contaminated runways;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: rejected take-offs and landings;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: steep turns;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: approach to a stall and recovery from a stall;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of the Flight Management Computer System (FMCS), Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS), Terrain Awareness and Warning System (TAWS), Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS), Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS) and any other specialized equipment installed in the private operator’s aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the execution in VMC of one collision avoidance manoeuvre in response to a GPWS or a TAWS warning, if the aircraft is equipped with a GPWS or a TAWS;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of navigation and communication equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of hydraulic, electrical and other system failures;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of flight control failures and, in the case of an aircraft with split control capability, briefings on degraded states of operation while in flight and during take-off and landing;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of aircraft fire on the ground or in the air;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of engine fire and engine failure while in flight;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of and recovery from turbulence and windshear during an approach, landing and take-off;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of an emergency evacuation of passengers and crew;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of pilot incapacitation while in flight and during take-off and landing;

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: crew resource management;

Paragraph.Label: (y)
Paragraph.Text: if the private operator provides the training using a flight simulator, the performance of one balked landing initiated in the low-energy regime using the same simulator;

Paragraph.Label: (z)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a pressurized aircraft, the actions to be taken in the event of loss of pressurization and emergency descent;

Paragraph.Label: (z.1)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a three-engine or four-engine aircraft, take-off, landing and flight with the critical engine inoperative or with two other engines inoperative, including driftdown and engine-inoperative performance capabilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (z.2)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a helicopter,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: hovering manoeuvres, slope landings and confined areas,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: autorotations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: transmission and main gear box faults and failures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: tail rotor, tail rotor drive and tail rotor gear box faults and failures.

Subsection.Text: When the training referred to in subsection (1) is provided on board an aircraft in flight, the private operator shall have procedures to ensure that situations are simulated or presented, and actions are simulated or performed, so as to not adversely affect the safety of the aircraft, its occupants or any other person.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — Level B, C or D Flight Simulator

Section.Text: Subject to sections 604.172 to 604.174, a private operator may provide the training referred to in subsection 604.170(1) and sections 604.177 and 604.178 to a flight crew member either on board an aircraft or using a level B, C or D flight simulator. However, if the private operator provides the training using a level B flight simulator, the private operator shall provide training in respect of the following activities on board an aircraft:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: pre-flight checks of the interior and exterior of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft manoeuvres on the ground;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: normal take-offs and landings;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: crosswind take-offs and landings;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a visual circuit, if the flight is conducted in VMC;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: approaches and landings with an engine simulated inoperative;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: simulated engine failure procedures during a take-off and a missed approach;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: approaches and landings without electronic glide slope indication;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a circling approach, if applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any other approach for which a level B flight simulator lacks the capability.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — Level C or D Flight Simulator

Section.Text: A private operator may provide the training referred to in subsection 604.170(1) and sections 604.177 and 604.178 to a flight crew member using only a level C or D flight simulator if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight crew member has acquired flight time on an aircraft certificated in the same category, and with engines using the same principle of propulsion, as the aircraft on which the flight crew member is to be trained; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator provides to the flight crew member, using the same flight simulator, training in respect of the following activities under variable visual meteorological conditions of dusk and night, or day and night:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft manoeuvres on the ground,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: normal take-offs and landings and crosswind take-offs and landings, up to 100% of the crosswind component specified by the aircraft manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: encounters with moderate to severe in-flight icing conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: simulated line flights that include at least one sector in which the flight crew member acts as pilot flying and at least one sector in which the flight crew member acts as pilot not flying or pilot monitoring,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: visual circuits and landings with variable wind, runway illusion and runway surface conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: approaches and landings with an engine simulated inoperative,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: approaches and landings without electronic glide slope indication,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: approaches and landings with flight control failures and abnormalities, if applicable, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: engine failure procedures during a take-off and a missed approach.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — Level D Flight Simulator

Section.Text: A private operator may provide the training referred to in subsection 604.170(1) and sections 604.177 and 604.178 to a flight crew member using only a level D flight simulator if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight crew member has at least 1,000 hours of flight time as a flight crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of training provided on an aircraft that requires a minimum flight crew of two pilots, the flight crew member holds an individual type rating for an aircraft that requires a minimum flight crew of two pilots; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator provides the training referred to in paragraph 604.172(b) to the flight crew member using that simulator.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — Turbo-jet-powered Aeroplane or Transport Category Aircraft — Level C or D Flight Simulator

Section.Text: A private operator who operates a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane or transport category aircraft shall provide the training referred to in subsection 604.170(1) and sections 604.177 and 604.178 to a flight crew member using a level C or D flight simulator if a level C or D flight simulator is used for that aircraft type in Canada, the United States or Mexico.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — Compatibility of Flight Simulators

Section.Text: A flight simulator that differs from the private operator’s aircraft with respect to installed equipment, systems, cockpit configuration, engine type or performance may be used for the training referred to in subsection 604.170(1) and sections 604.177 and 604.178 if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight simulator has performance and handling characteristics equivalent to those of the private operator’s aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s training program takes into account the differences between the flight simulator and the aircraft.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — High Altitude Indoctrination Training

Section.Text: The component of the training program for flight crew members who will operate an aircraft above 13,000 feet ASL shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: physiological phenomena in a low pressure environment, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the effects on respiration,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the symptoms and effects of hypoxia,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the duration of consciousness at various altitudes without supplemental oxygen, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the effects of gas expansion and gas bubble formation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the factors associated with rapid or explosive loss of pressurization, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the most likely causes of the loss of pressurization,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the increased level of noise, the change in cabin temperature and cabin fogging,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the effects on objects located near a point of fuselage failure, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the actions to be taken by flight crew members immediately after the loss of pressurization and the aircraft attitude likely to result from those actions.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — One-engine Inoperative Ferry Flights

Section.Text: The component of the training program for flight crew members who will operate an aircraft during a one-engine inoperative ferry flight under a flight permit issued under section 507.04 shall include training in the operational procedures and limits specified in the aircraft flight manual.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Crew Members — Upgrade to Pilot-in-Command

Section.Text: The component of the training program for flight crew members who have served as second-in-command and who are to be upgraded to pilot-in-command shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the elements of the training referred to in subsection 604.170(1) that are related to the duties of a pilot-in-command;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: training on the responsibilities of a pilot-in-command in relation to the use and operation of an aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight crew member who will conduct an operation under a special authorization, the training required to conduct that operation as pilot-in-command; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: crew resource management.

Section.Text: The component of the training program for flight attendants shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the roles and responsibilities of the private operator and crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the coordination of crew member duties and crew resource management;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft communications systems and communication procedures in normal, abnormal and emergency conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the content of the briefings given to passengers and crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: cabin and passenger safety checks;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft surface contamination procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures relating to passengers requiring special treatment;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: requirements and procedures relating to seats and restraint systems for passengers and crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for accepting and stowing carry-on baggage, and any applicable restrictions;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: policies and procedures relating to the use of portable electronic devices;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for fuelling with passengers on board;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: procedures relating to passenger service when the aircraft is on the ground;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: safety procedures relating to take-offs, landings and aircraft movements on the surface;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: safety procedures relating to the embarkation and disembarkation of passengers and their movement on the apron;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: procedures relating to passenger and crew member safety during periods of in-flight turbulence;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for entering the flight deck and for serving beverages and meals to flight crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for dealing with the incapacitation of a crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the location and operation of, and any safety instructions relating to, the various types of cabin exits and the flight deck escape routes;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of cabin systems and of safety and emergency equipment by flight attendants in normal and abnormal conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken with respect to the equipment identified on the minimum equipment list and intended for use by flight attendants;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken in the event of fumes or smoke in the cabin and to prevent fumes or smoke in the vicinity of the aircraft from entering the cabin;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: fire detection, fire-fighting systems and fire-fighting procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: procedures in the event of loss of cabin pressurization;

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: how to identify the need for administering supplemental oxygen, and procedures for administering the oxygen;

Paragraph.Label: (y)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the evacuation of passengers and crew members; and

Paragraph.Label: (z)
Paragraph.Text: training that includes the performance of the following emergency procedures:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the use of the public address and interphone systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the briefing of passengers,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the operation and use of the emergency exits on each type of aircraft to which the flight attendant will be assigned,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: emergency evacuation procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: if the flight attendants will be assigned to an aircraft equipped with life preservers, the donning and inflation of life preservers,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: if the flight attendants will be assigned to an aircraft equipped with an evacuation slide, the identification of the location of the manual inflation handle and the disconnect handle, and an evacuation using the slide,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the flight attendants will be assigned to an aircraft equipped with either first aid oxygen equipment or portable oxygen equipment, the operation and use of that equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the flight attendants will be assigned to an aircraft equipped with life rafts, the removal of life rafts from the stowage compartment and the deployment, inflation and boarding of life rafts, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: fire fighting, including the use of a fire extinguisher on an actual fire.

Subsection.Text: The component of the training program for flight dispatchers shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the content of the private operator’s operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the provisions of these Regulations, and of related standards, that affect the responsibilities of a flight dispatcher;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: flight planning and the private operator’s standard operating procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: radiocommunication procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft fuelling procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft surface contamination procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the use of minimum equipment lists;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: meteorological conditions, including windshear and aircraft icing, in the private operator’s area of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s navigation and instrument approach procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: accident and incident reporting;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: emergency procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: weight and balance control procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: pre-flight crew member briefings;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the differences between pilot self-dispatch procedures and co-authority dispatch procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: the provision of meteorological information to the flight crew without analysis or interpretation;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: foreign regulations, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: aeronautical information publications applicable to the private operator’s area of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: meteorological conditions and their effect on the flight and operation of an aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: the interpretation of meteorological information;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: the performance and limitations of the private operator’s aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: air traffic control procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: flight dispatch procedures.

Subsection.Text: The component of the training program for flight followers shall include the elements referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) to (q).

Section.Text: The component of the training program for flight crew members and ground personnel that relates to ground and airborne icing operations shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the responsibilities of the pilot-in-command and other operations personnel in respect of aircraft de-icing and anti-icing procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the provisions of these Regulations, and of related standards, that relate to ground and airborne icing operations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the meteorological conditions that are conducive to ice, frost and snow contamination;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures relating to pre-flight inspections and to the removal of contamination;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the hazards associated with the contamination of critical surfaces by ice, frost and snow;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: airborne icing recognition; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of training provided to flight crew members,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the basis of the certification of the aircraft for flight into known icing conditions,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: airborne icing definitions and terminology,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the aerodynamic effects of airborne icing,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the weather patterns associated with airborne icing, including both classical and non-classical mechanisms that produce freezing precipitation,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: flight planning and airborne icing information,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: information specific to the private operator’s aircraft fleet that relates to the operation of de-icing and anti-icing equipment, and operational procedures relating to that equipment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator’s directives concerning operations in airborne icing conditions set out in the private operator’s operations manual and, if established by the private operator, in the private operator’s standard operating procedures.

Subsection.Text: The component of the training program for persons who performs maintenance or elementary work shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the performance rules set out in section 571.02, and the recording requirements set out in section 571.03 and subsection 605.92(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s maintenance control system.

Subsection.Text: The component of the training program for persons who perform servicing shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures that are set out in instructions for continued airworthiness provided by the holder of the design approval document, and that are applicable to the types of aircraft operated by the private operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: details of the methods used by the private operator to record servicing under paragraph 604.127(k).

Section.Text: The component of the training program in respect of the private operator’s safety management system shall include the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: training in the concepts and principles of safety management systems;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: training in the organization and operation of the private operator’s safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: competency-based training for persons who have been assigned duties in respect of the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: appropriate objectives for each person; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: means of measuring the level of competency attained by each person who receives the training.

Subsection.Text: A private operator shall have an operations manual that sets out the processes, practices and procedures applied in the course of its operations. The operations manual shall include a table of contents and shall deal with the following topics:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the duties and responsibilities of all operational and maintenance personnel, and the hierarchy and chain of command within management;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the organization and operation of the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: personnel training and qualifications;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: record keeping;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the organization and operation of the maintenance control system;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for conducting an operation under a special authorization, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the organization and operation of the operational control system;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: procedures, if any, relating to minimum equipment lists;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures to follow in normal, abnormal and emergency conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s standard operating procedures, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: weather restrictions;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: flight time limits and flight duty time limits;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: controlled rest on the flight deck;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: accident and incident response considerations;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for dealing with security events;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft performance limitations; and

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the use and protection of records, if any, obtained from flight data recorders and cockpit voice recorders.

Subsection.Text: The private operator shall ensure that it is possible to verify the currency and validity of each part of its operations manual.
A private operator shall provide a copy of its operations manual and a copy of every amendment to that manual to every member of its personnel who is involved in the private operator’s operations.

Every person who has been provided with a copy of an operations manual under subsection (1) shall keep it up to date by inserting in it the amendments provided and shall ensure that the appropriate parts are accessible when the person is performing assigned duties.

Despite subsection (1), instead of providing every crew member with a copy of its operations manual and a copy of every amendment to that manual, a private operator may keep an up-to-date copy of the appropriate parts of that manual in each aircraft that it operates.

Section.Text: No private operator shall conduct flight operations unless it has a safety management system that meets the requirements of section 604.203.

Heading.TitleText: Components of the Safety Management System

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the private operator’s safety management system shall include the following components:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the overall objectives that are to be achieved by the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a safety management plan that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: specifies the duties that are assigned to the private operator’s personnel in respect of the safety management system,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: sets out performance goals for the safety management system and a means of measuring the attainment of those goals,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: sets out a policy for the internal reporting of aviation-safety-related hazards, incidents and accidents, including the conditions, if any, under which personnel will be protected from disciplinary action,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: describes the relationship between the components of the safety management system, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: sets out procedures for involving personnel in the establishment of the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a safety oversight program that includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures for managing aviation-safety-related incidents, including their investigation and analysis,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures for identifying and managing aviation-safety-related hazards, including the monitoring and risk profiling of those hazards,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a reporting and data collection system for collecting and communicating information relating to aviation-safety-related hazards and incidents that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: uses a record-keeping system to monitor and analyze aviation safety trends,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: includes a means of communicating with persons who report issues relating to the safety management system or aviation safety,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: is capable of generating progress reports for the person responsible for the functional area at intervals that the person determines, and

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: is capable of generating other reports in urgent cases,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures for investigating and analyzing aviation-safety-related hazards, incidents and accidents that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: take into account human, environmental and supervisory factors and organizational elements,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: make it possible to make findings as to root causes and contributing factors, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: make it possible to communicate the findings to the operations manager,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: risk management analysis procedures that include

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: an analysis of aviation-safety-related hazards,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a risk assessment based on risk criteria, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: a risk control strategy,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: corrective action procedures

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: for determining what corrective actions are necessary, if any, and for carrying out those actions,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: for keeping a record of any determination made under clause (A) and the reason for that determination, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: for monitoring and evaluating, in accordance with the quality assurance program referred to in section 604.206, the effectiveness of any corrective action carried out under clause (A),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures for disseminating to personnel, with the approval of the private operator, the following aviation-safety-related information:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: information relating to an incident,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: information relating to a hazard analysis, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: information relating to the results of a review or audit, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures for sharing, with any person with whom the private operator exchanges services, any information relating to aviation safety;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ensuring that all procedures relating to the safety management system are recorded and disseminated to personnel,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: managing and keeping all records and documents resulting from the safety management system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: ensuring that records and reports relating to the safety management system are retained for at least two years, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: reviewing all documents relating to the safety management system and keeping those documents up to date;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: emergency response procedures that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: cover all of the activities carried out by the private operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: ensure that the duties relating to those procedures are assigned to the appropriate personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the quality assurance program referred to in section 604.206; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the process for conducting a review of the safety management system under section 604.207.

Subsection.Text: The safety management system of a private operator who has no employees is not required to include the components referred to in the following provisions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subparagraphs (1)(b)(iii) and (v);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: clause (1)(c)(iii)(B);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subparagraph (1)(c)(vii);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subparagraph (1)(d)(i); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subparagraph (1)(e)(ii).

Subsection.Text: The operations manager shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: manage the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: implement the safety management plan referred to in paragraph 604.203(1)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: implement the safety oversight program referred to in paragraph 604.203(1)(c);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: implement the procedures referred to in paragraph 604.203(1)(d) in respect of all documents relating to the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: implement the emergency response procedures referred to in paragraph 604.203(1)(e);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: implement the quality assurance program referred to in section 604.206;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that any deficiency identified by the quality assurance program is analyzed to determine its root cause and contributing factors;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: communicate to the private operator any finding produced by the safety management system in respect of a hazard to aviation safety;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: share, with any person with whom the private operator exchanges services, any finding produced by the safety management system that is likely to have an adverse effect on aviation safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: analyze any information relating to aviation safety that is received from any person with whom the private operator exchanges services and take appropriate action to mitigate any hazard to aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: When a finding produced by the safety management system is reported to the operations manager, the operations manager shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine what corrective actions are necessary to address that finding, if any, and carry out those actions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a record of any determination made under paragraph (a) and the reason for that determination;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the operations manager has assigned management functions to another person, communicate any determination made under paragraph (a) to that person; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: notify the private operator of any deficiency that reduces the effectiveness of all or part of the safety management system, and of the corrective action carried out.

Section.Text: The personnel of a private operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: report to the operations manager any issue relating to the safety management system, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: deficiencies, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: aviation-safety-related hazards, incidents or accidents; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: share, with any person with whom the private operator exchanges services, any information relating to aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: The quality assurance program shall make provision for sampling the private operator’s processes in order to measure

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s effectiveness in conducting an audit under subsection (2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the private operator’s ability to carry out its activities effectively and safely.

Subsection.Text: An audit required by the quality assurance program shall be conducted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 12 months after the day on which the private operator registration document was issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to paragraph (c), within 12 months after the day on which the previous audit was completed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: within 36 months after the day on which the previous audit was completed, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the private operator submits to the Minister a risk assessment establishing that the private operator is capable of managing the aviation-safety-related risks that may occur during that 36-month period, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: none of the following events have occurred since the day on which the previous audit was completed:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a major incident,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a major change in the private operator’s activities, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: a finding resulting from a review of the safety management system and indicating that the quality assurance program is not achieving its objectives;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: following an accident, or incident, that affects aviation safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: following the identification, as a result of a review of the safety management system, of a deficiency that reduces the effectiveness of all or part of the safety management system.

Subsection.Text: A quality assurance program shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: checklists of all of the activities carried out by the private operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for determining what corrective actions are necessary to eliminate the root cause and contributing factors of each finding of non-compliance with these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for monitoring corrective actions to ensure that they are effective;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a system for recording the following information:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the findings resulting from an audit, and any supporting documentation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an analysis of the root cause and contributing factors of any deficiency identified by the quality assurance program,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any corrective action, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: any follow-up action; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for ensuring that each finding resulting from an audit is communicated to the operations manager and to any person who has been assigned management functions respecting the safety management system, and is made available to the private operator.

Subsection.Text: An audit conducted under paragraph (2)(d) or (e) shall be a complete audit.
No private operator shall assign a duty relating to the quality assurance program to a person who is responsible for carrying out a task or an activity evaluated by that program unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: owing to the size, nature and complexity of the private operator’s operations and activities, it is impractical to assign the duty to a person who is not responsible for carrying out the task or activity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: based on a risk analysis, assigning the duty to a person responsible for carrying out the task or activity will not result in an increased risk to aviation safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of the audit system in relation to the quality assurance program will not be compromised.

Heading.TitleText: Review of the Safety Management System

Subsection.Text: A periodic review of the safety management system shall measure the effectiveness of the system in the attainment of the performance goals referred to in subparagraph 604.203(1)(b)(ii).
A review of the safety management system shall be conducted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within 12 months after the day on which the private operator registration document was issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within 12 months after the day on which the previous review was completed; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: following an accident, or incident, that affects aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: A review of the safety management system shall include procedures for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identifying any deficiency in the operation of the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: investigating and analyzing the root cause and contributing factors of any deficiency identified by the review; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring that corrective actions are effective and are used on an ongoing basis to improve the safety management system.

Subsection.Text: A review conducted under paragraph (2)(c) shall be a complete review.

No private operator shall assign a duty relating to a review of the safety management system to a person who is responsible for carrying out a task or an activity that is the subject of the review unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: owing to the size, nature and complexity of the private operator’s operations and activities, it is impracticable to assign the duty to a person who is not responsible for carrying out the task or activity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: based on a risk analysis, assigning the duty to a person responsible for carrying out the task or activity will not result in an increased risk to aviation safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the integrity of the review of the safety management system will not be compromised.

Section.Text: The private operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct the review of the safety management system under section 604.207;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determine what corrective actions are necessary to address any deficiency identified by the review, and carry out those actions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: keep a record of any determination made under paragraph (b) and the reason for it; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the private operator has assigned management functions to another person, provide that person with a copy of that record.

Heading.TitleText: Division XIII — Flight Attendants and Emergency Evacuation

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Division and subject to subsection (2), model means aircraft master series as described in section 3.7 of version 1.3 of the document entitled International Standard for Aircraft Make, Model, and Series Groupings, dated October 2012 and published by the Common Taxonomy Team of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the Commercial Aviation Safety Team (CAST).

If no aircraft master series is assigned to an aeroplane, model in respect of that aeroplane means aircraft model as described in section 3.6 of version 1.3 of the document entitled International Standard for Aircraft Make, Model, and Series Groupings, dated October 2012 and published by the Common Taxonomy Team of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the Commercial Aviation Safety Team (CAST).

No person shall conduct a take-off in an aeroplane that is operated by a private operator and is carrying more than 12 passengers unless the take-off is conducted with the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck.
Subject to subsections (3) to (5), the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck is one flight attendant for each unit of 50 passengers or for each portion of such a unit.
No flight attendants are required if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane has 13 to 19 passengers on board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane is operated by a pilot-in-command and a second-in-command;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger cabin is readily accessible from the flight deck; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the flight crew members are able to exercise supervision over the passengers during flight by visual and aural means.

Subsection.Text: If a private operator has carried out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for a model of aeroplane using more flight attendants than would have been required in accordance with the ratio set out in subsection (2), the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck of an aeroplane of that model that is operated by the private operator is the number of flight attendants used in the demonstration.

If the emergency evacuation demonstration required for the certification of a model of aeroplane was carried out using more flight attendants than would have been required in accordance with the ratio set out in subsection (2), the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck of an aeroplane of that model is the number of flight attendants required in accordance with the ratio set out in subsection (2) plus an additional number of flight attendants that is equal to the difference between

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the number of flight attendants used in the demonstration, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of flight attendants that would have been required in accordance with the ratio set out in subsection (2) at the time of the demonstration.

Subsection.Text: If there is a conflict between subsection (3) and subsection (4) or (5), subsection (3) prevails to the extent of the conflict.

Section.Text: No private operator shall operate an aeroplane that is configured for 20 or more passenger seats unless the features that facilitate emergency evacuations meet the requirements set out in section 624.222 of Standard 624 — Emergency Features of the General Operating and Flight Rules Standards.

Subsection.Text: A private operator who decides to introduce a model of aeroplane into its fleet for the purpose of carrying passengers shall carry out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for that model of aeroplane before operating an aeroplane of that model to carry passengers.

If a private operator decides to introduce an aeroplane into its fleet and there is a difference in any of the following items between that aeroplane and other aeroplanes of the same model that are already in the fleet, the private operator shall treat the aeroplane as if it were a different model of aeroplane and carry out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for that model before operating the aeroplane to carry passengers:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the flight attendants or their emergency evacuation duties or procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of emergency exits; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of opening mechanisms for the emergency exits.

Subsection.Text: A private operator who decides to change any of the following items in respect of an aeroplane shall carry out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for the model of that aeroplane, as changed, before operating the aeroplane to carry passengers:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the flight attendants or their emergency evacuation duties or procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of emergency exits; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of opening mechanisms for the emergency exits.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) to (3) do not apply in respect of a model of aeroplane that is configured to carry fewer than 44 passengers.

Heading.TitleText: Carrying Out a Demonstration of Emergency Evacuation Procedures

Subsection.Text: A private operator who carries out a demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for a model of aeroplane shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: do so without passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: do so with flight attendants who have completed the private operator’s training program for that model of aeroplane; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: begin the demonstration using the private operator’s normal procedures, then transition to its emergency procedures.

Subsection.Text: The demonstration is successful if the flight attendants can, within 15 seconds after the transition from the private operator’s normal procedures to its emergency procedures,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: open 50% of the floor-level emergency exits that are required by the certification basis established in respect of the model of aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: open 50% of the non-floor-level emergency exits the opening of which is set out as an emergency evacuation duty in the private operator’s operations manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: deploy 50% of the escape slides.

Subsection.Text: The private operator shall record the demonstration using time-encoded video and keep the recording for at least five years after the day on which the demonstration is carried out.

If a private operator decides to operate an aeroplane to carry passengers in extended over-water operations and the aeroplane is required to have survival equipment under section 602.63, the private operator shall carry out a demonstration of its ditching emergency evacuation procedures for the model of that aeroplane before starting the extended over-water operations.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of an aeroplane that is configured for fewer than 20 passenger seats.

Heading.TitleText: Carrying Out a Demonstration of Emergency Evacuation Procedures — Ditching

Subsection.Text: A private operator who carries out a demonstration of its ditching emergency evacuation procedures for a model of aeroplane shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: use an aeroplane of that model, a life-sized mock-up of that model of aeroplane or a floating device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assume that the ditching occurs during daylight hours and that all required crew members are available;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that passengers are on board and participate in the demonstration if the private operator’s operations manual requires passengers to assist in the launching of life rafts;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that, after the ditching signal has been received, each evacuee dons a life preserver;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each life raft is removed from its stowage compartment;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that, as applicable, one life raft or one slide raft is inflated; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each evacuee boards the life raft or slide raft and that a crew member assigned to the life raft or slide raft indicates the location of the required survival equipment and describes the use of that equipment.

Subsection.Text: A life-sized mock-up of a model of aeroplane or a floating device must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be representative of the passenger cabin of the model of aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contain seats for all of the evacuees participating in the demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with the same survival equipment that is installed on the model of aeroplane, including a life preserver for each evacuee participating in the demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have emergency exits and doors that simulate those on the model of aeroplane; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: have enough wing area installed outside the window emergency exits to simulate the portions of the wings of the model of aeroplane that would be used in a ditching situation.

Subsection.Text: The private operator shall record the demonstration using time-encoded video and keep the recording for at least five years after the day on which the demonstration is carried out.

Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a private operator who operates an aeroplane to carry passengers shall ensure that all flight attendants assigned to a flight using that aeroplane are on board during passenger embarkation and disembarkation.
In the case of a flight to which more than one flight attendant is assigned, the private operator may reduce the number of flight attendants by one during passenger embarkation if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight attendant who leaves the aeroplane remains within the immediate vicinity of the door through which passengers are embarking and carries out safety-related duties for the flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the engines used for the propulsion of the aeroplane are not running; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at least one floor-level exit remains open to provide for passenger egress.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a flight to which more than one flight attendant is assigned, the private operator may reduce the number of flight attendants during passenger disembarkation if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the engines used for the propulsion of the aeroplane are not running;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one floor-level exit remains open to provide for passenger egress; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: half of the required number of flight attendants — rounded down to the next lower number in the case of fractions, but never less than one — remain on board.

Subsection.Text: Paragraphs (2)(b) and (3)(a) do not apply in respect of an engine on a propeller-driven aeroplane if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the engine has a propeller brake;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the propeller brake is set; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane flight manual indicates that the engine may be used as an auxiliary power unit.

Subsection.Text: The private operator shall ensure that, during passenger embarkation and disembarkation,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if only one flight attendant is on board, he or she remains in the vicinity of the door through which passengers are embarking or disembarking; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if more than one flight attendant is on board, they are evenly distributed in the passenger cabin and are in the vicinity of the floor-level exits.

Heading.TitleText: Emergency Evacuation — Before and During Surface Movement

Section.Text: A private operator shall, for each aeroplane in its fleet that is configured to carry 20 or more passengers, have procedures to ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least one floor-level exit provides for passenger egress before the movement of the aeroplane on the surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every automatically deployable means of emergency passenger evacuation is ready for immediate use during the movement of the aeroplane on the surface.

Section.Text: Despite section 605.09, no person shall conduct a take-off in a single-aisle aeroplane that is carrying passengers unless all emergency exits and escape slides are operative.

No private operator shall operate an aeroplane that is configured to carry 20 or more passengers unless the emergency equipment, the stowage locations for emergency equipment and the emergency procedures are standardized for all aeroplanes in the private operator’s fleet that are configured to carry 20 or more passengers.

Subsection.Text: This Subpart applies to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: persons operating Canadian aircraft other than ultra-light aeroplanes or hang gliders; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: persons operating foreign aircraft in Canada where those persons are Canadian citizens, permanent residents or corporations incorporated by or under the laws of Canada or a province.

Subsection.Text: The following requirements apply to persons operating foreign aircraft, other than persons referred to in paragraph (1)(b), while those aircraft are operated in Canada:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirement to carry a flight authority on board the aircraft in accordance with section 605.03;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the requirement that an aircraft be equipped with transponder and automatic pressure-altitude reporting equipment in accordance with section 605.35;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the requirement that an aircraft be equipped with one or more ELTs in accordance with section 605.38; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: radiocommunication and radio navigation equipment requirements that are specific to the aircraft and types of flight referred to in sections 605.14 to 605.21.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft in flight unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a flight authority is in effect in respect of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated in accordance with the conditions set out in the flight authority; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections (2) and (3), the flight authority is carried on board the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: Where a specific-purpose flight permit has been issued pursuant to section 507.04, an aircraft may be operated without the flight authority carried on board where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is conducted in Canadian airspace; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an entry is made into the journey log indicating

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that the aircraft is operating under a specific-purpose flight permit, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where applicable, any operational conditions that pertain to flight operations under the specific-purpose flight permit.

Subsection.Text: A balloon may be operated without the flight authority carried on board where the flight authority is immediately available to the pilot-in-command

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prior to commencing a flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on completion of the flight.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft, for which an aircraft flight manual is required by the applicable standards of airworthiness, unless the aircraft flight manual or, if an aircraft operating manual has been established under section 604.37 or Part VII, the aircraft operating manual is available to the flight crew members at their duty stations.

The aircraft flight manual or, if an aircraft operating manual has been established under section 604.37 or Part VII, those parts of the aircraft flight manual that are incorporated into the aircraft operating manual shall include all the amendments and supplementary material that are applicable to the aircraft type.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft in respect of which markings or placards are required by the applicable standards of airworthiness unless the markings or placards are affixed to the aircraft or attached to a component of the aircraft in accordance with those standards.

No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft, or permit another person to conduct a take-off in an aircraft in their custody and control, unless the aircraft equipment required by these Regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the applicable standards of airworthiness; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is serviceable and, where required by operational circumstances, functioning, except if otherwise provided in section 605.08, 605.09 or 605.10.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, in accordance with the MMEL/MEL Policy and Procedures Manual, establish a master minimum equipment list for each type of aircraft.

The Minister may supplement a master minimum equipment list that has been issued by the competent authority of a foreign state in respect of a type of aircraft where necessary to ensure compliance with the MMEL/MEL Policy and Procedures Manual.

Where a master minimum equipment list has been established for an aircraft type pursuant to subsection (1) or supplemented pursuant to subsection (2), the Minister shall approve a minimum equipment list in respect of each operator of that type of aircraft, if the requirements set out in the MMEL/MEL Policy and Procedures Manual are met.

Notwithstanding subsection (2) and sections 605.09 and 605.10, no person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has equipment that is not serviceable or from which equipment has been removed if, in the opinion of the pilot-in-command, aviation safety is affected.

Notwithstanding sections 605.09 and 605.10, a person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has equipment that is not serviceable or from which equipment has been removed where the aircraft is operated in accordance with the conditions of a flight permit that has been issued specifically for that purpose.

Heading.TitleText: Unserviceable and Removed Equipment — Aircraft with a Minimum Equipment List

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), where a minimum equipment list has been approved in respect of the operator of an aircraft pursuant to subsection 605.07(3), no person shall conduct a take-off in the aircraft with equipment that is not serviceable or that has been removed unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated in accordance with any conditions or limitations specified in the minimum equipment list; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the minimum equipment list is carried on board.

Subsection.Text: Where the conditions or limitations specified in a minimum equipment list are in conflict with the requirements of an airworthiness directive, the airworthiness directive prevails.

Heading.TitleText: Unserviceable and Removed Equipment — Aircraft without a Minimum Equipment List

Subsection.Text: Where a minimum equipment list has not been approved in respect of the operator of an aircraft, no person shall conduct a take-off in the aircraft with equipment that is not serviceable or that has been removed, where that equipment is required by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the standards of airworthiness that apply to day or night VFR or IFR flight, as applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any equipment list published by the aircraft manufacturer respecting aircraft equipment that is required for the intended flight;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an air operator certificate, a special authorization issued under subsection 604.05(2), a special flight operations certificate or a flight training unit operating certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an airworthiness directive; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Where a minimum equipment list has not been approved in respect of the operator of an aircraft and the aircraft has equipment, other than the equipment required by subsection (1), that is not serviceable or that has been removed, no person shall conduct a take-off in the aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the unserviceable equipment is not removed from the aircraft, it is isolated or secured so as not to constitute a hazard to any other aircraft system or to any person on board the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the appropriate placards are installed as required by the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an entry recording the actions referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) is made in the journey log, as applicable.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a power-driven aircraft for the purpose of day VFR flight unless it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated in uncontrolled airspace, an altimeter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated in controlled airspace, a sensitive altimeter adjustable for barometric pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an airspeed indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a magnetic compass or a magnetic direction indicator that operates independently of the aircraft electrical generating system;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a tachometer for each engine and for each propeller or rotor that has limiting speeds established by the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an oil pressure indicator for each engine employing an oil pressure system;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a coolant temperature indicator for each liquid-cooled engine;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: an oil temperature indicator for each air-cooled engine having a separate oil system;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a manifold pressure gauge for each

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: reciprocating engine equipped with a variable-pitch propeller,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: reciprocating engine used to power a helicopter,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: supercharged engine, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: turbocharged engine;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a means for the flight crew, when seated at the flight controls to determine

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the fuel quantity in each main fuel tank, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the aircraft employs retractable landing gear, the position of the landing gear;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections 601.08(2) and 601.09(2), a radiocommunication system adequate to permit two-way communication on the appropriate frequency when the aircraft is operated within

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Class B, Class C or Class D airspace,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an MF area, unless the aircraft is operated pursuant to subsection 602.97(3), or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ADIZ;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated under Subpart 4 of this Part, or under Subpart 3, 4 or 5 of Part VII, radiocommunication equipment adequate to permit two-way communication on the appropriate frequency;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated in Class B airspace, radio navigation equipment that will enable it to be operated in accordance with a flight plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated under Subpart 4 of this Part or under Subpart 5 of Part VII, radio navigation equipment that is adequate to receive radio signals from a transmitting facility.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a power-driven aircraft for the purpose of VFR OTT flight unless it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment referred to in paragraphs 605.14(c) to (j);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a sensitive altimeter adjustable for barometric pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a means of preventing malfunction caused by icing for each airspeed indicating system;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a gyroscopic direction indicator or a stabilized magnetic direction indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an attitude indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), a turn and slip indicator or turn coordinator;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is to be operated within the Northern Domestic Airspace, a means of establishing direction that is not dependent on a magnetic source;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: radiocommunication equipment adequate to permit two-way communication on the appropriate frequency; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: radio navigation equipment adequate to permit the aircraft to be navigated safely.

Subsection.Text: Where the aircraft is equipped with a third attitude indicator that is usable through flight attitudes of 360° of pitch and roll for an aeroplane, or ± 80° of pitch and ± 120° of roll for a helicopter, the aircraft may be equipped with a slip-skid indicator in lieu of a turn and slip indicator or a turn coordinator.
No person shall conduct a take-off in a power-driven aircraft for the purpose of night VFR flight, unless it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment referred to in paragraphs 605.14(c) to (n);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a sensitive altimeter adjustable for barometric pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), a turn and slip indicator or turn coordinator;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an adequate source of electrical energy for all of the electrical and radio equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of every set of fuses of a particular rating that is installed on the aircraft and accessible to the pilot-in-command during flight, a number of spare fuses that is equal to at least 50 per cent of the total number of installed fuses of that rating;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated so that an aerodrome is not visible from the aircraft, a stabilized magnetic direction indicator or a gyroscopic direction indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
