Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is to be operated within the Northern Domestic Airspace, a means of establishing direction that is not dependent on a magnetic source;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is an airship operated within controlled airspace, radar reflectors attached in such a manner as to be capable of a 360-degree reflection;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a means of illumination for all of the instruments used to operate the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: when carrying passengers, a landing light; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: position and anti-collision lights that conform to the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.

Subsection.Text: Where the aircraft is equipped with a third attitude indicator that is usable through flight attitudes of 360° of pitch and roll for an aeroplane, or ± 80° of pitch and ± 120° of roll for a helicopter, the aircraft may be equipped with a slip-skid indicator in lieu of a turn and slip indicator or a turn coordinator.

No person shall operate an aircraft that is equipped with any light that may be mistaken for, or downgrade the conspicuity of, a light in the navigation light system, unless the aircraft is being operated for the purpose of aerial advertising.

In addition to the equipment requirements specified in subsection (1), no person shall operate an aircraft in night VFR flight under Subpart 4 of this Part or Subparts 2 to 5 of Part VII, unless the aircraft is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an attitude indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vertical speed indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a means of preventing malfunction caused by icing for each airspeed indicating system; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an outside air temperature gauge.

Heading.TitleText: Use of Position and Anti-collision Lights

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall operate an aircraft in the air or on the ground at night, or on water between sunset and sunrise, unless the aircraft position lights and anti-collision lights are turned on.
Anti-collision lights may be turned off where the pilot-in-command determines that, because of operating conditions, doing so would be in the interests of aviation safety.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a power-driven aircraft for the purpose of IFR flight unless it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when it is operated by day, the equipment required pursuant to paragraphs 605.16(1)(a) to (h);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when it is operated by night, the equipment required pursuant to paragraphs 605.16(1)(a) to (k);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an attitude indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a vertical speed indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an outside air temperature gauge;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a means of preventing malfunction caused by icing for each airspeed indicating system;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a power failure warning device or vacuum indicator that shows the power available to gyroscopic instruments from each power source;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: an alternative source of static pressure for the altimeter, airspeed indicator and vertical speed indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient radiocommunication equipment to permit the pilot to conduct two-way communications on the appropriate frequency; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient radio navigation equipment to permit the pilot, in the event of the failure at any stage of the flight of any item of that equipment, including any associated flight instrument display,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to proceed to the destination aerodrome or proceed to another aerodrome that is suitable for landing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated in IMC, to complete an instrument approach and, if necessary, conduct a missed approach procedure.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a balloon for the purpose of day VFR flight unless it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an altimeter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vertical speed indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a hot air balloon,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a fuel quantity gauge, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an envelope temperature indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a captive gas balloon, a magnetic direction indicator; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections 601.08(2) and 601.09(2), a radiocommunication system adequate to permit two-way communication on the appropriate frequency when the balloon is operated within

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Class C or Class D airspace,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an MF area, unless the aircraft is operated pursuant to subsection 602.97(3), or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ADIZ.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a balloon for the purpose of night VFR flight unless it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: equipment required pursuant to section 605.19;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: position lights;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a means of illuminating all of the instruments used by the flight crew, including a flashlight; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a hot air balloon, two independent fuel systems.

Section.Text: No person shall operate a glider in day VFR flight unless it is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an altimeter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an airspeed indicator;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a magnetic compass or a magnetic direction indicator; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections 601.08(2) and 601.09(2), a radiocommunication system adequate to permit two-way communication on the appropriate frequency when the glider is operated within

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Class C or Class D airspace,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an MF area, unless the aircraft is operated pursuant to subsection 602.97(3), or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ADIZ.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection 605.23, no person shall operate an aircraft other than a balloon unless it is equipped with a seat and safety belt for each person on board the aircraft other than an infant.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a person operating an aircraft that was type-certificated with a safety belt designed for two persons.
A safety belt referred to in subsection (1) shall include a latching device of the metal-to-metal type.

Section.Text: An aircraft may be operated without being equipped in accordance with section 605.22 in respect of the following persons if a restraint system that is secured to the primary structure of the aircraft is provided for each person who is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carried on a stretcher or in an incubator or other similar device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: carried for the purpose of parachuting from the aircraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: required to work in the vicinity of an opening in the aircraft structure.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an aeroplane, other than a small aeroplane manufactured before July 18, 1978, unless each front seat or, if the aeroplane has a flight deck, each seat on the flight deck is equipped with a safety belt that includes a shoulder harness.
Except as provided in section 705.75, no person shall operate a transport category aeroplane unless each flight attendant seat is equipped with a safety belt that includes a shoulder harness.

No person shall operate a small aeroplane manufactured after December 12, 1986, the initial type certificate of which provides for not more than nine passenger seats, excluding any pilot seats, unless each forward- or aft-facing seat is equipped with a safety belt that includes a shoulder harness.

No person shall operate a helicopter manufactured after September 16, 1992, the initial type certificate of which specifies that the helicopter is certified as belonging to the normal or transport category, unless each seat is equipped with a safety belt that includes a shoulder harness.

No person operating an aircraft shall conduct any of the following flight operations unless the aircraft is equipped with a seat and a safety belt that includes a shoulder harness for each person on board the aircraft:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: aerobatic manoeuvres;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: class B, C or D external load operations conducted by a helicopter; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aerial application, or aerial inspection other than flight inspection for the purpose of calibrating electronic navigation aids, conducted at altitudes below 500 feet AGL.

Heading.TitleText: General Use of Safety Belts and Restraint Systems

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall direct all of the persons on board the aircraft to fasten safety belts

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: during movement of the aircraft on the surface;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: during take-off and landing; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at any time during flight that the pilot-in-command considers it necessary that safety belts be fastened.

Subsection.Text: The directions referred to in subsection (1) also apply to the use of the following restraint systems:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a child restraint system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a restraint system used by a person who is engaged in parachute descents; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a restraint system used by a person when working in the vicinity of an opening in the aircraft structure.

Subsection.Text: Where an aircraft crew includes flight attendants and the pilot-in-command anticipates that the level of turbulence will exceed light turbulence, the pilot-in-command shall immediately direct each flight attendant to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: discontinue duties relating to service;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: secure the cabin; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: occupy a seat and fasten the safety belt provided.

Subsection.Text: Where an aircraft is experiencing turbulence and the in-charge flight attendant considers it necessary, the in-charge flight attendant shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: direct all of the passengers to fasten their safety belts; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: direct all flight attendants to discontinue duties relating to service, to secure the cabin, to occupy the assigned seats and to fasten the safety belts provided and to do so oneself.

Subsection.Text: Where the in-charge flight attendant has given directions in accordance with subsection (4), the in-charge flight attendant shall so inform the pilot-in-command.

Heading.TitleText: Use of Passenger Safety Belts and Restraint Systems

Subsection.Text: Where the pilot-in-command or the in-charge flight attendant directs that safety belts be fastened, every passenger who is not an infant shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the passenger’s safety belt or restraint system is properly adjusted and securely fastened;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if responsible for an infant for which no child restraint system is provided, hold the infant securely in the passenger’s arms; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if responsible for a person who is using a child restraint system, ensure that the person is properly secured.

Subsection.Text: No passenger shall be responsible for more than one infant.

Heading.TitleText: Use of Crew Member Safety Belts

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the crew members on an aircraft shall be seated at their stations with their safety belts fastened

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: during take-off and landing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at any time that the pilot-in-command directs; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of crew members who are flight attendants, at any time that the in-charge flight attendant so directs pursuant to paragraph 605.25(4)(b).

Subsection.Text: Where the pilot-in-command directs that safety belts be fastened by illuminating the safety belt sign, a crew member is not required to comply with paragraph (1)(b)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: during movement of the aircraft on the surface or during flight, if the crew member is performing duties relating to the safety of the aircraft or of the passengers on board;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is experiencing light turbulence, if the crew member is a flight attendant and is performing duties relating to the passengers on board; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the crew member is occupying a crew rest facility during cruise flight and the restraint system for that facility is properly adjusted and securely fastened.

Subsection.Text: The pilot-in-command shall ensure that at least one pilot is seated at the flight controls with safety belt fastened during flight time.
No operator of an aircraft shall permit the use of a child restraint system on board the aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person using the child restraint system is accompanied by a parent or guardian who will attend to the safety of the person during the flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the weight and height of the person using the child restraint system are within the range specified by the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the child restraint system bears a legible label indicating the applicable design standards and date of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the child restraint system is properly secured by the safety belt of a forward-facing seat that is not located in an emergency exit row and does not block access to an aisle; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the tether strap is used according to the manufacturer’s instructions or, where subsection (2) applies, secured so as not to pose a hazard to the person using the child restraint system or to any other person.

Subsection.Text: Where a seat incorporates design features to reduce occupant loads, such as the crushing or separation of certain components, and the seat is in compliance with the applicable design standards, no person shall use the tether strap on the child restraint system to secure the system.
Every passenger who is responsible for a person who is using a child restraint system on board an aircraft shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: seated in a seat adjacent to the seat to which the child restraint system is secured;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: familiar with the manufacturer’s installation instructions for the child restraint system; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: familiar with the method of securing the person in the child restraint system and of releasing the person from it.

Section.Text: No operator of an aircraft shall permit the use of a flight control lock in respect of the aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight control lock is incapable of becoming engaged when the aircraft is being operated; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an unmistakable warning is provided to the person operating the aircraft whenever the flight control lock is engaged.

Section.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off or continue a flight in an aircraft where icing conditions are reported to exist or are forecast to be encountered along the route of flight unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command determines that the aircraft is adequately equipped to operate in icing conditions in accordance with the standards of airworthiness under which the type certificate for that aircraft was issued; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: current weather reports or pilot reports indicate that icing conditions no longer exist.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an unpressurized aircraft unless it is equipped with sufficient oxygen dispensing units and oxygen supply to comply with the requirements set out in the table to this subsection.

row.entry: Persons for Whom Oxygen Supply Must Be Available
All crew members and 10 per cent of passengers and, in any case, no less than one passenger
Entire period of flight exceeding 30 minutes at cabin-pressure-altitudes above 10,000 feet ASL but not exceeding 13,000 feet ASL
All persons on board the aircraft

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Entire period of flight at-cabin-pressure altitudes above 13,000 feet ASL

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: For aircraft operated in an air transport service under the conditions referred to in paragraph (a), a period of flight of not less than one hour

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a pressurized aircraft unless it is equipped with sufficient oxygen dispensing units and oxygen supply to provide, in the event of cabin pressurization failure at the most critical point during the flight, sufficient oxygen to continue the flight to an aerodrome suitable for landing while complying with the requirements of the table to this subsection.

table.title: MINIMUM OXYGEN REQUIREMENTS FOR PRESSURIZED AIRCRAFT FOLLOWING EMERGENCY DESCENT (NOTE 1)

row.entry: Persons for Whom Oxygen Supply Must Be Available
All crew members and 10 per cent of passengers and, in any case, no less than one passenger

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Entire period of flight exceeding 30 minutes at cabin-pressure-altitudes above 10,000 feet ASL but not exceeding 13,000 feet ASL

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: Entire period of flight at cabin-pressure-altitudes above 13,000 feet ASL

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: For aircraft operated in an air transport service under the conditions referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), a period of flight of not less than

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: 30 minutes (Note 2), and

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: for flight crew members, two hours for aircraft the type certificate of which authorizes flight at altitudes exceeding FL 250 (Note 3)

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Entire period of flight at cabin-pressure-altitudes exceeding 13,000 feet ASL

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: For aircraft operated in an air transport service under the conditions referred to in paragraph (a), a period of flight of not less than 10 minutes
Note 1: In determining the available supply, the cabin-pressure- altitude descent profile for the routes concerned must be taken into account.

Note 2: The minimum supply is that quantity of oxygen necessary for a constant rate of descent from the aircraft’s maximum operating altitude authorized in the type certificate to 10,000 feet ASL in 10 minutes, followed by 20 minutes at 10,000 feet ASL.

Note 3: The minimum supply is that quantity of oxygen necessary for a constant rate of descent from the aircraft’s maximum operating altitude authorized in the type certificate to 10,000 feet ASL in 10 minutes, followed by 110 minutes at 10,000 feet ASL.

Subsection.Text: Where an aircraft is operated at cabin-pressure-altitudes above 10,000 feet ASL but not exceeding 13,000 feet ASL, each crew member shall wear an oxygen mask and use supplemental oxygen for any part of the flight at those altitudes that is more than 30 minutes in duration.

Where an aircraft is operated at cabin-pressure-altitudes above 13,000 feet ASL, each person on board the aircraft shall wear an oxygen mask and use supplemental oxygen for the duration of the flight at those altitudes.
The pilot at the flight controls of an aircraft shall use an oxygen mask if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is not equipped with quick-donning oxygen masks and is operated at or above flight level 250; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is equipped with quick-donning oxygen masks and is operated above flight level 410.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Data Recorder and Cockpit Voice Recorder

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 605.34, no person shall conduct a take-off in any of the following multi-engined turbine-powered aircraft unless the aircraft is equipped with a flight data recorder that conforms to section 551.100 of Chapter 551 of the Airworthiness Manual and section 625.33 of Standard 625 — Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance of the General Operating and Flight Rules Standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of 30 or fewer passengers, configured for 10 or more passenger seats and manufactured after October 11, 1991;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an aeroplane in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of 30 or fewer passengers and configured for 20 to 30 passenger seats;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of more than 30 passengers; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an aircraft in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of cargo only and operated under Subpart 5 of Part VII.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 605.34, no person shall conduct a take-off in a multi-engined turbine-powered aircraft that is configured for six or more passenger seats and for which two pilots are required by the aircraft type certificate or by the subpart under which the aircraft is operated, unless the aircraft is equipped with a cockpit voice recorder that conforms to section 551.101 of Chapter 551 of the Airworthiness Manual and section 625.33 of Standard 625 — Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance of the General Operating and Flight Rules Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Use of Flight Data Recorders and Cockpit Voice Recorders

Subsection.Text: Except where otherwise permitted in this section, no person shall operate an aircraft for which a flight data recorder or cockpit voice recorder is required by these Regulations unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where a flight data recorder is required, the flight data recorder is operated continuously from the start of the take-off until the completion of the landing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where a cockpit voice recorder is required, the cockpit voice recorder is operated continuously from the time at which electrical power is first provided to the recorder before the flight to the time at which electrical power is removed from the recorder after the flight.

Subsection.Text: No person shall erase any communications pertaining to the flight being undertaken that have been recorded by a cockpit voice recorder.

Where a minimum equipment list has been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of an aircraft pursuant to subsection 605.07(3), the operator may operate the aircraft without a serviceable flight data recorder or cockpit voice recorder if the aircraft is operated in accordance with the minimum equipment list.

Where a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of an aircraft, the operator may operate the aircraft without a serviceable flight data recorder for a maximum period of 90 days after the date of failure of the flight data recorder if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a cockpit voice recorder is required by these Regulations, the cockpit voice recorder is serviceable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft technical records show the date of the failure of the flight data recorder.

Subsection.Text: Where a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of an aircraft, the operator may operate the aircraft without a serviceable cockpit voice recorder for a maximum period of 90 days after the date of failure of the cockpit voice recorder if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a flight data recorder is required by these Regulations, the flight data recorder is serviceable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft technical records show the date of the failure of the cockpit voice recorder.

Heading.TitleText: Transponder and Automatic Pressure-Altitude Reporting Equipment

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), no person shall operate an aircraft, other than a balloon or a glider, in transponder airspace, unless the aircraft is equipped with a transponder and automatic pressure-altitude reporting equipment.
The aircraft referred to in subsection (1) may be operated without a serviceable transponder and automatic pressure-altitude reporting equipment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a minimum equipment list has been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of the aircraft pursuant to subsection 605.07(3), the aircraft is operated in accordance with the minimum equipment list; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of the aircraft, the aircraft is operated

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to the next aerodrome of intended landing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: thereafter, in accordance with an air traffic control clearance, to complete a planned flight schedule or to proceed to a maintenance facility.

Subsection.Text: An air traffic control unit may authorize a person to operate an aircraft that is not equipped in accordance with subsection (1) within airspace referred to in section 601.03 where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air traffic control unit provides an air traffic control service in respect of that airspace;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air traffic control unit received a request from the person to operate the aircraft within that airspace before the aircraft entered the airspace; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aviation safety is not likely to be affected.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall conduct a take-off in a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane unless it is equipped with an altitude alerting system or device that conforms to the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.
An aeroplane referred to in subsection (1) may be operated without a serviceable altitude alerting system or device if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a minimum equipment list has been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of the aeroplane pursuant to subsection 605.07(3), the aeroplane is operated in accordance with the minimum equipment list; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of the aeroplane, the aeroplane is operated

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: from the place where the operator or pilot-in-command takes possession of the aeroplane to a place where the aeroplane can be equipped with such a system or device,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for the sole purpose of conducting a flight test, a competency check, a pilot proficiency check or flight crew member training, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the system or device becomes unserviceable after take-off, until it reaches an aerodrome at which the system or device can be repaired or replaced.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), no person operating under Subpart 4 or 5 of Part VII shall conduct a take-off in a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane that has a MCTOW of more than 15 000 kg (33,069 pounds) and for which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of 10 or more passengers, unless the aeroplane is equipped with a GPWS.

An aeroplane referred to in subsection (1) may be operated without a serviceable GPWS if a minimum equipment list has been approved by the Minister in respect of the operator of the aeroplane pursuant to subsection 605.07(3) and the aeroplane is operated in accordance with the minimum equipment list.

Where, in the interests of aviation safety, it is necessary during a flight to deactivate any mode of a GPWS, the pilot-in-command of the aeroplane may deactivate that mode if the deactivation is performed in accordance with the aircraft flight manual, aircraft operating manual, flight manual supplement or minimum equipment list.
This section

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: applies only in respect of aeroplanes manufactured on or before the day on which this subsection comes into force; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall cease to apply on the expiry of two years after that day.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no person shall operate an aircraft unless it is equipped with one or more ELTs in accordance with subsection (2).

An aircraft set out in column I of an item of the table to this subsection shall, for the area of operation set out in column II of the item, be equipped with the quantity and type of ELTs referred to in column III of that item, which ELTs shall be armed, if so specified in the aircraft flight manual, aircraft operating manual, pilot operating handbook or equivalent document provided by the manufacturer.

row.entry: All aircraft except those referred to in subsection (3)
One ELT of Type AD, AF, AP, A or F
Large multi-engined turbo-jet aeroplanes engaged in an air transport service carrying passengers
Over water at a distance from land that requires the carriage of life rafts pursuant to section 602.63
Two ELTs of Type W or S or one of each
All aircraft that require an ELT other than those set out in item 2
Over water at a distance from land that requires the carriage of life rafts pursuant to section 602.63
One ELT of Type W or S

Subsection.Text: An aircraft referred to in subsection (1) may be operated without an ELT on board where the aircraft is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a glider, balloon, airship, ultra-light aeroplane or gyroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: registered under the laws of a contracting state or a state that is a party to an agreement entered into with Canada relating to interstate flying, and is equipped with a serviceable radio transmitter that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is approved by the state of registry for search and rescue purposes, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has a distinctive audio signal and is capable of communication on the frequency of 121.5 MHz, or simultaneously on the frequencies of 121.5 MHz and 243.0 MHz;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: operated by the holder of a flight training unit operating certificate, engaged in flight training and operated within 25 nautical miles of the aerodrome of departure;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: engaged in a flight test;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a new aircraft engaged in flight operations incidental to manufacture, preparation or delivery of the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: operated for the purpose of permitting a person to conduct a parachute descent within 25 nautical miles of the aerodrome of departure; or

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: operated in accordance with section 605.39.

Subsection.Text: If an aircraft is equipped with one or more ELTs capable of broadcasting on the frequency of 406 MHz, each ELT shall be registered with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Canadian Beacon Registry of the National Search and Rescue Secretariat; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the appropriate authority of the country identified in the coded message transmitted by the ELT.

Subsection.Text: An aircraft that is required to be equipped with one or more ELTs under section 605.38 may be operated without a serviceable ELT if the operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: repairs the ELT or removes it from the aircraft at the first aerodrome at which repairs or removal can be accomplished;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on removal of the ELT, sends the ELT to a maintenance facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: displays on a readily visible placard within the aircraft cockpit, until the ELT is replaced, a notice stating that the ELT has been removed and setting out the date of its removal.

Subsection.Text: If an aircraft is required to have one ELT under section 605.38, the operator shall re-equip the aircraft with a serviceable ELT within

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 10 days after the date of removal, if the aircraft is operated under Subpart 4 or 5 of Part VII; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 30 days after the date of removal in the case of any other aircraft.

Subsection.Text: If an aircraft is required to have two ELTs under section 605.38, the operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if one of the ELTs is unserviceable, repair or replace it within 10 days after the date of removal; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if both ELTs are unserviceable, repair or replace

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: one ELT at the first aerodrome at which a repair or replacement can be accomplished, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the second ELT within 10 days after the date of removal.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall activate an ELT except in an emergency.
A person may activate an ELT during the first five minutes of any hour UTC for a duration of not more than five seconds for the purpose of testing it.
Where an ELT has been inadvertently activated during flight, the pilot-in-command of the aircraft shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nearest air traffic control unit, flight service station or community aerodrome radio station is so informed as soon as possible; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ELT is switched off.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane that is operated under Part VII without a third attitude indicator that meets the requirements of section 625.41 of the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards unless the aeroplane

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has a MCTOW of less than 5 700 kg (12,566 pounds); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: was operated in Canada in a commercial air service on October 10, 1996.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a transport category aircraft without a third attitude indicator that meets the requirements of section 625.41 of the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards unless the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is a transport category helicopter not operated in IFR flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is a transport category aeroplane powered by reciprocating engines that was manufactured before January 1, 1998; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is not operated pursuant to Part VII.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in a turbo-propeller powered aeroplane that is operated under Part VII without a third attitude indicator that meets the requirements of section 625.41 of the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards unless the aeroplane

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has a passenger seating configuration, excluding pilot seats, of 30 or fewer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a payload capacity of 3 402 kg (7,500 pounds) or less; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: was manufactured prior to March 20, 1997.

Subsection.Text: After December 20, 2010, no person shall conduct a take-off in a turbo-propeller powered aeroplane having a passenger seating configuration, excluding pilot seats, of 10 or more, and operated under Part VII, unless the aeroplane is equipped with a third attitude indicator that meets the requirements of section 625.41 of the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.

Subject to subsection (2), no operator shall operate a turbine-powered aeroplane that has a seating configuration, excluding pilot seats, of six or more, unless the aeroplane is equipped with an operative TAWS that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements for Class A or Class B equipment set out in CAN-TSO-C151b;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets, effective on the day that is five years after the day on which this section comes into force, the altitude accuracy requirements set out in section 551.102 of Chapter 551 of the Airworthiness Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has a terrain and airport database compatible with the area of operation.

Subsection.Text: The operator may operate the aeroplane without its being equipped with an operative TAWS if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane is operated in day VFR only;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the event that a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister and subject to subsection 605.08(1), the operation takes place within the three days after the day on which the failure of the TAWS occurs; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is necessary for the pilot-in-command to deactivate, in the interests of aviation safety, the TAWS or any of its modes and the pilot-in-command does so in accordance with the aircraft flight manual, aircraft operating manual, flight manual supplement or minimum equipment list.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of aeroplanes manufactured on or before the day on which this section comes into force until the day that is two years after that day.

Subject to subsections (3) and (4), no person shall conduct a take-off or permit a take-off to be conducted in an aircraft that is in the legal custody and control of the person, other than an aircraft operated under a special certificate of airworthiness in the owner-maintenance or amateur-built classification, unless the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is maintained in accordance with any airworthiness limitations applicable to the aircraft type design;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of any airworthiness directive issued under section 521.427; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: except as provided in subsection (2), meets the requirements of any notices that are equivalent to airworthiness directives and that are issued by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the competent authority of the foreign state that, at the time the notice was issued, is responsible for the type certification of the aircraft, engine, propeller or appliance, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for an aeronautical product in respect of which no type certificate has been issued, the competent authority of the foreign state that manufactured the aeronautical product.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a conflict between an airworthiness directive issued by the Minister under section 521.427 and a foreign notice, the airworthiness directive prevails.

The Minister shall exempt the owner of a Canadian aircraft from the requirement to comply with all or part of an airworthiness directive, subject to appropriate conditions relating to aviation safety, as specified in Appendix H of the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards, where the owner demonstrates to the Minister that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under circumstances specified in the exemption request, compliance is impractical or unnecessary; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the exemption will provide a level of safety that is equivalent to that required by the airworthiness directive.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall approve an alternative means of compliance with an airworthiness directive, for reasons set out in the approval, where the Minister is satisfied that the proposed alternative will maintain the level of safety that is provided for by the compliance time, the modification, the restriction, the replacement, the special inspection or the procedure set out in the airworthiness directive.

Subject to subsections (2) and (3), no person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft, or permit a take-off to be conducted in an aircraft that is in the legal custody and control of the person, where that aircraft has undergone maintenance, unless the maintenance has been certified by the signing of a maintenance release pursuant to section 571.10.

Where a maintenance release is conditional on the satisfactory completion of a test flight pursuant to subsection 571.10(4), the aircraft may be operated for the purpose of the test flight if no person is carried on board other than flight crew members and persons necessary for the purpose of making observations that are essential to the test flight.

Following a test flight conducted pursuant to subsection (2), the pilot-in-command shall enter the results of the test flight in the journey log and, where the entry indicates that the results of the test flight are satisfactory, that entry completes the maintenance release required by subsection (1).
No maintenance release is required in respect of tasks identified as elementary work in the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.

Subject to subsection (3), no person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft, or permit a take-off to be conducted in an aircraft that is in the person’s legal custody and control, unless the aircraft is maintained in accordance with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a maintenance schedule that conforms to the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated under Subpart 6 of Part IV or under Part VII, or is a large aircraft, a turbine-powered pressurized aircraft or an airship, a maintenance schedule approved by the Minister in respect of the aircraft operator pursuant to subsection (2).

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall approve a maintenance schedule in respect of an aircraft if the schedule conforms to the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.
The Minister shall authorize an operator to deviate from the requirements of the applicable maintenance schedule where the operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submits a request in writing to the Minister in accordance with the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: demonstrates that the deviation will not affect aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: Transfer of Aeronautical Products between Maintenance Schedules

Section.Text: No aeronautical product shall be maintained in accordance with a maintenance schedule that is different from the one under which it was previously maintained unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aeronautical product has been subjected to an inspection that establishes it on the new maintenance schedule; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the times remaining until each action on the new maintenance schedule is to be taken have been established in accordance with the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has been subjected to any abnormal occurrence unless the aircraft has been inspected for damage in accordance with Appendix G of the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.
Where the inspection referred to in subsection (1) does not involve disassembly, it may be performed by the pilot-in-command.
Every owner of an aircraft shall keep the following technical records in respect of the aircraft:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a journey log;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsections (2) and (3), a separate technical record for the airframe, each installed engine and each variable-pitch propeller; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: except where otherwise provided under the terms of a fleet empty weight and balance program referred to in subsection 706.06(3), an empty weight and balance report that meets the applicable standards set out in Chapter 571 of the Airworthiness Manual.

Subsection.Text: The technical records required by paragraph (1)(b) may consist of separate technical records for each component installed in the airframe, engine or propeller.

In the case of a balloon or glider, or an aircraft operated under a special certificate of airworthiness in the owner-maintenance or amateur-built classification, all entries in respect of the technical records referred to in paragraphs (1)(b) and (c) may be kept in the journey log.
Every person who makes an entry in a technical record shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make the entry accurately, legibly and in a permanent manner;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: enter the person’s name and signature or employee identifier or, where the record is kept as electronic data, enter the person’s user code or an equivalent security designation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: date the entry.

Subsection.Text: Where the owner of an aircraft keeps the technical records for the aircraft as electronic data, the owner shall ensure that the electronic data system that is used complies with section 103.04 and the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.
The owner of an aircraft shall ensure that all of the necessary measures are taken to protect the technical records for the aircraft from damage and loss.

Every person who brings into use a new volume of an existing technical record shall make the entries relating to the preceding volume that are necessary to ensure that an unbroken chronological record is maintained.

Subject to subsection (6), where a person alters an entry on a technical record for the purpose of correcting the entry, the person shall do so by striking out the incorrect entry in such a manner that the underlying information remains legible, and inserting the correct entry together with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the alteration;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reason for the alteration, if it is necessary to clarify why the alteration was made; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s name and signature or employee identifier or, where the record is kept as electronic data, the person’s user code or equivalent security designation.

Subsection.Text: Where a correction referred to in subsection (5) is being made to a technical record that is maintained as electronic data, the correction shall be made in a manner that does not render the original data inaccessible.

The particulars set out in column I of an item in Schedule I to this Division shall be recorded in the journey log at the time set out in column II of the item and by the person responsible for making entries set out in column III of that item.
No person shall make a single entry in a journey log in respect of a series of flights unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated by the same pilot-in-command throughout the series; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a daily flight record is used pursuant to section 406.56.

Subsection.Text: The owner of an aircraft shall retain every entry in a journey log for a period of not less than one year.

Unless recorded in the operational flight plan or operational flight data sheet, the pilot-in-command of an aircraft engaged in a commercial air service and operating in international flight shall record in the journey log the following particulars in respect of each flight:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the names of all of the crew members and their duty assignments;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the places and times of departure and arrival;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the flight time;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the flight, such as private, aerial work, scheduled or non-scheduled; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any incidents or observations relating to the flight.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft unless the journey log is on board the aircraft.
A person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft without carrying the journey log on board where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is not planned that the aircraft will land and shut down at any location other than the point of departure; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is a balloon and the journey log is immediately available to the pilot-in-command

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: prior to commencing a flight, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on completion of the flight.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Technical Records Other Than the Journey Log

Subsection.Text: The particulars set out in column I of an item in Schedule II to this Division shall be recorded in the appropriate technical record at the time set out in column II of the item and by the person responsible for making entries set out in column III of that item.

Where particulars of any maintenance performed on an aircraft are transferred from the journey log at the time set out in column II of item 4 of Schedule II to this Division, the person responsible for the entry shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: transcribe the particulars and include the name and identification number of the person who made the original entry; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the pages of the journey log have detachable copies, attach the copy of the page containing these particulars to the applicable technical record.

Subsection.Text: Where a component is installed on a higher assembly, the technical record for that component shall become a part of the technical record for the higher assembly.
Except in the case of the journey log, the owner of an aircraft shall retain each technical record for the applicable period set out in the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards.

Section.Text: Every owner of an aircraft who transfers title of an aircraft, airframe, engine, propeller or appliance to another person shall, at the time of transfer, also deliver to that person all of the technical records that relate to that aeronautical product.

As soon as practicable after the aircraft has received a conditional maintenance release for a test flight, but at the latest, prior to that test flight
The person who signed the conditional maintenance release
Particulars relating to the results of a test flight entered pursuant to subsection 605.85(3)
On completing the test flight but, at the latest, before the next flight
The pilot-in-command of the aircraft who conducted the test flight
Particulars of any defect in any part of the aircraft or its equipment that becomes apparent during flight operations
As soon as practicable after the defect is discovered but, at the latest, before the next flight

Except where a technical dispatch procedure is in place in accordance with section 706.06, the particulars of any defect in any part of the aircraft or its equipment that is not rectified before the next flight
The person who discovered the defect
Particulars of any maintenance action or elementary work performed in respect of items 2, 6, 9, and 10
As soon as practicable after the maintenance action or elementary work is performed but, at the latest, before the next flight
The person who performed the maintenance action or elementary work and, where applicable, the person signing the maintenance release

TableGroup.Caption: TECHNICAL RECORD FOR AN AIRFRAME, ENGINE, PROPELLER OR COMPONENT

row.entry: Aircraft manufacturer, type, model designation and serial number and, in the case of an airframe, aircraft nationality and registration marksIn the case of an engine, propeller or component, the identification number of the aircraft or higher assembly on which the aeronautical product is, or has been, installedAny features of the configuration of the airframe, engine, propeller or component that would affect its use or its suitability for installation on a higher assembly

On starting to keep a technical record and on bringing a new volume of an existing record into use, after any change in the data on the manufacturer’s data plate or following the installation or removal of an engine, propeller or component

The details outlining the scheduling provisions of any airworthiness directive applicable to the airframe, engine, propeller or component, or to any airframe, engine, propeller or component of the same type, and any part thereof
On the coming into effect of the airworthiness directive
The particulars of any abnormal occurrence to which the airframe, engine, propeller or component has been subjected and that has been recorded in the journey log pursuant to item 6 of Schedule I
No later than 30 days after the abnormal occurrence
The particulars of any maintenance performed, including the particulars of any maintenance performed in order to comply with the requirements of an airworthiness directive

As soon as practicable after the maintenance action is performed but, at the latest, before the next flight or, in the case of particulars transferred from the journey log, no later than 30 days after the maintenance action is performed
The person who performed the maintenance action or, in a case where particulars are transferred from the journey log, the owner of the aircraft

Total air time and, where applicable, the number of operating cycles or landings since date of manufacture, at the time of each abnormal occurrence or maintenance action recorded pursuant to item 3 or 4
No later than 30 days after the abnormal occurrence or maintenance action
The person responsible for the entry pursuant to item 3 or 4

Section.Text: No person shall carry weapons, ammunition or other equipment designed for use in war on board an aircraft unless the aircraft is a Canadian aircraft or the Minister has authorized the carriage of such equipment.

Subsection.Text: This section applies to every owner of an aircraft that is registered in Canada, or registered pursuant to the laws of a foreign state and operated in Canada, who is not required to subscribe for liability insurance in respect of the aircraft pursuant to section 7 of the Air Transportation Regulations.

Subject to subsection (3), none of the following aircraft owners shall operate an aircraft unless, in respect of every incident related to the operation of the aircraft, the owner has subscribed for liability insurance covering risks of injury to or death of passengers in an amount that is not less than the amount determined by multiplying $300,000 by the number of passengers on board the aircraft:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of a flight training unit operator certificate; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operator of a balloon in which fare-paying passengers are carried on board pursuant to Subpart 3.

Subsection.Text: The insurance coverage referred to in subsection (2) need not extend to any passenger who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is an employee of an owner referred to in paragraph (2)(a), (b) or (c), if workers’ compensation legislation governing a claim for damages against the owner by the employee is applicable; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is carried on board the aircraft for the purpose of conducting a parachute descent, where the air operator has posted a readily visible notice to inform passengers, before embarking, that there is no insurance coverage for parachutists.

Subsection.Text: No aircraft owner not referred to in paragraph (2)(a), (b) or (c) shall operate an aircraft of more than 2 268 kg (5,000 pounds) maximum permissible take-off weight unless the owner has, in respect of the aircraft, subscribed for liability insurance covering risks of injury to or death of passengers, other than passengers carried on board that aircraft for the purpose of conducting a parachute descent, in an amount not less than the amount determined by multiplying $300,000 by the number of passengers on board the aircraft.

No aircraft owner referred to in paragraph (2)(a), (b) or (c) shall operate an aircraft unless, in respect of every incident related to the operation of the aircraft, the owner has subscribed for liability insurance covering risks of public liability in an amount that is not less than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: $1,000,000, where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is not greater than 3 402 kg (7,500 pounds);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: $2,000,000, where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is greater than 3 402 kg (7,500 pounds) but not greater than 8 165 kg (18,000 pounds); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is greater than 8 165 kg (18,000 pounds), $2,000,000 plus an amount determined by multiplying $150 by the number of pounds by which the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft exceeds 8 165 kg (18,000 pounds).

Subsection.Text: No aircraft owner referred to in paragraph (2)(a), (b) or (c) shall, in order to comply with subsections (2), (4) and (5), subscribe for any liability insurance that contains an exclusion or waiver provision that reduces the insurance coverage for any incident below the applicable minimum determined pursuant to those subsections, unless that provision

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is a standard exclusion clause adopted by the international aviation insurance industry that applies in respect of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: war, hijacking and other perils,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: noise, pollution and other perils, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: radioactive contamination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is in respect of a chemical drift;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: includes a statement that the insurance does not apply in respect of liability assumed by the owner under any contract or agreement unless the liability would have attached to the owner even in the absence of such a contract or agreement; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: includes a statement that the policy is void if the owner has concealed or misrepresented any material fact or circumstance concerning the insurance or the subject thereof or if there is any fraud, attempted fraud or false statement by the owner touching any matter relating to the insurance or the subject thereof, either before or after an incident.

Subsection.Text: An aircraft owner referred to in paragraph (2)(a), (b) or (c) may comply with subsections (2), (4) and (5) by subscribing for comprehensive single limit liability insurance that consists of a single policy or a combination of primary and supplementary policies.

No aircraft owner not referred to in paragraph (2)(a), (b) or (c) shall operate an aircraft unless, in respect of every incident related to the operation of the aircraft, the owner has subscribed for liability insurance covering risks of public liability in an amount that is not less than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: $100,000, where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is 1 043 kg (2,300 pounds) or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: $500,000, where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is greater than 1 043 kg (2,300 pounds) but not greater than 2 268 kg (5,000 pounds);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: $1,000,000, where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is greater than 2 268 kg (5,000 pounds) but not greater than 5 670 kg (12,500 pounds);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: $2,000,000, where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is greater than 5 670 kg (12,500 pounds) but not greater than 34 020 kg (75,000 pounds); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: $3,000,000, where the maximum permissible take-off weight of the aircraft is greater than 34 020 kg (75,000 pounds).

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (10), no owner or operator of an aircraft shall operate the aircraft unless there is carried on board the aircraft proof that liability insurance is subscribed for in accordance with this section.
A balloon may be operated without the proof of insurance referred to in subsection (9) being carried on board if that proof is immediately available to the pilot-in-command

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prior to commencing a flight; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on completion of a flight.

Subsection.Text: No person shall use synthetic flight training equipment to provide training or to conduct a skills assessment required under Part IV, this Part or Part VII unless there is in force in respect of that equipment a flight simulator certificate or flight training device certificate issued under subsection (2) or an equivalent approval or certificate issued under the laws of a foreign state with which Canada has an agreement respecting such equipment.

The Minister shall, where it is determined that the synthetic flight training equipment meets the standards set out for that equipment in the Aeroplane and Rotorcraft Simulator Manual, issue to the operator of that equipment a flight simulator certificate or flight training device certificate.
A certificate issued pursuant to subsection (2) shall set out the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the operator of the synthetic flight training equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the type, model or series number of aircraft represented;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the qualification level of the synthetic flight training equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issuance of the certificate.

Subsection.Text: No certificate issued pursuant to subsection (2) remains in force unless the synthetic flight training equipment in respect of which the certificate has been issued

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintains the performance, function and other characteristics that are required for the issuance of the certificate, except in the cases set out in the Simulator Component Inoperative Guide (SCIG);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is maintained in accordance with the procedures set out in the Aeroplane and Rotorcraft Simulator Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is changed as required, where the aircraft type, model or series number represented by the synthetic flight training equipment undergoes a change as a result of the issuance of an airworthiness directive or an amendment to this Part or Part VII that affects the training being conducted.

Subsection.Text: A certificate issued pursuant to subsection (2) remains in force where the synthetic flight training equipment in respect of which the certificate has been issued is re-evaluated

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight simulator, at least every six months; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight training device, at least every 12 months.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (7), the certificate referred to in subsection (5) remains in force

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight simulator, until the first day of the seventh month following the month in which the flight simulator was evaluated; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a flight training device, until the first day of the thirteenth month following the month in which the flight training device was evaluated.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may extend the period in respect of which a flight simulator certificate or a flight training device certificate is in force by up to 60 days where the Minister is of the opinion that aviation safety is not likely to be affected.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: all-cargo aeroplane means an aeroplane that is equipped and used mainly for the carriage of goods; (avion tout-cargo)
areas of operation means areas in which operations are conducted between points in Canada, between points in Canada and points abroad, and between points abroad; (régions d’exploitation)

Definition.Code: se="700.01",df="{employed on a full-time basis}{employé à temps plein}"
Definition.Text: employed on a full-time basis means working for an air operator on a continuous basis for at least the number of hours required to carry out the duties of the position for the safe operation of the commercial air service; (employé à temps plein)

extended charter means the charter of a Canadian commercial aircraft to a Canadian or foreign air operator for a period of 21 days or more in order to supplement the fleet of the charterer; (affrètement de durée prolongée)

farmer means a person whose primary source of income is derived from the tillage of the soil, the raising of livestock or poultry, dairy farming, the growing of grain, fruit, vegetables or tobacco, or any other operation of a similar nature; (agriculteur)

Definition.Code: se="700.01",df="{flight crew member on reserve}{membre d’équipage de conduite en réserve}"
Definition.Text: flight crew member on reserve means a flight crew member who has been designated by an air operator to be available to report for flight duty on notice of more than one hour; (membre d’équipage de conduite en réserve)

main base means a location at which an air operator has personnel, aircraft and facilities for the conducting of aerial work or the operation of an air transport service and that is established as the principal place of business of the air operator; (base principale)

Definition.Code: se="700.01",df="{net take-off flight path}{trajectoire nette de décollage}"
Definition.Text: net take-off flight path means the one-engine-inoperative flight path that starts at a height of 35 feet at the end of the take-off distance required and extends to a height of at least 1,500 feet AGL, reduced at each point by a gradient of climb equal to 0.8 per cent for two-engined aeroplanes, 0.9 per cent for three-engined aeroplanes and 1.0 per cent for four-engined aeroplanes; (trajectoire nette de décollage)

Definition.Code: se="700.01",df="{operations between points abroad}{exploitation entre points à l’étranger}"
Definition.Text: operations between points abroad means air service operations that are conducted wholly outside Canada for any length of time; (exploitation entre points à l’étranger)

sub-base means a location at which an air operator positions aircraft and personnel and from which operational control is exercised in accordance with the air operator’s operational control system; (base secondaire)
types of operation means VFR, VFR at night and IFR operations; (types de vols)
types of service means a domestic service, a scheduled international service, a non-scheduled international service and a sightseeing operation. (types de service)

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an air transport service unless the person holds and complies with the provisions of an air operator certificate that authorizes the person to operate that service.

Subject to subsections (3) and (4), no person shall, unless the person holds and complies with the provisions of an air operator certificate that authorizes the person to do so, operate an aeroplane or helicopter to conduct aerial work involving

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the carriage on board of persons other than flight crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the carriage of helicopter Class B, C or D external loads;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the towing of objects; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the dispersal of products.

Subsection.Text: A person who does not hold an air operator certificate may conduct aerial work involving the dispersal of products if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person is a farmer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person owns the aircraft that is used to disperse the products;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the products are dispersed for agricultural purposes; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the dispersal of the products takes place within 25 miles of the centre of the person’s farm.

Subsection.Text: A person who does not hold an air operator certificate may conduct aerial work involving the carriage of persons other than flight crew members on board a single-engined aircraft if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person holds a flight training unit operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command is the holder of a valid flight instructor rating in the appropriate category of aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated in day VFR flight;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: there are no more than nine passengers on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is conducted for the purpose of sightseeing operations.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsections (1) and (2), a person who does not hold an air operator certificate may operate an air transport service, or operate an aeroplane or helicopter to conduct aerial work involving the transport of passengers or goods, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person holds a private operator registration document;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person operates the air transport service or conducts the aerial work under a management agreement with another person who has transferred to that person legal custody and control of the aircraft used to operate the service or to conduct the work;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the management agreement provides that the air transport service is operated or the aerial work is conducted exclusively in support of the activities of the person who has transferred legal custody and control of the aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: no payment is made in relation to the air transport service or the aerial work to a party to the management agreement by or on behalf of a passenger or the owner of a transported good unless the passenger or the owner is the person who has transferred legal custody and control of the aircraft.

Heading.TitleText: Authorization to Operate Specialty Air Service under NAFTA

Subsection.Text: A person who is a citizen, permanent resident or corporation of the United States of America or Mexico and who is eligible to operate a specialty air service in Canada in accordance with Chapter 12 and Annex I — Canada of the North American Free Trade Agreement shall, prior to operating the service, obtain from the Minister an authorization to operate the service. The request for the authorization shall be in the form and shall contain the information specified in the Commercial Air Service Standards.

The Minister may, on receipt of a request referred to in subsection (1) and where the requirements of the Commercial Air Service Standards are met, issue an authorization containing the conditions under which the specialty air service may be operated.
An authorization referred to in subsection (1) is required in addition to an air operator certificate for those persons who are required to hold an air operator certificate pursuant to Subpart 2.
A Canadian is eligible to hold an air operator certificate.

A person who is a citizen, permanent resident or corporation of a foreign state is eligible to hold an air operator certificate that authorizes the person to operate an air transport service in Canada if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holds a similar document of entitlement issued by the foreign state; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of Subpart 1.

Subsection.Text: A person who is a citizen, permanent resident or corporation of the United States of America or Mexico is eligible to hold an air operator certificate that authorizes the person to conduct aerial work in Canada if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aerial work is a specialty air service for which the person may obtain an operating certificate in accordance with Chapter 12 and Annex I — Canada of the North American Free Trade Agreement; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person meets the requirements of Subpart 2.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no Canadian air operator shall operate an aircraft in a commercial air service unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate of airworthiness that meets the requirements of Article 31 of the Convention has been issued for the aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aircraft registered in another contracting state, the Minister has authorized its operation under Part II and, where a Canadian type certificate has not been issued for the aircraft type, the aircraft has been approved for operation under Part V.

Subsection.Text: No air operator that is a citizen, permanent resident or corporation of a foreign state shall operate an aircraft in a commercial air service in Canada unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is registered in Canada under Part II or in the foreign state; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where a Canadian type certificate has not been issued for the aircraft type, the aircraft has been approved for operation under Part V.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may authorize the operation of an aircraft in aerial work under Subpart 2 if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a special certificate of airworthiness in the restricted or limited classification has been issued in respect of the aircraft; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign flight authority that is the equivalent of a special certificate of airworthiness in the restricted or limited classification has been issued in respect of the aircraft and validated by the Minister under section 507.05.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft on an extended charter unless the air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: No air operator shall manage another air operator’s operation unless the air operator that manages the operation

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an air service between points abroad unless the air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: The holder of an air operator certificate issued under section 702.07, 703.07, 704.07 or 705.07 shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint an operations manager and, where the holder does not hold an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate, a maintenance manager; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the operations manager meets the requirements of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 722.07 of Standard 722 — Aerial Work of the Commercial Air Service Standards,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 723.07 of Standard 723 — Air Taxi — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 723.07 of Standard 723 — Air Taxi — Helicopters of the Commercial Air Service Standards,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 724.07 of Standard 724 — Commuter Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: section 724.07 of Standard 724 — Commuter Operations — Helicopters of the Commercial Air Service Standards, or

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 725.07 of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the maintenance manager meets the requirements of section 726.03 of Standard 726 — Air Operator Maintenance of the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the holder of an air operator certificate issued under section 705.07, ensure that the operations manager performs the duties set out in subsections 705.03(1) and (2);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of the holder of an air operator certificate issued under section 705.07 who is also the holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate issued under section 573.02, ensure that the person responsible for maintenance performs the duties set out in section 705.04;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: provide the operations manager and the maintenance manager with the financial and human resources necessary to ensure that the holder of the air operator certificate meets the requirements of these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: authorize the maintenance manager to remove aircraft from operation, where the removal is justified because of non-compliance with the requirements of these Regulations or because of a risk to aviation safety or the safety of the public;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that corrective actions are taken in respect of any findings resulting from a quality assurance program established under section 706.07 or a safety management system referred to in section 705.151; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: conduct reviews of the safety management system to determine its effectiveness.

Subsection.Text: The maintenance manager appointed under paragraph (1)(a) shall be the person responsible for the maintenance control system of the air operator appointed under paragraph 706.03(1)(a).

The holder of an air operator certificate issued under section 705.07 shall ensure that the person managing the safety management system referred to in section 705.153 performs the duties set out in that section.

Heading.TitleText: Approach Bans — Non Precision, APV and CAT I Precision

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (3), the visibility with respect to an aeroplane is less than the minimum visibility required for a non-precision approach, an APV or a CAT I precision approach if, in respect of the advisory visibility specified in the Canada Air Pilot and set out in column I of an item in the table to this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR measured by RVR “A” for the runway of intended approach is less than the visibility set out in column II of the item for the approach conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by only one of RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR for the runway of intended approach is less than the visibility set out in column II of the item for the approach conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where no RVR for the runway of intended approach is available, the runway visibility is less than the visibility set out in column II of the item for the approach conducted; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the aerodrome is located south of the 60th parallel of north latitude and no RVR or runway visibility for the runway of intended approach is available, the ground visibility at the aerodrome where the runway is located is less than the visibility set out in column II of the item for the approach conducted.
