Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (3), the visibility with respect to a helicopter is less than the minimum visibility required for a non-precision approach, an APV or a CAT I precision approach if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR measured by RVR “A” for the surface of intended approach is less than 1,200 feet; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the RVR is measured by only one of RVR “A” and RVR “B”, the RVR for the surface of intended approach is less than 1,200 feet.

Subsection.Text: Where the visibility is less than the minimum visibility set out in subsection (1) or (2), as applicable, no person shall continue a non-precision approach, an APV or a CAT I precision approach in an IFR aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the time a visibility report is received, the aircraft has passed the FAF inbound or, where there is no FAF, the point where the final approach course is intercepted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is on a training flight where a landing is not intended and the appropriate air traffic control unit is informed that a missed approach procedure will be initiated at or above the decision height or minimum descent altitude, as appropriate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the RVR is varying between distances less than and greater than the minimum RVR;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the aerodrome is located south of the 60th parallel of north latitude and no RVR or runway visibility for the runway of intended approach is available, the ground visibility at the aerodrome where the runway is located is reported to vary between distances less than and greater than the minimum visibility;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a localized meteorological phenomenon is affecting the ground visibility to the extent that the visibility on the approach to the runway of intended approach and along that runway, as observed by the pilot-in-command in flight and reported immediately to ATS, if available, is equal to or greater than the advisory visibility specified in the Canada Air Pilot in respect of the runway of intended approach for the instrument approach procedure conducted; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the approach is conducted in accordance with section 703.41, 704.37 or 705.48.

Subsection.Text: No pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft operated under this Part shall commence a non-precision approach, an APV or a CAT I precision approach to an airport where low-visibility procedures are in effect.

Heading.TitleText: Approach Bans — CAT II and CAT III Precision

Section.Text: No pilot-in-command of an IFR aircraft operated under this Part who is conducting a CAT II or CAT III precision approach shall continue the approach beyond the FAF inbound or, where there is no FAF, the point where the final approach course is intercepted, unless the RVR is equal to or greater than the minimum RVR specified in the Canada Air Pilot in respect of the runway or surface of intended approach for the instrument approach procedure conducted.

Heading.TitleText: Division III — Flight Time and Flight Duty Time Limitations and Rest Periods

Subsection.Text: Every air operator shall establish a system that monitors the flight time, flight duty time and rest periods of each of its flight crew members and shall include in its company operations manual the details of that system.

Where a person becomes aware that an assignment by an air operator to act as a flight crew member on a flight would result in the maximum flight time referred to in section 700.15 or the maximum flight duty time referred to in section 700.16 being exceeded, the person shall so notify the air operator.

Subject to subsection (2), no air operator shall assign a flight crew member for flight time, and no flight crew member shall accept such an assignment, if the flight crew member’s total flight time in all flights conducted by the flight crew member will, as a result, exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 1,200 hours in any 365 consecutive days;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 300 hours in any 90 consecutive days;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 120 hours in any 30 consecutive days or, in the case of a flight crew member on call, 100 hours in any 30 consecutive days;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the flight is conducted under Subpart 4 or 5 using an aircraft other than a helicopter, 40 hours in any 7 consecutive days;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where the flight is conducted under Subpart 2 or 3, or is conducted using a helicopter, 60 hours in any 7 consecutive days; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: where the flight crew member conducts single-pilot IFR flights, 8 hours in any 24 consecutive hours.

Subsection.Text: An air operator may assign a flight crew member for flight time, and a flight crew member may accept such an assignment, where the flight crew member’s flight time will, as a result, exceed the flight time referred to in subsection (1) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the increase in flight time is authorized in the air operator’s air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator and the flight crew member comply with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 700.17, a flight crew member who reaches a flight time limitation established by this section is deemed to be fatigued and shall not continue on flight duty or be reassigned to flight duty until such time as the flight crew member has had the rest period required by section 700.16 or 700.19.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Duty Time Limitations and Rest Periods

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (5) and (7), no air operator shall assign a flight crew member for flight duty time, and no flight crew member shall accept such an assignment, if the flight crew member’s flight duty time will, as a result, exceed 14 consecutive hours in any 24 consecutive hours. Where the flight is conducted under Subpart 4 or 5 using an aircraft other than a helicopter, flight duty time shall include 15 minutes for post-flight duties.

Where the flight is conducted under Subpart 4 or 5 using an aircraft other than a helicopter or a DeHavilland DHC-6 aircraft pursuant to the Commercial Air Service Standards, a flight crew member shall receive at least 24 consecutive hours free from flight duty following 3 consecutive flight duty time assignments that exceed 12 consecutive hours unless the flight crew member has received at least 24 consecutive hours free from flight duty between each flight duty time assignment.
Following a flight duty time assignment, an air operator shall provide a flight crew member with the minimum rest period and any additional rest period required by this Part.
A flight crew member shall use a rest period provided pursuant to subsection (3) and section 700.19 to obtain the necessary rest and shall be adequately rested prior to reporting for flight duty.

Where flight duty time includes a rest period, flight duty time may be extended beyond the maximum flight duty time referred to in subsection (1) by one-half the length of the rest period referred to in paragraph (b), to a maximum of 3 hours, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator provides the flight crew member with advance notice of the extension of flight duty time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator provides the flight crew member with a rest period of at least 4 consecutive hours in suitable accommodation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the flight crew member’s rest is not interrupted by the air operator during the rest period.

Subsection.Text: The minimum rest period following flight duty time referred to in subsection (5) and prior to the next flight duty time shall be increased by an amount at least equal to the extension to the flight duty time.

An air operator may assign a flight crew member for flight duty time, and a flight crew member may accept such an assignment, where the flight crew member’s flight duty time will, as a result, exceed the flight duty time referred to in subsection (1) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the increase in flight duty time is authorized in the air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator and the flight crew member comply with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: The maximum flight time referred to in paragraphs 700.15(1)(a) to (e) and the maximum flight duty time referred to in subsection 700.16(1) may be exceeded if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight is extended as a result of unforeseen operational circumstances;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command, after consultation with the other flight crew members, considers it safe to exceed the maximum flight time and flight duty time; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator and the pilot-in-command comply with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: Where a flight crew member is notified of a delay in reporting time before leaving a rest facility and the delay is in excess of 3 hours, the flight crew member’s flight duty time is considered to have started 3 hours after the original reporting time.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Time Free from Duty

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), an air operator shall provide each flight crew member with the following time free from duty:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the operation is conducted under Subpart 4 or 5 using an aircraft other than a helicopter, one period of at least 36 consecutive hours within each 7 consecutive days or one period of at least 3 consecutive calendar days within each 17 consecutive days;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the operation is conducted under Subpart 2 or 3 or is conducted using a helicopter, one period of at least 24 consecutive hours 13 times within each 90 consecutive days and 3 times within each 30 consecutive days; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the flight crew member is a flight crew member on call, one period of at least 36 consecutive hours within each 7 consecutive days or one period of at least 3 consecutive calendar days within each 17 consecutive days.

Subsection.Text: An air operator may provide a flight crew member with time free from duty other than as required by paragraphs (1)(a) and (b) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the time free from duty is authorized in the air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator and the flight crew member comply with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall notify a flight crew member on call of the commencement and duration of the flight crew member’s time free from duty.

Section.Text: Where a flight crew member is required by an air operator to travel for the purpose of positioning after the completion of flight duty time, the air operator shall provide the flight crew member with an additional rest period at least equal to one-half the time spent travelling that is in excess of the flight crew member’s maximum flight duty time.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall provide flight crew members on reserve, within each 24-hour period, with a rest period that meets the requirements of the Commercial Air Service Standards.
Every air operator shall outline in its company operations manual a method for ensuring compliance with this section and the Commercial Air Service Standards.

A flight or series of flights that terminates more than 4 one-hour time zones from the point of departure, other than flights conducted entirely within Northern Domestic Airspace, shall be limited to 3 sectors and shall be followed by a rest period that is at least equal to the length of the preceding flight duty time.

Where a flight referred to in subsection (1) is a transoceanic flight, the maximum number of sectors that may be completed after the transoceanic sector is one, excluding one unscheduled technical stop.

Heading.TitleText: Controlled Rest on the Flight Deck

Section.Text: An air operator may institute a program of controlled rest on the flight deck if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the program is authorized in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator and the flight crew members comply with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: This Subpart applies in respect of the operation in Canada of a foreign state aircraft or an aircraft operated by a foreign operator in an air transport service.

Heading.TitleText: Requirement for Canadian Foreign Air Operator Certificate

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), no person shall operate an aircraft in Canada unless the person complies with the conditions in a Canadian foreign air operator certificate issued to that person by the Minister pursuant to section 701.07.

A person is not required to hold a Canadian foreign air operator certificate in order to conduct an overflight of Canada or to perform a technical landing in Canada unless the person operates the aircraft under section 701.19, 701.20 or 701.21.
A person is not required to hold a Canadian foreign air operator certificate in order to operate a foreign state aircraft in Canada.

No person, other than the holder of a Canadian foreign air operator certificate, shall conduct an overflight of Canada or perform a technical landing in Canada unless the person is authorized to do so in a flight authorization issued by the Minister pursuant to section 701.10.
No person shall operate a foreign state aircraft in Canada unless the person is authorized to do so in a flight authorization issued by the Minister pursuant to section 701.10.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance or Amendment of Canadian Foreign Air Operator Certificate

Section.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by the Commercial Air Service Standards, issue or amend a Canadian foreign air operator certificate.

Heading.TitleText: Contents of Canadian Foreign Air Operator Certificate

Section.Text: A Canadian foreign air operator certificate shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the legal name, trade name and address of the foreign air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the foreign air operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the effective date of certification;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the general conditions identified in section 701.09;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: specific conditions with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the areas of operation authorized,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the types of service authorized,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the types of aircraft authorized, the conditions of operation and, if applicable, their registration, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the base of operations and the designated points in Canada, if applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: where the foreign air operator complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards, operations specifications with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: instrument approach procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: special weather minima authorizations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: navigation system authorizations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: authorizations concerning flight crew member complement,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: special helicopter procedures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: any other condition pertaining to the operation that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: General Conditions of Canadian Foreign Air Operator Certificate

Section.Text: A Canadian foreign air operator certificate shall contain the following general conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator shall have a valid air operator certificate or equivalent document issued by the state of the foreign air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator shall make no change in its air transport service in Canada, except in the case of an emergency, without notifying the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator shall notify the Minister within 10 working days after any change in its legal name or trade name;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator shall conduct flight operations in accordance with the ICAO standards;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator shall maintain its aircraft in accordance with the ICAO standards;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator shall comply with the applicable provisions of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator shall conduct a safe operation.

Section.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by the Commercial Air Service Standards, issue a flight authorization

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to conduct an overflight of Canada or to perform a technical landing in Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to operate a foreign state aircraft in Canada.

Section.Text: A flight authorization shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the holder of the flight authorization or of the person responsible for the flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the type of aircraft, the registration mark and, if applicable, the serial number;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the routing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date and time of arrival at, and departure from, the airports concerned;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the places of embarkation or disembarkation of passengers or freight;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an authorization for the transportation of dangerous goods or agricultural products, if applicable;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign state aircraft, an authorization to conduct flight operations referred to in section 701.19, 701.20 or 701.21;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a requirement to conduct all operations in accordance with the applicable provisions of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any condition pertaining to the operation that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no foreign air operator shall commence a flight in Canada in a twin-engined aeroplane certified for more than 20 passenger seats that is intended to be operated on a route containing a point that is farther from an adequate aerodrome than the distance that can be flown in 60 minutes at the one-engine-inoperative cruise speed, unless the flight is conducted wholly within Canadian Domestic Airspace.
A foreign air operator may commence a flight referred to in subsection (1) where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane is turbine-powered;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator holds a valid authorization or equivalent document issued by the state of the foreign air operator for extended range twin-engined operations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator is authorized to do so in its Canadian foreign air operator certificate.

Heading.TitleText: Canadian Minimum Navigation Performance Specifications (CMNPS) or North Atlantic Minimum Navigation Performance Specifications (NAT-MNPS) Airspace

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no foreign air operator shall commence a flight in Canada in an aircraft that is intended to be operated in airspace designated as CMNPS or NAT-MNPS unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft has been certified by the state of registry as meeting the minimum navigation performance specifications contained in the North Atlantic MNPS Airspace Operations Manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator holds a valid authorization or equivalent document issued by the state of the foreign air operator or the state of registry for flight operations in airspace designated as CMNPS or NAT-MNPS; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator is authorized to do so in its Canadian foreign air operator certificate.

Subsection.Text: A foreign air operator may, in airspace designated as CMNPS, commence a flight in Canada in an aircraft that has not been certified in accordance with paragraph (1)(a) where the appropriate ATC unit indicates that the aircraft can be accommodated without penalizing CMNPS-certified aircraft.

Section.Text: No foreign air operator commencing a flight in Canada shall, in uncontrolled airspace, conduct an IFR flight or a night VFR flight on a route other than an air route unless the foreign air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its Canadian foreign air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 602.122, a person may conduct an IFR flight where an alternate aerodrome has not been designated in the IFR flight plan or in the IFR flight itinerary if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign air operator, the foreign air operator is authorized to do so in its Canadian foreign air operator certificate and complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person who operates a foreign state aircraft, the person is authorized to do so in a flight authorization and complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 602.126, a person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft where weather conditions are below the take-off minima specified in the Canada Air Pilot if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign air operator, the foreign air operator is authorized to do so in its Canadian foreign air operator certificate and complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person who operates a foreign state aircraft, the person is authorized to do so in a flight authorization and complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: For the purposes of subsection 602.128(4), a person may conduct a CAT II or CAT III precision approach in an IFR aircraft if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foreign air operator, the foreign air operator is authorized to do so in its Canadian foreign air operator certificate and holds a valid authorization or equivalent document issued by the state of the foreign air operator to conduct a CAT II or CAT III precision approach in Canada; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a person who operates a foreign state aircraft, the person is authorized to do so in a flight authorization and complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Transport of Passengers in Single-engined Aircraft

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no foreign air operator commencing a flight in Canada shall operate a single-engined aircraft with passengers on board in IFR flight or in night VFR flight.
A foreign air operator may operate a single-engined aircraft with passengers on board in IFR flight or in night VFR flight if the foreign air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so by the state of the foreign air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its Canadian foreign air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: Where a Department of Transport air carrier inspector presents an official identity card to the pilot-in-command of an aircraft operated by a foreign air operator in Canada, the pilot-in-command shall give the inspector free and uninterrupted access to the flight deck of the aircraft.

A foreign air operator and the pilot-in-command shall make available for the use of the air carrier inspector the observer seat most suitable to perform the inspector’s duties, as determined by the inspector.

Section.Text: A foreign air operator shall provide a cabin safety inspector who is performing an in-flight cabin inspection in Canada with a confirmed passenger seat in the passenger compartment.

Subsection.Text: In this section, “critical surfaces” means the wings, control surfaces, rotors, propellers, horizontal stabilizers, vertical stabilizers or any other stabilizing surface of an aircraft and, in the case of an aircraft that has rear-mounted engines, includes the upper surface of its fuselage.
No person shall conduct or attempt to conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has frost, ice or snow adhering to any of its critical surfaces.

Notwithstanding subsection (2), a person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has frost caused by cold-soaked fuel adhering to the underside of its wings if the take-off is conducted in accordance with the aircraft manufacturer’s instructions for take-off under those conditions.
Where conditions are such that frost, ice or snow may reasonably be expected to adhere to an aircraft, no person shall conduct or attempt to conduct a take-off in the aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft has been inspected immediately prior to take-off to determine whether any frost, ice or snow is adhering to any of its critical surfaces; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the foreign air operator or the holder of the flight authorization has

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: established, in accordance with ICAO Document No. 9640 entitled Manual of Aircraft Ground De/Anti-icing Operations, an aircraft ground icing operations program that has been approved by the state of the foreign air operator or of the holder of the flight authorization, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: submitted to the Minister an aircraft ground icing operations program that meets the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: The inspection referred to in paragraph (4)(a) shall be performed from outside the aircraft.
The inspection referred to in paragraph (4)(a) shall be performed by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a flight crew member of the aircraft who is designated by the pilot-in-command; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person, other than a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), who is designated by the foreign air operator or the holder of the flight authorization.

Subsection.Text: No person shall perform the inspection referred to in paragraph (4)(a) unless the person has received annual training concerning aircraft surface contamination in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Where, before commencing a take-off, a crew member of an aircraft observes that there is frost, ice or snow adhering to the wings of the aircraft, the crew member shall immediately report that observation to the pilot-in-command, and the pilot-in-command or a flight crew member designated by the pilot-in-command shall inspect the wings of the aircraft before take-off.

Section.Text: In this Division, payload capacity means the maximum zero fuel weight of an aeroplane set out in the type certificate issued in respect of the aeroplane less

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the empty weight of the aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment necessary for the operation of the aeroplane; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operating load of the aeroplane, which includes the minimum flight crew.

Subsection.Text: All the provisions of this Division apply in respect of the operation by a foreign air operator, in Canadian airspace, of a transport category aircraft that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger-carrying aeroplane in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of 20 or more passengers; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an all-cargo aeroplane with a payload capacity of more than 3 405 kg (7,500 pounds) that was equipped with a flight deck door on June 21, 2002.

Subsection.Text: Section 701.28 also applies in respect of the operation by a foreign air operator, in Canadian airspace, of a transport category aircraft that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger-carrying aeroplane in respect of which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of fewer than 20 passengers; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an all-cargo aeroplane with a payload capacity of 3 405 kg (7,500 pounds) or less that was equipped with a flight deck door on June 21, 2002.

Section.Text: No person shall be admitted to the flight deck of an aeroplane other than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a flight crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a crew member performing their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an inspector of the civil aviation authority of the state where the aeroplane is registered; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a person who has expertise related to the aeroplane, its equipment or its crew members and who is required to be in the flight deck to provide a service to the air operator.

Heading.TitleText: Closing and Locking of Flight Deck Door

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the pilot-in-command of an aeroplane that is equipped with a lockable flight deck door and that is carrying passengers shall ensure that at all times from the moment the passenger entry doors are closed in preparation for departure until they are opened on arrival the flight deck door is closed and locked.
Subsection (1) does not apply when crew members or persons authorized in accordance with subsection 701.28 are required to enter or leave the flight deck

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the performance of their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for physiological needs; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for an overriding concern related to the safety of the flight.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), no foreign air operator shall operate a transport category aircraft, except for a newly manufactured aeroplane on a non-revenue flight and any aeroplane on an overflight, unless the transport category aircraft is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a passenger-carrying aeroplane,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a door between the flight deck and the passenger compartment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the aeroplane is equipped with a crew rest facility having an entry from the flight deck and a separate entry from the passenger compartment, a door between the crew rest facility and the passenger compartment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an all-cargo aeroplane that was equipped with a flight deck door on June 21, 2002,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a door between the flight deck and a compartment occupied by a person, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the aeroplane is equipped with a crew rest facility having an entry from the flight deck and a separate entry from a compartment occupied by a person, a door between the crew rest facility and the compartment.

Subsection.Text: The doors required by subsection (1) shall be equipped with a locking device that can be unlocked only from inside the flight deck or the crew rest facility, as the case may be.

A key shall be readily available to each crew member for each door that separates a passenger compartment or a compartment occupied by a person from an emergency exit, with the exception of a door required by subsection (1).

No crew member, except a flight crew member, shall have a key to a door required by subsection (1) at any time from the moment the passenger entry doors are closed in preparation for departure until they are opened on arrival unless the locking device required by subsection (2) is installed and locked.

No foreign air operator shall operate an aeroplane that is required by subsection (1) to be equipped with a door unless each door meets the design requirements of section 525.795 of the Airworthiness Manual in effect on May 1, 2002.
Subject to subsection (2), this Subpart applies in respect of the operation of an aeroplane or helicopter in aerial work involving

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the carriage on board of persons other than flight crew members;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the carriage of helicopter Class B, C or D external loads;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the towing of objects; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the dispersal of products.

Subsection.Text: This Subpart does not apply in respect of the operation of an ultra-light aeroplane, or in respect of the operation of an aircraft in aerial work involving sightseeing operations.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft under this Subpart unless the air operator complies with the conditions and operations specifications in an air operator certificate issued to that operator by the Minister pursuant to section 702.07.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance or Amendment of Air Operator Certificate

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by the Commercial Air Service Standards, issue or amend an air operator certificate where the applicant demonstrates to the Minister the ability to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain an adequate organizational structure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: maintain an operational control system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: meet training program requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: comply with maintenance requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: meet the Commercial Air Service Standards for the operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: conduct the operation safely.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), an applicant shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a management organization capable of exercising operational control;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: managerial personnel who meet the Commercial Air Service Standards, are employed on a full-time basis and perform the functions related to the following positions, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: operations manager,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: chief pilot, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the applicant does not hold an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate, maintenance manager;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the ground handling services and equipment necessary to ensure the safe handling of its flights;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft that are properly equipped for and flight crew members who are qualified for the area of operation and the type of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an operational control system that meets the requirements of section 702.12;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a training program that meets the requirements of this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: legal custody and control of at least one aircraft of each category of aircraft that is to be operated;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a company operations manual that meets the requirements of sections 702.81 and 702.82; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a maintenance control system approved pursuant to Subpart 6.

Section.Text: An air operator certificate shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the legal name, trade name and address of the air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the air operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the effective date of certification;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the general conditions identified in section 702.09;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: specific conditions with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the areas of operation authorized,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the types of service authorized,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the types of aircraft authorized and, if applicable, their registration, and any operational restrictions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the main base and, if applicable, sub-bases; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: where the air operator complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards, operations specifications with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft performance, equipment and emergency equipment requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: instrument approach procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: operations over a built-up area or in an aerial work zone,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the carriage of persons other than flight crew members and persons whose presence on board an aircraft is essential during flight,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: special weather minima authorizations,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: authorizations concerning flight crew member complement,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: navigation system authorizations,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: pilot training and pilot proficiency checks,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: special helicopter procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: the air operator maintenance control system approved pursuant to Subpart 6,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: leasing arrangements, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other condition pertaining to the operation that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: General Conditions of Air Operator Certificate

Section.Text: An air operator certificate shall contain the following general conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall conduct flight operations in accordance with its company operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain an adequate organizational structure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall employ managerial personnel who meet the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall conduct training in accordance with its training program approved pursuant to this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain aircraft that are properly equipped for the area of operation and the type of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall employ crew members who are qualified for the area of operation and the type of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain its aircraft in accordance with the requirements of Subpart 6;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain operational support services and equipment that meet the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall notify the Minister within 10 working days after

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: changing its legal name, its trade name, its main base, a sub-base or its managerial personnel, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: ceasing to operate a type of aircraft authorized under this Subpart; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall conduct a safe operation.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall ensure that all operations personnel are properly instructed about their duties and about the relationship of their duties to the operation as a whole.
The operations personnel of an air operator shall follow the procedures specified in the air operator’s company operations manual in the performance of their duties.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft unless the air operator has an operational control system that meets the Commercial Air Service Standards and is under the control of its operations manager.
No person shall commence a flight unless the flight has been authorized in accordance with the procedures specified in the air operator’s company operations manual.

No air operator shall permit a person to commence a flight unless an operational flight plan that meets the Commercial Air Service Standards has been prepared in accordance with the procedures specified in the air operator’s company operations manual.
No air operator shall permit a person to conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has not been maintained in accordance with the air operator’s maintenance control system.
No air operator shall allow a person who is not a flight crew member to be carried on board an aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s presence on board is essential during the flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator is authorized in its air operator certificate to permit parachute descents and the person is a parachutist; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is authorized in its air operator certificate to carry a person, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: VFR Flight Minimum Flight Visibility — Uncontrolled Airspace

Subsection.Text: Where an aeroplane is operated in day VFR flight within uncontrolled airspace at less than 1,000 feet AGL, a person may, for the purposes of subparagraph 602.115(c)(i), operate the aeroplane when flight visibility is less than two miles if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: Where a helicopter is operated in day VFR flight within uncontrolled airspace at less than 1,000 feet AGL, a person may, for the purposes of subparagraph 602.115(d)(i), operate the helicopter when flight visibility is less than one mile if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Night, VFR OTT and IFR Operations

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no air operator shall operate an aircraft at night, in VFR OTT flight or in IFR flight

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: while towing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while carrying a helicopter Class B, C or D external load;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: while dispersing products; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is a single-engined aircraft.

Subsection.Text: An air operator may operate an aircraft at night, in VFR OTT flight or in IFR flight in any of the cases referred to in subsection (1), if the air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft at night with persons other than flight crew members on board unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command has an instrument rating;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator is authorized in its air operator certificate to permit parachute descents and night VFR flight and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the persons are parachutists,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the flight takes place within 10 nautical miles of the aerodrome of departure, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the flight takes place at night; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator is authorized in its air operator certificate to carry persons, other than parachutists, and the air operator complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Entering or Leaving a Helicopter in Flight

Section.Text: For the purposes of paragraph 602.25(2)(b), the pilot-in-command of a helicopter may permit a person to enter or leave the helicopter in flight

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the helicopter is operated at a low hover,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the person is able to enter directly from or alight directly onto the supporting surface,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the air operator is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the air operator complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the helicopter is operated to enable hoisting or rappelling, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the air operator complies with section 702.21.

Section.Text: No air operator shall, except when conducting a take-off or landing, operate a land aircraft over water, beyond a point where the land aircraft could reach shore in the event of an engine failure, unless the air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no air operator shall operate a helicopter to carry a helicopter Class D external load unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the helicopter is a multi-engined helicopter that meets the transport category engine-isolation requirements of Chapter 529 of the Airworthiness Manual and that is capable of hovering with one engine inoperative at the existing weight and altitude;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: An air operator may operate a helicopter other than a helicopter described in paragraph (1)(a) to carry a helicopter Class D external load if the air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Built-up Area and Aerial Work Zone

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection 602.13(1), a person may conduct a take-off, approach or landing in an aircraft within a built-up area of a city or town at a place other than an airport, heliport or a military aerodrome, if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has an authorization from the Minister or is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph 602.15(2)(a), a person may operate an aircraft over a built-up area at altitudes and distances less than those specified in paragraph 602.14(2)(a), if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has an authorization from the Minister or is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection 602.16(2), a person may operate a helicopter that is carrying a helicopter Class B, C or D external load over a built-up area or in an aerial work zone, if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has an authorization from the Minister or is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Briefing of Persons Other Than Flight Crew Members

Section.Text: The pilot-in-command shall ensure that persons, other than flight crew members, who are on board the aircraft are given a safety briefing that meets the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Operation of Aircraft in Icing Conditions

Section.Text: When icing conditions are reported to exist or are forecast to be encountered along the route of flight, no person shall authorize a flight or its continuation or conduct a take-off or continue a flight in an aircraft, even if the pilot-in-command determines that the aircraft is adequately equipped to operate in icing conditions in accordance with paragraph 605.30(a), if, in the opinion of the pilot-in-command, the safety of the flight might be adversely affected.

Heading.TitleText: Division IV — Aircraft Performance Operating Limitations

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft at night unless the aircraft is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least one landing light; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the aircraft is operated in icing conditions, a means of illumination or other means to detect the formation of ice.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate a multi-engined aircraft in IMC unless the aircraft is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two generators or two alternators, each of which is driven by a separate engine or by a rotor drive train; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two independent sources of energy, at least one of which is not a battery, and each of which is able to drive all flight instruments requiring a source of energy and is installed so that the failure of one instrument or one source of energy will affect neither the energy supply to the remaining instruments nor the other source of energy.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft on a single-pilot operation in IFR flight unless the aircraft is equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an auto-pilot that is capable of operating the aircraft controls to maintain flight and manoeuvre the aircraft about the lateral and longitudinal axes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a headset with a boom microphone or equivalent and a transmit button on the control column; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a chart holder that is equipped with a light and that is placed in an easily readable position.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft unless the pilot seat and any seat beside the pilot seat are equipped with a safety belt that includes a shoulder harness.

No air operator shall operate an aircraft carrying an external load unless the attachment device is authorized in a supplemental type certificate or in an airworthiness approval relating to the operational configuration of the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no air operator shall operate a turbine-powered aeroplane having an MCTOW greater than 15 000 kg (33,069 pounds) in RVSM airspace unless the aeroplane is equipped with an operative ACAS that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C119b or a more recent version of it or other requirements that the Minister has accepted as providing a level of safety that is at least equivalent to the level that that CAN-TSO provides; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is equipped with a Mode S transponder that meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C112 or a more recent version of it.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no air operator shall operate a turbine-powered aeroplane having an MCTOW greater than 15 000 kg (33,069 pounds) in airspace outside RVSM airspace unless the aeroplane is equipped with an operative ACAS that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C119a or a more recent version of it or other requirements that the Minister has accepted as providing a level of safety that is at least equivalent to the level that that CAN-TSO provides; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is equipped with a Mode S transponder that meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C112 or a more recent version of it.

Subsection.Text: The air operator may operate the aeroplane without its being equipped with an operative ACAS if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister and subject to subsection 605.08(1), the operation takes place within the three days after the date of failure of the ACAS;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is necessary for the pilot-in-command to deactivate, in the interests of aviation safety, the ACAS or any of its modes and the pilot-in-command does so in accordance with the aircraft flight manual, aircraft operating manual, flight manual supplement or minimum equipment list; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane is engaged in or configured for use in fire fighting, aerial spraying services or aerial surveying and operates only in low level airspace.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of aeroplanes manufactured on or before the day on which this section comes into force until two years after that day.

Section.Text: An air operator shall designate for each flight a pilot-in-command and, where the crew includes two pilots, a pilot-in-command and a second-in-command.
No air operator shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as a flight crew member in an aircraft unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holds the licence and ratings required by Part IV or, where the air operator is the holder of an air operator certificate issued in accordance with the North American Free Trade Agreement, the equivalent foreign licence and ratings;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is operated in IFR flight and persons other than flight crew members are on board, has successfully completed a pilot proficiency check, the validity period of which has not expired, for that type of aircraft, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the person is not the chief pilot, has successfully completed a competency check or a pilot proficiency check, the validity period of which has not expired, for that type of aircraft in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: has fulfilled the requirements of the air operator’s ground and flight training program.

Subsection.Text: A pilot proficiency check shall be conducted by the Minister.
Any other check required under this Subpart may be conducted by the Minister.

Subject to subsections (3) and (5), the validity period of a pilot proficiency check expires on the first day of the twenty-fifth month following the month in which the proficiency check was completed.

Subject to subsections (4) and (5), the validity period of a competency check and the annual training referred to in section 702.76 expires on the first day of the thirteenth month following the month in which the competency check or training was completed.
Where a pilot proficiency check is renewed within the last 90 days of its validity period, its validity period is extended by 24 months.
Where a competency check or annual training is renewed within the last 90 days of its validity period, its validity period is extended by 12 months.

The Minister may extend the validity period of a pilot proficiency check, a competency check or annual training by up to 60 days where the Minister is of the opinion that aviation safety is not likely to be affected.

Where the validity period of a pilot proficiency check, a competency check or annual training has been expired for 24 months or more, the person shall requalify by meeting the training requirements specified in the Commercial Air Service Standards.
Every air operator shall establish and maintain a ground and flight training program that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed to ensure that each person who receives training acquires the competence to perform the person’s assigned duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: approved by the Minister in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: An air operator’s ground and flight training program shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: company indoctrination training;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: upgrading training;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: training in the aerial work to be conducted; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: initial and annual training, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft type training,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft servicing and ground handling training,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: emergency procedures training,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft surface contamination training for pilots and other operations personnel,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: training for personnel who are assigned to perform duties on board an aircraft or who are carried externally by an aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: any other training required to ensure a safe operation under this Subpart.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include a detailed syllabus of its ground and flight training program in its company operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that adequate facilities and qualified personnel are provided for its ground and flight training program, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a safety awareness program concerning the adverse effects of aircraft surface contamination and provide the program to all flight operations personnel who are not required to receive the training described in subparagraph (2)(d)(iv).

Subsection.Text: Every air operator shall, for each person who is required to receive training under this Subpart, establish and maintain a record of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s name and, where applicable, personnel licence number, type and ratings;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the person’s medical category and the expiry date of that category;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the dates on which the person, while in the air operator’s employ, successfully completed any training, pilot proficiency check, competency check or examination required under this Subpart or obtained any qualification required under this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: information relating to any failure of the person, while in the air operator’s employ, to successfully complete any training, pilot proficiency check, competency check or examination required under this Subpart or to obtain any qualification required under this Subpart; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the type of aircraft or flight training equipment used for any training, pilot proficiency check, competency check or qualification required under this Subpart.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall retain the records referred to in paragraphs (1)(c) and (d) and a record of each pilot proficiency check for at least three years.
An air operator shall retain a copy of the most recent written examination completed by each pilot for each type of aircraft for which the pilot has a qualification.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements relating to Company Operations Manual

Subsection.Text: Every air operator shall establish and maintain a company operations manual that meets the requirements of section 702.82.
An air operator shall submit its company operations manual, and any amendments to that manual, to the Minister.

Where there is a change in any aspect of an air operator’s operation or where the company operations manual no longer meets the Commercial Air Service Standards, the air operator shall amend its company operations manual.

The Minister shall, where the Commercial Air Service Standards are met, approve those parts of a company operations manual, and any amendments to those parts, that relate to the information required by section 702.82.

A company operations manual, which may be issued in separate parts corresponding to specific aspects of an operation, shall include the instructions and information necessary to enable the personnel concerned to perform their duties safely and shall contain the information required by the Commercial Air Service Standards.
A company operations manual shall be such that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all parts of the manual are consistent and compatible in form and content;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manual can be readily amended;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the manual contains an amendment control page and a list of the pages that are in effect; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the manual has the date of the last amendment to each page specified on that page.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), an air operator shall provide a copy of the appropriate parts of its company operations manual, including any amendments to those parts, to each of its crew members and to its ground operations and maintenance personnel.

If an air operator has established procedures in its company operations manual for amending the manual, the air operator may, instead of providing a copy of the appropriate parts of that manual to each crew member, place a copy of those parts

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in each aircraft that it operates; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in an appropriate place other than an aircraft that it operates for the purpose of conducting a parachute descent within 25 nautical miles of the aerodrome of departure.

Subsection.Text: Every person who has been provided with a copy of the appropriate parts of a company operations manual pursuant to subsection (1) shall keep it up to date with the amendments provided and shall ensure that the appropriate parts are accessible when the person is performing assigned duties.

Every air operator shall, for each of its aircraft that is required to be operated by two or more pilots, establish and maintain standard operating procedures that enable the crew members to operate the aircraft within the limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual and that meet the Commercial Air Service Standards.
An air operator that has established standard operating procedures for an aircraft shall ensure that a copy of the standard operating procedures is carried on board the aircraft.

Section.Text: This Subpart applies in respect of the operation by a Canadian air operator, in an air transport service or in aerial work involving sightseeing operations, of any of the following aircraft:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a single-engined aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a multi-engined aircraft, other than a turbo-jet-powered aeroplane, that has a MCTOW of 8 618 kg (19,000 pounds) or less and a seating configuration, excluding pilot seats, of nine or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b.1)
Paragraph.Text: a multi-engined helicopter certified for operation by one pilot and operated under VFR; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any aircraft that is authorized by the Minister to be operated under this Subpart.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft under this Subpart unless the air operator complies with the conditions and operations specifications in an air operator certificate issued to that operator by the Minister pursuant to section 703.07.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance or Amendment of Air Operator Certificate

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 6.71 of the Act, the Minister shall, on receipt of an application submitted in the form and manner required by the Commercial Air Service Standards, issue or amend an air operator certificate where the applicant demonstrates to the Minister the ability to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: maintain an adequate organizational structure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: maintain an operational control system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: meet training program requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: comply with maintenance requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: meet the Commercial Air Service Standards for the operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: conduct the operation safely.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), an applicant shall have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a management organization capable of exercising operational control;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: managerial personnel who have been approved by the Minister in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards, are employed on a full-time basis and perform the functions related to the following positions, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: operations manager,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: chief pilot, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the applicant does not hold an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate, maintenance manager;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: operational support services and equipment that meet the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: aircraft that are properly equipped for and flight crew members who are qualified for the area of operation and the type of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an operational control system that meets the requirements of section 703.16;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a training program that meets the requirements of this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: legal custody and control of at least one aircraft of each category of aircraft that is to be operated;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a company operations manual that meets the requirements of sections 703.104 and 703.105; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a maintenance control system approved pursuant to Subpart 6.

Section.Text: An air operator certificate shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the legal name, trade name and address of the air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of the air operator certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the effective date of certification;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issue of the certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the general conditions identified in section 703.09;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: specific conditions with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the areas of operation authorized,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the types of service authorized,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the types of aircraft authorized and, if applicable, their registration, and any operational restrictions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the main base, scheduled points and, if applicable, sub-bases; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: where the air operator complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards, operations specifications with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft performance, equipment and emergency equipment requirements,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: instrument approach procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: enroute aerodrome authorizations and limitations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: special weather minima authorizations,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: authorizations concerning flight crew member complement,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: pilot training and pilot proficiency checks,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: special helicopter procedures,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the air operator maintenance control system approved pursuant to Subpart 6,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: leasing arrangements, and

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: any other condition pertaining to the operation that the Minister deems necessary for aviation safety.

Heading.TitleText: General Conditions of Air Operator Certificate

Section.Text: An air operator certificate shall contain the following general conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall conduct flight operations in accordance with its company operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain an adequate organizational structure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall employ managerial personnel who meet the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall conduct training in accordance with its training program approved pursuant to this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain aircraft that are properly equipped for the area of operation and the type of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall employ crew members who are qualified for the area of operation and the type of operation;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain its aircraft in accordance with the requirements of Subpart 6;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall maintain operational support services and equipment that meet the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall notify the Minister within 10 working days after

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: changing its legal name, its trade name, its main base, a sub-base, a scheduled point, or its managerial personnel, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: ceasing to operate a type of aircraft authorized under this Subpart; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator shall conduct a safe operation.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall ensure that all operations personnel are properly instructed about their duties and about the relationship of their duties to the operation as a whole.
The operations personnel of an air operator shall follow the procedures specified in the air operator’s company operations manual in the performance of their duties.

Subject to subsection (2), every air operator that operates a scheduled air service for the purpose of transporting persons shall operate the service between airports or heliports or between an airport or heliport and a military aerodrome.

An air operator may operate a scheduled air service for the purpose of transporting persons between an airport and an aerodrome other than a military aerodrome or between two aerodromes if the air operator is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft unless the air operator has an operational control system that meets the Commercial Air Service Standards and is under the control of its operations manager.
No person shall commence a flight unless the flight has been authorized in accordance with the procedures specified in the air operator’s company operations manual.

Subsection.Text: No air operator shall permit a person to commence a flight unless an operational flight plan that meets the Commercial Air Service Standards has been prepared in accordance with the procedures specified in the air operator’s company operations manual.

The pilot-in-command of an aircraft shall ensure that a copy of the operational flight plan is left at a point of departure, in accordance with the procedures specified in the company operations manual.
An air operator shall retain a copy of the operational flight plan, including any amendments to that plan, for the period specified in the company operations manual.

Section.Text: No air operator shall permit a person to conduct a take-off in an aircraft that has not been maintained in accordance with the air operator’s maintenance control system.
No air operator shall authorize a flight and no person shall commence a flight unless the aircraft carries sufficient fuel to meet the fuel requirements of Part VI and to allow the aircraft

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aeroplane operated in IFR flight,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to descend at any point along the route to the lower of

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the single-engined service ceiling, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to cruise at the altitude referred to in subparagraph (i) to a suitable aerodrome,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: to conduct an approach and a missed approach, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: to hold for 30 minutes at an altitude of 1,500 feet above the elevation of the aerodrome selected in accordance with subparagraph (ii); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a helicopter operated in night VFR flight, to fly to the destination aerodrome and then to fly for 30 minutes at normal cruising speed.

Subsection.Text: Where a Department of Transport air carrier inspector presents an official identity card to the pilot-in-command of an aircraft, the pilot-in-command shall give the inspector free and uninterrupted access to the pilot’s compartment of the aircraft.
An air operator and the pilot-in-command shall make available for the use of the air carrier inspector the seat most suitable to perform the inspector’s duties, as determined by the inspector.

Heading.TitleText: Transport of Passengers in Single-engined Aircraft

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no air operator shall operate a single-engined aircraft with passengers on board in IFR flight or in night VFR flight.
An air operator may operate a single-engined aircraft with passengers on board in IFR flight or in night VFR flight if the air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: No air operator shall, except when conducting a take-off or landing, operate a land aircraft over water, beyond a point where the land aircraft could reach shore in the event of an engine failure, unless the air operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Number of Passengers in Single-engined Aircraft

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate a single-engined aircraft with more than nine passengers on board unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is a transport category helicopter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: Except where carriage of an external load has been authorized in a type certificate or supplemental type certificate, no air operator shall operate an aircraft to carry an external load with passengers on board.
No person shall, where passengers are on board an aircraft, simulate emergency situations that could affect the flight characteristics of the aircraft.
Except when conducting a take-off or landing, no person shall operate an aircraft in VFR flight

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at night, at less than 1,000 feet above the highest obstacle located within a horizontal distance of three miles from the route to be flown; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is an aeroplane, during the day, at less than 300 feet AGL or at a horizontal distance of less than 300 feet from any obstacle.

Heading.TitleText: VFR Flight Minimum Flight Visibility — Uncontrolled Airspace

Subsection.Text: Where an aeroplane is operated in day VFR flight within uncontrolled airspace at less than 1,000 feet AGL, a person may, for the purposes of subparagraph 602.115(c)(i), operate the aeroplane when flight visibility is less than two miles if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: Where a helicopter is operated in day VFR flight within uncontrolled airspace at less than 1,000 feet AGL, a person may, for the purposes of subparagraph 602.115(d)(i), operate the helicopter when flight visibility is less than one mile if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Section.Text: No person shall commence a VFR flight unless current weather reports and forecasts, if obtainable, indicate that the weather conditions along the route to be flown and at the destination aerodrome will be such that the flight can be conducted in compliance with VFR.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no person shall conduct a take-off in an aircraft in IMC where weather conditions are at or above the take-off minima, but below the landing minima, for the runway to be used unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the take-off is authorized in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: A person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft in IMC where weather conditions are at or above the take-off minima, but below the landing minima, for the runway to be used, if the weather conditions are at or above the landing minima for another suitable runway at that aerodrome.

For the purposes of section 602.126, a person may conduct a take-off in an aircraft in IMC where weather conditions are below the take-off minima specified in the instrument approach procedure, if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, the landing minima are the decision height or the minimum descent altitude and the visibility published for an approach.

Section.Text: For the purposes of section 602.122, a person may conduct an IFR flight where an alternate aerodrome has not been designated in the IFR flight plan or in the IFR flight itinerary, if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is authorized to do so in an air operator certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.
