Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C119a or a more recent version of it or other requirements that the Minister has accepted as providing a level of safety that is at least equivalent to the level that that CAN-TSO provides and is equipped with a Mode S transponder that meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C112 or a more recent version of it.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), no air operator shall operate an aeroplane referred to in subsection (1) or (2) in RVSM airspace unless the aeroplane is equipped with an operative ACAS that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C119b or a more recent version of it or other requirements that the Minister has accepted as providing a level of safety that is at least equivalent to the level that that CAN-TSO provides; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is equipped with a Mode S transponder that meets the requirements of CAN-TSO-C112 or a more recent version of it.

Subsection.Text: The air operator may operate the aeroplane without its being equipped with an operative ACAS if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister and subject to subsection 605.08(1), the operation takes place within the three days after the date of failure of the ACAS; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is necessary for the pilot-in-command to deactivate, in the interests of aviation safety, the ACAS or any of its modes and the pilot-in-command does so in accordance with the aircraft flight manual, aircraft operating manual, flight manual supplement or minimum equipment list.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of aeroplanes manufactured on or before the day on which this section comes into force until two years after that day.
Subject to subsection (2), no air operator shall operate an aeroplane unless the aeroplane is equipped with an operative TAWS that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements for Class A equipment set out in CAN-TSO-C151b;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets, effective on the day that is five years after the day on which this section comes into force, the altitude accuracy requirements set out in section 551.102 of Chapter 551 of the Airworthiness Manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has a terrain and airport database compatible with the area of operation and a terrain awareness and situational display.

Subsection.Text: The air operator may operate the aeroplane without its being equipped with an operative TAWS if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the event that a minimum equipment list has not been approved by the Minister and subject to subsection 605.08(1), the operation takes place within the three days after the day on which the failure of the TAWS occurs; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is necessary for the pilot-in-command to deactivate, in the interests of aviation safety, the TAWS or any of its modes and the pilot-in-command does so in accordance with the aircraft flight manual, aircraft operating manual, flight manual supplement or minimum equipment list.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply in respect of aeroplanes manufactured on or before the day on which this section comes into force until the day that is two years after that day.

Section.Text: No person shall operate, with passengers on board, an aeroplane for which a type certificate has been issued authorizing the transport of 60 or more passengers, unless the following number of portable battery-powered megaphones are carried on board the aeroplane and are conveniently located and readily available for use by the flight attendants:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for each passenger deck, at least one megaphone;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 61 to 99 passenger seats, one megaphone; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 100 or more passenger seats, two megaphones.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft unless the following number of first aid kits that meet the Commercial Air Service Standards are carried on board the aircraft:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 0 to 50 passenger seats, one kit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 51 to 150 passenger seats, two kits;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 151 to 250 passenger seats, three kits; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: 251 or more passenger seats, four kits.

Subsection.Text: First aid kits shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: distributed throughout the aircraft cabin;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: readily available to crew members and passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: clearly identified;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: marked with the date of the last inspection; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft is equipped with only one first aid kit, located as close as practicable to an emergency exit.

Subsection.Text: A stowage compartment that contains a first aid kit shall be clearly marked as to its contents.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft that has a seating configuration, excluding crew seats, of more than 100 unless an emergency medical kit that meets the Commercial Air Service Standards is carried on board the aircraft.
No person shall operate an aircraft unless a crash axe is carried on board the aircraft.

Subsection.Text: No person shall operate an aircraft unless hand-held fire extinguishers for use in the flight deck, passenger compartment and cargo compartment are carried on board the aircraft.

The type and quantity of extinguishing agent shall be suitable for extinguishing fires that are likely to occur in the flight deck, passenger compartment or cargo compartment where the extinguisher is intended to be used and, in the case of the extinguishing agent for extinguishers intended to be used in the passenger compartment, shall be designed to minimize the hazard of toxic gas concentrations.

At least one hand-held fire extinguisher shall be conveniently located and readily available for immediate use in each class E cargo compartment that is accessible to crew members during flight, and at least one hand-held fire extinguisher shall be located in each isolated galley.
At least one hand-held fire extinguisher shall be conveniently located on the flight deck and readily available for immediate use by the flight crew members.
The following number of hand-held fire extinguishers shall be conveniently located, readily available for immediate use and uniformly distributed throughout the passenger compartment on each deck:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 60 or fewer passenger seats, two extinguishers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 61 to 200 passenger seats, three extinguishers;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 201 or more passenger seats, one extra extinguisher for each additional unit of 100 passenger seats.

Subsection.Text: At least two hand-held fire extinguishers shall contain Halon 1211 (bromochlorodifluoromethane) or its equivalent.
A stowage compartment or stowage container that contains a hand-held fire extinguisher shall be clearly marked as to its contents.

Section.Text: No person shall operate a pressurized aircraft above FL 250 unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is readily available to each flight attendant on board portable oxygen equipment with a 15-minute supply of oxygen; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient portable oxygen units with masks, or spare outlets and masks, to ensure an immediate supply of oxygen to each flight attendant are distributed throughout the cabin.

Section.Text: No air operator shall operate an aircraft unless the equipment carried on board the aircraft pursuant to sections 602.61 and 602.63 meets the additional requirements of the Commercial Air Service Standards.

No air operator shall operate an aircraft unless the emergency equipment carried on board pursuant to this Division is inspected regularly in accordance with the inspection schedule set out in the company operations manual.
Each flight attendant required under section 705.201 shall have a flashlight readily available for use.
An air operator shall designate for each flight a pilot-in-command and a second-in-command.
[Reserved, SOR/2015-127, s. 18]
[Reserved, SOR/2015-127, s. 18]

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), no air operator shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as the pilot-in-command, second-in-command or cruise relief pilot of an aircraft unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: holds the licence, ratings and endorsements required by Part IV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within the previous 90 days,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has completed at least three take-offs and three landings as the pilot at the controls and one sector assigned to duty as a flight crew member in an aircraft of that type,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has completed five sectors assigned to duty as a flight crew member in an aircraft of that type, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: has fulfilled the training requirements set out in the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed a pilot proficiency check, the validity period of which has not expired, for that type of aircraft, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed or is undergoing a line check or line indoctrination training, the validity period of which has not expired, for that type of aircraft, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: has fulfilled the requirements of the air operator’s training program.

Subsection.Text: A pilot who does not meet the requirements of subparagraph (1)(b)(i) or (ii) shall regain competency in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards.
An air operator may permit a person to act and a person may act as the pilot-in-command or second-in-command of an aircraft where the person does not meet the requirements of subsection (1), if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is operated on a training, ferry or positioning flight; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is authorized to do so in its air operator certificate, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: complies with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: A pilot shall, on successful completion of a pilot proficiency check, meet the requirements of the consolidation period in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Heading.TitleText: Flight Engineer and Second Officer Qualifications

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no air operator shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as a flight engineer or a second officer on board an aircraft unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person holds the licence and endorsements required by Part IV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator has determined, by means of a check in flight or in a flight simulator that has been approved by the Minister under Subpart 6 of Part VI, that the person meets the Commercial Air Service Standards for that type of aircraft, or the person has, within the previous six months, completed at least 50 hours of flight time as a flight engineer on an aircraft of that type;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person has successfully completed or is undergoing line indoctrination training for that type of aircraft, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person has fulfilled the requirements of the air operator’s training program.

Subsection.Text: A person who is qualified to act as a pilot-in-command or a second-in-command in accordance with section 705.106 may act as a second officer on board an aircraft during the cruise portion of a flight, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person has received initial and annual recurrent training in normal and emergency procedures pertaining to the cruise portion of the flight, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator has determined, by means of a check, that the person meets the Commercial Air Service Standards for that type of aircraft.

Section.Text: No air operator shall assign a pilot-in-command and a second-in-command to an aircraft unless their combined experience on that type of aircraft meets the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: No air operator shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as a flight attendant on board an aircraft unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed the air operator’s training program, except that a person may act as a flight attendant while undergoing line indoctrination training if the person is carried in addition to the number of flight attendants required under section 705.201 and is under the supervision of a flight attendant; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed line indoctrination training within 90 days after completing the air operator’s training program or has regained competency in accordance with the Flight Attendant Training Standard.

Subsection.Text: A person who has not completed line indoctrination training within the period specified in paragraph (1)(b) shall requalify in accordance with the Flight Attendant Training Standard.

No air operator shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as a flight dispatcher unless the person has fulfilled the requirements of the air operator’s training program and, after June 1, 1998, holds a flight dispatcher certificate.
An air operator shall notify the Minister whenever a flight dispatcher certificate is issued or becomes invalid.

Section.Text: No air operator shall permit a person to act and no person shall act as the pilot-in-command of an aircraft on a flight along a route or into an aerodrome unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within the previous 12 months, the person has acted as a flight crew member or has been on the flight deck as an observer on a flight along that route and into that aerodrome; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person has received training and demonstrated adequate knowledge, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: A pilot proficiency check shall be conducted by the Minister.
Any other check required under this Subpart may be conducted by the Minister.

Subject to subsections (4) and (5), the validity period of a line check and of the training referred to in section 705.124 expires on the first day of the thirteenth month following the month in which the check or training was completed.
Subject to subsections (4) and (5), the validity period of a pilot proficiency check expires

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the first day of the seventh month following the month in which the check was completed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the first day of the thirteenth month following the month in which the check was completed, where the pilot successfully completes the six-month recurrency training that has been approved by the Minister, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards, as a substitute for the pilot proficiency check and that is identified in the company operations manual; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at the end of the validation period, where the air operator has an operations specification authorizing an advanced qualification program in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards and the pilot completes a proficiency evaluation within the evaluation period authorized for the air operator in the operations specification.

Subsection.Text: The validity period of a flight dispatcher competency check expires on the first day of the thirteenth month following the month in which the check was completed.

Where a pilot proficiency check, a flight dispatcher competency check, a line check or training is renewed within the last 90 days of its validity period, its validity period is extended by six or 12 months, as appropriate.

The Minister may extend the validity period of a pilot proficiency check, a flight dispatcher competency check, a line check or any training by up to 60 days where the Minister is of the opinion that aviation safety is not likely to be affected.

Subject to subsection (7), where the validity period of a pilot proficiency check, a line check, or annual or semi-annual training has been expired for 24 months or more, the person shall requalify by meeting the training requirements specified in the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Where the validity period of a flight dispatcher competency check or annual training has been expired for 12 months or more, the person shall requalify by meeting the training requirements specified in the Commercial Air Service Standards.
Every air operator shall establish and maintain a training program that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed to ensure that each person who receives training acquires the competence to perform the person’s assigned duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: approved by the Minister in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards and, in respect of flight attendants, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards and the Flight Attendant Training Standard.

Subsection.Text: An air operator’s training program shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for flight crew members:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: company indoctrination training,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: line indoctrination training,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: upgrading training, where applicable, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: initial and annual training, including

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: aircraft type training,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: aircraft servicing and ground handling training,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: emergency procedures training, and

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: aircraft surface contamination training;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for flight attendants:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: aviation indoctrination,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: line indoctrination training,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in-charge training, where applicable, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: initial and annual training, including

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: safety procedures training,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: aircraft type training,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: emergency procedures training,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: aircraft surface contamination training, and

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: first aid training;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for flight dispatchers:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: initial and annual aircraft type training,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on-the-job training, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: aircraft cockpit familiarization training;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: initial and annual aircraft surface contamination training for those operations personnel designated in the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other training required to ensure a safe operation under this Subpart.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include a detailed syllabus of its training program in its company operations manual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that adequate facilities and qualified personnel are provided for its training program, in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a safety awareness program concerning the adverse effects of aircraft surface contamination and provide the program to all flight operations personnel who are not required to undergo the training described in paragraph (2)(d).

Subsection.Text: The Minister may give conditional approval to a training program where an air operator submits to the Minister a copy of a syllabus of its training program that provides enough information for a preliminary evaluation of the training program in light of the Commercial Air Service Standards.

An air operator may conduct training under a training program that has received conditional approval until the Minister has evaluated the effectiveness of the training program and has informed the air operator of any deficiencies that must be corrected.

The Minister shall give final approval to a conditionally approved training program when the air operator demonstrates that the training conducted under that program is adequate to permit the persons who receive it to safely perform their assigned duties and when any identified deficiencies have been corrected.

Section.Text: An air operator may conduct emergency training and testing on a cabin emergency evacuation trainer, rather than on an aircraft, if the trainer has been approved by the Minister in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: Every air operator shall, for each person who is required to receive training under this Subpart, establish and maintain a record of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s name and, where applicable, personnel licence number, type and ratings;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the person’s medical category and the expiry date of that category;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the dates on which the person, while in the air operator’s employ, successfully completed any training, pilot proficiency check or examination required under this Subpart or obtained any qualification required under this Subpart;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: information relating to any failure of the person, while in the air operator’s employ, to successfully complete any training, pilot proficiency check or examination required under this Subpart or to obtain any qualification required under this Subpart; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the type of aircraft or flight training equipment used for any training, pilot proficiency check, line check or qualification required under this Subpart.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall retain the records referred to in paragraphs (1)(c) and (d) and a record of each pilot proficiency check for at least three years.
An air operator shall keep a master copy of each examination on file and make it available for review by the Minister for a period of not less than three years.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements relating to Company Operations Manual

Subsection.Text: Every air operator shall establish and maintain a company operations manual that meets the requirements of section 705.135.
An air operator shall submit its company operations manual, and any amendments to that manual, to the Minister.

Where there is a change in any aspect of an air operator’s operation or where the company operations manual no longer meets the Commercial Air Service Standards, the air operator shall amend its company operations manual.

The Minister shall, where the Commercial Air Service Standards are met, approve those parts of a company operations manual, and any amendments to those parts, that relate to the information required by section 705.135.

A company operations manual, which may be issued in separate parts corresponding to specific aspects of an operation, shall include the instructions and information necessary to enable the personnel concerned to perform their duties safely and shall contain the information required by the Commercial Air Service Standards.
A company operations manual shall be such that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all parts of the manual are consistent and compatible in form and content;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manual can be readily amended;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the manual contains an amendment control page and a list of the pages that are in effect; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the manual has the date of the last amendment to each page specified on that page.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), an air operator shall provide a copy of the appropriate parts of its company operations manual, including any amendments to those parts, to each of its crew members and to its ground operations and maintenance personnel.

An air operator may place a copy of the appropriate parts of its company operations manual in each aircraft that it operates, instead of providing a copy to each crew member, if all amendments to the manual are included in the system for the dissemination of general operational information referred to in section 705.18.

Every person who has been provided with a copy of the appropriate parts of a company operations manual pursuant to subsection (1) shall keep it up to date with the amendments provided and shall ensure that the appropriate parts are accessible when the person is performing assigned duties.
An air operator may establish and maintain an aircraft operating manual for the use and guidance of crew members in the operation of its aircraft.
An aircraft operating manual shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft operating procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the aircraft flight manual is not carried on board the aircraft, the aircraft performance data and limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual, which shall be clearly identified as aircraft flight manual requirements.

Subsection.Text: An air operator that has established an aircraft operating manual shall submit a copy of the manual, and any amendments to that manual, to the Minister for approval.
The Minister shall approve an aircraft operating manual, and any amendments to that manual, where the Commercial Air Service Standards are met.
An air operator that has established an aircraft operating manual shall ensure that a copy of the manual is carried on board each aircraft to which it relates.

Every air operator shall, for each of its aircraft, establish and maintain standard operating procedures that enable the crew members to operate the aircraft within the limitations specified in the aircraft flight manual, and that meet the Commercial Air Service Standards.
An air operator shall submit a copy of its aircraft standard operating procedures, and any amendments to those procedures, to the Minister.
An air operator shall ensure that a copy of the standard operating procedures for an aircraft is carried on board the aircraft.
Where an air operator has established an aircraft operating manual, the standard operating procedures for the aircraft shall form part of that manual.

Every air operator, other than an air operator that is authorized solely for the transport of cargo in its air operator certificate, shall establish and maintain, as part of its company operations manual, a flight attendant manual for the use and guidance of flight attendants in the operation of its aircraft.

A flight attendant manual shall contain the instructions and information necessary to enable flight attendants to perform their duties safely and shall contain the information required by the Flight Attendant Manual Standard.

The Minister shall, where the Flight Attendant Manual Standard is met, approve those parts of a flight attendant manual, and any amendments to those parts, that relate to the safety and emergency information contained in Part A of the Flight Attendant Manual Standard.
An air operator shall provide a copy of its flight attendant manual, including any amendments to that manual, to each of its flight attendants.

Every flight attendant who has been provided with a copy of a flight attendant manual pursuant to subsection (4) shall keep it up to date with the amendments provided and shall ensure that the appropriate parts are accessible when the flight attendant is performing assigned duties on board an aircraft.

Section.Text: The safety management system required under section 107.02 in respect of an applicant for, or a holder of, an air operator certificate shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of Subpart 7 of Part I and section 705.152;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be under the control of the operations manager appointed under paragraph 700.09(1)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: cover the maintenance control activities undertaken under Subpart 6.

Heading.TitleText: Components of the Safety Management System

Subsection.Text: The safety management system shall include, among others, the following components:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a safety management plan that includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a safety policy that the accountable executive has approved and communicated to all employees,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the roles and responsibilities of personnel assigned duties under the quality assurance program established under section 706.07 or the safety management system,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: performance goals and a means of measuring the attainment of those goals,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a policy for the internal reporting of a hazard, an incident or an accident, including the conditions under which immunity from disciplinary action will be granted, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a review of the safety management system to determine its effectiveness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for reporting a hazard, an incident or an accident to the appropriate manager;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the collection of data relating to hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for analysing data obtained under paragraph (c) and during an audit conducted under subsection 706.07(3) and for taking corrective actions;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an audit system referred to in subsection 706.07(3);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: training requirements for the operations manager, the maintenance manager and personnel assigned duties under the safety management system; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for making progress reports to the accountable executive at intervals determined by the accountable executive and other reports as needed in urgent cases.

Subsection.Text: The components specified in subsection (1) shall be set out in the air operator's company operations manual and maintenance control manual (MCM).

Heading.TitleText: Person Managing the Safety Management System

Section.Text: The person managing the safety management system shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a reporting system to ensure the timely collection of information related to hazards, incidents and accidents that may adversely affect safety;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify hazards and carry out risk management analyses of those hazards;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: investigate, analyze and identify the cause or probable cause of all hazards, incidents and accidents identified under the safety management system;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: establish and maintain a safety data system, either by electronic or by other means, to monitor and analyze trends in hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: monitor and evaluate the results of corrective actions with respect to hazards, incidents and accidents;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the concerns of the civil aviation industry in respect of safety and their perceived effect on the air operator;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: determine the adequacy of the training required by paragraph 705.152(1)(f); and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: where the operations manager has assigned the management functions for the safety management system under subsection 705.03(3) to another person, report to the operations manager the hazards, incidents and accidents identified under the safety management system or as a result of an audit required under subsection 706.07(3).

Heading.TitleText: Holder of More Than One Certificate

Section.Text: The holder of an air operator certificate issued under section 705.07 who is also the holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate issued under section 573.02, shall adhere to the requirements referred to in section 573.30 with respect to a safety management system when undertaking maintenance control activities under Subpart 6.

Heading.TitleText: Division XI — Interference With a Crew Member

Section.Text: In this Division,

Definition.Code: se="705.171",df="{interference with a crew member}{entrave au travail d’un membre d’équipage}"
Definition.Text: interference with a crew member means any action or statement set out in the levels listed in section 705.175 by a person on board or about to board an aircraft that distracts a crew member from their assigned safety responsibilities or prevents the crew member from carrying out those responsibilities; (entrave au travail d’un membre d’équipage)

operational personnel means an air operator’s employees whose duties require that they interact directly with persons on board or about to board an aircraft, and includes crew members, gate and check-in staff and their immediate supervisors. (personnel d’exploitation)

Heading.TitleText: Preventing and Managing Incidents of Interference with a Crew Member

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall establish procedures to prevent and manage incidents of interference with a crew member covering the topics set out in section 725.172 of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards.
An air operator shall specify in the company operations manual and in their flight attendant manual the procedures established in accordance with subsection (1).

Section.Text: An air operator shall provide initial and annual training to all operational personnel that covers the topics set out in subsection 725.124(56) of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards for the purpose of enabling

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition, prevention and management of behaviour that could reasonably be expected to lead to an incident of interference with a crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition, prevention and management of incidents of interference with a crew member; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the knowledge of post-flight procedures related to incidents of interference with a crew member.

Heading.TitleText: Reporting Incidents of Interference with a Crew Member

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall establish procedures to ensure that level 2, level 3 and level 4 incidents of interference with a crew member are reported to the air operator and to allow for the reporting of a level 1 incident.
An air operator shall specify in the company operations manual and in their flight attendant manual the procedures established under subsection (1).

A report of an incident of interference with a crew member shall contain the information set out in section 725.174 of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards.
An air operator shall ensure that reports are retained for a period of three years after the date of the incident and are made available to the Minister on request.

An air operator shall submit to the Minister statistics relating to incidents of interference with a crew member, the content of which is set out in section 725.174 of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards, every six months.

Heading.TitleText: Levels of Interference with a Crew Member

Section.Text: The levels of interference with a crew member are as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a level 1 incident, which is an incident of a minor nature that either requires no action of the crew member beyond heightened awareness or is quickly resolved by a crew member, and which includes but is not limited to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the use of unacceptable language towards a crew member,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: unacceptable behaviour towards a crew member, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a display of suspicious behaviour;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a level 2 incident, which is an incident of a moderate nature that is resolved by a crew member only after some difficulty and which includes but is not limited to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the repetition of a level 1 incident,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the continuation of a level 1 incident that was unresolved,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the repeated failure of a passenger to comply with a crew member’s safety instructions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: belligerent, obscene or lewd behaviour towards a crew member;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a level 3 incident, which is an incident where the safety of passengers or crew members is seriously threatened and which includes but is not limited to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: threatening a person on board or about to board the aircraft or making threats in an attempt to board the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the continuation of a level 2 incident that was unresolved,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: tampering with any emergency or safety equipment on board the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: deliberate damage of any part of the aircraft or any property on board the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: injuring a person on board the aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: violent, argumentative, threatening, intimidating or disorderly behaviour, including harassment and assault; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a level 4 incident, which is an incident that constitutes a security threat and which includes but is not limited to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an attempted or unauthorized intrusion into the flight deck,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a credible threat of death or serious bodily injury in an attempt to gain control over the aircraft,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the display or use of a weapon,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the sabotage of, or the attempt to sabotage, an aircraft that renders it incapable of flight or that is likely to endanger its safety in flight,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: any attempt to unlawfully seize control of the aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: an incident that is required to be reported under section 64 of the Canadian Aviation Security Regulations.

Heading.TitleText: Division XII — Flight Attendants and Emergency Evacuation

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Division and subject to subsection (2), model means aircraft master series as described in section 3.7 of version 1.3 of the document entitled International Standard for Aircraft Make, Model, and Series Groupings, dated October 2012 and published by the Common Taxonomy Team of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the Commercial Aviation Safety Team (CAST).

If no aircraft master series is assigned to an aeroplane, model in respect of that aeroplane means aircraft model as described in section 3.6 of version 1.3 of the document entitled International Standard for Aircraft Make, Model, and Series Groupings, dated October 2012 and published by the Common Taxonomy Team of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the Commercial Aviation Safety Team (CAST).
No air operator shall operate an aeroplane to carry passengers unless the air operator does so with the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck.

Subject to subsections (4) to (7), the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck of an aeroplane is determined in accordance with one of the following ratios that is selected by the air operator in respect of the model of that aeroplane:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one flight attendant for each unit of 40 passengers or for each portion of such a unit; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one flight attendant for each unit of 50 passenger seats or for each portion of such a unit.

Subsection.Text: Persons referred to in paragraphs 705.27(3)(c) to (e) who are admitted to the flight deck are not counted as passengers for the purposes of paragraph (2)(a).
An air operator who has selected, in respect of a model of aeroplane, the ratio set out in paragraph (2)(b) shall not operate an aeroplane of that model with only one flight attendant unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane has a single deck and is configured for 50 or fewer passenger seats;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane was certified under

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: part 25, title 14, of the Code of Federal Regulations of the United States, in the version in effect on March 6, 1980 or after that date,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the European Joint Aviation Requirements — Large Aeroplanes (JAR-25), published by the Joint Aviation Authorities, in the version in effect on November 30, 1981 or after that date,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Certification Specifications, Including Airworthiness Code and Acceptable Means of Compliance, for Large Aeroplanes (CS-25), published by the European Aviation Safety Agency, in the version in effect on October 17, 2003 or after that date, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: Chapter 525 — Transport Category Aeroplanes of the Airworthiness Manual, in the version in effect on July 1, 1986 or after that date;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: only one flight attendant was used for the emergency evacuation demonstration required for the certification of that model of aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator’s flight attendant manual indicates how normal and emergency procedures differ depending on whether the aeroplane is operated with one flight attendant or with more than one flight attendant;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the flight attendant occupies a flight attendant station that is located near a floor-level exit; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the public address system and the crew member interphone system are operative and are capable of being used at the flight attendant station.

Subsection.Text: If an air operator has selected, in respect of a model of aeroplane, the ratio set out in paragraph (2)(a), but has carried out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for that model using more flight attendants than would have been required in accordance with that ratio, the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck of an aeroplane of that model that is operated by the air operator is the number of flight attendants used in the demonstration.

If an air operator has selected, in respect of a model of aeroplane, the ratio set out in paragraph (2)(b), but has carried out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for that model using more flight attendants than would have been required in accordance with that ratio, the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck of an aeroplane of that model that is operated by the air operator is the number of flight attendants used in the demonstration.

If the emergency evacuation demonstration required for the certification of a model of aeroplane was carried out using more flight attendants than would have been required in accordance with the ratio set out in paragraph (2)(b) and, after the demonstration, an aeroplane of that model is reconfigured for fewer passenger seats, the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck of the reconfigured aeroplane is the number of flight attendants required in accordance with the ratio set out in paragraph (2)(b) plus an additional number of flight attendants that is equal to the difference between

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the number of flight attendants used in the demonstration, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of flight attendants that would have been required in accordance with the ratio set out in paragraph (2)(b) at the time of the demonstration.

Subsection.Text: An air operator who decides, in respect of a model of aeroplane, to change the ratio that it has selected for the purposes of subsection 705.201(2) shall not implement this change unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator has provided the Minister with a notice in writing of the decision at least 60 days before implementing the change; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister has acknowledged receipt of the notice.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall acknowledge receipt of the notice not later than one working day after receiving it.

Section.Text: If an air operator has selected, in respect of a model of aeroplane, the ratio set out in paragraph 705.201(2)(b), the air operator shall not operate an aeroplane of that model unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the features that facilitate emergency evacuations meet the requirements set out in paragraphs 725.202(a) to (n) of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the passenger seats and flight attendant seats meet the requirements set out in paragraph 725.202(o) of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: compartments occupied by passengers and crew members meet the requirements respecting flammability set out in paragraph 725.202(p), (q) or (r) of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the thermal insulation and acoustic insulation meet the requirements respecting flammability set out in paragraph 725.202(s) of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: An air operator who decides to introduce a model of aeroplane into its fleet for the purpose of carrying passengers shall carry out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for that model of aeroplane before operating an aeroplane of that model to carry passengers.

If an air operator decides to introduce an aeroplane into its fleet and there is a difference in any of the following items between that aeroplane and other aeroplanes of the same model that are already in the fleet, the air operator shall treat the aeroplane as if it were a different model of aeroplane and carry out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for that model before operating the aeroplane to carry passengers:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the flight attendants or their emergency evacuation duties or procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of emergency exits; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of opening mechanisms for the emergency exits.

Subsection.Text: An air operator who decides to change any of the following items in respect of an aeroplane shall carry out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for the model of that aeroplane, as changed, before operating the aeroplane to carry passengers:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the flight attendants or their emergency evacuation duties or procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of emergency exits; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number, location or type of opening mechanisms for the emergency exits.

Subsection.Text: If an air operator who has selected the ratio set out in paragraph 705.201(2)(b) in respect of a model of aeroplane decides to reconfigure an aeroplane of that model by adding or removing passenger seats, and if the reconfiguration will result in a change in the minimum number of flight attendants required on each deck, the air operator shall carry out a successful demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for the reconfigured model of that aeroplane before operating the reconfigured aeroplane to carry passengers.
Subsections (1) to (4) do not apply in respect of a model of aeroplane that is configured to carry fewer than 44 passengers.

Heading.TitleText: Carrying Out a Demonstration of Emergency Evacuation Procedures

Subsection.Text: An air operator who carries out a demonstration of its emergency evacuation procedures for a model of aeroplane shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: do so in the presence of the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: do so without passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: do so with flight attendants who have completed the air operator’s training program for that model of aeroplane; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: begin the demonstration using the air operator’s normal procedures, then transition to its emergency procedures.

Subsection.Text: The demonstration is successful if the flight attendants can, within 15 seconds after the transition from the air operator’s normal procedures to its emergency procedures,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: open 50% of the floor-level emergency exits that are required by the certification basis established in respect of the model of aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: open 50% of the non-floor-level emergency exits the opening of which is set out as an emergency evacuation duty in the air operator’s operations manual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: deploy 50% of the escape slides.

Section.Text: If an air operator decides to operate an aeroplane to carry passengers in extended over-water operations and the aeroplane is required to have survival equipment under section 602.63, the air operator shall carry out a demonstration of its ditching emergency evacuation procedures for the model of that aeroplane before starting the extended over-water operations.

Heading.TitleText: Carrying Out a Demonstration of Emergency Evacuation Procedures — Ditching

Subsection.Text: An air operator who carries out a demonstration of its ditching emergency evacuation procedures for a model of aeroplane shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: do so in the presence of the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: use an aeroplane of that model, a life-sized mock-up of that model of aeroplane or a floating device;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assume that the ditching occurs during daylight hours and that all required crew members are available;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that passengers are on board and participate in the demonstration if the air operator’s operations manual requires passengers to assist in the launching of life rafts;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that, after the ditching signal has been received, each evacuee dons a life preserver;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each life raft is removed from its stowage compartment;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that, as applicable, one life raft or one slide raft is inflated; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that each evacuee boards the life raft or slide raft and that a crew member assigned to the life raft or slide raft indicates the location of the required survival equipment and describes the use of that equipment.

Subsection.Text: A life-sized mock-up of a model of aeroplane or floating device must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be representative of the passenger cabin of the model of aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contain seats for all of the evacuees participating in the demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with the same survival equipment that is installed on the model of aeroplane, including a life preserver for each evacuee participating in the demonstration;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have emergency exits and doors that simulate those on the model of aeroplane; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: have enough wing area installed outside the window emergency exits to simulate the portions of the wings of the model of aeroplane that would be used in a ditching situation.

Subsection.Text: An air operator who operates an aeroplane with more than one flight attendant shall designate an in-charge flight attendant for each flight and keep a record of that designation for at least 90 days after the day on which the flight is completed.

Subject to subsection (3), an air operator shall not allow an individual to act as an in-charge flight attendant and no individual shall act as an in-charge flight attendant unless the individual has successfully completed in-charge training as part of the air operator’s training program.

An air operator shall set out procedures in its company operations manual for the selection of an acting in-charge flight attendant if the designated in-charge flight attendant becomes incapacitated after take-off.

In the case of a flight with scheduled stops, an air operator shall replace an acting in-charge flight attendant with a new designated in-charge flight attendant at the first scheduled stop where the replacement can be made.

An air operator who has selected, in respect of a model of aeroplane, the ratio set out in paragraph 705.201(2)(a) and who has assigned two or more flight attendants to a flight using an aeroplane of that model may operate the aeroplane for that flight without one of the flight attendants if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one of the flight attendants is incapacitated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no other flight attendant who is qualified for the model of aeroplane is available at the point of departure;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command authorizes an employee of the air operator to occupy a flight attendant station until the aeroplane reaches the nearest airport at which the employee can be replaced by a flight attendant who is qualified for the model of aeroplane;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: before the movement of the aeroplane on the surface, the employee is briefed under the supervision of the pilot-in-command on the operation of the emergency exits and on emergency procedures, including those related to the flight attendant station to be occupied by the employee; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command is of the opinion that the employee understood the briefing.

Subsection.Text: The air operator shall keep a record of the replacement for at least two years after the day on which the flight is completed.

Subject to subsections (2) and (3), an air operator who operates an aeroplane to carry passengers shall ensure that all flight attendants assigned to a flight using that aeroplane are on board during passenger embarkation and disembarkation.
In the case of a flight to which more than one flight attendant is assigned, the air operator may reduce the number of flight attendants by one during passenger embarkation if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the flight attendant who leaves the aeroplane remains within the immediate vicinity of the door through which passengers are embarking and carries out safety-related duties for the flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the engines used for the propulsion of the aeroplane are not running; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at least one floor-level exit remains open to provide for passenger egress.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a flight to which more than one flight attendant is assigned, the air operator may reduce the number of flight attendants during passenger disembarkation if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the engines used for the propulsion of the aeroplane are not running;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one floor-level exit remains open to provide for passenger egress; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: half of the required number of flight attendants — rounded down to the next lower number in the case of fractions, but never less than one — remain on board.

Subsection.Text: Paragraphs (2)(b) and (3)(a) do not apply in respect of an engine on a propeller-driven aeroplane if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the engine has a propeller brake;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the propeller brake is set; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane flight manual indicates that the engine may be used as an auxiliary power unit.

Subsection.Text: The air operator shall ensure that, during passenger embarkation and disembarkation,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if only one flight attendant is on board, he or she remains in the vicinity of the door through which passengers are embarking or disembarking; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if more than one flight attendant is on board, they are evenly distributed in the passenger cabin and are in the vicinity of the floor-level exits.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall not permit passengers to remain on board an aeroplane during an intermediate stop unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the engines used for the propulsion of the aeroplane are not running;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one floor-level exit remains open to provide for passenger egress;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aeroplane operated with only one flight attendant, the flight attendant remains on board;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aeroplane operated with more than one flight attendant, at least half of the required number of flight attendants — rounded down to the next lower number in the case of fractions, but never less than one — remain on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: flight attendants are located in the vicinity of the floor-level exits and are ready to initiate and oversee an emergency evacuation.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(a) does not apply in respect of an engine on a propeller-driven aeroplane if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the engine has a propeller brake;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the propeller brake is set; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the aeroplane flight manual indicates that the engine may be used as an auxiliary power unit.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(b) does not apply if the exit is closed or latched for climatic reasons.
A flight attendant on board an aeroplane referred to in paragraph (1)(c) or (d) may be replaced by an individual other than a flight attendant if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the individual has successfully completed the air operator’s training on the emergency evacuation procedures for the model of that aeroplane in accordance with subsection 725.124(14) or (47) of Standard 725 — Airline Operations — Aeroplanes of the Commercial Air Services Standards;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the individual is identified to the passengers as an acting flight attendant; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the individual is located in the vicinity of a floor-level exit and is ready to initiate and oversee an emergency evacuation.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall, for each model of aeroplane in its fleet that is operated to carry passengers, set out, in its flight attendant manual, the duties to be performed by the flight attendants in an emergency.
The air operator shall not operate an aeroplane to carry passengers unless those duties are assigned to flight attendants on board the aeroplane.

Heading.TitleText: Emergency Evacuation — Before and During Surface Movements

Section.Text: An air operator shall, for each aeroplane in its fleet that is operated to carry passengers, have procedures to ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least one floor-level exit provides for passenger egress before the movement of the aeroplane on the surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every automatically deployable means of emergency passenger evacuation is ready for immediate use during the movement of the aeroplane on the surface.

Section.Text: Despite section 605.09, no person shall conduct a take-off in a single-aisle aeroplane that is carrying passengers unless all emergency exits and escape slides are operative.

No air operator shall operate an aeroplane to carry passengers unless the emergency equipment, the stowage locations for emergency equipment and the emergency procedures are standardized for all aeroplanes in the air operator’s fleet that are operated under this Subpart to carry passengers.

Heading.TitleText: Subpart 6 — Aircraft Maintenance Requirements for Air Operators

Section.Text: This Subpart applies to every person who operates an aircraft in a commercial air service under this Part.
No person shall operate an aircraft unless the aircraft is maintained in accordance with a maintenance control system that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of this Subpart; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is described in the air operator’s maintenance control manual (MCM) required by section 706.08.

Subsection.Text: The holder of an air operator certificate shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a person responsible for the maintenance control system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (4), ensure that the person responsible for the maintenance control system has achieved a grade of 70% or more in an open-book examination that demonstrates knowledge of the provisions of the Canadian Aviation Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person responsible for the maintenance control system demonstrates to the Minister knowledge of the topics set out in subsection 726.03(1) of Standard 726 — Air Operator Maintenance of the Commercial Air Service Standards within 30 days after their appointment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the person responsible for the maintenance control system performs the duties referred to in subsections 706.07(2) and (3);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: provide the person responsible for the maintenance control system with the financial and human resources necessary to ensure that the holder of the air operator certificate meets the requirements of these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: authorize the person responsible for the maintenance control system to remove aircraft from operation if the removal is justified because of non-compliance with the requirements of these Regulations or because of a risk to aviation safety or the safety of the public; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that corrective actions are taken in respect of any findings resulting from a quality assurance program established under section 706.07.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall conduct an interview with the person appointed under paragraph (1)(a) to assess their knowledge of the topics referred to in paragraph (1)(c).

The Minister shall notify the person appointed under paragraph (1)(a) of the results of the assessment and identify any deficiencies in their knowledge of the topics within ten days after the interview.
The knowledge requirement set out in paragraph (1)(b) does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person responsible for the maintenance control system who held that position on January 1, 1997; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME) licence.

Subsection.Text: The holder of an air operator certificate shall ensure that no person is appointed to be responsible for the maintenance control system or remains responsible for the system if, at the time of their appointment or during their tenure, they have a record of conviction for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offence under section 7.3 of the Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two or more offences under any of sections 605.84 to 605.86 not arising from a single occurrence.

Subsection.Text: The person responsible for maintenance control system of the holder of an air operator certificate may assign the management functions for specific maintenance control activities, to another person if the assignment and its scope are described in the maintenance control manual (MCM) of the air operator.

If the holder of an air operator certificate is also the holder of an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate issued under section 573.02, the person appointed under paragraph (1)(a) shall be the person responsible for maintenance of the AMO appointed under paragraph 573.03(1)(a).

Section.Text: An air operator shall provide the person who is responsible for its maintenance control system with the staff, facilities, technical and regulatory data, supplies and spare parts referred to in the Commercial Air Service Standards that are necessary to ensure compliance with this Subpart.
An air operator shall include in its maintenance control system the procedures referred to in the Commercial Air Service Standards for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: recording aircraft defects;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring that defects are rectified in accordance with the requirements of these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: detecting defects that recur and identifying those defects as recurring defects; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to sections 605.09 and 605.10, scheduling the rectification of defects whose repair has been deferred.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall include in its maintenance control system technical dispatch procedures to ensure that aircraft are not operated unless they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: airworthy;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: appropriately equipped, configured and maintained for their intended use; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: maintained in accordance with the air operator’s maintenance control manual (MCM).

Subsection.Text: Where an additional flight authority has been issued in respect of an aircraft pursuant to section 507.08, the technical dispatch procedures required by this section shall include procedures to control the use of that additional flight authority.

Where an air operator has a fleet empty weight and balance control program approved in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards, the technical dispatch procedures required by this section shall include specific procedures that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure the quality of the program by meeting the applicable requirements of the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that accurate empty weight and balance data for each aircraft to which the program applies is provided to the flight crew of the aircraft, or is input into the program, prior to each flight.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall, in order to ensure that its maintenance control system and all of the included maintenance schedules continue to be effective and to comply with these Regulations, establish and maintain a quality assurance program that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is under the sole control of the person responsible for the maintenance control system appointed under paragraph 706.03(1)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meets the requirements of section 726.07 of Standard 726 — Air Operator Maintenance of the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: The person responsible for the maintenance control system shall distribute the records relating to the findings resulting from the quality assurance program to the appropriate manager for corrective action and follow-up in accordance with the policies and procedures specified in the maintenance control manual (MCM).
The person responsible for the maintenance control system shall establish an audit system in respect of the quality assurance program that consists of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an initial audit within 12 months after the date on which the air operator certificate is issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsequent audits conducted at intervals set out in the MCM;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a record of each occurrence of compliance or non-compliance with the MCM found during an audit referred to in paragraph (a) or (b);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: checklists of all activities controlled by the MCM and the maintenance schedules;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for ensuring that each finding of an audit is communicated to them and, if management functions have been assigned to another person under subsection 705.03(3) or (4), to that person;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: follow-up procedures for ensuring that corrective actions are effective; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a system for recording the findings of initial and periodic audits, corrective actions and follow-ups.

Subsection.Text: The records required under paragraph (3)(g) shall be retained for the greater of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two audit cycles; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two years.

Subsection.Text: The duties related to the quality assurance program that involve specific tasks or activities within an air operator's activities shall be fulfilled by persons who are not responsible for carrying out those tasks or activities.

An air operator shall establish, maintain and authorize the use of a maintenance control manual (MCM) that contains information to ensure the efficiency of the maintenance control system, as set out in the Commercial Air Service Standards.
The Minister may authorize the incorporation by reference in an MCM of detailed procedures manuals prepared by the air operator, where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the policies affecting the detailed procedures remain in the MCM;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the incorporation is clearly indicated in the MCM;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air operator ensures that the incorporated manuals meet the requirements of this section; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person responsible for the air operator’s maintenance control system, or the person to whom the management function has been assigned pursuant to subsection 706.03(3), has certified in writing that the incorporated manuals meet the requirements of this section.

Subsection.Text: Except where otherwise authorized by the Minister in writing where it is demonstrated that the granting of the authorization will not jeopardize the safety of the product or service, an air operator shall comply with the policies and procedures contained in its MCM.

An air operator shall submit each page of its MCM to the Minister for approval, either individually or in accordance with an equivalent procedure that meets the applicable requirements of the Commercial Air Service Standards.
An air operator shall amend its MCM when instructed to do so by the Minister where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the MCM does not meet the requirements of this Subpart; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the MCM contains policies or procedures, or a lack thereof, such that the air operator’s maintenance control system no longer meets the requirements of these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall provide the means to ensure that a current copy of its MCM, or of the relevant portions of its MCM, is made available to each person who performs or certifies a function that is dealt with in the MCM or in any manual that is incorporated in the MCM in accordance with subsection (2).
An air operator shall amend each copy of its MCM within 30 days after the approval of an amendment under subsection (8).
The Minister shall approve an air operator’s MCM, and any amendments to that manual, if the requirements of the Commercial Air Service Standards are met.

No air operator shall permit a person or organization to perform maintenance on the air operator’s aircraft unless the person or organization has adequate facilities, equipment, spare parts and personnel available at the site where the maintenance is to be performed and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person or organization holds an approved maintenance organization (AMO) certificate issued pursuant to section 573.02 with a rating in a category applicable to the maintenance to be performed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the maintenance is to be performed outside Canada by a person or organization that does not hold an AMO certificate issued pursuant to section 573.02, the person or organization has been approved under the laws of a state that is party to an agreement with Canada that provides for recognition of the work performed; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in cases other than those described in paragraphs (a) and (b), the performance of the maintenance by the person or organization has been approved by the Minister as being in conformity with these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall ensure that a maintenance arrangement made with a person or organization pursuant to subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: specifies the maintenance required and clearly defines the tasks to be performed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is made in accordance with the procedures governing maintenance arrangements included in the MCM or is approved by the Minister as being in conformity with these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Where an air operator makes a maintenance arrangement to have maintenance performed outside Canada by a person or organization that does not hold an AMO certificate issued pursuant to section 573.02, the Minister shall, in the following cases, authorize the arrangement by issuing a maintenance specification to indicate that the maintenance control procedures set out in the arrangement conform to the Commercial Air Service Standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance is performed by a person or organization that has been approved in accordance with paragraph (1)(b) and the issuance of a maintenance specification is either required by the agreement or requested by the foreign state; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance is performed in a state that is not party to an agreement with Canada that provides for recognition of the work performed.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall ensure the completion of all of the tasks defined in a maintenance arrangement in accordance with subsection (2).

Section.Text: No air operator shall authorize a person to perform, without supervision, a task that is elementary work set out in the Aircraft Equipment and Maintenance Standards unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has satisfactorily completed training for the task under a training program required by section 706.12; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has previously performed that task under the direct supervision of the holder of an aircraft maintenance engineer (AME) licence or a training organization approved pursuant to Subpart 3 of Part IV.

Section.Text: An air operator shall ensure that each person who performs or requests the performance of servicing has satisfactorily completed training, under a training program required by section 706.12, for the servicing to be performed.

An air operator shall implement a training program to ensure that persons who are authorized to perform a function under this Subpart are trained in respect of the regulations, standards and air operator procedures applicable to that function, as specified in the Commercial Air Service Standards.

Subsection.Text: An air operator shall establish, maintain and retain for at least two years after an entry is made, for each affected person, a record of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all personal qualifications in respect of any appointment made pursuant to section 706.03;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any authorization to perform elementary work given in accordance with section 706.10 and incorporated in the maintenance control manual (MCM) in accordance with the Commercial Air Service Standards; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all training conducted pursuant to section 706.12.

Subsection.Text: The air operator shall provide a copy of each record required by subsection (1) to the person to whom the record refers on the completion of any training or the giving of an authorization referred to in paragraph (1)(b).

Section.Text: The holder of an air operator certificate shall report to the Minister, in accordance with Division IX of Subpart 21 of Part V, any reportable service difficulty related to any aircraft that it operates.

The holder of an air operator certificate issued under section 705.07 shall, for all maintenance control activities performed under this Subpart, adhere to the requirements set out in section 705.151 or 705.154 with respect to a safety management system.

Subsection.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Code: se="800.01",ss="1",df="{air traffic servicesATS}{services de la circulation aérienneATS}"
Definition.Text: air traffic services or ATS includes air traffic control services, air traffic advisory services and flight information services; (services de la circulation aérienneouATS)
emergency assistance services means services provided for the purpose of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assisting aircraft in a state of emergency, including aircraft in the uncertainty, alert and distress phases,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assisting aircraft involved in a hijacking, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: alerting rescue coordination agencies of missing or overdue aircraft; (services d’urgence)

Definition.Text: operational location means the physical location of an operational air traffic control unit or flight service station. (emplacement opérationnel)

Subsection.Text: Any reference in this Part to an annex to the Convention includes the differences notified to ICAO by the Government of Canada in respect of the standards specified in that annex.

Section.Text: This Part does not apply in respect of any air navigation services that are provided by or under the authority of the Minister of National Defence.

Subsection.Text: No person shall act as an air traffic controller or a flight service specialist

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within eight hours after consuming alcohol;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: while under the influence of alcohol; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: while under the influence of any drug or other substance that impairs the person’s faculties to the extent that aviation safety is affected.
